AXIMBDTsFJH2LGepEvTLxw.text: We really enjoyed our buffet here. We've been to 4 buffets on the strip and this has been the best out of the 4. I would recommend this buffet.

pT4Ze4qifQjVQC4JxCnhZw.text: Not worth the price, the only thing that might be good there is the hot crab.  I tried lots of other stuff there and did not find one thing good.  Very strange since a lot of reviews said this place is sooooo good.  Fail...not going there again!

X4QskDM2cIYpIOGC7aBeQQ.text: Skip the Aria buffet poor customer service and the food is not fresh at all. The food looks like it has been sitting there for a few hours. When you ask for fresh stuff they tell you this is it until the next batch comes out which can be an hour or so. They do have a variety of selection the crabs are way too salty. The sushi rice was hard as a rock. They only thing they got right was the drinks. Not worth $46 for dinner. You are better off going to In and Out burger place.

OD2ZqKtRYCqVG-nghDRBmg.text: Excellent spread and food. Worth the wait. Good selection of asian, italian, american cusine.

_ReJramjoeOjC4g27hNk7Q.text: If you're a seafood lover, you may have a little bit of fun here but not for long--unless all you plan on eating is seafood such as crab legs and mussels. The variety of fish is not very impressive. There's no baked, broiled, or smoked fish. The salad bar is very sad. As far as fresh vegetables go, your salad choices are greens and tomatoes, and then the rest of the salad bar is just composed of candied fruits. I was expecting to see chopped cucumbers and sprouts and you know, a real salad bar with actual variety! Not everyone wants to fill up on only heavy dishes. Fresh salads would have been nice.  The seafood that they do have is delicious and the bean salads that they have are nice, but after serving two small plates of cold seafood, I felt bored and unsatisfied. I walked around the buffet a few times but nothing stood out to me. The variety of foods just does not look appealing. I left the buffet hungry. You know something is wrong when you leave a buffet hungry. For the expensive price tag, I would not return.

cH8d-lPLKdT1kYMb0pzN7Q.text: Used a BOGO Lunch and at almost $40 was quite expensive but certainly the best meal we had while in Vegas.  It is not a huge buffet, but the food was all amazing.  Everything we tried was delightful!  Wish we could go back for more.

vxq4Y21TGLqidnChrnTV5A.text: Dear Aria Buffet: YOU RUINED FATHER'S DAY FOR US.  I took my husband here for Father's Day because he wanted to try this place out - this buffet ruined our holiday, single handed. As an avid buffet adventurer, I have been to 90% of the buffets offered on the Strip - and, congratulations, you are by far the WORST one yet. Before you start defending your so-called gourmet delicacies, I'd like to say that I am not a buffet expert, a chef, or anyone who knows culinary art. However, I have eaten at a LOT of buffets, more than I care to count, mainly because I enjoy variety in my food and the endless possibilities, and I'd like to think that I have at least somewhat of an idea of what food is supposed to taste like. But, let me make my case:  1. The food..MEDIOCRE, at best. For a very expensive buffet ($50/person), it lacked everything that an expensive buffet had. Let me start with the selection - limited, bland, and everything was just all wrong.  ASIAN - they had vegetable dumplings, vegetable potstickers, vegetable everything (more on veggies later). There were only 2 choices of soup there, fried rice, chow mein, and crab legs. ITALIAN - spaghetti, some kind of veggies (again), veggie lasagna, a bowl of banana chips and a bowl of cranberries (WTF?).  CARVING STATION - meats were cold...they just sat there under a heat lamp, but once it hit your plate, it went cold quick.  TANDOORI - I'm sorry, I'm not Indian, but I swear the "tandoori chicken" looks/tasted exactly like baked chicken. Not sure why they even tried to pass that off as anything tandoori. The rest of the curry tasted like melted mustard. DELI - didn't even try this station, it just looked like a large collection of Lunchables meats and cheese.  FISH MARKET (seafood station) - The station was full of duplicate foods just too make it look like it was filled. Two buckets of crab legs, 2 buckets of crawfish, 2 buckets of mussels, and 1 bucket of oysters. The oysters looked like they were picked from the bottom of the reject buckets from other, better, buffets. The oysters were stale tasting, and they sat in a pile on the ice...the ones on top were warm and the ones on bottom were still frozen. Pretty sure they're not supposed to be like that at all - something about food regulations, I'm sure.  DESSERT - this is by far the only dessert station on the Strip that pales in comparison to the dessert bar at my local 9.99 Chinese buffet. The desserts aren't even made there - they came from a box, and all your "chefs" did was pull it out of the box and plop it on a plate. And seriously, who serves chocolate chip cookies and boxed pies? At a $50/person buffet? I expected this from the $9.99/person Chinese buffet down the street from my house, but not from YOU, fancy-hotel&buffet-on-the-strip. I was really, really disappointed.   2. Did I mention the customer service? The "chef" at the seafood station was rude and nasty. I was standing next to a young girl waiting for the prawns. She obviously didn't know ENglish because the chef asked what she wanted and she just pointed at the grill. He proceeded to YELL at her at least a half dozen times with things like "WHAT?" WHAT DO YOU WANT?" "YOU WANT ONE? TWO? WHAT DO YOU WANT???" It got to the point that the girl hung her head down, shook her head and walked away. It was the worst type of customer service I had ever experienced. And this asshole of a chef just looked at me and asked me what I wanted, "WHAT YOU WANT?" and I just walked away. It was despicable. The second instance of poor customer service was when I had to ask for a water refill...TWICE. On a day where the facility was not even half full...there were empty tables around us. Why did I have to keep asking for water when we are literally 1 out of only 4 tables for you? Seriously.  To be quite frank, the food did not deserve the $110.00 I spent for my husband and I that day. What really made me bad was the poor customer service; I was embarrassed for the hotel more than anything. I work really hard for my money - and I don't mind paying a lot of money for good food (Bacchanal's price is even lower than this dump) - but seriously, the food did NOT justify the price. Furthermore, the customer service left a bad taste in my mouth. I have already started telling my friends, family, and co-workers not to waste their money on such a poor excuse of a "buffet" - you're better off sticking with your mom & pop Chinese buffet down the street - you'll get the same food, but you'll save $40/per person.

ytzpb8W4UUg0NGuG7jP-9A.text: Very disappointing dinner. In a city known for its delicious, extravagant buffets, and in this brand new hotel, for $37, I expected much more.  We mostly went for the unlimited wine (chardonnay or merlot) and lobster. No line at 5PM and our party of 11 was seated right away. We were also made to go back to the line and pay a separate 18% gratuity charge when they realized we were all in the same group. Sure, we are served wine, and we probably would have left something anyway, but a forced gratuity for a BUFFET is just ridiculous in principle. That meant we had no intention to leave anything else.   Our waiter, who turned out to be awesome, started by bringing small carafes of whatever wine we wanted. He ended up bringing 4 or 4 at a time and just leaving them on the table. You definitely won't go thirsty here.   The food was not as much of a selection as most other buffets I've been to. Not many desserts and they weren't as good as other buffets. The rest of the food consisted of carved meats (including salmon), sushi, crab legs, peeled shrimp, some Asian stir fries, salad, pasta, and a few others. Nothing was spectacular enough for me to want to go back for more, and they seemed to be missing most of the basics. The crab legs were pre-cut in half, which I liked (I'm lazy).   Each person got 1/2 a lobster, which I really enjoyed. If you like lobster, crab legs, shrimp, and as much wine as your heart desires, this is the place to you. But the other food left us all disappointed for what we paid and for the expectations of this hotel.

mVJZJKHBwsdLppkxy6eCYA.text: This was probably one of my favorite buffets in Vegas. The variety was large and the food was actually pretty yummy. You have a lot of different genres of food, Asian, sea food, Mediterranean, Latino, American and steaks. The dessert area had gelato looking ice cream, a little more ice cream texture. They also had pastries and cheesecakes.   The kids ate everything and I left satisfied and full. Oh I can't forget this part - bottomless BEER, mimosas and Bloody Mary's for $12.99 so so so WORTH IT.

MJ4Ivne88txKSU0Szni3Bg.text: I am posting my review I wrote to the establishment.  I am not one to moan and complain about something but being in the industry I feel I need to give feedback about my buffet experience since Aria takes so much pride in it.  Granite the buffet was free, this was a horrible experience.  I am not complaining because I want anything free or I am trying to down your casino/buffet.  You have a wonderful casino, from gambling options to hotel, to awesome guest relations but your buffet needs improvement, a lot!  When I came into Vegas all I have been seeing on advertisement is how good your buffet is.  I don't have a really high standard for buffets but when I visited Wicked Spoon last year at the Cosmo, the bar went through the roof.  I never try to compare buffets but when one hits the fan such as your I want to notify your establishment.  I always wanted to check out Aria's buffet because how you acclaim that it is amazing, so I decided to give it a try.  To start me off, how you list your food options on the chalkboard is definitely creative but hard to digest.  Digest being the board sometimes is in the middle of the option food bar and trying to distinguish which item is which becomes a little tough especially when there is a line of people behind you and you don't want to hold them up.  The choices were not neaten and seemed a little trashy like a Home Buffet.  The food at best was par and the lady cutting the prime rib told me my piece of meat was med/rare when clearly it was medwell+.  I wasn't going to argue with her because there was a line behind me and I am easy going but that is the first time I didn't finish a piece of A1-Prime rib.  It was dry and not appealing.  Your Asian selection was definitely below par.  Half the food didn't taste fresh and the steam pork bun was super dry.  The only plus side was your seafood selection.  I mean it is hard to mess up cold seafood but it was the only and the best part of dinner.  The worst part of about the experience was the server Victoria.  She seems like a nice lady but if she was doing full service she would crash.  I don't know if she was overwhelmed or was behind but it is not that hard to grab a spoon or listen to a specific drink request which she both botched. My guest and I asked her for a spoon two separate times and she did not return with one.  She didn't get the drink request right and she barely came by to clear done items off the table.  I still left her a good tip because it was a free buffet but that left a sour taste in my mouth.  I served before and it is almost an insult that she fails at a buffet which is the easiest serving job in a world.  If someone was to ask me to recommend a buffet to them in Las Vegas I would not say yours until it improves.  dp

5iru1msAmxhkFfgBJOcmwQ.text: Really not impressed at all. After waiting twenty minutes for a table (when half of them were empty, apparently they were trying not to open that section or something?), we sat down and waited for drinks. Ten minutes later, after not having seen a waitress, we decided to get food and figured we would order drinks when we got back. After finishing my first plate, I got up and asked one of the hostesses if she could send a waiter/waitress over to get our drinks, as ourselves and the other three tables around us were still waiting on that.   She could have been polite. Instead, she literally told me that I was being impatient (no water or any other drinks after 20-25 minutes), and basically told me to sit down and be quiet, and that they'd get me drinks when they were ready to.   We should have left then, and asked for a refund. The manager did very little to help, though she did say she would have a talk with her staff and see what happened. We got our drinks more than a half hour after being seated at our table, and the food was mediocre at best. I also had an upset stomach that afternoon, and that was the only thing I'd eaten since the day before.   I only rated it two stars because the food was so-so, but it was pretty bland and after the entire experience, it was NOT worth it. I wouldn't go back, and the staff's rudeness has made certain that the Aria will not see another dollar our of my wallet.

iJk2dAfEHZqiLzHJC1nfZw.text: First of all I think with any buffet it's smart to go right before the switch from lunch to dinner.   I enjoyed the crab legs most ! I really liked the way they cut them so it was easy to eat. They looked sliced for you so you didn't have to do the hard work and have to crack them which was awesome  :) tasted great with the melted butter.   I loved the curry chicken ! Really really good, flavor was perfect along with the Nann and Biryan rice   The dessert was good, lots of gelato flavors. Carrot cake was good :)  Overall was memorable enough  to want to return for my future visits to Vegas :) and also next time I will make sure to not have a stomach full of Fat Tuesday slurpy right before coming here lol I think I could have enjoyed it more lol

16trPqgDzNfmGnSLSsT7Pw.text: Giving this a 3 star rating, +1 because we won $1500 at the Aria.  Buffets are to get stuffed. And this does it well. Price was decent if you go prior to 330pm.  Personally I favored the seafood and the carvery. Tried the asian food, was probably worse than Panda-Express quality.   Also if you don't intend on drinking more than 2 beverages from the bottomless well, just go ahead and pass on that. Not worth the extra 12 bucks in my opinion.   NOTE: Took the monorail to get to the Aria. And it was quite the journey (not in a good way). The monorail says you have access to the Aria from the Bally's/Paris station... This is far from accessible. You have to walk all the way through Bally's casino floor to the front entrance where we were greeted with 120 degree heat and escalators that didn't work. Then up and across the street to the Bellagio, then all the way through the Bellagio casino floor to the opposite side to the tram that takes you to Crystals. Then through the Aria casino floor and finally to the Buffet. The walk was probably 4 times the time it took to take the monorail from LVH to Bally's.

mgarWOcCaGUkngBg9x_sUA.text: Life's a Buffet and Vegas abounds with them!  The wait for lunch at Aria's buffet was about 20 minutes, the service  friendly and responsive, and the counter staff super efficient.  The stations were as follows:  seafood sushi breads/bagels w/ spreads salads cold cuts soup carving counter (ham, roast beef, chicken rope sausage, roast chicken, mashed potatoes, mixed vegetables) Indian w/freshly made naan Mexican pizza sauteed hot dishes Vegetarian cheese and salami Chinese pasta made to order dessert  Compared to other buffets in Vegas, this one for lunch was good. Yeah, and so most of them also strive to keep the guys on "Deadliest Catch" going for another season by serving the king crab legs, sliced in half, with drawn butter and lemon. Aria's were sweet and tasty!  The boiled prawns, on the other hand, were watery and devoid of flavor. The shrimp cocktails were awesome while the scallop and mussel ones were kinda rubbery.   Loved the ham but the roast beef was one of the TOUGHEST and least flavored pieces of meat I've ever tasted. Was I at Arby's?! They also had no visible condiments available like mustard, horseradish, au jus, etc  The Indian, Mexican, and Chinese food rocked and made up for the sad roast beef.  Desserts were hella great!  Would I come back? Mmm, YES, but it just wouldn't be my 1st, or 2nd choice!!!

ZlCbIx6c3GSEYH6eupz6Wg.text: Didnt take long to figure out what was going on here. The Aria is so unapologetically expensive coupled with the fact that it is actually laid-out to make money that you come to the buffet just looking for a good deal. The reason you will pick the buffet for breakfast is bc there is no coffee makers in the rooms, no place to buy a coffee besides starbucks, and the line for starbucks EVERY MORNING is about 25-45 min. It literally wraps around the outside of the store. If you do get your coffee here its about 2 bucks more then any other starbucks. So you go looking for the buffet bc you are almost going to spend that much picking up some drinks and a few light snacks.  The buffet will have a line but its a line for food, right? The staff is not cheerful, the waitress's were talking about personal business while deciding where to sit us. Thats never bothered me before but we stood there for awhile while they chatted. The server was SHOCKED that I would ask for coffee AND a coke?!  The Aria bills there buffet as being special "a new kind of way to buffet" or something? because they have international stations. THIS IS NOT NEW ARIA.  Some of the international offerings at breakfast are a huge station for dim sum, egg rolls, chinese food (same every morning) hummus, babaganoush, the cucumber sauce, flat bread - all average. Like the stuff you get at the olive bar at a grocery store, maybe even less flavorful. No one was really eating it.  There is enough breakfast options to leave you really happy the first day. But by the second day you will be trying to find something new. So like me, maybe you will try the beautiful salad bar. 3 different types of lettuce mixes, 3 choices of dressings, and a man to spin it in a bowl for you... Until you get to the topping choices, garbanzo beans? canned beets? The only thing I could find to put on my salad was carrots! No fresh cut veggies, no nuts, only blue cheese. It was so weird. The shrimp was good but the cocktail sauce was not fresh. The one mussel I got to try had an enormous barnacle inside so I passed on that. I did eat a lot of bagels and lox but I know a small part of the population are into smoked salmon for breakfast because I happen to be a chef.  Overall I used to be in charge of the buffet at a 4 star hotel in Texas and  our buffet was far better. Made to order omelets, some kind of roast with a sauce (they have roasted chicken with brown gravy that was dry), a bunch of different premade mixed salads with fresh veggies and marinades.   But again, if you dont come to the breakfast buffet you will spend as much or more at the Aria Cafe/room service/ or the hellacious starbucks with the 25 min line and spiked prices.   So enjoy the buffet!

0stW0qcpOQo5nxAfMpmWiQ.text: Not really impressed. We went the day after thanksgiving and called before going. We were quoted $29.99 per person until 3 pm, when we got there it was holiday prices (but no change in the menu) for $37.99 each. We ate and there wasn't anything that stood out. The sushi was maybe the best item and it was mostly California rolls. There is a large selection of ice cream, but the lady serving it acted like you were putting her out when you picked one. The salad dressings had been all sloshed together (obviously not the restaurants fault, but they should clean it up). Not recommended.

jygLzRXfJ9ufRs3Y-ub7Ww.text: Aria is by far one of the best buffets in Vegas and I think it is the best one I have ever eaten at. The eclectic variety is more than you get at even places like the Bellagio. And since the buffet is tucked away on the second floor, the lines aren't long either.  I ate here both for lunch and dinner and while the menus were nearly identical, the food was great both times. Aria served a mix of Indian food, Chinese food, fresh sushi, steamed and cold crab legs, scallops, fish, pork shoulder, prime rib and carved ham and chicken.  Even the salads were better and prepared in front of you by chefs. After all that you can hit the dessert table and get Butterfinger ice cream. As you can imagine, I felt fat.

0yN8IAx7lWNia8KSzOm11A.text: I have to say for 40 bucks it was pretty good, very nice and clean. Food like pled very fresh and not like other buffets where it's been sitting there. Only thing I have to say was that he ting our drinks refilled took a bit. Other than that I would go back again

ifqIDwhx6xQ_Gg03EBXzow.text: Although we are locals we went here a few months ago and loved it! The selection is great they have everything. I had part of breakfast and lunch selection plus some ice cream of course. We have been to a few other buffets but this one TOPS them all!

h7H7teeuYpU3aRrz3AII6Q.text: My boyfriend and I visit several buffets in Las Vegas and this one was my FAVORITE. It was the most classy of them all. My favorite items were: sushi, crab, fish, cheese/olive/meat bar, meat carving area, so on. It was all so high quality! Little pricey at $43 each but it was my birthday dinner.

GaawArXHybTxpK0Z2Kd04Q.text: They need to more work in Asian food taste so bad and dry.  The place look big out side when you go inside is not that big and not that many food. Place look nice and clean, Service was great thanks to Asian guy for got his name... he clean very fast. They need to work more on the food and sweets area.

nyZDvxpdeJKDurnOVNQTiw.text: The Buffet at The Aria today was a disappointment!  We went for brunch, we were seated, waited like 10 minutes for someone to take our drink order and non one showed up.  Went to get am omelette, came back and ate and still no one had taken our order for drinks.  Asked several staff members for cream cheese and everyone answered the same thing....."can you go ask the guy behind the counter"  when I finally found that guy he said they were out of cream cheese.  I just wanted a bagel with cream cheese and my coffee and couldnt get either at a buffet?????  Wow!!!  Asked to speak with the manager and she just apologized, but still my breakfast was ruined or at least not what I wanted.  Did not expect this.  I had been to this buffet before and had a way better experience.

k_yUNH_1PS45eWg_AsLRZQ.text: Not bad. Didn't mind the ambiance and was neither super wowed nor did I swear off a return visit.  For me, gotta have lots of variety and things have to be cooked properly. Flavor and service from drinks person is also taken into account.  Nothing was a standout for me. But it is rather steep all round at Aria. My stay alone crested $380 for two nights!

SWDdQgGXZphhmODZBT7ciw.text: I am so glad I don't live in Vegas or come here often because if I did, I would eat here all the time and never get sick of it. Everything I had was amazing and there is so. much. food. Anything you can imagine they will probably have here. The mashed potatoes are hand whipped by God himself. The mac and cheese was amazing and the steaks/meats were cooked perfectly. Salad bar is plentiful and there are numerous toppings. Other items I had were great too. Not sure how busy it is during the week, but we had at least a 45 minute wait every time we came on the weekend. When I come back to Vegas, I know where my first stop will be!

7N-YY5udRfmDrT9Q2TI7bQ.text: Great value. Variety of food. Fresh and well done. Service was great. Place was clean.

MPOQV2T8MamxIsi_10n5Jw.text: Out of all the buffets that I've ever eaten at in Vegas, this one is the BEST one I've been to so far! They have a huge selection of lots of seafood. There is even a seafood bar that cooks made to order seafood dishes. There was a wait for that, so I never got to try anything there despite it being fairly early in the day. That was really odd to me. There were only three people waiting for the chef to finish cooking the specials. Only a few seafood tacos were out that didn't look that great. I wanted to try the fresh trout and a few other things. I feel like they were just being slow on purpose. Not cool!  My husband and  I came there for a late brunch. This is one of the more expensive buffets out there, but it's worth it! If you love shrimp, you'll love this place! I had some of the best honey walnut shrimp that I've ever had as well as some shrimp dish in a cilantro cream sauce. I've never had anything like it before. I wanted more, but it was all gone when I went back for more-:(  They have a large selection of seafood here like shrimp, crab, and other stuff. They also have sushi, pho, ramen, dim sum, and other types of Asian food. I think that they had pizza too. They had lots of different types of meats. I had some of the best stuffing and green bean casserole ever that day. They have a large selection of soup too. I did'n't try the chicken noodle soup, but my husband said it was good. They also have lots of different types of hummus and dips too. The dips I tried were all good.  There is also a large selection of veggies and some fresh fruit too. The desserts weren't good though. The gelato looked delicious, but it didn't taste good to me. I got the butter pecan and birthday cake one. I didn't finish it. I ate the watermelon and pineapple instead which weren't to sweet, but at least it was fresh and crispy. I guess it's not in season now. You must go here if you love seafood! Also, drinks are served to you at the table unlike other places. The servers are nice and attentive too.  The dining area is huge and clean. Try to go there after the lunch rush or before the dinner rush to avoid the crowds. Hardly anyone was there when we ate there at 2 p.m After eating, you can walk around the gorgeous shopping center that's an indoor mall that has lots of beautiful displays up as well as a few really cool looking restaurants inside. The casino is nice too and not that crowded, at least it wasn't when we were there.

7BCJjNHYm_fJz9CkFMQ5Gw.text: Very good buffet with a wide variety of different food. Very comfortable environment and great staff. Would go eat there again when back in Vegas.

zIa4vnWV-Fq6n6qKE--ubQ.text: Everything on their spread is good. So good that we ate their 2 days in a row. I will be back and will be staying at the hotel just to eat here again. I will be recommended if to everyone visiting Vegas

3Bp9v57H06l4i8bf5e8Seg.text: This used to be our 2nd favorite buffet in Vegas with lots of options of all the various types of cuisine that included meat dishes, the carving station used to have a nice selection of high quality well prepared meats. This last visit was all pastas and fillers, there were basically no meat dishes of any kind anywhere except the carving station and that was less than desirable by being fatty and overcooked with exception of some of the prime rib which depended on when you asked for it.  All the chinese were vegetable side dishes with exception of the chicken pot stickers. Sushi had no nigiri all cheap non meat rolls and was tryingto do poke bowls with warm tuna and scottish salmon. If you dont know what you're doing dont offer it This was not worth the task of going there let alone the $50+ they are charging for it!  This and Bellagio were both HUGE disappointments as they used to be our two favorite places.

2RFfnfwX5iIfNx4CPCb09A.text: Came here for dinner with a friend we arrived around 6:30 PM and there was no line so we were seated promptly. The price is very reasonable its a alot cheaper than Bacchanal buffet and also Wicked spoon. Now the food is pretty good they have a Seafood station which has crab legs, shrimp, mussels,clams and sushi. The carving station has a variety of meats to choose from they are all very delicious. The Italian, Asian and Indian section are great also. I really liked the Asian and carving station the most. Don't forget the desert section where you can get a variety of delicious treats to finish off the meal. And may I add this is the first buffet that I came to that has popcorn.

D_W2XqI-GO-TA-R4IxwBIA.text: We went there for dinner because we were so impressed with Aria hotel and we thought the buffet would be as amazing. We went in for dinner and there was no line at all (that should've been our hint) started looking around and some seems appetizing, most of em are meh. I went straight to the meat section, the guy who gave me my meat was helpful but sounded really tired. I went on looking for other food. Nothing was appetizing to look at. It looked ok.  Grabbed a lil bit of everything, it was edible but not savory or tasty. All in all i was very disappointed. My least favorite buffet in vegas.

D78DfKVxJ9Kc4YYBk8fivg.text: My family just dined at the buffet--husband, sister and I.  We are very sick.  It is not only the food that was awful but also whatever we consumed made us extremely sick.  Please avoid.  This isn't a 5 start buffet.  Do yourself a favor and go else where.  I just called Aria to inform that we are sick.  I spoke to the concierge desk and the person was really professional and nice and said that the buffet manager will get back to me ASAP.  It doesn't change the fact that everyone is sick right now. (We dined @ 6:35p and was only there maybe 40 mins)

2ECo5ThIhPWMFG4gjrjT4A.text: This was my favorite buffet by far! We went for our anniversary last year and are going back for more this year!  The seafood was so fresh and delicious! The other dishes were also lovely but the seafood was what I wanted and it was heaven!  The people were above and beyond friendly they came and asked me if I wanted certain sauces or to have my chilled crab warmed.  The server was friendly and on top of our drink refills!  We went to the Bellagio buffet the next day and the seafood was subpar and service not friendly and it cost more! I couldn't believe it.

ARvTBEonhdyoZnNXVVAfVA.text: The line stars at 11:15am on weekends. We got in around 11:42am. The variety was really great and most things were well prepared. The sushi was questionable so I skipped that.  Too hard to describe all the stuff I had, but it was good. Not only that, our server was super attentive and nice. We were there for a bit over the 2 hours they suggested.  I definitely would come back here though. From the reviews it seemed hit or miss. Luckily for us, it was definitely a hit!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The lay of the land.

K_KtlD_AO-LR45G6no9PBg.text: Great buffet. Great variety. Highly recommend it. One of the best in Vegas.  The food was on point. Everything was cooked well with great seasoning. Service was great as well. The wait was a little long but it's worth the wait.

SS9nuvGqvrB3IwoUlniA3A.text: One of y favorites. Very well done.everything was delicious. I got full before I could even sample everything I wanted to taste. We ate lunch for 30 dollars on a buy one get one free coupon. So $15 .00 each. Great deal.

4KCZ3SGvPAZJ82WErQURbA.text: Probably the best buffet I've been to in Vegas! Lots of choices from around the world, huge Asian section, Italian section, lots of ice cream choices, nice kids buffet area, and carving station. Would highly recommend! For $100 total my husband and I got the unlimited buffet and unlimited drinks on a holiday weekend (prices are cheaper normally). It was a great deal, because the drinks were strong and the service was great! You can stay for up to two hours, so you're sure to get your fill! Great value!  *Tip - Make sure you have your player's card with you (MLife), otherwise the line is LONG.

7Z85ZqiXsDDlRC_72QUY2g.text: The Aria buffet is pretty solid and boyfriend and I have been here a few times. Compared to the Bacchanal buffet at Caesar's, this one is quite a bit smaller, but they still have a variety of items to choose from. All of the usual suspects are here; Chinese, prime rib, Mexican, Italian, seafood, Japanese, etc. We like to get down on the crab legs and shrimp.  The place is clean and service is always pretty good, but you have to ask for crab leg crackers. They don't automatically give them to you, which is kind of weird. Price point is pretty average, but given the selection, it's still a great deal if you're hungry.

1raFo2QWhq1Tth8xzUO9BQ.text: The service was terrible and the food was very low level compared to their hotel's reputation.  I do not recommend this buffet to anyone for the price and the quality.  I am never returning to this restaurant.

u6bHtbRoU7-p5wbirSu1xg.text: Their seafood and dessert are worth the price you pay!  SEAFOOD/ASIAN: Came here for brunch -- and disclaimer: I skipped all of the meat portion, it didn't look appetizing to me. The seafood was amazing! Their alaskan crab was delicious. They had a great variety of mussels too. Their hacau and shumai in the Asian section was delicious! Not too soggy, and the shrimp and other meat were cooked beautifully. Definitely did not taste like buffet Chinese food.   DESSERT: Their gelato was so rich and creamy. The freezer spins around so you can see all the selections. I loved their cookies & cream. Highly recommend. Their macarons were amazing. The taste and quality of those were at least $2 a pop. I grabbed about 5-7 and each of the flavors had a rich taste. Definitely recommend the lemon and strawberry macaron.   DRINKS: They had a deal going on $20 for 2, unlimited drinks. We thought it was just unlimited mimosas...but NOPE! We got unlimited margaritas, beer, wine, everything! Such a steal.  Needless to say, my friends and I were definitely happy about our experience~!

l6aH6_8ujnSt_yCZhgOFPw.text: Good food clean and the server are friendly ^_^    im going to come back here for sure...

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Good food and good service.....

TXv70kzU5BkVEqgxVskikA.text: The food quality was ok I didn't think was it was great not worth coming back again . The price was ok for the food selection was ok too .

gPFNGEN72bS4-TdsqXSUHw.text: Food is excellent, but service is definitely so-so. Rude, unsmiling waitstaff for the most part.

gaPh1-Vnaawantxx09_4hQ.text: Pretty ordinary fare.   Nothing was memorable.   The kids eat free so that makes  it affordable but no game here...

Vx2Rj0WEeiswmz7UtljdOQ.text: I was extremely disappointed in the service, especially the attitude of the hostess. Plus the quality of the food was mediocre at best. The hot foods were barely room temperature.I had a comp through M Life's My Vegas. I went to the hostess desk and saw a line of at least 150 people. As I was comped by M Life I went in the Players Club line. The hostess asked for my player's card and told me I was in the wrong line. I said I have a comp and you want me to stand in that line. Snappily she said yes. She said see this sign you don't have the right players card. You'll have to wait in that line. The wait was over 30 minutes and even though it was technically free I wouldn't go back. I prefer my local Asian Buffet at 1/4 of the price. The quality and service are much better. I ate at the Main Street Station Buffet the same week and it was less then half the price with very good quality and very good service. Buyer beware.

E0MSu7u5srcf_WLEtVEszw.text: This is my review for the breakfast buffet only.  * Price: $42 for 2 for breakfast.. not cheap but cheaper than Jean Phillips or any restaurants in this area. 4 star.  * Ambiance: clean, simple decor. Farmer market feels. 4 star.   * Location:  on the promenade level, by the pool area. Convenient to stop by here before or after hanging out at the pool. Far away from the casino... so you don't have to eat with cigarette smokes. 4 star.   * Meals: fresh.  There are plenty of choices from bagels, oatmeals,  salads to dim sum, roasted beef, omelet... There are a sort of pastries but not much of desert for breakfast.  Food quality is good but not very exciting nor inventive like Wicked Spoon or the Bellagio 's buffet.  4 star.   * Service: friendly waitress. 4 star.  Thus, it is averaged to 4 star based on my PALMS rating!    We did enjoy the seafood station with cocktail shrimps,  crawfish, crab legs, clams and muscles.  The sushi station is very simple with veggie rolls and spicy tuna rolls. Dim sum is good with 3 to 4 items (sumai, bun and congee). There is a Mediterranean and Indian food sections which are also very simple and generic.  We did not go here for lunch nor dinner so could not comment on the other meal selections.   We probably would come back if staying at the Aria since it is pretty good deal for the amount and variety of food.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. My favorite station

vP4B49l24cHk43BRmcPLwg.text: This is a great buffet for the price. Carving station, crab legs, pasta bar, etc. Also you can't go wrong when the buffet has Creme Brulee!

1qeOyQKNSs6nVuD5D-F72A.text: So my friends were staying at the Aria and we wanted to try their buffet out , not so good and they're overpriced by comparing to Spice market buffet because all the food is not tasty at all at the Aria buffet I didn't like it at all and my friends didn't like their food as well , well I just wanted to try it out , but never going back again

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

o8DPWNc7A3-lPwl2yvQkEQ.text: When I was in Vegas last year, I checked out Aria's buffet to see what was on their menu. What I saw was something spectacularly presented. The price was out of my range at the time, but I had budgeted to attend for this year's visit. Unfortunately, the presentation wasn't nearly as good. What happened? Not only were the dishes plain, but there were crumbs and sauces spilled everywhere. Many of the nameplates above the food weren't there and some were mislabeled. I had to ask a few times to figure out what something was. Another disappointment was when I frequented the Chinese section's "Dim Sum" area, many of the bamboo steamers were empty. I checked about 5 times during the span of an hour, and they were out each time. What can make this worse was that a lady behind the dessert section, who was having a bad day, snapped at me for waiting for her to put the food out. At this point, Aria deserved a 1 star from me.  Fortunately, the dishes I sampled were outstanding. The chow fun and fried rice in the Chinese section were very authentic and had great "wok-hay." This translates from Chinese as "captured flavor by the high-heat from a seasoned wok." The tender roast beef was cooked perfectly with small sections of fat attached for flavor. One my favorite items I indulged were Italian large shrimps meant as a pasta topping. I just ate them by themselves. The shrimp was cleaned well, cooked to the right temperature, contained lots of meat, and smothered in a heavenly butter sauce. I had a good waitress and the few dishes I had made it worth coming. In the future, I will probably not return since there are other good buffets to try in Vegas for approximately the same price.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mexican street corn
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Civiche
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. salad

SZb2ei-sMxcrMECz8Q0kKA.text: I was concerned to go here when I looked on yelp but it's actually surprisingly good.  $85 for two weekday dinner.  Good food choices and everything was clean and well presented. Everything we tried we enjoyed and the dessert selection is amazing.  The line outside gets long - we waited 45 minutes. Would have been nice to sit at a bar and be called when the table was ready instead of just standing in line.

X8lv45OvHvdgKnjY0tyLgg.text: So we've been to the Buffet at Aria each time we go to Vegas - probably 3-4 times now, and it never disappoints. We came on a weekday for dinner for my most recent birthday trip - and were able to take advantage of a BOGO we got from myVegas (great comp!) so dinner was only like $40 for 2 - total steal!   The variety they have at this buffet is unbelievable - they had crab legs and shrimp and prime rib and various cuts of meat - they have everything - and it was all DELICIOUS! We did get lucky though, I think we were there on a Wednesday and swung in around 7:30PM - and there was no wait and the Buffet was pretty empty - good for us cause we didn't have to wait to be seated or to get food. Their deserts are fabulous too - lots of items in bite size portions so you have the opportunity to try a lot. Even with the regular food, some of it is pre-portioned in cute containers so you can just try a little bit (think mini deep fryer baskets of fried chicken nuggets, mini iron skillets of pot roast, etc...). That being said - presentation is gorgeous as well.  We also love the fact that Aria is still a newer hotel/casino so the decor is modern and it's still very clean. We will absolutely be back :)

JNRTL-n198nOp9i-Jn1PGQ.text: I could not believe what just Happened, I came for a diner at this Buffet , was my first time .The Hostess with Tablets who sits guests are  SO RUDE.. First the one who stand next to cashiers African American entire time she turn back against guests so you can call forever to ask question she pretend does not hear you.Then I went with Asian hosts she supposed to take me to a table and I asked "why we are  waiting in line so long if is buffet almost empty" Here is what shocking situation comes - "she goes and say that how we want , you want your money back I am not gonna give you a table , then she left " I said WOW WOW  then i  came back to African American lady requested Manager she said she will call , so instead Manager i spoke with someone who my be Manager assistant I asked him do I have a right to ask question or you guys turn back on guests just like that after they ask question He dis apologize he said you have right to ask . They really needs to improve customer service they should go to Luxor Buffet to see what is high customer service

J_Z_z7k0a6Ur5U_6ucZVAw.text: The Buffet was very good. I mostly ate seafood as they had all you can eat King Craps. The dessert was good as well, especially the ice cream. They were very slow at refilling our drinks. Even when we asked multiple times they took forever.

u1FY44jYVb87tscol62Huw.text: Too good  I remember being here back in 2010. It was good, I really wanted to come back again. Needless to say in April 2017, I ended up back here after Wicked Spoon already comped our free buffet. Theirs is good too but too expensive.  This is probably the best buffet on the strip for me. With good value $22-27 for brunch daily, you can't beat it with the good food. They have a lot of vegetables which is a plus. I am impressed, however, the sorbet selection isn't as good. I won't give a minus for this one though.   Will be back

YjktpHlpx0Fh8JatuCJW8g.text: Surprisingly decent buffet. With so many choices on the Strip I was hesitant to dine here based on the reviews/rating, but ended up here due to a promotion I received. We waited about 30 minutes on a weekday for the lunch service. The stations are all clearly labeled and there's lots of walking room. Our server was very attentive and nice. Make sure you try the prime rib.

UM9Fr3G_zuD9bSmmWRwagw.text: Came in for late dinner on Tuesday. Food was just average, not much selection. Even the desserts selection were not much. I think the brunch selection are better than dinner. This is for the weekday. They probably ( hopefully) have much more items on weekends.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Nothing much about the food.

Bp-n_KnSVNXFflHmZ4EFjQ.text: Vegas Buffets are awesome! We picked this one because it was close and it was 4 star rating. We were well taken care of with drinks and refills and all the food I had was yummy!

isgdJt_WRMRMvWIN_1oEKw.text: Not worth the price. Only soft drinks included. Crab legs taken from newborn crabs. A challenge with no payoff.

CmyBBxYCscuoQoSz6snUqQ.text: I've been to Vegas more times than I can count on both hands. It's a tradition for me to eat at 1 buffet minimum per trip. I can seriously share that although the environment at this place is comfortable - cute people at Aria, classier layout of food, better presentation - the food is the same as most mid tier buffet at Vegas.   Prime rib was decent, desserts was pretty good, I liked the variety of bread, there was lobster bisque, and most memorable was that they had warm crab legs as oppose to cold salted ones.   For the price, I could find better buffet elsewhere, but it's not a bad place either.

2brVPReLrwgdV8TqFVT4Cg.text: Disappointing experience at the Aria buffet. Checked in on Sunday after a long flight and went straight the the Sunday dinner buffet. Sunday buffets are expensive but are generally super good with variety and exquisite food. Arias buffet had neither. I enjoy all kinds of food and meats but Arias spread was sub par, tastes were bland and service ordinary. I have always liked the hotel and will probably like to come back but hope the staff can make it right !

ft_RvRvPn-lvYvZrOGiqNA.text: Came to this buffet on a recent trip for brunch and it was very good. Excellent quality and I was so excited to see bagels and lox! I'm sad I didn't get to eat the crab legs, but I'm not one who can eat more than a little seafood before 10am.  The wait staff was great, I was sick and had no voice and she brought me lemon and honey and hot water and kept it filled.  Dessert selection left something to be desired, but otherwise I was very happy.

XaMwBs1F3r6rk7wAmfy0TA.text: Went back recently and glad to see decent king grab legs back on the menu. They're still served cold. I have to ask them to steam it and they'll give you a dirty look. Not too expensive compared to other places, but I had a food voucher so I can't complain.

hC62P0WI_OFVGshehyAcWQ.text: I don't know how this restaurant is 3 stars but I enjoyed the food very much. I love how they have from different ethnicity/varieties of food here. I definitely did order me the unlimited drinks also and I did drink enough to get myself buzz ;) food is good, I will definitely come back here when I'm back in Vegas. The reason I didn't give 5 stars is because when we were first seated and the waitress came to take our drinks order, she asked us for an ID and I was confused since at check in we already show our IDs and got a wristband for it. That was my only issue but I didn't make it a big deal.

JorrxYOZp76glFVjx8FKlA.text: Five stars for Danny !!!! Our server was amazing never been to a  pace with such a nice guy love the food love the place coming back

M9l-Iql1XWuqLvcC7bPkwA.text: My family came here for dinner. The price was about $50 per person, which is pricey, but it's holiday price in Vegas. Also compared to the prices of other buffets, this place is reasonable, especially for their selection. My family was delighted with the options. We especially enjoyed the rack of lamb and seafood. This buffet also has an excellent salad bar. Desserts were good too; they have gelato, cakes, etc. Me and my family plan to return here in the future!

405ZxoOy6N7rYJa8cG9uDA.text: The worst buffet experience in Las Vegas !!! If you do you a choice for buffet, you just don't want to try this shit. First of all, extremely slow service, after you pay you have to wait at least 20-30mintues, the reason that you have to wait for so long is not because they are busy. I don't really know what's wrong their service, lots of empty seats and tables (at least half empty space), they keep asking you to wait. After half hour, One waitress try to table us, after a round walking she told us "sorry we don't have table right now, can you please go back there and wait". What the fk is this, very ridiculous ever seen!!! Such bullshit service; second, for the food, so so taste not too bad not too good. Totally, it's not worth. Try to go to a different one.

UjN9Scwv0Kf9sj5r2QsZsg.text: Let me preface this review with, I hate buffets! My husband has dragged me to every buffet in Vegas and then some. I actually enjoyed my meal at The Buffet. Typical buffet when it comes to selection. They had seafood, Asian, Greek, Italian, Mexican and a carving station. The difference was the flavor! It was all delicious and much better than your average buffet experience. Desserts were fresh and delicious. My only complaint was the cheese platter looked a little old. The $12.99 unlimited champagne/beer/wine was great too!! Service was pleasant and I never had an empty glass!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pretty sure they make their own gummie bears!
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

x7TpqTGZCcJEnpztNZ2sGQ.text: Any buffet that calls itself "The Buffet" is either very comfortable with what it is (a buffet) or is trying to sound like "THE buffet" (kind of like the pretentious alums of THE Ohio State). In the case of "The Buffet" at Aria, it is the more humble laidback version. The light, bright, and open atmosphere of the buffet and simple, yet delicious dishes means The Buffet is a good choice when at the hotel, casino, or City Center. This isn't really a buffet to go out of your way for in Vegas, but is a nice option if you're already there.  It's only $21 for lunch. If you want all-you-can-drink wine, then try the $37 dinner. The good stuff (aka Gourmet with Lobster) is only served Friday and Saturday dinner. If you are used to Las Vegas buffets, then the pile of crab legs, small selection of sushi, meats, pastas, and salads will seem very familiar. Nothing really stood out or sucked. I liked the pasta with alfredo sauce for some reason and a simple salad. Maybe it was because we were towards the end of our stay. Of course, desserts are a highlight of any Vegas buffet and the same is True at Aria with little cakes, pastries, and ice cream.

a_VoxNre28df5AWzgGbeLA.text: $50 a person for this?? Plus 18% gratuity for parties over 8. We saw our "server" twice. We had to chase people down to get our drinks. The food was mediocre at best, I've had better microwave tv dinners.The only thing I enjoyed was the coffee at the end.   If you're looking for a disappointing meal, try McDonald's instead; at least you're only paying $6 for a bad meal instead of $50.

Bka08nGEli7c3vsR7AmIrg.text: Honestly, if it weren't for the free dinner buffet comps, I would never eat here.  In fact, if I paid, I'd probably ask for my money back only because their food is just so old, dry and nasty.  I mean, you would think that ARIA of all places would have a nice buffet, but they don't.  - Indian curries - all watery and spices, naan - old and stale - seafood - old and nasty crab legs - latin - super salty - salad bar - pathetic  - italian - dried up spaghetti noodles, super greasy pizza - desserts - not appetizing. old cookies.  only memorable item was their gelato, dinner roll, and the pepperoni on the pizza.   Again, it was free and I wanted to try it once. I'm not sure what's worse... The Buffet at ARIA or the Mirage Buffet.... they both suck.   I'd highly recommend Bayside Buffet (at Mandalay) over this garbage.  If money is not a problem, go to Bacchanal Buffet (at Caesar's) because it's worth every dollar!

hhwt64kwRWPlb0JbcT4yDg.text: Beautiful place, nice atmosphere, yet extremely standard in terms of food quality. Had a nice time at their lunch buffet, but wouldn't be too eager to go back.  The lunch options were good, just mostly unappetizing. Dry glazed ham and watery mac and cheese for starters. Favorite part about our meal was probably their gelato, loved the watermelon and thai tea flavors although I wish they offered the option to be served in cones. Other than that the dessert selection was underwhelming - mostly cookies of sorts.

1qZWhskOzxG4esMek9LIbQ.text: I was with family 8-1-16 about 6pm  they serve old sushi. I told manager she say nothing wrong. rice was almost uncook.  came out from freezer bite. winn buffet was very good.

kidlCTXkzkr71hsv6cqn_Q.text: $36 for "holiday buffet"?  I asked the hostess what was special about it to warrant the higher price at 3pm.  She said it was bigger and better, more like brunch.  It's an ok buffet, loaded with lots of starchy carbs like breads, pizza, mashed potatoes; lots Of proteins like prime rib, salmon, shellfish, but strangely devoid of vegetables and a real and proper salad bar.  (Of note to vegetarians and vegans or those on a low carb regime.).  Salad was a pathetic little station with small bowls like you'd see at Carl's Junior - in fact Carl's may have a bigger selection at their salad bar.  There's no way you could build a salad meal here.  If you want only a side salad, you're in business.  Grilled vegetables were way across the room on a small dish perhaps 4" in length at best, next to some cured olives at the "Mediterranean" station.  Somewhat pathetic.  A strange orphan station with salsa and guacamole plus sour cream were standing alone on one side of a small kiosk (with sushi and soups) without any appropriate foods that they might actually accompany nearby.... Huh?  Eggs Benedict didn't just have runny yolk, the whites were uncooked. Yuck!  Desserts looked pretty, but some looked a little shop worn (lemon squares), perhaps sitting in the case too long.  On the upside: Indian station,  chilaquilles, a couple of fine cheeses, gelato.  This was visually nice looking but in execution perhaps not the best Vegas buffet.

cKHpbeMJDoS8heg4RmSDWw.text: So this definitely falls short of the bellagio buffet even though it's only a bit cheaper ... But it's still really good...  Came here during brunch so we had a nice variety of food,though didnt seem as big as the bellagio.   Eggs Benedict was on point... Deserts were also pretty good but again fell short of it's old world neighbor.  Staff was amazing though, came in a bit rough so hydration was key... I was working with coffee orange juice coke and water and I'll tell you wat not one of them were ever empty   Definately would recommend but the bellagio is better

pOtrC8k5qp0EcbfWX_odAw.text: I came here the first time about a year ago and thought is was decent, I came back again yesterday with the whole family and the quality seems to have went WAY down. Cheap poorly made food. Of course my kids basically had a slice of rubbery pizza and some desert, it sucks that they charge the same price for kids. I myself was highly disappointment in the food, I tried just about EVERYTHING hoping at least one thing would be good but it was all awful. There is really no noticeable difference between lunch and dinner. Save your $$$ and go elsewhere. The kids even said the deserts sucked, cute display but no taste whatsoever.

fVYbaW0JClkQyP0LfhrtKA.text: I'm not a huge fan of buffets as I realize the challenge they present in terms of keeping food fresh and high quality. This buffet was not my favorite and was not as visually impressive as some others, but the food was decent and my husband liked it more than Wicked Spoon.  Pros: wide selection, good flow, clean, great service, awesome selection of desserts.   The waitress made a special effort to write the birthday boy's name on the plate of desserts she brought, along with a candle, and a song with other employees. Because of the buffet setting, she had a hard time catching him when he wasn't up at the buffet, but she was persistent and that was so appreciated!  (Wicked Spoon just brought over a plate of desserts.)

yT0AmY18aA4UnA6EzSKaJQ.text: On a whirlwind tour of buffets in Las Vegas, I came here this past weekend to try the brunch buffet on Saturday.  There was about a fifteen minute wait at about 11 a.m., which I thought was a little surprising.    After having gone to Bachannal for dinner the night before, I wasn't sure my stomach would be able to handle another buffet, but I often think of brunch the way some people think about desserts - it deserves its own stomach!  There's a lot of selection here.  For $30 per person (and an additional $12 for bottomless drinks), I'd say it's a decent deal for a Vegas buffet.  I skipped over most of the Asian food since it looked mostly like reheated frozen stuff and helped myself a lot of the other things.  There's too much to name, but let me hit some of the highlights:  amazing breakfast pizza, yummy pre-made waffles (with different fillings - try the banana), decent corned beef hash, your own made-to-order eggs benedict bar,  a variety of refreshing pre-made salads, an interesting assortment of Indian foods (including naan and curried veggies and meats), etc.  They also have a made-to-order eggs and omelette station.  The ham at the carving station was delicious - lean but tender and flavorful - they have prime rib too if that's your fancy.  In other words, there's something for everyone here!  There were some foods that weren't so great.  I felt like this was much more common in the dessert department.  For example, the donut that I had tasted crusty and dry, and a lot of their cakes tasted like they'd been sitting out for a while.  I probably wouldn't get an omelette again either - they're far too big and I don't like how they don't wrap the ingredients inside but instead intersperse them throughout the egg batter.  Service:  Can't compare to the service you get at Bachannal.  They seem understaffed here (even though the restaurant wasn't at full capacity), and you have to exert some energy to flag someone down.  Bottom line:  A decent option for a brunch buffet in Vegas.  I am realizing I forgot to try the gelato so next time...

ZSBnVMH_jKao8bDXFIvizg.text: Food is still good.  Really enjoyed the salmon and ahi tuna.  Tasty prime rib.  Only disappointment was the all you can drink selections.  In the past had lots of beer and wine selections now they limit the selections which are less tasty (meaning cheaper).  Got it for free on my vegas.

4Dg4sG4bWKCr9IpoPzTJlQ.text: First Impression: Great decor, bright seating, many food selections  What impressed me: Crab legs were sliced lengthways to allow easy consumption Omelettes were made fresh to order Jean Philippe cakes were displayed on top of dessert shelf Servings portioned out to allow tasting  I enjoyed this buffet for brunch. I would even go as far to say that I prefer this over Wicked Spoon. The food here was fresh and tasty.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. cake display by jean philippe
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. cake display by jean philippe
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

CficpNjbGmE4babfOOGYcw.text: This is for their weekend brunch buffet. Honestly, my review might have been about 3 stars maybe if it wasn't for the fact that I found a piece of HAIR in my food! It was a very short, kind of curly hair, which I'm pretty sure we all know what that would remind us of if we saw it in our food. YUCK!! It completely ruined my appetite and I wasn't able to eat any of the main entrees after that. I found it in my medium rare brisket, which I thought AT FIRST was really good, but after seeing that hair I could barely keep it down. The other food I was able to eat before I got the brisket was average. Nothing I'd go crazy for and tell my friends to pay $25. But I wasn't able to try out everything since I got the brisket in the beginning of my meal.  After a while I decided to try out the desserts. They all looked appetizing, as does most buffets with desserts, but they tasted average. Except for the strawberry shortcakes OMG heaven!! As far as from my experience, that is the only thing I'd go back there for to eat.  My friends and I were having trouble deciding on whether to go this buffet or Cosmopolitan's Wicked Spoon. But since we've already been to Wicked Spoon we decided to try this place.  And now I'm sad to say I would have much rather gone to Wicked Spoon than this. It may be a couple of dollars more expensive, but the quality and diversity of the food is definitely worth it.

WnRp3b0ijiJXN7eB7_4jUA.text: The food quality is so far. Items aren't replenished often enough to be appealing. Especially for the dinner price, I would never never never recommend people to come. I've been here for lunch, and I've had a better experience then. Tonight's dinner service was just appalling. The Beef Steamship is a cheap excuse to serve dry, old beef instead of a simple prime rib. Crab legs are reboiled in heavily salted water to eliminate taste buds from sensing the rancid quality of the baby crab legs. I cant note a single thing at the buffet that was memorable or fantastic. Suck it up and pay $10 more for the Bacchanal buffet at Caesar's or pay $20 less at a lower quality buffet anywhere else on the strip to save money and receive the same quality of food.   The redeeming quality is the waitstaff and cashiers. Fantastic service trying to muddle the horrendous nature of the disgusting food...

DbererMQH8q-8jr1nxP_pA.text: I rated this Buffet 3 stars for the lack of variety. They had different stations but little variety in each station. The buffet was smaller than I expected. The food was ok. I enjoyed a few shrimp items they had as I am less picky than my girlfriend. I wasn't impressed by any of the items As I said a couple of the shrimp items were good but I had to add chopped shrimp to enhance the flavor.  $32 per person wasn't overly priced, I can at least say we tried it out. After all you will never know until you try it right so now we know and won't be returning to this Buffet. Hope this helps you guys out...

SA8A1-K6jWPwzumVwnLbBg.text: I had doubts about this place...I'm not much of a buffet fan and would rather spend my money and calories on AYCE sushi instead but this place definitely proved me wrong! They were super busy but the food was beyond my expectations! Although there was a long line on a Sunday, the wait wasn't too long and worth the wait! The food selection seemed like the usual but it actually wasn't! They had a variety of all kinds of food, even drinks like Thai tea! I thought that was pretty cool. My family and I went in on the crab legs, prime rib,  and bone marrow! Sooooo delicious!!!! I'm definitely coming back here when craving for crab legs.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

r9OXcYm-3ssCtKYM4b2Ojg.text: Let me start with what is really nice here  They have a lot of dessert options and they are all delicious.  They charge a lot and if you are vegetarian highly not recommended. The food options they have are very limited and the people at the counters are not really helpful and understanding. Make sure not to waste your money. Its all a show put up with a least and low-quality food options.

R1rd3Lj-m0aKr2MsguHZHA.text: I was debating between 3-4 stars but decided on a 3 star after polling my sister and Mom.  The buffet is pretty and offered quite a bit for their brunch however nothing wowed me.  Everything was good but nothing was great. The major downfall was the dessert section which offered very little (s'mores popcorn, two types of cookies, and a few other items that I can't recall). The best part was the Mediterranean sections where the offered several types of hummus and pita chips. Compared to the MGM grand down the street, for a much more reasonable price, I felt a bit let down. I struggle to write anything less than 5 star for Aria because it's one of my favorite casinos to visit when in Las Vegas.  We just had the highest expectations but enjoyed the MGM just as much if not better  Update: much better experience and loved the wide variety offered. I'm changing to 4 Stars!!

evjoFK74FNtWG4SG42XnHA.text: I've been to the Aria buffet a few times. I will say the food was a lot better when they first opened. Now it's just become another buffet, still ok but just not as good as it doesn't seem as high quality and variety has gone down. We came for brunch and luckily made it in time to avoid the long line that had started to form around noon.  There is still a variety of food to choose from - an omelette station, dim sum, salad bar, seafood - shrimp and crab legs. But I was looking for the delicious mini filet I had awhile back but they didn't seem to have this, maybe it's at dinner time? I wish the dim sum had more options but the steamed pork buns were alright. They have a nice selection of gelato. I would come back but I won't hold my expectations as high and will likely try a different buffet first.

q8DkWGOEXOsoaimzAfhfXg.text: We were staying at nearby Park MGM one early Summer weekend. And since most of the hotel is under renovation (nightmare) and a lot of it's eateries arent set up yet, we went over to Aria because we are quite familar with it, staying at Vdara often throughout the year. Park MGM is connected to Aria via a long walkway or the CityCenter tram.   I've always wondered how the The Buffet was having walked by it many times. It was Sunday around 1pm and the lines were LONG. Thankfully my MLife (Gold) status was able to place us in an expedited line but we waited at least a good 15+ minutes or so before being seated for our party of 2. Once seated, you can relax and strategize how best to tackle the buffet. There were many different food options from seafood to pasta to dim sum and even spanish cooking. There was a prime rib/roast/sausage section where they cut your meat for you. There was a shellfish station that was very popular. I got a little bit of everything. I had some dimsum (har gow & siu mai) and sauteed green beans, all from the Asian section of the buffet. I got spanish rice and bacon. Random but great pairing I thought. Ha! I also got Mexican pinwheel crackers, pizza, naan bread, prime rib and bratwurst. Two plates were all I could about handle. I got a little bit of dessert but I was plenty full by then. Some bread pudding, caramel popcorn, macaroons and a slice of carrot cake.   All the food was decent. Nothing really stood out. As far as Vegas goes, The Buffet at Aria is about middle of the pack. It was good enough but not great like Bacchanal or Wynn Champagne Brunch. For what we paid, it wasnt bad. $34 per person. You can choose to eat what you like. Very many options. Service was decent. MLife membership pays... Got us in quicker. Way quicker.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

8F9KlrDHahueu-d7BBKvJA.text: The Buffet at ARIA is easily the most impressive, diverse, and delicious buffet I've ever been to. From start to finish, I was floored by the sheer number of options, beautiful playing, great service, and exquisite taste of everything. If you're in Vegas, this is an absolute must try!  It's no secret that buffets are often talked up but fail somewhat to deliver on taste and freshness. Let me tell you-- the Buffet at ARIA is unlike any other buffet you've ever been to. There is so much food, but somehow they manage to keep everything fresh and hot to the point where it feels like it was made just for you. Everything is organized into stations, so that makes making your way through everything a little more manageable and less overwhelming.   Again, everything I had was great, but here's the shortlist of my favorite things at the brunch buffet. The giant meatball!! It's in its own cute little serving bowl and is served on a bed of spaghetti and let me tell you-- it is to die for. Literally, it's the best meatball I've had in my life. If it wasn't so huge, I would have had another. Next up, the barbacoa at the Latin American station! The meat is incredibly tender and perfectly spiced. I had bits of this several times throughout my visit to the buffet. Their kielbasa!! Now I know what you're probably thinking-- kielbasa is really one of the best things on this buffet? YES. It's juicy beyond belief, and the smoky and savory flavor is unreal. My whole family ooh-ed and aah-ed over this one. They also have tons of fruit and veggies and I know that vegetarians would get along great here, but I was really feeling all the meats that day.   There's way more delicious food than I can fit in a review, but trust me-- you'll be so happy you ate here, so go!!

se4AEENCIf0fkPDXiaBdmg.text: I went to The Buffet at Aria with my mom for weekday brunch since she had a 2 for 1 deal from her MyVegas app. It's been a very long while since I've done more than one buffet during one Vegas trip. The other one being the Le Village Buffet at Paris LV. The Aria Buffet was definitely the better of the two, but the food was just okay and not up to the quality with the likes of Bacchanal and Wicked Spoon. Here are some highlights from their weekday brunch: Kielbasa, prime rib, cowboy steak -- bit.ly/2lhls4l Short rib, scallop potatoes, shrimp & grits -- bit.ly/2lgi8pT Apple Cider & Blood Orange Creamsicle Gelato -- bit.ly/2lf8ILB As I said earlier, the food was good, but not too much to brag about which is like how it is any any other buffet. I enjoyed the first plate I had from the carved meats station and also the short rib and and shrimp & grits were delicious. And no complaints with their gelato selection, the apple cider and blood orange creamsicle gelato were refreshing and a great way to finish off my buffet session. I think what turned me off was how they left a lot of signage out there that were incorrectly displayed for the food being served at the time. I naively picked up some scallop potatoes when the sign said they were bone marrow. I should've known better since scallops and bone marrow are completely distinguishable. But there were a lot of displays where I would see Chicken & Waffles and they have just pancakes out. That was pretty disappointing. Another disappointing thing was how even though it was already close to lunchtime, they didn't have anything unique to offer. I was really looking forward to trying stuff from their much-talked about tandoori oven, but it wasn't even fired up. Overall, weekday brunch at the Aria Buffet was good and with the 2 for 1 coupon we had it made it a great deal. Though I think for what they offer at $28.99 per person is a little bit lackluster.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Apple Cider &amp; Blood Orange Creamsicle Gelato
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Short rib, scallop potatoes, shrimp &amp; grits
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kielbasa, prime rib, cowboy steak

secdkjmSqo68PE9y39-f1Q.text: I sit here at The Buffet disappointed.  Many of the items listed available on little tag up on the buffet are "out."  The seafood bar is a bunch of misc stuff all thrown together.  I wanted shrimp but didn't want to spend 10 minutes trying to find a few under a ton of muscles.  The rest of the food was good but it's far from the best buffet on the strip.  I would go somewhere else and spend your money.  I had to add to my review after visiting the desert bar.  I found them bland and generic.  I doubt they are made in-house.  Cheap bulk food.

RR8B4m0H0DTOfnYz6fzISQ.text: This restaurant is always clean and the service is always good. The servers are always nice and ready to help. The Aria is a nice hotel and it's convenient to have a good buffet on the premises. There is a good variety of different kinds of food. Check it out if in Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

L7MttrNxQDhEvSv0rSwROw.text: So good. They have a good variety of food that accommodates to everyone. My kids loved it. And the quality of the did is on point... Didn't taste like mass produced food. Would totally come here again!!   It is pricy though but so worth it.

w2xGN1abcQQbmZNz2VP70Q.text: This buffet has gone through a lot of adjustments over the last few years, but I love that the prices have stayed fairly consistent. In the beginning when Aria opened I really didn't like the dinner buffet very much, and there was a lot of competition on the strip for great buffets. But over the years it has definitely improved. My preference is the brunch, although I was sad that they no longer serve steamed crab legs on the brunch menu during the week. You can still get the cold ones, but the way they steam crab legs there is definitely not the same. Those steamed crabs are delicious. The freshly made naan bread is my absolute favorite thing about this buffet. If all I ever had to eat in life again was crab legs and naan bread I think I would be in heaven. In fact, I hope that's what they serve in heaven.   I do feel like service is a little hindered because there don't appear to be bussers for the tables like there used to be. Or maybe I was just imagining it before? but I could swear that the waiters didn't have it so tough. The waiters are always friendly and accommodating, but they are also trying to bus their own tables in between taking drink orders. I feel at times the customers are not getting paid attention to for simple things. So maybe management could bring back a busser for each section to help the waiters out? Either way, I definitely recommend this to anyone looking for a solid brunch or dinner!

SmgJE8Sb9vmaNx5yLv2bPQ.text: Excellent variety of American, Mexican, Asian (mostly Chinese), Indian, Italian, and more cuisines. Came here at 2:30pm and paid the lunch price ($28.99 per person), although we ended up getting to sample the dinner dishes as well since dinner began at 3:00pm. That means I ate my weight in snow crab legs, as they are not offered at lunch and only come out around 3pm. Also opted for the $19.99 unlimited 2-for-1 drinks, which means my girlfriend and I paid $20 for both of us to drink as much as we liked. The drinks included are Blue Moon, Stella, Bud Light (possibly 1 other beer option), wine, champagne, and a selection of cocktails including a delicious rum punch and margaritas (in classic or watermelon lime).   Everything I sampled food-wise was great, especially the snow crab legs, beef barbacoa, curried veggies, and the kale power salad (I don't even like kale, and I was pleasantly surprised--I'm gonna need them to hit me with the recipe!). That said, there is also a decent selection of healthy options, mostly fresh seafood and a big salad bar. Highly recommend this buffet as a good value for money, especially if you eat as many snow crab legs as I did!   Minus 1 star because the dessert was just okay, but there was a huge variety (including gelato) and I didn't try everything.

k__vEfCuHb8gia6yWVjKUw.text: Came to the Aria Buffet for dinner with friends while in Vegas and before going to see Penn & Teller show. We used our 2 for 1 discount vouchers...it pays to play so we got a good value for our $.  Great variety of food stations for the buffet... king crab legs were delicious. There were also carving stations, sushi, soup, salad, pizza, seafood, hot and cold foods, bread....And of course desserts.   Found the desserts to be a bit bland and ok. the main stations were better.
