They offer a bottomless drink (Wine/beer/cocktails) menu for additional $16.99.  For the price of the buffet the M casino offers their wine and beer with the price.   If I was asked to come here again I would probably say no, not a huge selection of choices. I will say the server we had was extremely helpful and pleasant to talk to.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dinning area

tEBo3xAbhRoSAk-s7heBLw.text: Like most buffets in Las Vegas, this place had a long wait time (1 hr). We decided to stick it out, but must say the cashier was unfriendly and rude. Once we were seated a gentleman took our drink order right away and was very attentive and would offer refills with a few minutes of finishing your drink.   The food: Theres SO many choices here! mexican, fish market, asian (sushi, build your own pho, etc), indian, italian, a salad bar, soul food (fried chicken, mac and cheese) various meats and an array of desserts (key lime, gelato, caramel popcorn, popcorn with chocolate drizzling, etc). The food was pretty good and fresh, although not great. I was mostly impressed at the variety of foods offered.

cavcqcsodYZoBnFl8Y320w.text: The food is a 4/5, but the staff SUCKS!! come on Aria get some people with shining customer service skills...this is the #1 thing at any restaurant or company. As soon as I walked in I felt the lack of customer service among staff. First of all I came to eat alone since my husband is here for work. It was immediately assumed I was with another single guest. I said, "nope just me". Then the staff member repeatedly said "solo? by yourself?" shheeezuz... that was kind of embarrassing. THEN the staff member who walked me to my table did the same thing! "just for one? one? by youself?"..... guess I should look into an escort next time! haha jk  So please tell your staff: don't assume & treat others as you would like to be treated. =)

fa3qGAbUs_gM19Lt5YWdlA.text: Im staying at this hotel and theres a ridiculous line to eat at the buffet at 11 pm on a weekday.  Oh, yeah, did I mention the restaurant is mostly empty. They dont want to pay enough staff to be there so the guests are supposed to waste hours of their time? Absurd!

GVLyxJQ9cMKWXMaaYyUvZA.text: I've now been here for breakfast, lunch and dinner and would continue to go back. It's a nice solid buffet that has something for everyone, including high-value items like sushi and crab legs during lunch and dinner. Of course you're going to be disappointed and find it overpriced if you come here and just eat pizza and salad.   My one complaint is that they're either not staffed correctly or for some other reason they make people stand around waiting for a table while half the tables in the places are sitting empty. That said, the last four times I went we didn't have to wait at all, but it was pretty early on weekdays.

wz31icpA4wFdbVw3XCGHJQ.text: WORST Buffet on the strip. with all food wrong Labeled, which made me put some meat in my mouth beeing a vegetarian... Horrible , plus food looks dry and old. all seafood is frozen , and with a  really low quality, was expecting much more from ARIA  go to The Bacchanal in Ceaser's palace, or the wicked spoon at the cosmo, to at the bellagio, 5 or 10 $ dollars but quality its much better. Servers are  only worried f you are going to drink and put so much pressure on you for ordering drinks etc.... AVOID this Buffet,

bymMGpcxbqSPiKn9HjW9DQ.text: I'm not a huge buffet fan, but we received a few complimentary meals at Aria's buffet so we couldn't help but to try it out.  Crab legs, carved meats, dim sum, an entire dessert corner... this buffet has every delicious food you could possibly desire. I don't understand these mediocre reviews at all; this buffet boasts quality & quantity! I also appreciated the huge seating area & space between tables - I can't stand the hectic, cramped, run-to-get-another-plate ambiance of the typical buffet. Aria's buffet was certainly busy but fortunately didn't feel like it.  One thing... I didn't notice much of a menu change from lunch to dinner. I recommend skipping the inflated evening price by arriving before 3:30p. Service was on the slow side & you kind of need to seriously flag down a waiter for a drink refill. Overall though it was a very yummy experience without the stereotypical buffet atmosphere.

cCkBuxCw5Lr9CRIYoITOkw.text: KING CRAB LEGS FOR DAYZ.   It was a bit pricey, yes.  BUT, my group and I spend months on the Facebook app myVEGAS slots and took advantage of that when we hit up the buffets.  I was impressed by the selection and variety of food- pasta, dim sum, an assortment of meats, fruits, and soups, and a dessert bar to die for.    BUT THE UNLIMITED KING CRAB LEGS.  PRE-CUT FOR YOU SO YOU DON'T HAVE TO DO ANYTHING BUT PULL THE MEAT OUT.  I definitely ate my money's worth on these alone.  I probably had 4-5 plates of them DRENCHED IN BUTTER.  I got the worst stomachache from the butter, but IT WAS WORTH IT.  I'D DO IT AGAIN.

nmougxF5IMNCB1diumSV-A.text: Let me first say that the buffet wasn't horrible but wasn't great.  Me and my family came on a weekend for lunch and the prices stemmed normal for a Vegas buffet. The selection was okay but not those really unique foods like the other unique foods at the Wicked Spoon. Once he ate the food we didn't know if it was good or bad. It was a mix of it. Also let me say that the service is good and the buffet seemed clean.  Conclusion: I really don't recommend coming to the buffet here at the Aria but there's also many other restaurants at the Aria.

6hsTi5tsVUxDhdANgw5FXg.text: We came here have dinner cos it's free. Vegetables are good, sweets are good, seafood is so so. I don't think I will pay for eat here, but for free is ok~

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

hH0nVoFhUNukbyLwFqh5Kg.text: I've been here before and loved it! Crab, lobster, made to order fish and other items. The price has gone up and the food has gone down. Crab is still good, but at the steep price of $43 it is not worth it!

vcjRfW7B4ED4ig9QimMQ_A.text: Three stars is a pretty fair assessment. The place is very spacious and modern decor. Staffs are very attentive refilling drinks and cleaning out the dishes. Those are pretty much the pluses.   What's not so good? The food is pretty disappointing. While they have a wide selection of cuisines,  they are average at best. For example, the sushi rice wasn't well cooked. The crabs were too salty. My expectations would probably be much lower if this is not situationed inside a 5-star hotel.

4wnAou_q9czqR7ZXR0QB2w.text: This buffet is the place to go for gluten free! I asked about gluten free when we were paying and she immediately called someone over who walked me over to the Chef. He was able to point out all the gluten free dishes. They had gluten free bread, all the meats except one sausage were gluten free, lots of Mediterranean dips, plenty of seafood options, sushi (with gluten free tamari from the chef), Indian food and even desserts!! Creme brulee, marshmallows, macaroons, oatmeal raisin cookies and fresh made gelato. We will definitely revisit on another vacation trip!!

TZsaljIuJvBxCENYQ_WdJw.text: DISAPPOINTMENT  My wife and I heard all the raves about The Buffet at Aria so decided to cashed in on the comp dinner buffet from Myvegas.  Food - 0/5  We did the typical routine, walking around getting a little of each to try so we know which one to come back for seconds. On the outside, all foods look very picture perfect, but boy were we wrong.  The food tasted like the chefs had extra salt laying around so they decided to add a few extra table spoons to each dish. I finished 2 glasses of coke before I could finish what was on my plate. After "the sample" dish, we bolted for the desert and didn't bother coming back for seconds.   Desert was just ok. Nothing exceptional.  Service - 5/5  Our server was great. Bring our second glass of drink right when we finish our first one. That's attention to detail. Keep up the good work.   In summary, we were disappointed even when the dinner was free. Could you imagine if we paid $80 for 2 people?

Nk-802QQ8uRZHQS6k0hhXw.text: Decent buffet. I do wish though that our drink waiter would be around more often so that I could have gotten a few more mimosas in for my $12.99 unlimited option. Even though I was here on a Monday, service was a bit slow and one of the meat cutter guys seemed so unhappy to be working. The food itself was alright. I had everything from their hummus and pita chips, to their crab legs, their chorizo breakfast burrito and their cinammon bun. Their hashbrowns were surprisingly great! Crispy and not too oily. Their fruit salad (banana and strawberry) was kinda bland. They had a few kinds of meats, cheeses, an omelette station, some crazy giant three layer pancake and a good handful of flavors of ice cream to end your meal. They also had dumplings, oysters, crayfish and pizza. Good range of foods, alright tasting but service lacked. Would be nice to see a smile or two in there and for sure my drink guy around so that my glass wouldn't be sitting there empty for a long time. No need to bend over backwards for this place.  #24/2015

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Round 2
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Round one

fv74ElID_baR_nqz6vNydA.text: I love going to the Aria period, so going to their buffet always brings a smile to my face. When people asks what's the difference, it's the little things and not so little things. Yes, it's a buffet, so as long as the food tastes good, that's all I care about. Everything here is good and I love that there are so many options, so it doesn't matter if you're a carnivore/vegetarian/vegan/gluten free. It's very clean and the staff works hard to make sure everyone is happy. I love the $12.99 bottomless drinks! The mimosas, rum punch, and sangria are to die for.  My only suggestion would be to have more options for desserts, but after eating all that food it doesn't really matter.

-xTOTUCoYnXlG_-fp2DDQQ.text: My family decided to go Aria for buffet dinner June 18th.  I really liked the menu item they served.  Roasted beef was tender and had nice flavors had couple of dim sum was also good. Kids loved turkey with stuffing, however typical of any Vegas buffet restaurant their Sushi was subpar at best, what ever the reason restaurant continue to use cheap non sushi rice and without any additional sushi  seasoning, no flavor.  They should pay few extra dollars to purchase prime sushi rice grain, rice makes the sushi not Neta aka topping.  Other than that I liked the layout of buffet item cluster by meal type.  Server service was excellent

x195spXkpvNLft0iA3Z5pA.text: Better experience than Cravings in TI, but anything would be better than Cravings. Buffet is deep in the Aria and took a little while for us to find. However, they were very prompt in having us pay and seating us. Price was on the steep side it was $65 altogether for lunch and bottomless drinks. Gratuity of 20% is included for large groups.   We had a group of nine and we all did the bottomless mimosas, wine & beer in addition to the buffet. Wait staff will only bring you refills for one type of drink at a time. You can double fist the same type of drink but they will make you finish your glass to switch over to another type of drink.  The mimosas were extremely fizzy and carbonated thus hard to drink fast and really filling. Don't have too many mimosas if you're trying to get your $35 out of eating at the buffet! My friends did not enjoy the Bloody Mary. Most of us stuck to beer and drank about 4-6 drinks to get a value out of the bottomless. I tried one of the champagne vodka cocktails and that was pretty good too. Overall this is a great spot for large groups to all find what they like to eat and also get some day drinking in.

HnRDuFjBXIAbFdbH5Itgcg.text: I'll start by saying: my wife and I are not buffet people. But, we got comped buffet passes upon check-in, and with our MLife status got to skip the (HUGE) line on a Sunday brunch, so why not?  As I mentioned, I don't have a lot of buffet experience to go on here, but wow was this thing solid. All the usual food types were available: Chinese, Mexican, Italian, meat carving station, etc. Desserts were a plenty, and the bottomless mimosas were an amazing value. Also really impressed with the service!

OU_Baid-A9EbCgfE1q-YNg.text: The food selection is large! A great variety of all kinds of foods. The line to get in took us about 20-25 minutes and costs around $35. You can add bottomless drinks for $20. Bottomless drinks option was buy one, get one free. The staff was friendly. Our group of 7 stayed for about 4 hours just drinking most of the time and never felt rushed out!

WTzx5CQRD6JZRKoGL4ftAA.text: I would not eat here. I didnt have breakfast and ate here for lunch. I got sick pretty bad. How could i assume its other food if i didn't have breakfast.   I def didn't have dinner afterwards cause i was feeling so nauseous.  Would i go here again? No.... pay approx $25 to get sick is not my idea of a good place to eat.   Judge for yourself

qkiCS0vBbftQrGNe5QhCWQ.text: *Thumbs up* Lots of bad reviews before the revamp -- I never tried the buffet back then. But I've eaten here after the remodel (both food and decor), and I actually enjoyed this buffet. It doesn't have the variety and flashiness like with Bellagio, Wynn, or Wicked Spoon, but it'll satisfy the belly if you stick with the hot crab legs and meat station.  *Thumbs down* A lot of the other smaller dishes that aren't as popular will sit around and quickly become cold and stale. Stick with the dishes that are popular and are always being replenished.

QT5_-RpRI1PkEDVA45DD5A.text: My Wife and I went to this Buffet on Dec. 5th 2013 around 7 pm, it was DEAD here and I KNOW why!!!  This is a really small buffet compared to the lavish buffets you are use to getting in Las Vegas, I was really surprised & kinda let down by this buffet.  Each station had a few items to offer and they all looked like they had been sitting there for a while!  There were a few things I did see them making fresh, so at least I do know they do make things there, however I just really wasn't impressed with the selection or taste of any of it.  I think the best thing I ate was a salad...really?! Yeah, really, simple iceberg,black olives, cheese, tomatoes, croutons, broccoli and ranch dressing, the lady tossed it for me and that was good.  Luckily we only had to pay for ONE of these Dinner buffets, we got a comped one play MyVegas on Facebook ;)

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Decent Dessert buffet
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dry Crab legs,  room temperature shrimp cocktail...wah wah
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Nothing Spectacular. ..

8zlsMNaXKK3PBaVy9O44pQ.text: Wish I would have checked Yelp before coming here. I can't believe I paid $45 for a dinner that would have cost under $20 at a non-buffet restaurant. For what it's worth, the food did taste REALLY good (get the turkey breast!!) but for the price, I don't think the options were worth it. There was a variety, sure, but in each section it was only a small amount of foods.  The service was pretty poor and they hardly came around to check on us even though the place was nearly empty.

mwrTEun9RUd_HvGAvcB-9w.text: It's a nice, bright place inside the ARIA hotel. We ate there a few times during our stay in Vegas and were mostly satisfied with the food.   The prices aren't low (but what IS cheap in Vegas :D?) - $20 for breakfast, $30 for lunch and $35 for dinner buffet. And if you like to get drunk in the morning, for bottomless alcoholic beverages you must add another $13. The staff is really good in managing guest, as there is always a lot of people there, but lines are up to 10 minutes at most. Breakfast selection is great - a lot of eggs in different forms (the omelet guy is a wizard, I tell you!), pizza, asian rolls, toast, sausages, cereals, skillets, make-your-own-salad station and many many other things. Even crab legs and other seafood, I never knew people eat that for breakfast. Everything was warm and tasty. Dinner there was a bit worse. I imagine it's a mix of breakfast and lunch food. It was good but nothing special. I tried some meats and different kinds of fish and there always was something slightly wrong with it. But the pasta guy is awesome (i think it's the same person that makes omelets!). His dishes are simply wonderful, especially with Alfredo sauce. Mmm. There is also a corner with beautifully made desserts and pastries. I tried a few and they were good, but nothing above average. However, I simply adored the Peanut Butter Gellato. I have eaten it every single day after breakfast or dinner or both :).   All in all, I would recommend this place for breakfast, especially with the family, as I imagine even the most choosy kid will find something to eat there. As for dinner or lunch, I suppose there is a lot of better places to try, even in the ARIA alone.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dessert
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. I couldn&#39;t decide :)

gfgaazBswVVsa9WZKo4GNw.text: This is a 3.5 star review that leans 4... it's it pricey? Yes,  is there a few flaws? Yup. That said We were happy with the food and there's allot of options to choose from. Omelet station was good and bacon was crispy which is rare at a buffet in my experience. Would i go here again? I'm not sure but I'm glad we tried it once

Ooh2wjXECU6-uYWt12ENMg.text: Went here and it was very pricey for what you get. Waited in a long line and the variety wasn't the best plus there isn't much that I liked. If I had the chance to go back I wouldn't much better places to eat for less money.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Salad
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dessert was pretty good!

EUloE3yI-GemZAJ2oXG7vA.text: A good friend with his partner treated our family of 8 to dinner here June 19 and my family had a great time.  International food selection okay although the wide array is not as much as The Vikings in my home country (PH) which is our favorite. Loved their desserts, chowders and pastas. The fruit shakes we got were also quite good and our very friendly and warm server (a Filipina compatriot) was prompt to offer and refill our drinks. She even cheerfully took our photos.  In my country, seafood is plentiful and can be found really fresh, so I detected a hint of lack of freshness in the crab legs which is still understandable. But am amazed at the quantity available. And many I saw actually were very happy with them. People had to queue for the crab legs because of so many wanting to get them over and over again.  Saw a long line outside wanting to come in. Grateful we didn't have to wait in line as our host made a reservation. 44sh degrees celsius outside so thumbs up too for their powerful a/c.  The lone star I did not give is on account of the guy behind the Japanese selection.  But still this sumptuous dinner made our day complete after the Grand Canyon tour we had earlier that day.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

qtoEQEy5RBDYXayaXyBdcQ.text: Worst buffet ever $105 wasted Asian food : very few and bad Meats: pure fat and hard to chew Salads: regular - Avoid this place

Ru3hO3Zq3isID-_58VlOHw.text: I am not a buffet person. My parents live in Vegas and they love buffets. I must admit, for a person who eats healthy (me), this worked for me and I ate here twice during my stay, once for lunch and for breakfast. The selection is not as massive as most but the food is refreshed often, the presentation is good and it worked for me. Is it knock your socks off? Absolutely not. But for $20 for breakfast and $24 for lunch it is a good value. What did I like? They will toss your salad and it is good choices. This won me over. The smoked salmon (lox) was pretty good quality. The fresh fruit was decent. The roasted beets for lunch were delicious. I left happy and not stuffed. Perfect. And I didn't hate it, like I usually do at Mandalay Bay. Well done, Aria.

P78PvWfV7tLjDlRMvncGpQ.text: We went on a Monday after lunch. We also got bottomless drinks. It was pretty good. The drinks were generous. The service was very good.

tJuLKSUMWEI9jO2aj7dP4w.text: Even with the notification of it being renovated does not really say much in terms of organization. I am not sure who designed the lay out in how the food should be organized but it makes no sense. Fellow Yelper Yvonne R. was right about how certain foods are found in random areas. You would think the signs that denote the type of foods there are would help. If you were asked, "Where did you get that?" some items will leave you kinda giving abstract directions in an unknown city.   I did notice they have steam crab legs or fresh ones. I am wary to eat the seafood. I had the nigiri and the fish wasn't very fresh. I have to make note I did enjoy the brisket but it's weird because it looks like sauced ribs at the carving table. Do not be confused like me, then again I don't really eat red meat that often. There was not really a wait. I came here on a Friday around lunch time right after arriving into Las Vegas. The place is clean though and the restroom of course is outside the buffet.

MMGwy6L2zchxNcZCW4EmdQ.text: We went for dinner buffet.  There was a good variety of food at the buffet.  Seafood, Asian,  Indian, Mediterranean, carved meat,  salad bar, dessert. Food was average at best.  I guess you pay for the variety/options for food.service was atrocious.  They have you pay for buffet beforehand,  and I guess it was my bad,  I included the tip beforehand. I would hve never left a good tip for the atrocious service we received.  We had to flag down our server for refills.  Our plates were not cleared off our table. Thankfully we didn't opt for all you can drink for two hours for additional $17, we would have never received our drinks in time .  Next time we ll try Caesar or Wynn.

DSNHDIye2JNmsy2SwbYeog.text: One of my favorite buffet places in Vegas. Bellagio's was meh, Wynn's was good & so was Rio's seafood buffet & Mandalay's. The Buffet at Aria was fun, exciting, enjoyable & honestly quite impressive.  I'm subtracting 1 star because there was a large group of us eating there (about 12 adults, plus I think 3 kids), & they said they'd have to charge an extra $100 bucks to seat us together. My cousin voluntarily paid - through the nose. Never in my life had I heard of an extra $100 charge to seat a big group together. Maybe that's Aria's version of 'Welcome to Vegas'. I'm not sure the place was full, but yeah.  Apart from the annoying $100 charge & the "the buffet" logo with its awful kerning (sorry), there really was nothing to complain about. Vegas really does have amazing chefs, & a bunch of them are at Aria. The place has a young, modern feel to it; the food selection was diverse (there was pizza amongst all the sushi & lobster -- or was that crawfish? no idea, hehe); the seafood was fresh & clean but flavorful; the desserts were adventurous & artistic. It was expensive (can't remember how much, exactly), but it's worth the $ if you're a foodie, or eating there for the experience.

Sfg1q54YpEnMVL-TYvoVPA.text: Overall, it was quite good, although there wasn't anything particularly stellar. I did appreciate how many different cultural foods they managed to include however; I ate a little bit of everything and enjoyed some of the Asian and Middle Eastern cuisine they offered.  The spinning ice cream/gelato display was pretty interesting, though.

NmSb1GHKKdmIbxI4mByTRg.text: Amazing. It truly is what everyone says it is. I don't eat seafood at all, so that's saying a lot. I love the little decadent portrayals of the food, served in cute little containers. The food is very fresh and the service is impeccable! I will most definitely return, worth every $25.99 for weekday lunch!!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. So cute &amp; absolutely delicious!!

6vY83VfHDnFgrqY5xft1KA.text: Prime rib ribs are Awesome!  Tandoori chicken thumbs up. Hot crab legs nice seafood selection.   Prime rib good cowboy steak a little chewy.  Salad selection ok. Deserts great!  Great for the price.

EA8h0uf2UiNutYKG_3JVCQ.text: For $43 definitely not worth it! The only good quality food in this buffet is desert section and Italian, the rest is really not good I expected more from this really modern beautiful hotel

VDDzG8g-V6As-aMISI55Vg.text: This is hands down my favorite buffet in Las Vegas - I've eaten at all of MGM band buffets and this one is my favorite.  I eat here at least twice every visit to Las Vegas.  They have a pho bar where you can mix your own pho, a carving station with a wide selection of meats, crab legs (my personal favorite), a dim sum station, an awesome salad bar with fresh squeezed juices sometimes (interesting ones too, like watermelon).  One dinner I had there included ahi tuna steaks that were cooked to perfection.... something that would have been very expensive in a high end restaurant and so amazingly good.  Could not believe something like this was served at a buffet and how good it was.  I love how they put the individual servings in cute little containers.  Also, their dessert station is off the hook - everything I have tried was nothing short of amazing - oh, and they have a gelato station with probably 15-20 different flavors to try. I'm planning a trip in October and will be back.  Can't wait to come back here.

EOKASQubifOaZEQerAceeg.text: This was our first stop in Vegas. The facility was impressive. Food was replenished timely. There was a good variety to choose from. Asian, Italian, Greek, American, breakfast items, omelette station, meats and a large selection of dessert and gelato. It was a good experience and worth it when you're super hungry. The price seemed fair compared to other eateries on the strip.

3r_3AZFaOqisv8W277e0Cg.text: The buffet doesn't have many selections compared to others but it's not bad! I mostly went back to the carving station but the seafood section was amazing. I wish they had more Japanese selections and Chinese selections. There were only 4-5 different options for each. No sashimi which is a bummer!  Their sweets and fruit selection is plenty so you can never go wrong!   Our waitress Stephanie was amazing. She was so attentive to our table, and the rest of her section. She's quick on clearing our table to make room for more plates. Always has a smile, sweet lady! I would recommend being seat at her table! She'll take care of you.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

c4iXWda3sMLCfP00bY8dbg.text: Very disappointing and will not be coming back. The food is not great! We came here around 3pm, not as packed, seated right away. Server takes sooo long to bring drinks and refills, she also takes long to pick up plates.   The food is not great. The dim sum soggy, the bbq pork bun quickly turns cold and hard.   The Italian station only consist of meatballs in tomato sauce and boiled noodles on the side, very bland. The chicken parmigiana is dry and salty. Looks good but doesn't taste good.  The sushi/seafood bar, typical crab legs, crawfish, clams, and oysters. Clams and oysters not cleaned very well, sandy. The crab legs and crawfish bland no seasonings at all. Even the butter didn't taste like butter. There were only three different kind of rolls not a lot of variety and not very good. Very chewy.  Carving station is usually my favorite!!!! But nope. They had a cart of fresh prime rib, when the guest in front of me asked if he can get the meat that came out fresh and was sitting in the cart, the chef said no. He said they were not going to serve it until about 5:30pm and the time was about 4pm then. The prime rib left on the carving station was well done about two carvings left and we had to take it. I asked if I may have a piece that was medium rare but the chef acted like he couldn't hear me.   Salad bar is the usual and last but not least I had high expectations for their dessert bar. Disgusting. Creme brulee salty. Cookies were hard as rocks. Everything tastes so dry. The only thing good they've got going is probably the gelato which I didn't even bother to try by then.  First and last time. The hype is not real. Food is not worth $41.99 per person. Oh and my party waited until 5:30pm still no beef bone but they finally put out a new slab of meat. Wow... Not so fancy after all.

D1EFqxIhwDmT8aM_g5cKyQ.text: Had dinner here. Desserts were amazing- crab legs had seen better days- but there were so many people eating them that it was understandable.

BMPlHiqhlugUUYt5QRFgYQ.text: What a big let down. I've read online how aria has one of the best buffets in vegas.  Sadly after attending I learned that is not the case.   The wait to eat on new years eve was not terrible. Maybe 30-45 min. We went around brunch time and the service was better than many people gave them credit for.  The food selection seemed very limited compared to the wynn and bellagio.  But that wasn't even what I was most disappointed with,  the food quality lacked majorly in flavor.  I think the only meat worth eating there was their kilbasa sausage. Pork was over cooked and skin was hard to even cut with their huge bulky dull knife, tri tip was very over done, and their chorizo sausage had no spice.  They had an Italian section which I expected to have all sorts of pastas, instead there was maybe 4 kinds of pizza and spaghetti.    I do not believe I will be coming back.

VzgJ3WeTUiW8iqmyPmqO5A.text: This so-called "luxury" hotel needs to up their game. I was so disappointed after ponying up $50 a person for their "holiday special" buffet, granted this was after Christmas and before NYE so I don't know why they had a surcharge. In any case I think this buffet was geared for international folks from Asia because most of the lines were for the seafood only.  The line was so long, I didn't bother.  The bad- the Mexican food like the Pork verde looked amazing but it tasted like death.  The taquitos and guac too bad and so so sad.  Dessert- the only thing redeeming was the gelato but the small cakes and desserts had about zero flavor.  Salad bar- oh it looked so good, the pre-made salads again were flavorless yet overdressed.  Save your money and go to Wicked Spoon in Cosmo or something better than this mess.

mVR8s7n6zC6t8e6M7FqVaA.text: Honestly, coming in here, I did not know what to expect.  I have not really heard much about the buffet at Aria.  Some people have said it was good, and others have condemned the place.  I have to say that Aria gets a B+ in my book.  Considering that the night before, I had eaten at the Bellagio buffet, and was utterly disappointed at the selection, the freshness, and hoards of people trying to load up on food in the already, cramped space.  I was in complete disarray of how horrible Bellagio was this time, compared to the last time I went there.  From a large walkway to accommodate lots of people searching for what they want to pile on their plates, to the modern decor, the Aria buffet was definitely a breath of fresh air.  Of course getting in for free does help quite a bit, thanks to myVegas.    There is a lot of selection to choose from.  Some of the food is already pre-portioned, allowing ease for people to just grab what they desire.  They have types of cuisine which are typical at any buffet.  The dessert selection is also a delight, which features gelato, cakes, pastries, and an assortment of tarts.    I would recommend the Aria buffet considering the fact that maybe Bellagio has peaked, and they do not care about quality of food anymore.

gMzl-jHuFIjeHnAsO0IAKg.text: Had holiday brunch here. Wait was an hour. Food totally not worth the wait for the price. The $38.99 holiday brunch is worse than the holiday brunch at MGM at $29.99 or even the regular lunch at MGM. --- Regular Hours & Pricing Breakfast: $21.99* Monday - Friday 7:00 AM - 11:00 AM Lunch: $25.99* Monday - Friday 11:00 AM - 3:00 PM Brunch: $31.99* Saturday & Sunday 7:00 AM - 3:00 PM Dinner: $36.99* Monday - Thursday 3:00 PM - 10:00 PM Gourmet Dinner: $41.99* Friday - Sunday 3:00 PM - 10:00 PM --- Holiday Brunch $38.99 (kids 5+ $21.99) 7:00 a.m. - 3:00 p.m. Holiday Dinner $47.99 (kids 5+ $25.99) 3:00 p.m. - 10:00 p.m. However, holiday is defined as 12/13-1/?, so you are pretty much stuck in the higher prices. 3 or younger eat free. - Regular and holiday pricing: aria.com/en/restaurants/...

2MRxeuO7GMG7bT7g216KTw.text: My wife and I were staying at Aria for our second wedding anniversary. We decided to try out The Buffet at ARIA despite the mediocre reviews because, for the cost, you can really get your money's worth. At $35 a person (on a weekday) it isn't hard to eat enough crab and carved meat to leave satisfied. The same can't always be said for the $60 buffets. If that had been it, I would probably have left a four-star review.  Unfortunately, in the hour and a half that we were there, we were not waited on once. Thirty minutes in we sought out the hostess who sat us, and she brought us both drinks and assured us that she would send a waiter our way. Six plates and those same two drinks later, we left without ever seeing someone.  It was unfortunate because up until then we have had nothing but amazing service from all of the staff at ARIA.

mQdN4gbC_s01Izr6QjxFeA.text: The best thing about this buffet, in my opinion, is the dessert bar: tons of selections and most pastries/cakes come straight from Jean Philippe Patisserie! I came hungry, after reading reviews and the restaurant guide from Aria, I knew I had to save room for dessert. You won't be disappointed eating here if you've got a sweet tooth!  The entrees/selections were OK - price was $38.99 per person on a Saturday night, which comes with unlimited wine & a lobster for two, plus endless supply of food from the buffet.  Some notable items on the buffet were the sushi bar, tandoori chicken, freshly baked naan, grilled salmon, and king crab legs. We made our own dipping sauce using butter, pepper, salt, and lemons.  It was delicious and a great experience here.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mango Cheesecake (from Jean Philippe, serves in the Buffet).
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Apple Pie with Hazelnut Creme.
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The Buffet at Aria (with a Raspberry Mini Cake).

EfJhNvhFfRr1v4iCaS6fNg.text: I've been to buffets at the Wynn, Bellagio, Paris (gross), and a few others, and I'll rank this five stars easily.  It's not fancy but the food outstanding.  It's inexpensive too!

U4ooZ8gpApVmGlxAB0eWcw.text: We went here bc it was so highly rated on TripAdvisor.  Should've listened to you, YELP.   So many buffets to choose from, and at a comparable price ($40) to Como's (Wicked Spoon) and Encore's -- this one pales in comparison.   - The line to get in seems to always be really long, except at random hours that aren't usually when people eat - We went after reading all about the crab, but this is where we were most disappointed (and entire Yelp Star off) for the crab (snow, king):  they served it cut in half (length wise) which means you're getting little shards of meat, not those heavenly huge chunks you can get when you crack it yourself. They also serve it cold (read: it's completely frozen) and steamed (limp, soggy, gross) - Huge selection, so if your goal is to stuff your face you're all set and you'll be in heaven -- but if your goal is to taste really well-done versions of international foods-- then this is not your place  - Sushi/sashimi are terrible

ApsRxDhZOLIEN8RLBkvvag.text: We ate at the Aria buffet on Thursday - 1/25/2018.  Food was cool to luke warm.  Made to order pasta was hot, but so saturated in butter and garlic that it was pretty inedible.  Crab legs smelled like they had been in the sun all day long.  Carved meat looked like it had been out just as long.  This place is a rip off.  Don't waste your time.

yeLprf9Eowe6OXtbA-tucg.text: The food was very fresh and appetizing. We were not sure what to expect but were completely satisfied. I especially liked the dim sum options. They had warm and iced crab legs. The pita bread was made right in front of you. They have a huge gelato selection as well as other desserts.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

5nZU51NyTVQAW6JbNFPuLA.text: Went on a Tuesday dinner time 530pm. Cost was $40. Inside was clean. Not much quality of food. The asian theme barely had any asian entree. They did serve small bowls of pho! Something I have yet to see in vegas buffets. Standard seafood. Crab legs. Cold or steamed. Cocktail shrimp. Various mussels. Some sushi that was weak. Had Italian and Latin food also. Craving station also. 3 star because the quality and quantities didn't meet my expectation for a buffet in a higher end hotel such as the Aria.  I came hungry. I didn't walk out full. That meant the quality didn't give me the wow factor to continue to fill this belly.  Advice. Pay the extra 20 to eat at Bachannal buffet at Ceasars Palace.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The steamed crab legs was good

cVXV42bwQOCcdGmuykMtRg.text: Since I love to stay at Aria whenever we visit Vegas, we decided to give this place a try. I mean, why not?? Aria was giving me credit towards to their buffet!   Although I love Aria for their comfy beds and their customer service... this buffet is not the best. If I didn't have credit for the buffet... I most likely won't be paying to be eating here. Unless I am super hungry and intoxicated and am not able to drive anywhere else... then, I probably would pay to eat there.

254t4ZwlNrMp9Mvia_6CLQ.text: This has always been one of my favorite buffets in Las Vegas. I've eaten here probably 8-10 times over the past few years. What I like most about The Buffet - on than the great food - is it's been very consistent. I've noticed many of the buffets in Vegas are good and then decline. For example, I used to love the buffet at Mirage, but it's become a mediocre meal.  Aria's buffet offers a good mix of cuisines. Pretty much anything you eat here is at least decent, if not great. The seafood is fresh, and that's my favorite part of the buffet. The crab legs, clams, etc. are delicious, always. Make sure you save room for dessert because The Buffet has one of the best dessert bars in town.

K82XsGNdPMEc9Roiao9U7Q.text: Quite disappointed how we had to wait so long in line while there were plenty of open seats. There was only 1 cashier and their computer system is not working. We gave a group of angry customers behind and I wondered where the manager was and they were no where to be found.  The food was great. It has what a typical buffet has just more upscale. Quality of food is a whole lot better. I think they have the best selection of desserts among Las Vegas buffets. Presentation and taste is phenomenal.  I have to mention about their bottomless alcoholic drinks worth $12. They have a great selection of alcoholic drinks. It's pretty worth it.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. King crab
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Meat
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Surf and turf

piBXA2yZ-1Tq4pigGLaAvA.text: I used my 2 for 1 lunch reward from MyVegas slots, so I went in for a Cheaper price! I've been here multiple times and this buffet is pretty much average. There's nothing really good (except the flan) and there's nothing really bad. It has all the standard stations that you'd expect from a Vegas buffet, just without the premier foods.   I got my money's worth from eating endless snow crab that was already cut in half so it was time efficient! They have normal crab claws, but it takes too much time to open it. If you're one of those people who say " but there's more meat in the claws" think again. Although you might be right, you can eat the crab meat a lot faster from the ones that are already cut open than taking time to open the crab claws. Thus resulting in more meat!   The service here seemed to have died.. I remember having great service last year with constant refills and check ups. Now you have to chase down someone just for more napkins..   Despite the fall in service and quality of food, I would probably come back again just for the crab and the flan.   P.s. I've had Caesars, Bellagio's and this buffet all in one stay, and the flan is the best here! It's a must have compares to others.

EKn5ZkfymRGbEj3B4jNjyQ.text: Food was amazing and Ava was a great server. She was on top of keeping our drinks full, which was much appreciated. The variety was great and food even better.

Z5wh-yijPeVt_R9IUyob9Q.text: In all seriousness, this buffet isn't anywhere near as good as other buffet places in the price range. I came here during the Memorial Day weekend and there was a premium price ($38.99) for lunch. After tax and tip, we were $100 in ($50.00 per person). It's slightly cheaper on non busy time (non holiday) so I guess you get more value then.  The food was just okay. The Flan tasted like it was bad (I never spit out food but this was my first time). The egg Benedict was cold and didn't taste very pleasing. The selection is small, and you don't really see this before you get in. We were very hungry and jumped at the first thing that didn't have a very long line--now I can see why. There is better out there (eg. we will be going to Caesar's for better buffet tomorrow and their price is comparable to this but with much better food.  We only liked the sausage and Mexican rice. Their sweets section is largely good. But the other food was just bad. I'm giving this three stars because it could have been worse. I know buffets aren't supposed to have the best quality (usually quantity over quality), but it was just average. I wouldn't come here again because I didn't feel like I got anywhere near even 20% value of what I paid.

ee7KcS5ulB0lYogNtcffQg.text: Beautiful buffet with a great variety of options.  I was just disappointed that they didn't have children's prices.  My kid's, who dine on mac and cheese, meal was the same price as my crab leg eating husband.  So, ditch the little ones and enjoy a nice, pricey buffet.

aJCKFGuo41C3Rv1jb36hbw.text: 4th of July at the Aria in Las Vegas at the buffet was hoping. It was ok, but not worth the money. The service was awesome. The chef walked me around prior to paying and showed me what was safe to eat. If I ate meat, it would have been a better value. But too shabby for what I was able to eat.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

tqJ6ZQhglb9QIJesvQih5A.text: We came here for breakfast, we got free vouchers to come here since we were staying at the Aria. The buffet is small compared to the others we've been to in Vegas. It was a Saturday morning and so it was pretty packed. Pretty good breakfast options, but not as worldly as I suspected it to be.   Long lines to get your omelette made your way, I'm not even sure how long I waited for mine but I was over it by the time I got my omelette. The guy making it was very nice though and spoke many different languages, very cool!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

_RHSmxGmLzu_SXjxOmlUSw.text: This place has a variety of crab legs and a variety of ethnic foods, including curry, dumplings, and pho. There is a moderate selection of meat at the carving station.  The desserts are okay if you like them American-style.  What stood out the most were the dumplings. There was plenty of stuffing inside! You don't get that often, since they usually try to minimize the stuffing to keep costs down.  The sticky rice was also good.  Bottom line is, if you're okay with just snow crab legs but want the best meat, go to Le Village Buffet in Paris. If you want to have a variety of crab legs, curry, and Asian food, it is better to go here.  Keep in mind that lines can form, and it can take a while until the servers take your drink orders.

2NU7Q9hkK9cJhRW7E1Twvw.text: My biggest mistake to wait an hour for their less than mediocre low quality buffet that costs nearly $60. Sea food not fresh; taste salty; beef chewy;a lot less competitive than other same-tier buffets. Avoid this buffet at your best.

i244hs2Ut8rv4pzS0cy7Ig.text: Mediocre is what described this place. It's a buffet so I don't expect things to taste like it's from a michelin star winning restaurant but nothing tasted good here. Asian dishes were really salty and in the Latin section it had onion and cilantro and the onions were chopped in huge chunks like the chef just didn't give a shit. Soda was so flat it just tasted like sugar water and the waitress was nice but the service was so slow because the server was overworked. You would expect much more from a such nice hotel but they serve you with subpar prison cafeteria food that costs $45 a person. A couple of positive things about this buffet was the location and short line.

Nb1_ZSmNXJpJirZUI1KfrA.text: Worst option. Don't waste your money.   We paid $50 for Sunday brunch and nothing special about this place.

lXxhdMfmJmubBzFHADrpDQ.text: The Buffet at the ARIA is not too shabby. I admit, compared to the numerous buffets in Las Vegas, the Buffet doesn't stand out, however, there are a definitely things that one will love about this buffet.  Now this review was during Saturday Brunch on Valentine's Day/President's Day weekend. The regular brunch price is $29.99 per person but they decided to increase the price to $35.99 due to the holiday weekend. This was sneaky on their part to raise prices just for the weekend, but I realized $5 wasn't a big deal in Vegas (especially when you have a $50 room credit). It's also convenient for those staying at the ARIA. The line was nonexistent at 9:30a but grew after we left. Still, the line was not ridiculously long.  The Buffet is modern as you would expect walking into the ARIA. There are windows all around so it's quite bright. The decor & furniture also help make the entire restaurant bright. The waiter service was just okay. My orange juice order was forgotten but plates were removed at a reasonable amount of time. I do love that they give you a large pitcher of coffee instead of having to flag the waiter down for a refill.  Overall, they have a good selection of foods. You can find Chinese, Indian, Korean, American, Mexican, Italian, French, and even Filipino food here. Their Asian foods were probably my favorite as they had Filipino longanisa (sausage) and their kimchi fried rice was delicious! They also have a legit tandoori oven to bake the naan. I really appreciate the gluten free options but I did find those dishes to be a bit bland. Most will appreciate that their snow crab legs are already cut in half. Although this saves the mess and time, I definitely feel more satisfied cracking open a crab leg myself. I also think that this dries out the crab meat. Speaking of dry, I found that a lot of their dishes were a bit dry possibly due to overcooking. Their desserts are quite good. I especially loved their revolving gelato machine. Other desserts one should try are their pecan pie and flan.  The Buffet at the ARIA met my expectation and was decent enough with the room credit. I do wish that some of their dishes were more flavorful and less dry. I don't see myself going out of my way to eat at this particular buffet though.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pre-cut snow crab legs, breakfast quiche, gluten-free pizza, and breakfast burrito!
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tandoori oven!
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Seafood goodness!

SPlQZpQ8iPJT9nYbDMb7LQ.text: Rude, rude and then some more rude. This wasn't our first visit to the buffet. We had been before. Their food is not amazing, but my husband is a fan of all you can eat crab legs. The selections are vast, foods from different cultures, but really they don't have much flavor. Overall their customer service while purchasing and ordering needs major improvements as well. What made my experience here even more horrible was that I tripped on something that was left on their ground. It was a food item. I fell, twisting my ankle and hurting my lower back. Some nice people sitting and having dinner tried helping me. A waiter gave me a chair and called the manager. The manager came and quickly but all she cared about was the area and called for the incident reporters to come and take pictures and she just asked me for my ID. I asked for an ice pack, and she said no. She just stood there and waited for the pictures to be taken. I was asked to write a report about what happened and they kept taking pictures. During this time, not one individual cared about what I was feeling and the pain I was in. Finally, I got upset and asked for ice again and it was given. We waited over an hour for the paramedics to come and access my situation. Luckly, nothing was broken. I had minor muscle strains. But, the way this was handled was extremely unprofessional and lacking major customer service. The manager did not even come by to see how I was doing. They gave me a refund on the meal, which I didn't even eat. All in all, I had a better opinion about Aria and this definitely changed my perspective of them. The was not the first but will definitely be the last time I go there...

4_8OvnieshOvWcVjkOBTtw.text: We enjoyed what I would say the best sea food sauted in garlic and butter we ever had.  From our server to the Chef the service was outstanding!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Attention seafood lovers!  By far the best crab legs, green muscles and shrimp sautéed in garlic and butter!  Thank you Aria Buffet!

uZ9CWGJEhq48ZvlLckM-uQ.text: This buffet has been vastly improved over its predecessor. The food selection is much more expansive, the pricing - fairly reasonable, and the layout, no longer a cluster#4k (although some sections still have retarded elevation changes). I recently tried the weekend brunch buffet for about $30 per person. They've decoupled the price of food and alcohol to make the buffet seem more economically priced compared to other high end buffets like Bacchanal over at Caesars. I'd still say that Caesar's buffet is still the better of the two, but Aria's at least will not leave you disappointed. There's some standout food items like the dim sum tray and the indian food selection. One sore spot for the buffet would be the lack of fruit choices for brunch- watermelon, cantaloupe, and honeydew shouldn't be the only fruit choices at a high end buffet.   If you have an Mlife players club card (Pearl and above) you can utilize the buffet line pass. Overall, a nice option, if you are trapped within City Center.

K1eKJFe5TAbRGPrcIH9wIw.text: Battle of the buffets! I came here Saturday evening around 6pm and paid for the gourmet dinner ($39.99 plus tax). So, oh so many options...from the split crab legs to the mini pizzas...freshly carved brisket to the freshly made pasta selections...let's just say the best thing about the buffet is that no matter how much food you think you have on a plate, there will be someone that will have more.  I mostly gravitated towards to the seafood but some of my other faves were on the dessert section...the mini triple chocolate cake pops and mocha flavored cupcakes were stand outs for me. They also had several varieties of pies and several flavors of ice cream/gelato available.  Drink service was decent too. Left the waitress a fiver since she was nice and pleasant.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fresh pasta dish cooked to order.
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. One of many plates.

1iKvOzRo4NpUmFYQkr_irQ.text: Aria's buffet was good.. but when compared with the other buffets that I've visited during my stay - my "good" stamp became an "OK" stamp haha.  Service needs improvement - drinks and check-in intervals took a very long time. I'll give this place 3-3.5/5 stars.   The highlight of the buffet was the scallop and angus beef dish (the sides, which includes the wasabi flavoured mashed potato was yummy too!). Several chefs were designated at separate stations of the buffet, you can request for them to cook you their specialty.   With the hotel facilities and rooms being so new and nice, I was expecting better food variety at the buffet.  Since I stayed here while I was in Vegas, it would've been nice if the buffet had better variety so we can escape the blazing heat outside haha.

4sL-whj3Nv07t5t6g-sGjA.text: We had lunch there today and after seeing the long lines I was expecting a good meal and selection. What I had was one of the worst buffet experiences ever. I am not a buffet expert but still has lot of buffets on cruise and other resorts which are free or included and they are lot better than this one. The selection was very bad almost 2 chicken dishes  in the whole buffet and just cold unpeeled shrimps if you like shrimps. In both selection and taste i would rate it poor. Was very disappointed.

PtmEKRbpswPZw_fJIbzj0g.text: Been in line for 45 minutes and the place is practically empty inside. I think there holding people until price goes up at 3;00. Dont come here unless you want to spent your day standing on line. This place SUCKS BALLs.

-hCSjx-TuNryliZB3ZSTJA.text: Maybe because I haven't had a buffet in awhile, maybe cuz it was a weekday and not weekend & maybe because we went at 1030a and had breakfast and lunch or maybe cuz it was free!  But I enjoyed it and don't understand all the negative reviews.  Yea it's not the best and not at caesars level but even if I had to pay for 21.99 that's not bad at all.  Plus the service was outstanding.  Go when it's not hectic right before lunch & enjoy the wide selection.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Flan, Carmel macchiato gelato, tiramisu, choco croissants
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Short rib, prime rib, duck
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Carnitas, Dungeness, stone, snow crabs, steamed clams

aBsgl5rl0XnpTCx-SGkwhg.text: for the price 45$ the selection was decent.  Had a lot of food I liked such as snow crab, stew lab, different cuts of beef, pork....... just many things like a vegas buffet would have  horchata was too sweet though..  price: good  taste: good  service: ok

C5KEaWV1lqFJ-e2UCDwwfQ.text: Hands down the best buffet in Vegas. Been here twice in 2017 and the quality has remained the same both twice. They have a wide spread of cuisines with a mix of different flavours unlike your other buffets in Vegas. The Nutella pancake is a must try option

Mr8Hv_x9iC2ZcfJPQnY4XA.text: After months of Facebook propaganda from Aria, we finally came here (of course with 2 comp buffets and thanks to the players card, front of the line pass). I was very excited to try the SEAFOOD they were promoting so much...only to be disappointed. There wasn't much there except some baked salmon, clam chowder and a sad looking ceviche. The meat carving station was pretty good but the placement is awful - people that were just trying to get some pancakes and other breakfast items were constantly crossing paths with us. The dim sum/Asian area was not good. Cute concept (that every other buffet is doing these days) but the food was dry and overcooked. The ice cream/gelato spinning freezer was a nice touch and the desserts were overall better than average.  Come here if you're on a budget because it's one of the cheaper "nice" buffets on the strip. But don't expect quality like Wynn, Bellagio or Caesars.

cSN2nqmKD55BK436Gb3IBg.text: My 1st time at this buffet and it won't be my last. The food was delicious as was the staff. Our waitress Ruby was wonderful. The food selection and quality was superb.

xobE1VeNezwgvrsC4Z4kWg.text: Buffet is possibly one of the worst over-priced buffets on strip. We ate here based on the reviews on Yelp. Granted there are many, some glowing and others not. Our own experience started out horribly and didn't improve much. We noticed two lines. Regular and an MLife member/sky suite line. It was about 5:30 pm and restaurant was half full. We were staying at the Aria and have M-Life membership, though the lowest level. We got into the MLife line and waited there probably about 20 minutes. Neither lines were really moving much, though the other line had gotten longer. Then an employees comes out and asks for our card and then rudely points us and several other guests to the other line. We should of made a fuss as we had waited so long, but as it was early dinner for us we just moved lines and waited approximately 20 more minutes.  We bought the unlimited cocktails but as we feel waiter staff should earn their tips, and not just be automatically given an arbitrary percentage, we chose to tip in cash versus charging our room. Not sure if this was a mistake or not but our waiter was definitely slow in bringing refills. We did though leave a nice tip as he did take plates away rather quickly. Many of the chefs along the various stations were pretty rude as well. With the exception of the make your own pasta station, he was quite pleasant and it was by far the best food at the buffet.  The food. Well, it was pretty awful. We maybe didnt do enough research ourselves. But we were let down. We saw many pictures of bone marrow and pork belly and lamb etc. no such dishes were served. The prime rib was not good, usually a buffet staple. The latin foods were quite bland. Asian felt like frozen dumplings that they just reheated. There were some dishes that just didnt seem to be replenished frequently. Especially the thai tea. There was really nothing spectacular there.  And many of the labels were either missing or simply wrong. This was simply unacceptable for such a high priced buffet. Please if you are on the fence, stay away from this place. It is definitely not worth the time nor money.

_MRSR9NlNkThB4wFvAj1CQ.text: This is my third time dining at the Aria buffet but unfortunately today's visit was a huge disappointment compared to what I had experienced in the past. I brought two guests and we all agreed that it was a poor value for what we paid.  First, there were no crab legs. This is what I look forward to the most and is what is shown in all of Aria's advertisements for the buffet. Next, the Asian food was dry or had a funky taste to it. The only food I enjoyed was fried chicken and mashed potatoes. Things also seem to have gone downhill on presentation. During my previous visits, everything was put together like a miniature work of art. Not so impressed this time.  For a $28.99 brunch we expect a lot more. Time for me to find another option for our next Vegas trip.

gq7vB-dceyd4p7VGbTzfyQ.text: My best friend and family was here visiting and on their last day here we came for dinner.  Haven't been here for a while so I wasn't expecting much.   My friends loves the variety but I thought it was a little lackluster since I've been to plenty of buffets here.  I was disappointed that there was no prime rib for dinner in the craving station.  They had ham, turkey, sausage and 2 cheap cuts of beef.  The beef that I got was a little dried out.  The sushi section was just 2 trays of laughable and dried out sushi rolls.  I guess to make up for it, they have a fresh poke station.  The Indian section was actually decent but the curries was a tad too spicy.  The Mexican and Italian stations had food that was all dried up and just looked like it should have been thrown away.  The desserts were more fresh and the gelato wheel is cool to look at but the flavors weren't all that appealing to me.  I did chose the watermelon lime vegan sorbet and it was very refreshing.   Oh and the crab legs were so skinny with little bits of meat, the clams and mussels were rubbery... just wasn't the best food.  Service was good, our server came around quite often to clear the table and make sure our drinks were full. So kudos to him!

x4KBrWtJ3geG0sVnhT24Vw.text: Wide variety of foods. Our waitress was excellent. The server at the oyster bar was very unfriendly and rude. I asked for oysters she said after 11 am. I came back after 11 and she says the same thing but added I TOLD YOU EARLIER AFTER 11. If your running behind schedule just admit it. Do be rude about it and know what time is it.

Cp2kAQg5gX9eBYw3-qTTLA.text: Another example of MGM corporate cutbacks. This used to be a great buffet with good options. Went there at 10 a.m. for brunch. Few breakfast options available but but lunch entres, which should have just been set out, look like it been sitting since yesterday. We got our money back and left without eating

tlWNnHFCWwpEFCXr4kJsKg.text: Great buffet that made up for the smaller size with quality of offerings.  Everything we tried was awesome.  It seems like since they offer less they were able to pay more careful attention to seasoning and doneness of their offerings.  The details matter sometimes, and they get it right here.   They offer an Indian cuisine section which was a nice change, and I am always a sucker for a pasta bar where you create your own pasta dish.  Their carved meats were seasoned perfectly.   Service was great as they brought out carafes of our chosen beverages so we never had to worry about asking for a refill.  The desserts were great also.  Creme brulee was awesome, and they even gave us a couple fresh ones with the crispy top!

_-Ujvb5vuqCdQ1PXvCXdBw.text: Let me kick off this brief by saying that I'm not a buffet guys, I don't seek buffets at all. However, after a recommendation I stepped into the Aria buffet and things changed quickly. This is by far the best buffet I have ever set eyes on. But wait, it gets better... The variety is one thing but the freshness really seals the deal for me. Highly recommended for breakfast or brunch.

6b1emCGaHE-J8QwbnVr4LA.text: My absolute favorite buffet for crab legs. They boil them fresh and hot and the legs aren't salty because of this. The rest of the buffet is nice as well, but my go to when I come here are the crab legs.

RLw_v8RUFXA1OmWPn1Byzw.text: If your staying at the Aria hotel and casino then I would say go for it and eat at the buffet. It's at least convenient. I wouldn't say that it's a great place to dine, as there are so many other great buffet's at the same price point on the Las Vegas strip. But as I said it's convenient for hotel guests.  I waited at the carving line for sometime before someone came to assist me and many items were gone and it seemed to take a while for someone to bring out more. I can say that the waiting staff is very friendly and attentive. To reiterate, I'm not saying not to eat here but don't make a trip to aria just for the buffet.

ResSuxHJqSgdC6My_3JUOw.text: ***Forgot to add- THEY HAVE COKE! Most of the strip is Pepsi. Wynn and Aria have Coke if you prefer Coke over Pepsi! - I actually like this brunch buffet better than the Wynn Brunch. This brunch buffet was a special one for Chinese New Year. It cost $5 more, but it was worth it! -Line was long but they move as fast as there are tables.  -No problems- nice buffet, but nothing so so great that is blew my socks off.  - The decor is nice. Modern and comfy to sit in. Wynn beats them on decor because of the flowers etc, but still very good to sit down and enjoy your food. - Service was fine! Waitress was polite and no judgement on how much you ate. She even told us to get dessert before we left! - They had Shu Mai and Pork Buns which made me really happy for the New Year Brunch, so I dont know if these are on the menu all the time for brunch. Stir fry flat white noodles which is hard to get on a buffet made me really happy! They had peeled and de-veined cold shrimp + Purple Rice Sushi!!!! These foods right here gave it 4 stars!  - Their Mac and & Cheese tickled my fancy. Some of the best I had. Pizza didnt taste that great, and the fried chicken was getting cold because it was sitting out for awhile. Didnt bother me or anything, but these 2 were my least favorite.

JM3VD4q0irVli3ViRMywaw.text: Excellent service! Delicious food with great variety! Best buffet I have ever been too and will definitely come back! HIGHLY recommend!

aZBEoSpWEorjaQBCHJMeEw.text: A most delightful dining experience!  Food from all parts of the world and all are cooked to absolute perfection!  If you haven't experienced a 5 star buffet in your lifetime you need to eat at Aria for the dining experience of a lifetime!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

8WdTgytl-7SlpuEpS4dmrg.text: Very clean buffet pleasant staff. The food was good the variety is less than offered at Caesar's buffet, still good. Oyster bar, pho bar, fruit salads. Wings. Dessert bar had one vegan option which was delish, strawberry tart gelato. Good price.

yKc01PXq3dPHBaWgNudcig.text: We arrived early one morning to stay at our hotel at Vdara and Aria is just literally next door.  From our hotel, you can either walk outside and use the sidewalk or to avoid the hot temperatures you can use the Tram (air conditioned every step of the way).  We were hungry and decided to stop by for brunch.  Personally, brunch gives you more bang for your buck.  The price can seem steep but they have a huge display of food from just about every country for lunch and made to order omelets and breakfast items in case you wanted both lunch and dinner.  We paid $28.99 per person.  Breakfast is $20.99 and Dinner is $38.99 during the week.  Prices increase during the weekend and during the holidays.  They also offer an unlimited drink option for $19.99 for 2 people.  This covers a selection of mixed drinks and sodas.  As far as service goes, the lines are a little long and if you plan to eat during the normal times then you can expect a wait so try to arrive early.  We waited in line for about 20-25 minutes.  Their service was great.  For each section you're assigned a server and ours was very attentive.  I tried just about every item from each country and all tasted pretty good.  I was a little disappointed about the crab legs (I'm extremely picky about my seafood) but they were bland and dry.  Great place for all you can eat with a wide selection of items.  I rated this place 4 stars only because of the over cooked seafood.  Service was pleasant, great establishment in a hip hotel.

0c6G7xNs3gRqWoHFcDBnIA.text: Food was disappointing for the cost of $40 pp. We tried everything and the only thing that stood out waf the crab legs when they were served hot. Prime rib was also ok. Service was excellent. Kitchen, do better!

1e1aUfUsKkiqBydO3GI0yQ.text: Fairly good buffet. Many Asian dishes from pho to saimin to sushi . Good variety of meats,  salads,  pizza, and desserts. Really liked the gelato  bar and never saw it displayed that way. Really neat.   The cost is fairly reasonable, $28.99.  Who can eat $50 worth? Not me 3.5 stars .

aUgR0uKphZ4OlXQdTJntuA.text: located in the Aria Resort   nice open spaced boofayy with lots of bay windows and natural lighting.  spacious dining area.  great food menu selection for what it is  at the same time, not the best you ever tasted but at 37.99 a head ...it is good!
