LfIlCoonQsv9e8wbNSkrcA.text: Absolutely horrible buffet! Giving one star only for the food because that at least was decent besides the dessert. Dessert was not good at all. The wait was 1.5 hours which would have been fine if they actually used all of the tables. We saw at least 12 tables open that weren't even being used. Managers just walked around not helping clean tables. Once we finally got to the front of the line to pay, Teresita had an attitude when ringing us up. She didn't listen to us when we told her we were using our myVEGAS rewards and then got rude when she messed up. She was also talking to a coworker and ignoring us the whole time. The bartender had an attitude problem and asked us for our receipt when we were only on our second drink, then tells us our waiter should be getting our drinks... they never asked us once if we wanted anything from the bar. Seems like they didn't even want us here. Waste of time and money. Would never recommend this place.

WBx_c7SbBFg8TZG1EC6fyA.text: There were a few good items, but was mostly forgettable. I'd rank Aria's offering in the Vegas buffet lineup somewhere in the middle.  Let's start with some good points.  As silly as it might sound, the horchata was my favorite thing! It's rich and creamy a perfect touch of cinnamon. No es authentico pero es muy sabroso!  The pan roast was delicous, with fat pieces of seafood. The prime rib was seasoned and cooked to perfection. All. You. Can. Eat. Prime. Rib.   Finally, their caramel cream puffs were a great way to cap off the glorious assault on my bowels.  Now, onto the not-so-good points...  Imagine if #saltbae had severe Alzheimer's and kept forgetting whether or not he seasoned his food. That's how I imagine the person who made the paella. It was so salty that when I put it in my mouth, it made me wince and spit it out.  Besides the prime rib, most of the other meats were very dry. The slice of beef on the steak salad was particularly dry; borrowing a Gordon Ramsay retort, it was like eating Gandhi's flip flop!  The "ethnic" foods were poorly done, with little regard to authenticity. Also, Stevie Wonder seems to be in charge of labeling the food. Many things were labeled totally wrong. For example, I saw carne asada and tortillas labeled as Indian curry. Wrong labeling might not be a big deal to most people, but some rely on them due to dietary restrictions.  Service was good and very attentive. Unfortunately, considering that there are numerous better buffets along the strip, I can't recommend Aria's.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

WHAbhimj71SziZfs2iiJdg.text: For my birthday me and my wife were so excited to go to Aria Buffet. We don't make a habit of spending nearly $100 on buffets, but we felt this was an special occasion. It was absolutely terrible! We went on Friday evening 6/28/2019. Because we were so excited, upon our arrival I happily greeted the person at the cashiers counter with a very happy hello. She didn't smile, she didn't reply, and she didn't say hello or a how are you? Instead.....and almost instantly she just gave of the price for out meal. I even said to her, "not even a hello?" Still nothing. We paid and got seated. We sat at our table for nearly 25 minutes without a single word or drink orders being taken. I even asked the person who sat us, and probably sat a dozen more tables around us if she could get our server. She replied by saying she is on her way. I asked another server for service, she told us she wasn't our server....and we continued to wait. Tired of waiting and hungry, we went to get our food. We returned and still no drinks and no server. It wasn't until towards the end of our first round that finally someone showed up. By this time the experience was completely destroyed. For some reason the food experience was also not the best, as the pictures we saw online about the buffet did not match what they were serving. The sushi offered was terrible, or nearly nonexistent. I do not recommend anyone spend this kind of money for a buffet, not to mention the cost of parking, etc. please do not waste your time.

ryrgu8r_uuWTwI-4TCpt1Q.text: $74.06 for 2 brunch on Monday... the serve lady was nice but the food was is just on average... The Indian food is good, the Chinese food is on average, and the grilled short ribs is good. But they don't even have raw oysters and fresh crab legs (the kind they have is not fresh at all). From the attached picture you could see there were remaining food from last customer(s) and I could even tell what she/he/they had... Anyway, I'm not going to say this place is terrible, but I wouldn't recommend this place to my friends.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

MUignED6WVjMiKV6IuqDwQ.text: I love this buffet. Breakfast is good and homemade ice cream is fabulous. The seafood come out around 11:30.  I didn't feel like they were trying to push us out quickly like I did at the Wynn.

MDuxxTVwyOwItt3SXR8UCw.text: Like I've said many times, the difference between five stars or less is customer service. Building a spectacular eating establishment with unique architecture and good food is much easier than providing great customer service.  My ARIA brunch buffet started rough. The cashier and hostess were not friendly. They seemed put off that I would even ask questions.  The buffet has almost endless choices of Asian, Italian, American, Mexican and even German cuisine. (Sausages)  I tried some new selections. Taro Buns. Not a fan but I'm sure some diners love them. The sauce was good.  Try their smoothies and fresh fruit. Healthy and delicious.  In the end, I had a decent brunch. But, the customer service was well below average for what everyone deserves and pays for in a five-star resort hotel.  I probably won't come back because there are so many excellent choices in Las Vegas.  Recommendation: go somewhere else.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

hc8Zvt9KCnAovC4uAWpREw.text: Location - Aria Hotel  Service - can be improved. It's a typical resort in the LV strip.   Price - $$$  Food - Stone crabs do justice for the price and if you can eat as much as you can, do so. Don't forget the made to order stations

3qnA9p93CLhjImbcMrsyoA.text: I have eaten at many buffets in Vegas, and hardly ever feel that I get my money's worth when dining at them. I prefer quality of food over quantity, and you usually don't get that at a buffet.  Let's start with the positives of my experience at Aria's Buffet. The service was friendly and finished plates were immediately cleaned off the table to make room for more. The stations of food were constantly refilled and kept clean as well. I came here for the Sunday brunch, and I really like that they limit the total number of people dining at a time. There is always a long line at any omelet station, however that was not the case here. Although the dining area looked full, there were never more than a few people at each section to get food.  Sadly, my group had so much consistent food waste that you could probably feed a homeless camp. Most of the food looked quite appetizing but it was barely edible/enjoyable.   I was really excited to see that pho was an option. You fill your bowl with glass noodles, meat and the steaming hot soup base. However, because the meat and noodles were apparently frozen cold to begin with, the soup instantly turned cold. Nothing is worse than cold pho.  The fried chicken, well all of the chicken dishes that I tried were very dry and had no seasoning on it. The crab legs were oddly overly salted and did not taste fresh at all. The pizza and omelet were probably my favorite dishes from the buffet, but why would I need to go to a buffet for items such as those?  I love staying at ARIA when I'm in Vegas, but I won't be back to this buffet any time soon.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

2N2Xt2FbLO7zM-81yx0yqA.text: The service was slow especially with clearing our plates off the table.   Not a single check for any refills.   Long wait to be escorted for our tables. Understandable since we went during peak hours.   Crab legs were very salty. Most of their foods are salty or plain. Oyster Rockefeller was cold and less meaty. Shrimp in fried rice was over cooked. Fruit and salad station were abysmal.   Not much worth of the price.

C9Svj7GK1IDApf3IWYOTrg.text: We stayed at a nearby hotel and was looking for buffet options around the general vicinity. Never been to the Aria's buffet, so decided to give this place a try. On this trip, my in-law wanted to come, and we had no real option of leaving the kids at home, so we took them. Aria's buffet is $43 as of this date, and the plus was that kids under 12 eat free. Super huge bonus because my girls don't eat much.  I was surprised at the mediocre ratings of this buffet. I know Bacchanal is top dog, but I think people have to get that out of their heads that there are other great options as well. Unlike some buffets that are on the casino level, this one is on the mezzanine, which is probably the reason the seating area is massive. We came on a Sunday night at around 7:30pm and was immediately seated.  Looking around, I could already see the myriad of foods ready to be eaten. The things that stood out for me? Prime rib, lamb chops, mango sausage, poke bowl, and pho. And of course, the crab feast.  The prime rib and lamb were cooked nicely, if anything, they could have been a touch rarer and it would have been perfect. Poke bowl was fresh and they had this salmon dish that was awesome. And for those so inclined...bone marrow. Not me.  The highlight was dessert! A rotating selection of really good gelato. I recommend the mango coconut - holy crap, it was one of the best tasting ice creams I've ever had. Another must try was their ube cookie. My wife thought about wrapping up a few "to go" but the fat gods might punish us later said the husband.  Service was great - plates cleared quickly and drinks refilled. Even coffee was offered, which is a rarity for buffets.  With their pricing and selection, I think this place is a great Vegas buffet value.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Coconut mango!

ULmI_pFKD0WAah5jokmCVA.text: So for a buffet at the Aria, It's ok. The food is plentiful and constantly filled to the brim. Seafood can be a bit picked over but I doubt it's any better anywhere else, but I was thrilled to see crab legs and dip.   I recommend the buffet, but honestly, splurge and hit some of the other restaurants instead. Save this for a lazy day.

D4OHuoNMql_lJlyB4tL1-A.text: Such a great buffet.  My wife and i have been to them all and this is consistently the best all round.  Always delicious.  Always fresh.  Make sure you go for brunch and you'll enjoy giant carrot cake and red velvet pancake  Years later this is still the best on the strip.  Special thanks today for Chef CRAIG HERBER who always make it happen.  Last year he was able to make us  our favorite carrot cake pancakes after the were closed and this year he made another item happen was wasn't available on today's menu.  That's the service that's makes this place a so special.  Thank you CRAIG and ARIA for always making us feel special.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

M_a9EyMUtt_eVxWvNg2_ng.text: SALTY! SKINNY! CRAPPY CRAB "LEGS"  Don't come here. We spit out our food a few times because it was sooooo SALTY! I'm not talking about a few items but EVERYTHING was ruined by too much salt.   Crab legs TINY ANOREXIC crab. So disappointed.

YqZq2378slbsvYYUILayVA.text: The Buffet at Aria $43.99/person (Gourmet Dinner) We were pleasantly surprised when we got the local discount of $30/person!!!  (Kids 0-12 FREE~!!!)  Good amount of seafood   Dungeness crab legs, Jumbo crab claws, Snow crab legs, King crab legs  You can order 2 lobsters for an additional $25  I was surprised by the amount different types of meats. Some includes brisket, pork belly, etc...  Items that stood out: Dimsum, Ramen, poke bowl station & chocolate dipped strawberries!!!  For $30/person (local discount) it was GREAT quality for the price. The kids ate so much too  $60 for our family of 4 for AYCE is such a great deal   Breakfast Monday - Friday 7:00 AM - 9:00 AM  Adults $24.99* Children (5-12) $12.50  Brunch Monday - Friday 9:00 AM - 3:00 PM Adults $28.99* Children (5-12) $14.50  Dinner Monday - Thursday 3:00 PM - 10:00 PM Adults $38.99* Children (5-12) Free**  Brunch Saturday & Sunday 7:00 AM - 3:00 PM  Adults $33.99* Children (5-12) $16.50  Gourmet Dinner (what we ate) Friday - Sunday 3:00 PM - 10:00 PM Adults $43.99* Children (5-12) Free** *Prices are subject to change during holidays.  **Children (5-12) Up to 2 children per 1 paying adult are free for dinner. 5 or more children - $15 per child.  #dinner at @ariabuffetlv inside @arialv   #forkyeah #vegaseats #lveats #vegasfood #lasvegaseats #vegasdining #vegasbuffet #ayce   #thebuffetaria #ariabuffet #arialasvegas #lasvegas #vegas #vegaslocal #ilovevegas #vegaslife #thestrip #vegasnightlife #LML #friYAY

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

QO7WJ4-1swffoZkPdLX-LA.text: Buffet: "Salty".   Seems like everything has salt on it. Not kidding.  I had to drink so much water afterwards because of the high salt content on practically everything.  Salty steamed crab legs that were steamed in small portions, so if 3 adults fill up their plates, you gotta wait till the next patch is steamed up...,so they can add more SALT in the steaming process is my guess.  Crab claws had no salt in them, which is better for me  Very salty and fatty beef and pork meats... it would of been nice if the meat stations were labeled.   Mini pho bowls where the broth was saltier than needed  Spicy Indian food, even for me.  Overall, this was one of the "saltiest" buffet I've eaten at.   Waitress was 5 STARS and Awesome!  Wait time in the line to get in was an hour. Seem like an eternity with everyone watching the hotel guests go in first. Was this buffet worth the 1 hr wait time? NO. Only worth it if you have BOGO.   Waitstaff working the crab seafood stations were just rude and tolerable. Every question was answered "rudely" with a condescending "tone". Not one time, but every time with a "sneer laughter".  Unacceptable. Don't like your job?? Look elsewhere if you don't like dealing with the public in a professional manner.  Overall experience is it's barely a 3 STARS buffet despite everything

51rBBQ7DtwnOcWT-Eddf4Q.text: WOW. I don't think that I've ever been so disappointed at a buffet before. Like, how can you hate an opportunity to stuff your face, so this is a new one for me.  Let me use Marie Kondo's 'KonMari' method to describe the food here. Grab a dish, eat it, and if it sparks joy, then eat it again. If it doesn't spark job, thank it and move on. Literally nothing sparked joy, I didn't reach for seconds with any dish. The only two things that made me want to reach for seconds were the Truffled Potatoes Gratin, the Kielbasa, and the Chicken Jalapeno Mango Sausage.  After I downed my disappointing meal, I joked around with my friend that I could see Herringbone across the way. Just there, mocking me, because I know 100% that I could've had such a better meal for the same price.  Aria, get it together with your buffet. You are a prized hotel on the Strip, but this buffet just made your reputation look sad. Bring in some creativity and amp up your food presentations, then it might spark joy for all future diners.

vdAk4Q8kHW4q8bx9QsB3Bg.text: The ultimate foodgasm awaits you at The Buffet. I visit this restaurant annually on a work trip and it's always the highlight of my entire Vegas experience. I cannot tolerate dairy and gluten, and this year  Chef Jose Mendoza whipped me up a special batch of the most delicious French toast I've ever had. He went the extra mile to ensure that I had a great dining experience despite my issues. I am so grateful, and I cannot wait to return!

KJUH7IUJlGhu926EYX0NYA.text: I came here for breakfast on a Friday in February to use myVEGAS coupon  free buffet. Since it was Chinese New Year week, the prices were considered holiday price. We got there at 8ish am and no line to pay. The place wasn't crowded yet. The price $40 is not worth it for breakfast. The Asian had thick congee and bbq steam bao with 2 other soups, beef chow fun. The omelette line was short and they make a delicious omelette. The margherita slices of pizza was my favorite. In the seafood area was shrimp and crawfish.  No crab legs before 9 am. I didn't get any Indian food or plate of fruit. The server gave us a pitcher of coke and came by often to pick up the plates. I feel the quality went downhill and service was okay.

eFSV7e2vAIBY6A_FCrEiEw.text: Aria is one of Las Vegas' top buffets. Service is excellent and they have a wide selection of food. Notable is the Indian tandoor oven for food like Chicken Tandoori and that they also have all-you-can-eat crab legs at dinner. I prefer the crab over at Wynn, though, because it is split and easier to eat. At Aria, that isn't the case. Also, the shrimp at Aria has full shell and has to be peeled more. Desert selection at the buffet was pretty good as was the spread of East Asian food.

EaGG6ZJlIMzFDZAOJrXs4Q.text: Came here on the Saturday of St. Patrick's day weekend & was expecting a huge line but thank god there was no wait, because we were starving! This was my first time coming to an infamous Vegas buffet and I'm glad I experienced it. The food was plenty and wasn't too bad.           Interestingly enough, the chefs mentioned that some of the food was halal, which was a major plus for me because that satisfied my moms dietary restriction. I'm not 100% certain on the validity of that statement but it would be appealing to a lot of people if it were True!

MNci7YXJaqZyOUBW0xgWEA.text: I had a great time with my high school friends and my feelings about the place is mixed. I like the choices of cuisine - Asian, Mediterranean, seafood and more. And the dessert section my favorite . Had one of the best gluten-free cake, shuffles, pudding . We ended out meal with green tea and coffee.   But then, it's not a great place for vegetarian, dishes are not marked & people around not too helpful or they're too busy to assist.

Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

vJVzhH92fblSXe4RKXaPiQ.text: The service is not the best for the amount you spend. We were done with our food by the time we were able to get a refill. The funny this is that your kind of forced to tip before you are seated hmm. By the way, not crab legs as advertised.

eiyZHnOTg4nTpXEnjhnejA.text: We really wanted to try a buffet in Vegas and this was one of the highly ranked ones.  I had pretty high expectations coming in.  They had a lot of options, but none that really wowed me. A lot of the food options was already pre-portioned in small servings, which seems nice, but unfortunately, a lot of the food looked dry and appetizing from sitting out.  The crab legs tasted like it was boiled and was kind of mushy. I liked the dessert options and was a fan of the gelato flavors. I thought they were be a long line, but we went during an off hour, so it took no time at all to get in. We had a buy 1, get 1 free, so I thought it was worth it for the price we paid, but I wouldn't pay full price for the buffet.

chfyZCMoPAYnOZnQbANKHw.text: This place has a vast variety of options and all of the food is fresh. Just about everything I had was delicious and cooked to perfection. They have just about everything you could ask for. Some of the highlights.. poke bowl station, lots of seafood options, made to order pasta, great salad bar and all types of delicious meats to choose from.   The only reason for 4 stars is that all the "chefs" or people working at the food stations refused to smile or be friendly. I smiled and was polite and even tried to compliment a few and all I got in return was a straight face and stare. The guy working the meat station even offended me a little and made me feel like an idiot for asking what one of the meats were.   I would come back, but it would be nice to see some smiling faces from the staff!

f3_MMZcKm74kTeUpaBkqbw.text: My fiance and I splurged on our last trip and got a skysuite at Aria, which meant we got to skip the regular lines (although these never looked that bad). I heard the buffet was recently renovated, and it looked really nice. The atmosphere was really bright and airy. The servers are very nice and prompt and cleared our dishes very quickly. When we got the bottomless drink option, the waiter was very good about asking if we wanted refills whenever the glass got low.  We came here three times for lunch during our weekend stay, and each time was great. Compared to other places we've eaten (Wynn Buffet, Spice, and Bacchanal), the crab legs were the best by far. They're always very fresh, constantly replenished and not once did they event run low! There are also plenty of mussels, clams, etc. The only thing I didn't like about the selection was the lack of good sushi (there were only 3 or 4 different kinds, and none looked very appetizing) and fruit variety (melons + pineapple). Overall I really loved it here! The service and food was the best I've had at Vegas so far.

_-IG70D6n8UAlhERC3LRpQ.text: *Food Allergy Review*  They had a great selection of Gluten Free items.  All GF items had an asterisk next to the name.  Pizza, desserts, Italian, India, Latin, etc. all had GF options, and they were all very tasty.  It's good to know that there's a reliable place I can go to when I'm in Vegas.

H1bT2gPDq4g8UyATmTnsaA.text: The thing to do in Vegas (besides gambling/drinking/clubbing) is eating buffets! My friends have been telling me that this place is one of the better buffets in Vegas so I knew I had to give this place a try.  I came here for Brunch on a Saturday..when I got here there was a line, but it moved pretty fast and we didn't wait too long even though there was a group of 12 of us. The price was about $32 and plus gratuity was about $41 bucks for each of us. Some of my friends chose to get bottomless champagne /mamosas....their total came out to be about $50.   The buffet like everything else about Aria is very pretty. I noticed the dessert area first and it was sooo pretty. Probably the prettiest dessert bar that I have seen in any Vegas buffet. The selection of the food was good...not too big not too small. Its all about quality over quantity here. Everything that I got was good for the most part...this is probably one of the better buffets that I have been to in Vegas. My favorite part here is the dessert of course. So good and yummy.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. shrimp cocktail
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. cream puff
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. whoopie pie

gEhkNR1Q76AvGx3WUKcgGg.text: This Buffett was surprisingly very delicious!  Bottomless mimosas for Memorial Day started things off on a high note. It is very upscale and has quite a variety for being a Buffett.   I had crab legs, which were steamed, seasoned well and already open for you. I also had smoked salmon, garlic chicken and some potatoes.  They had breakfast items, Chinese food, all kinds of meat and more. The decor is very nice & upscale, I would go back!

zpX5nzRsz26GTGQfr3_YVg.text: Forced us to pay gratuity up front, then pushed an "bottomless alchohol" package for $13 additional. After I finished my food, I still hadn't received my first "bottomless" drink... everyone else at least got soda, I was sucking on ice cubes from a glass of water...  They refunded the 13 dollars for the drinks... I want the gratuity back too.

6L4lJCWdtHn2KHO9ZDigig.text: I came here with very high expectations since it is in fact, Aria. However, overall the experience was disappointing.  The Good: - The look of the room is fantastic. Very modern and extremely clean. - The service, although slow at first, was great once it picked up. Clean plates were taken and drinks were always refilled (sometimes with a little extra umph in there :) - Very spacious, no trouble walking around in between stations.  The Bad: - The selection of great food is minimal compared to other buffets - Only very few items actually  stick out, and out of those, only 1 or 2 are actually good  There's really not much else to say about this buffet. I honestly wasn't overly impressed compared to other buffets.

EvN71fvzR_RP_49bN5QvXw.text: It's a Vegas Casino Buffet, everyone comes to one expecting a lot. I wouldn't come here again to eat because:  1) There are smaller casinos in Minnesota that offer a larger variety of food 2) The sushi was not good; the rice was hard and the fish not fresh 3) the waitresses are unattentive, rude, and forgetful 4) the prime rib wasn't as rare as it should be and on the dry side 5) for the same price you could walk over to The Buffet at The Bellagio for a wider variety, better service, and more quality food.  The only things I did like about this buffet were the choice of deli meats, and the quality of their flan. But those two alone would not get me to step foot in this buffet again.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The Buffet at Aria: chocolate cake w/coffee ice cream
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The Buffet at Aria: flan
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The Buffet at Aria: assorted deli meats and cheeses w/naan bread and mozzarella salad

_ZXVNADeeTL3p3ONcaSVKA.text: There were 3 of us for Sunday dinner. There wasn't a long line, it took a few minutes for someone to come take our drink orders, but after that service was fast, pleasant and good. One of us couldn't eat Gluten, so the blackboard menus at each station showing the gluten free items was a nice touch. However, she said there weren't any special gluten-free dishes, all were what you could eat almost anywhere - except the pizza.   For my other friend and myself the sushi and fish dishes were good, but not outstanding. I thought the Chicken Parmesan to be very good, we both loved the baby beets and lamb with mint jelly.  Desserts were ok, the pistachio ice cream was a hit with all three of us. With tax and tip the cost for all 3 was just shy of $150. We decided that was a bit steep - perhaps brunch or a weekday dinner if we were in the neighborhood. For this cost I'd rather be at the Wynn.  Bottom line: just acceptable

QlwZonw_rcZ164vTgwbeZw.text: I am a resident of Las Vegas and came to The Buffet at Aria! We specifically came here because they said they have an amazing seafood selection and for locals the cost is $30/person, however, when we arrived they said because it is Labor Day weekend, there is no deal and we paid $45. We have been to many buffets in Vegas and I would say this is one of the worst. The so called "King crab" is not that at all. Service is mediocre, very unorganized! I make better food blindfolded! I don't recommend this at all, all around is was terrible food!

tNI_0BQZkaOX92u3B60oqQ.text: I am surprised that this buffet is not rated better because I really liked it. The seafood was outstanding: shrimp and mussels so fresh you can't stop eating. The crab legs were less impressive, but good enough for a buffet. The bottomless drinks were also pretty fantastic - I've had sangria and a mimosa, my husband had a bloody mary and a beer - and both food and drinks were relatively inexpensive. Last but not least: the dessert selection was fabulous. I still relive the caramel flan...  The biggest problem with this buffet was that it took some time to get in: long line at the door even though it appeared half empty inside.  Other than that, highly recommend: it's worth your time and money.

JHoE00gB-kkW46b-iuJ-rg.text: Always friendly staff and clean environment,however; the food slightly questionable. Sadly, I didn't try the fish market but, I tried everything else. Fresh ingredients over at the salad bar. Some of the food was lacking but, there were some tasty food within the mix. Pace yourself there's definitely a large variety of food.

qP0ubAC4tupW9b8MZBsqqg.text: Excellent!! Aria Buffet is one of the best in Vegas =) (Except the chinese section)

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

xUVB9AQWYZm55yeMGyE4Uw.text: For $35.99/ person I would expect a lot more. Especially on a holiday. Yes they had sea food. But nowadays all the buffets have sea food for a lower price. I had high expectations of this place. And it was yummy. But I probably won't go back not recommend this biggest to someone who is visiting Las Vegas. Spend a little more and go to Caesars Palace buffet.

y9pOiEHAPUS_6mykZRZkiQ.text: We were here last Friday night for the Gourmet dinner. Everything was really delicious!!!! The night before we went to Bellagio buffet which was okay but the line was over an hour. Aria had no line wait which is surprising considering it was way better than Bellagio. The buffet had unlimited lamb chops and delicious Macaron cookies which is worth the money right there. In addition, it had make your own pasta station and delicious prime rib/ cowboy steak. The crab legs were also a lot better than Bellagio.

YC412La3bUget51pNzAYDQ.text: $25 buffet for dinner with prime rib and king crab legs not bad!   The prime rib, crab legs, and prawns were pretty much all I ate..Everything else is just mediocre. The "asian bar" is not well executed as EVERYTHING there tasted like soysauce. lol   I'd be back for the fresh seafood: king & snow crab, prawns, and the prime rib...nom nom!!!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pumpkin Cheeseake, Creme Brulee
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Apple cobbler, Pumpkin &amp; butterfinger gelato, Carrot Cake
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Prime Rib, Snow Crab, King Crab and prawns

vIs0lz0xD-skw8CXqsN_ew.text: Casino buffets along the Las Vegas strip set the bar as only Sin City can with a plethora of items for the palate. The Buffet at the Aria delivers on this element with random abandon, but the total tragedy of taste and inconsistency that is delivered with some items prepared almost perfectly and some contemptuously under-prepared is truly heart breaking for any buffet loving foodie.  The buffet area and dining areas are kept impeccably clean, the staff were friendly, and swept in when necessary without becoming a nuisance. The dining area hosts numerous seating arrangements with different views and a fantastic modern design. It's very unfortunate that the price to value is underwhelming against them with respect to the amount of preparation variance in the buffet items.

XF0CkV8-n6z9zGNh4Pg_8Q.text: Food here is decent but for the price you pay it is not worth it at all. If I'm gonna pay the same price range as Bellagio or Wicked Spoon, then I want the same amount of options. Thank God I had a $100 food voucher and didn't have to pay for this place,

IWlQFl-Hi71oZWo7YS78NQ.text: We went there twice, dinner and brunch.  I enjoyed stuffing my face full of crab legs.  I remember the prime rib being another highlight.  The sushi variety was sub-par so I didn't bother with it.  I don't have a crazy sweet tooth, but the group I was with seemed to really enjoy the dessert selection.  I did try the flan and pistachio gelato which I liked.  Bottomline, I ate so much crab it was worth it.  One recommendation for brunch is to wait 2 or 3 hours after they open to avoid the leftovers from the previous night.  Overall, the food quality was good.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Brunch...a little bit of everything.

78CWIz--jzbyA5kE22V5lg.text: The Aria Buffet is excellent for those that want the taste of a fine restaurant but also want the ease and assortment that you will find in a buffet. Their stations are manned with an exceptional number of employees and are always in stock with their items. This is your chance to pair foods from their tastes. For example I had the Spanish rice with cilantro with my salmon from the seafood section. They also had 3 different types of crab legs! I don't usually eat pie but when I saw their apple pie next to their assortment of ice cream flavors, I just had to have dessert.   The only thing is it was a little in the pricey end as it came out to $80 for two but you're at the Aria what did you expect?

zK0wSDEONJxSHSWIkw5IAw.text: One of my new favorite buffets! Great selection of food, loved the salad bar with (seperately) chopped egg whites & yolk, really good dessert bar, and the prime rib melts in your mouth!

jccc2yNq_IM1f9hU9F3FEA.text: It's been a while since I went to the buffet at Aria, and I did not disappointed. I recently went to some of the others and thought the food at Aria was way better than the other places in Vegas.   The buffets at Caesars and Bellagio have been disappointing recently, so I'm glad the buffet at Aria was worth my money.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

ZfASYGNkL-Xwr7Tu-fAg1w.text: My second visit here n  this buffet is getting better. They do  small plates , now, which is great. This allows you to flavor more of the buffet .  great value for money                  When in Vegas you go to do Aria Buffet

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

uOGqau92RKJZEymiGQ5byw.text: Best buffet at the MGM properties period. The prime rib, the sausages and made to order pasta is worth the price of admission alone then there are the desserts!!!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. My 2 favorite desserts, salted caramel pretzel topped blondes and a hazelnut crunch bar topped with gold speckled chocolate &amp; mousse!

hFyBJ6qlfhL6XEFaVj63XA.text: I went for lunch on 10/9/2017 around 2 PM. The food was good, if not great, and the desserts are good. But what ruined the experience for me was the service.   Specifically, the cashier who checked in me and rang up my sale was really horribly rude to me. I was lined up to redeem my myvegas reward for myself, however I had another person at my party who was in a different line. As soon as I walked up she barked "How many people in your party" in a bored yet aggravated tone, as if I was inconveniencing her. Wanting to sit with my friend but not wanting to be charged for two buffets, I started to explain: "Well, I am redeeming a reward from Myvegas but..."  That's when she cut me off by saying "NO, I asked you HOW MANY PEOPLE IN YOUR PARTY?".  I was speechless for a second then decided to reply lest I incur more of her wrath. "OK, I have two". She quickly rang me up for two buffets although I could see my friend across the other line already paying for hers. Then she asked "How are you paying?" like some angry robot. I replied that i am using a Myvegas reward - this is True. She then asked me "NO, how are you paying for the difference"? "Well, I am NOT paying for the difference. There are two people in my party but I am paying for myself only. I was trying to tell you." She just looked at me like I had bananas coming out of my ears, then said " You know you can redeem both rewards here" and proceeded to ring up the meal silently (but still with attitude) handing me the folio with my receipt.  That's nice lady but that's not what's happening. If you didn't cut me off mid-sentence,  you'd know what's going on.   So, this unfortunately ruined the lunch for me. It's very disappointing considering the reputation of Aria as a 4-star resort. This was my 3rd time coming here and I had always had good experiences and good meals. My server was great and attentive and everything she should be. But due to this poor service with this cashier, I don't think I would be back.

Jyc25nZRSkDCZVzza3NCnQ.text: I really really wanted to like this place. It's a cute little buffet with 6 or 7 stations to choose from. The food is okay. Not as tasty as you would expect from an expensive buffet on the strip. Also the service is lacking. We came in for Friday night dinner. Everyone we encountered was super nice, however  the problem was getting someone to attend to us. We were on our second plate of food before someone came to our table to ask what we'd like to drink. After that, we had a pile of dirty dishes on the side of our table. And didn't get a refill on my drink until halfway done with dessert. I completely understand if the situation was because of being under staffed, but with the food and service leaving something to be desired, I don't see us returning here.

7a25TUfQkXr6D5KZ6ACrmw.text: I booked Aria for my vacation and the day before 4th of July I decided to go to "the Buffet" simply because I love buffets, I have dining credits, and it has great rating online. I don't know what happen to the restaurant that day, but the food experience is a total disappointment. Although there are big variety of food to choose, but the food quality is very low. Frist, everything tastes so salty, except for the sweets or deserts. If you have high blood pressure, heart problem or kidney problem, please don't eat there. There a tons of sodium just in one piece of meat or vegetable. In additional, there are sands on the seafood occasially. My partner and I both experienced dizziness or headaches after eating the buffet. I almost feel like I am getting a stroke or infection from the raw seafood. The dinner costs $38 per person and it is a lot worse than an average Buffett in my city in California only cost $15. Speehless, sad, and disappointed. Great waiter, employees and customer service tho, that's why 2 stars instead of 0.

GHfkzMkKe-kS7Fysl_BL6g.text: I thought it was good just a tad over priced. I mean I'm not a seafood person so I see why they charge so much on a Thursday night. They have a variety of food including tons of seafood and two carving stations with an array of meats and grilled veggies (my favorite). They also have some pre portioned sized plates which is great for those that want a sample sized amount.   I would give it 4 stars if it wasn't so over priced.

Q-cnhsiCpUguYjU2KYOo1A.text: Thursday night dinner: $34.99. If you want lobster, $10 more. If you want bottomless alcohol, $12.99 more. Arriving at 7pm, wait in line for at least an hour. Sighs~  Food quality is average. Choices are okay. Didn't really WOW me with the price they charge.  Food display is kind of spread out so no long wait line to get the food. However, putting the food inside the heavy pot... not too convenience. First, the lid is way too heavy & hot. Also, you have to put down your plate first then open the lid to get the food?? With the lid on, you can't really see what's inside. Not an ideal way to display the food.   Service is bad. Each server is taking care too many tables. Hard to get the server to refill the drink.   Not too impressed with the dinning experience.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

1m4cplu2CT5J3lN7AUGwbw.text: Seafood isn't as fresh as Caesar's buffet, and overall taste of everything is bad. Bacon is oily and too crispy, pizza looks horrible, Vietnamese pho is so strong in MSG it burns the throat, hostesses are so useless and ignored us the whole time for changing tables because we had a handicap person sitting too far. The only people working hard are the waitresses / bus boys.

yAIQ0vyz5BGpB4iFxym7Ug.text: This will be my recommendation for dinner buffet if you in the middle of LV strip. It's way better than Bellagio dinner for sure. Not so much selection if you try to compare to the Bacchanal at Caesars but it's a reasonable food options for a reasonable price.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

nq-bS33hRWf_Umb4JAk0cQ.text: Food was not spectacular but wait time was not bad  Highlights: 1. King crab with lemon and salt 2. Tomato bisque (better than broccoli cheddar) 3. Caramel Macchiato gelato and vanilla gelato 4. Orange Chicken  5. Red velvet pancakes

bwnqB_o998Dk4cecgucObQ.text: Tour the world in one buffet. Not cheap but all items were well prepared and not typical buffet food troughs. The thick crab claws were nearly impossible to dissect and looking around to other tables a sad waste of our ocean life. All in all well done!

DqcgTjPhcQ-aUbekg6Zolg.text: WOW! Let me just say I am impressed! I don't really eat at buffets much, but I feel compelled to give this one a lot of credit. Everything from the staff to the food was amazing from beginning to end. The staff was friendly and was always providing top notch service. We never had a dirty dish on our table and always had our beverages filled to the top. I also appreciated  how Chef Kreg asked how we were enjoying our meal. The little things like that help enhance your experience and make you feel valued.  The food was absolutely phenomenal! I almost wish I didn't get full so fast so I could try more. My favorite part was the endless amount of fresh seafood. They never ran low on anything and every item I picked seemed like it was in the ocean the day before. I also would like to rave about the lamb chops. I am picky with lamb, so it says a lot if they got my approval with that one. It was cooked to perfection along with their other meat choices. I had the prime rib as well and wish I had saved room for the cowboy steak. I didn't have it, but my friend said it was her favorite.  My favorite dessert was the pistachio gelato. I have this odd obsession with pistachios so I when I saw it in the gelato form, I had to indulge. It was the perfect way to end my perfect dinner.  The best way I could describe this experience is it truly is fine dining cuisine in a buffet setting. Kudos to Chef Kreg, our server Kelly, and the rest of the staff. Keep up the good work, guys! I'll be back soon!

dNmGVPi4XVQXhjZqTQvsSg.text: Our second time there and the food is great.  Lots of options from meats, to seafood.  The selection is very good for a buffet at this price range.  The service was very good as well.  The dim sum was just ok though.  It's very international, so if you feel like an American omlet made to order, go for it, if you feel like India food, it's there.  We would go again.

Q35gnZxVmaKA_FxCpiY8ZQ.text: This was probably a better choice over wicked spoon. This buffet offered a lot more choices of food and they actually tasted surprisingly good. I gave four stars because they can improve on the asian food section with some nice waiters/waitresses (not someone who has no shame in showing the fact that he/she has been over worked, thus too tired to be friendly). Otherwise, my fanily and I enjoyed this buffet and would recommend this one to friends and family.

rMf7FbLYzJLnfKHf06xNJg.text: We did the all day pass which is a good value.  It's $60/person and you can eat from 7am to 10pm - so we planned this to be a day where we stayed close to the hotel. (We stayed at the Aria)  What's not that great: the crab legs and dessert bar - both just average.  What is great is the variety and selection.  It seems like they have everything.   Great asian selections, some new things like the mediterranean side, then the good home cooked meals like fried chicken and shrimp & grits.  The carving station is also good, but they only gave one slice at a time you have to keep going back.  I don't think the value is there unless you have some sort of coupon/deal, or you do the all-day-pass.

F9f1hN9fR0EARfvCdJS4bg.text: Cool things: kids under 12 eat FREE. $19.99 unlimited mimosa drinks for 2. Good food. Not so cool: no lobster and I could not find good steak :) Not many variations. Definitely will be back because kids love the place.

Qn8sDgye1-cUcGCXEGLYzQ.text: I'm sad to say that I'm disappointed with The Buffet at Aria.  My last Vegas buffet was at the Wynn and I was blown away. Their selection was good but everything tasted amazing. They had a wide variety of items.   Here at Aria, I didn't see that. Their selection seemed limited and whatever was there, was rather basic and lacked in flavor. They literally had like two to three kinds of sushi, how disappointing. A lot of their food didn't have the flavor that hooked me.  The service was also not up to par. Our waitress/server lagged in cleaning up our used plates, etc. It was a really busy night so I understood how she must've had many tables, but I took note that she kept going to two specific tables more often than ours. We literally had to call her over because we had so many dirty dishes piled up. It was really disappointing. I'm not sure I'd recommend this buffet to anyone and I'm sad to say so.  UPDATE: Not sure what my sister ate there but she's been throwing up all night since we had dinner.

vDqHsDPCqC9JPmm9XJPW6g.text: The buffet here is okay. I have tried better elsewhere  with a larger selection of ethnic foods. Since we were hungry and a little hungover from the night before, anything that looks appetizing was good.  I basically stuck around the section with all the crab legs. Now you know what I eat the most. Lol. They were fresh as it was packed around ice. The beauty of these crab legs wasn't about its size, but how they're already cut in half for you to easily consume. Delicious!   Other items I've tried was the roasted beef (not prime rib), roasted chicken, smoked salmon,  spicy tuna sushi roll, broccoli, pepperoni pizza, their dim sum sieu mais (dumping), the tossed green Cesar Salad, and finally their fresh fruits.  I don't know why they call their beef "roasted beef" rather than using the fancy prime rib. Maybe it was a different area of the cow? But that huge roasted slab of meat did look wonderful.  But I think they should have let the meat absorb the marinated flavor a bit longer since it wasn't too flavorful in the mid cut.   Believe it or not, aside from the crab legs, I probably enjoyed the salad and the fresh fruits the most. It look so fresh that I had to indulge. Yep, I need my greens and vitamin C.   It kind of sounds like I'm an oinker for eating so much which I actually am, but really I only took a small proportion of everything to try out. Yes, I was stuffed from the variety.  The buffet is well kept and very clean. I wouldn't worry too much about getting food poisoning since they deal with huge volumes. So the probability of something getting spoiled is rare.  Again, the food is mediocre. But come and enjoy anyways. For us, nothing beats a free comp meal.  Haha.

mW0GV94s4jsrU0DyKdYxnA.text: I am not sure if we are all rating the same the place or not, but for its value, price, and service, I think it is the best on the strip. They grill oysters for you. They make pan roast for you. Herbert and Stephanie were wonderful waiters. What more can you ask?

_9WNXkgKEEDuoYZFvCVdaQ.text: ok note to buffet eaters in Vegas.. if you're worried about the hefty price tag going during lunch! its cheaper  and now proceeding to the food (which really deserves 3.5 stars) King Crab Legs (i piled my plate high with such high expectations, they over salted so that you limited what you ate - fail) Roast - cooked to perfection Sushi/Sashimi - decent considering it was a buffet Grilled Shrimp - devoured.. inhaled really.. Ceviche - really refreshing, clean flavors Desserts - ALL AMAZING!  decor was interesting, plenty of seating, a bit of a wait but wasn't terrible (20 minutes?) average cost for a buffet in Vegas, but well worth it!

dCVwyBjTgGCxm89fqeO3Bw.text: Parents with kids be forewarned:  children over 3 years of age will be charged as an adult.  I thought this was pretty outrageous.    As for the food, it's a mix.  Most of the salads are excellent including the crab legs.  The meats--prime rib, chicken, etc.--not so good.    Desserts--not great.  Bad apple pie and flan.  The bread pudding (my favorite) looked so bad I didn't even try it.    If you can, look elsewhere for a buffet.

RrVHnX0ilSxcZyfvDFiK8A.text: I was staying at Aria with some friends and we had some resort credit to use, so of course, we opted for staying in our hotel for BUFFET :D Only 20ish dollars for the weekend brunch, not bad, not bad at all. We also came a little bit before dinner, so we could pay the brunch price and get both brunch AND dinner foods. Gotta love beating the system :)  Immediately, the buffet pleased me. Why, you ask? There was no line! I'm so used to waiting in huge lines whenever I eat at the buffets in Vegas (especially Paris&Bellagio, those buffets ALWAYS have at least a 45 minute wait). We were seated pretty quickly, even though we were a large group, and we were immediately chowing down. For the weekend brunch, they had a good amount of food items. Snow crab legs, sushi, eggs benedict, caprese salad, sliced bacon, pancakes, breakfast burritos... I could go on forever. Most of the food was decent, but nothing really blew me out of the water. Once the menu changed to dinner, there were king crab legs, lobster ravioli, freshly baked naan, prime rib, refried beans, etc etc. Some of the food was delicious and some was just meh. The refried beans were INCREDIBLY salty to the point where I couldn't eat anymore after the first bite. I was also pretty disappointed with the king crab legs. I LOVE crab and I've had king crab legs at a buffet before (the wynn) but these didn't taste as good; they tasted exactly the same as the snow crab legs, which was really disappointing.  This buffet really shined in the dessert area. All of the desserts looked beautiful and I was really happy with their spread; plenty of cakes, cookies, and even a serving station for gelato. I tried the nutella cake (DELICIOUS), pot de creme (freaking amazing!!!), and of course, the creme brulee. Everything I tried from the dessert bar was orgasmic-tasting. I thoroughly enjoyed it.  As for the service, ours was pretty decent. There were portions of time where they wouldn't come and plates would be stacking, but we always had liquid to drink and I was pretty content.  Overall, it's a decent buffet. Food is average & the desserts are GREAT. The price is definitely better than some of the other buffets in Vegas, but I think if you want some quality food, I'd go for the Wynn or Bellagio buffets. Otherwise, I feel like this buffet is still undiscovered, so you are bound to not have to wait too long to get your buffet on :) 3.5 stars!

357_ODmh_brIx__4P8_yEA.text: REALLY BAD!!! Service was bad and the food was bad. Servers there have no facial expression, slow on collecting finished plates. Food was just bad, their king crab legs were small like baby crab legs and very salty. Prime rib tasted like beef brisket. They did offer a glass of wine for everybody and 1 lobster per 2 persons for free, but the lobster meat was so nasty, it separated itself when we tried to stick the fork in. Only has a few types of sushi, salmon & shrimp sushi, some rolls, no sashimi, the rice was soooo hard. Dessert didn't have much choices too, worst creme brulee I've never had. Overall, the buffet doesn't worth $36 and will never go back again. So disappointed on such a high end hotel would have such a bad buffet.

-mfptzZCae2DAeVSD5M6Pw.text: all i have to say about the buffet here is BLECH...it's not SO bad that it gets only 1 star, but it's far inferior to buffets i've tried elsewhere in vegas (i.e. bellagio)...especially for the price...for roughly $35/person, it's money better spent elsewhere...and actually, now that i think about it, yuck, i would not eat here again  like most vegas buffets, they had an assortment of cuisines, but nothing really stood out...they had king crab legs, prime rib, steak, turkey and sushi stations...sure it SOUNDS good, but don't let your eyes and ears trick you...everything tasted a little off, i feel like nothing was fresh! and i would DEFINITELY avoid the sushi and i'm pretty sure the shrimp was the thaw and serve kind...also, each person get's HALF a lobster with their meal...but again, didn't taste that fresh and they don't clean them very well so it wasn't a very appetizing presentation...and when i mean not clean them very well, lobster poo was still all up in there...i know for some folks out there, they just eat that sh*t up, but for me, no thanks because seriously, do you serve kobe beef with a side of poo, no!  so overall review, either their food had been sitting out for awhile, or it was thaw and serve...blech blech blech...i mean, for it to be in the ARIA hotel and have TROPICANA quality buffet, i would totally skip  desserts were AWFUL...the selection was limited and again, nothing tasted quite right...i would go with the creme brulee, i mean seriously, you have to be tastebudless to get that classic dessert wrong  not to sound like a lush, but the only saving grace is the fact they had unlimited wine included in the $35...i'm sure it's boxed wine, but compared to the tasteless slop they were serving, the wine tasted like rainbows  oh, FYI, after dinner (and for the rest of the night) i had the worst heartburn/stomach ache...i'm convinced it was the lobster!

fZ5qM6OYAQHWoT7mZ7jafw.text: I can't believe the comments. This buffet was great. Definitely one of my favorites on the strip. Try beef ribs, gazpacho, scallops, brisket and the yuzu sorbet.

kZSQhcItuyR2iuLbYmjcpw.text: When choosing a buffet in Las Vegas Strip, there is a balance of food quality, variety, cost and ridiculous lines. Both Wicked Spoon and Bacchanal Buffets get a lot of press, but they also are more expensive and also have long lines. I am vegetarian so a variety of exotic meats are not a high priority for me, so that was also a reason I am not partial to those buffets as well. I thought Aria had a variety of choices for the Sunday Brunch when i visited. I enjoyed that they had a number of asian dishes including Chinese and a couple Indian dished that were respectable quality. The omelets were pretty bland, but the deserts were fantastic. Gelato and pies were amazing. The service is very friendly, lines were a bit long. Food quality varies based on what you are looking for, but I would call it above average among popular buffets on the strip.

BncNEBhgAUW_1lqK_-R0Yg.text: We decided to check out City Center, now that grand opening is over and the crowds would have thinned out by now. Overall the City Center is kind of futuristic and had a industrial/modern theme to it. I felt like I was in some futuristic movie like "Logan's run". ha ha. We had dinner at the Buffet on a Sunday night. No line to get in, so we were seated right away. Below average busy and it felt touristy. Food was good and bad, some stuff was good, some stuff was bad. If you got the right combination of choices, you may be pleased, but you needed to try a little of everything to find out what you like, then by that time your stomach is saying, "What the hec is going on?" Crab was good, Sushi was dry and tasteless (for tourists) and don't touch the Raw, dry salmon, get the root word here, SALMON-ella. Salad bar, boring, Meats? undercooked, Indian, OK, Pizza? The same junk like other buffets, how could this be at a nice fancy place? The pasta, chesses, grilled veggies, again boring and some where dry. Chinese food? a few acceptable items, but mostly bland and nothing special. Bread, cheese, this that...nothing great. Desserts looked impressive, but none being noteworthy. Please get rid of that fancy curved plate! It's not functional in a buffet setting and some of the corners were chipped. There are other reviews here beaming about the dessert, but surely we didn't see what was so special about it. Service was barely acceptable. A dessert fork would have been nice since you only get a single fork the entire meal. I used my teaspoon. We noticed some people got up to get some dessert and when they returned to their seat the table was cleared and new customers sitting it their place. So the seating system needs some practice. I had to ask for a drink refill and the bussing of the tables were good and bad. Also when a patron is eating crab legs, maybe offer a extra plate for the shells? I don't know, but we probably won't return....no we are locals and know better, we won't return, unless by some unseen set of events. City Center Buffet at Aria, good for tourists I guess.

o8zyyFwBTS8xt166Hu3S1Q.text: Seafood Friday and there are better places for the price you pay.  The prime rib was good, but I loved the dessert here, it was awesome.

3FpUI_QY_2uOrmnq6M7ALA.text: This is honestly the WORST Vegas buffet EVER! From decor (or lack of) to food, it really was probably the worst thing to come out of Aria. For being such an amazing hotel, they sure are stingy. The waitress forgot to give one of our friends a lobster and when we brought it to her attention she insisted that she had brought out the right amount. She argued and gave us attitude for a good 5 minutes before finally giving in. The selection was MINIMAL and honestly there was just a lot of empty space. Not only was it bad food, it was OVER PRICED! I would definitely skip this place when at Aria

80uUhrqh-7Q8U6ji-o3xCw.text: MUCH better the second time around.  They definitely worked out a lot of the kinks from the service.

z6QsGC5ki4EOPkDindPkGA.text: I am a stickler for not only good food, but also quality food... That being said, I definitely will not be returning to this buffet. The food was edible, but the lack of selection and spotty service makes this a place that I will only need to go to once in my short life here on Earth.

L8Xe8wBXZB84tOd_ww09UQ.text: Part of staying at the Aria Hotel is that we were given $100 for resort credits that we could use daily. So, instead of wasting extra bucks, we ended up trying this buffet place. The service was poor, they were really slow in getting our drinks, and the food was way too dry and not much choice. Oh well, what do you expect for free food? I'd suggest to go to another hotel if you plan not to ruin your taste buds to get nicer brunch menu!

V1-V-IHjGDXDkcIW28pt8A.text: We got free buffets with our stay at Aria and now I know why they're giving out free buffets! This buffet is nothing special. The food was bland and the selections were unexciting. The best part of the buffet was probably the pastries section, which consisted of pastries from the hotel's famous Jean Philippe Patisserie.  I believe it's $28 per person for buffet and unlimited champage -- for mediocre food.  Compared to some of the other buffets in Vegas, this one doesn't come close!

q99AgPoNFNOXVZKmulCDng.text: Lunch at this buffet is pretty decent for the price of twenty five.  I had the roast beef quite a number of times along with the king crab legs.  The apple burrito was excellent and so was the toast.  The chinese food was okay.  But to top it off, the buffet had great deserts from the flan to the italian ice cream.

-3hkjvkTk_WoNhsu4F-fkQ.text: Gracie and Catalina made our experience fantastic and soared above all expectations. Definitely will be back!

AxqSZohbgm21jAXMWD5VXQ.text: We came here for lunch. Food is not good. Its better to go out of the hotel and eat at Mcdonalds. Their gourmet dinner during weekends may be much better.

q1aFooAdSA_gUL7xLiztbw.text: this was my first las vegas buffet experience. crab, shrimp, tons of fresh veggies. I had no idea they were this good!

SxdQrMK6YDqgHxAeKL4qog.text: Not that great of a buffet.  Not much selection of food over the weekend.  Weak in fruit and desert selections.  Better to go to Wynn or Cosmopolitan (across the street) if you want a good buffet.

VkEQ-WNHsdT5aj4p2JiiPg.text: When I go to a buffet, I'm there for the food and not the decor and this buffet lacks the food. The food was so mediocre. There was nothing special. There weren't a lot of sushi like other buffets and the buffet was small in comparison to the other, but costs almost the same price. I rather go to the Bellagio and get a much better buffet with more varieties of food.

bCPs3L4uI0tPCmf9Z90mmg.text: The food here was all just okay. Nothing tasted horrible but they didn't taste good either. I went on Thursday so maybe the good chef works on Friday or Saturday when they have their Gourmet dinners.   I would say the best item here was either the prime rib (for a buffet place, it's good) or else the cocktail shrimp. The sauce was perfect and not a skimpy shrimp and it was decorated very well. My favorite thing here was the desserts. The Whooping Pie was like a mousse filling with a soft chocolate cake around it.  The thing that saved our evening here, was our waiter was just AWESOME.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Flan, whoopie pie, s&#39;mores cake

-_mMf3bzwehhIZSZYCDS7A.text: I've been to almost all of the buffets on the strip. I was not too impressed with this one. I went at 2:45 on a Saturday, dinner started at 3, so I saved myself a couple of bucks. The food was good. There was not as much selection as I've seen at others. Prime rib was good and there was lots of crab.  Looking at pictures others have posted on here, I think I got the short end of the stick with dessert :( It's one of the main reasons I go to buffets. Maybe they get fancier desserts out as it gets closer to actual dinner time. Nice layout and interior, nice staff.

Dw8H_lFBFa-fcryTaeTC_w.text: I always love it here. The staff are so accommodating and helpful when discussing allergens and ingredients in their food. The prime rib is awesome, butter chicken, crammed corn and the grilled prawns. They have a variety of desserts including many Gelato flavors

mb7TFtpwHtX2rZZkywgjNg.text: The food at The Buffet at ARIA is really good. We have been there many times and have always enjoyed it. It is less expensive than Caesars or the Wynn, but the quality is pretty close. If you like prime rib, shrimp, sushi, salads, meats and other seafood this is a great buffet for you. The line is usually shorter than most of the other Strip buffets as well.

zeuhPUpG_JEbVEFhO6geLQ.text: I ate here at 2pm and its now midnight and I'm still not hungry.   For $32 you get all the snow crab legs you can eat w out getting sick, endless California rolls, amazing blueberry blintzes, diverse desserts, and much more.   The only thing I wish this place had was chicken wings or fried chicken.

k9uhmmgnixSuoqlJVjyk6g.text: This is the best breakfast buffet I have ever had! The food is excellent and they have so many different types of food to satisfy any cravings. Would highly recommend.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

vfYSYu_yf6hBmwzIfSWBWw.text: Ok, here's the scoop. We're Las Vegas locals and try and hit most of the Strip and off Strip restaurants, buffets included. We gave it a whirl for Saturday night dinner buffet.  First stop  ..the centrally located Seafood island. We got a sampling of crab legs, oysters on the half shell, yellowtail sushi etc. The crab was mushy, I also got a few bad oysters (mushy too), the sushi was passable.  Next we hit the rest of the lines offerings.  Skipping most to try a few items I normally like. Tried the obligatory Prime Rib, which was fine, but certainly not as good as a stand alone Prime Rib restaurant. Tandoori chicken was next.  The chicken was ok, but very dry. I then got a few slices of deli salami.  All were overly chewy and had a funny taste. At that point I went on to some melon , all of which were totally unripe and tasted like cardboard.  I finally went to the desert station and got a small sampling of baked goods. They were ok, but I have to say I was disappointed that they had no ice cream to complement the Bananas Foster. In all fairness they told me the machine was broken.  All in all, I would say the meal was mediocre.   The meal was barely passable, however we will not be making a return trip. My wife made the same comments to me. If you want a truly good buffet, try The Bachanal at Caesars Palace. It was NOT worth the price of admission.

N0-sPO6rWxt2nCmoTqWsbA.text: What to say?  Mid-priced buffet in a nice environment.  ~$34 per person for a Thursday night buffet.  Tables and buffet area were clean and neat.  Pleasant, refined-feeling atmosphere - which was a real plus.  Layout of buffet is pretty well organized, with a semi-circular layout around another center station.  Waitress was attentive to remove empty plates and even kept our water and ice tea full (There is no drink self-service).  I liked the food.  There was a good variety, and it didn't seem to be a bunch of low-rent/cheap items.  The items were fresh, and the carver station meats were moist.  Good selection of dessert items, which a Vegas buffet is always expected to have.  Really what more can you say about a buffet?  Not a bad choice, appropriate for the price level, and you'll get what you paid for.

ytsYJFsxN1_6RDPBuR4L_A.text: This is 1-star buffet. I never come back again even for free  I had two free vouchers so we went for dinner I'm so glad that I didn't have to pay for this meal. They had few of seafood, and different meats.  With the dinner for $35.99 without any of good sushi & no salmon, tuna or any of sashimi......We tried a little of almost everything and our taste-bud were at best.

Qb-fmOlaRseJu8hW2u3F2A.text: Can be a pretty long wait for the lunch buffet, so plan accordingly. This is your standard Vegas buffet. A lot of food for cheap. Nothing really blew my mind but if you are looking to work off that hangover and not pay $30 for a burger at one of the casino eateries then this is the place for you.

KV7c1HrfDgjGNtVnPSwSMw.text: Me and my girlfriend decided to try out the buffet on a thursday evening. We got free complimentary dinner buffet through my vegas.  The original cost would have been 34.00/person. When we got there, there was no line and inside the restaurant, it was half empty.  When I went to get some food, it felt like the food was just sitting there for hours, the snow crab legs were decent, but not great and it was not huge.  I thought this buffet would have been great since it is inside of a new hotel. The only thing that was good was the gelato.  I sure would not pay that much for the buffet here.

Xv5An6yoE8PLn_qAIKDsHQ.text: The staff at the Buffet exceeded my expectations with the food and great hospitality. I would recomend them to anyone wanting a great experience.

56Qaw-lQlrk3QCW59hKlVw.text: bad coffee O.K. food the best part is the rotating gelato bar  at least it was free becuase we stayed at the vdara and they gave us credit for the buffet

DDKSNWq-Tc6ZnLsosAtexA.text: I LOVE Aria as a hotel and casino. So this pains to me to give their buffet such a low rating, but I was really disappointed with their post-renovation offerings...  Food: The crab legs were good and the prime rib decent but there was a real lack of selection! The entire Mediterranean section was basically hummus. And there were a lot of things that repeated. The desserts LOOKED good but were for the most part uninspiring. The gelato was delicious (and fun to look at as its display case rotated) but was too soft probably due to the case opening and closing too many times.  Service: Service was excellent and we had the friendliest waitress ever. Kudos to her!  So all in all, I can't recommend the Aria buffet. It's a shame as the hotel is great and one of our favorites. Is it that hard to make a better buffet to match the rest of the hotel, especially when they're charging more than Bellagio? Skip this and take the monorail to Bellagio for a more satisfying experience.  Tip: If you MUST eat here, lunch/dinner swaps out around 3:30pm so come a little before that and pay the lunch price ($22.99 on M-F) but get the dinner selections saving you about $11 per person ($17 on Friday!). Just make sure you don't cut it too close on time as the line can get pretty long, especially on weekends. (If you have a pearl or higher Mlife card, you can go to the VIP line.)

2-4uGdcbBc6PjTTswLzbdA.text: Excellent for breakfast or brunch.  David serves up a great omelette.  Got one every day I was there.  Shout out to David at the omelette station.

NPoH-EQ3qiZ9rzgdiMckPA.text: The buffet was our least favorite of restaurants on site. I never find any buffet food up to standard as it's just a place to gorge yourself. This was pretty much the same. We wanted to try it because everyone says the buffets in Vegas are the best. The hot foods were mediocre-good, but the desserts were really tasty. Whomever is making those desserts can do with a raise because I went back for seconds.  The tandoori chicken at the Indian station sat too long and was dry. The curry was good. Everyone goes mental for pre-cracked crab legs, I never really understood that. They feel as if they are getting one-up on the man if they shove 40 crab legs down their throat. The cioppino was being stored at a very dangerous temperature. I had one sip and realized it wouldn't be wise to continue eating it. The asian station was a step-up mainly because it was busy so the food was being made fresh. The carvery was good as well, the roast chicken was juicy and tasty. The sushi wasn't bad although it wasn't freshly rolled and the choices were limited. Who doesn't love cured meats and cheeses, can't go wrong at the italian station.

sJ_6ry8TZnfPw2ngZV1t1g.text: Food was good. The service was ok. I made a request to move to better seating area about 1/4th the way in and my request was granted.  However after I moved, I was ignored until I was halfway through desert (right before I left).  In general, I kind of like it this way.  I always hate having servers constantly asking you questions over and over when your mouth is full of food and you are trying to eat in peace. However they broke my #1 rule of rules.  One rule to rule them all! Keep my cup full.  Since we are not permitted to fill our own cups like we are at some buffets, this left me rather thirsty for most of the meal, which sucks.  To be fair though, the server did recognize the issue after 30 minutes or so and apologized profusely for forgetting me. It was probably my fault anyways, messing up her groove by requesting a move to another table.  BTW, buffet decor, great! I love the modern, artsy feel to the place.  Plenty of good food and presentation was good. Didn't see any stations go near empty.  I gave it a 4/5. It was an honest mistake in my opinion and other than that blunder, I was satisfied.  PS: this isn't a 5 diamond establishment. Some reviewers want to pretend and rate it like it is. :-/.

mRucGCYBmiExeCQvCRd6Mw.text: Last week I sampled the buffets at both Aria and Bellagio. I'm sure some will disagree, but after trying both, I'd opt for Aria. And I generally hate buffets.  Variety was pretty good at both, but I thought on the whole the food at Aria was much better for just about everything. I tried a lot of different flavors, Mediterranean, Latin, Tandoori, Italian, Asian. Everything was really tasty here. Their Fish Market had some really outstanding whitefish.   The only thing I came away a bit disappointed with was the Asian. I was really looking forward to this, but they came up short here. Generally bland dim sum, rice and stir fry. They need to do a little work on this part of the world, but even so, I think I'd go back for lunch.

TQ8ERqnRlCEYs3NdgPcVaA.text: This is my favorite buffet in all of Vegas. It's never super crowded, and the pricing is a bit lower than others. But best of all, the food is fantastic! The Chinese station had the best General Tso's chicken I've ever had. This place also has an Indian station, which I haven't seen at others. And the hot bbq sauce at the carving station is good enough to pour all over everything on your plate. The server was prompt with refills, and the desserts are yummy while looking so pretty (usually you only get one or the other).

F8RNPukJ6rjcOEKAEV1R_w.text: Visited this buffet for breakfast before the long ride home. The variety of food was nice. I enjoyed some of the non-breakfast foods as well. My favorite thing was the french toast sticks. I wasn't too impressed with the dessert counter though. I'm easy to please, but I just felt there was something lacking there. I also feel like they could have expanded in their Asian cuisine section as well. All in all, this place is sure to get the job done. I wouldn't mind refueling here again.

W4U7NOSAmEMlB8t_Nj4csw.text: Love this buffet! We have done all of them. Bellagio, Silverton, Bacchanal (excellent), Wynn, Terribles (yuck), but we always end up here time and time again. Maybe because we love the snow crab legs. So until we find another GOOD VALUE buffet, we'll keep coming back.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The Buffet at the Aria
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The Buffet at the Aria
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The Buffet at the Aria

4QQWOqm-DVHvneGlbSipPw.text: Thanks to MyVegas, I used their 2-for-1 dinner buffet coupon! My boyfriend and I came here on a Tuesday evening and the line was long. It didn't take long for us to get in though. Everyone was nice in there and so was our server who brought us our drinks. Their food selection is meh. I wish we would've ate here during the weekend since it's their "gourmet" selections, but nonetheless, still good. Their desserts are ON POINT though!

bmTuJAmCMWyrHD3YFoKkyw.text: My last stay in Vegas was at the Aria, so naturally we had to check out the buffet at least once, right?  We came here on a Saturday at around 1:30 pm and the line was already quite long.  It took us about 45 minutes before we got seated.    WHAT I LOVE: I love that this place is so bright!  It wakes me up from my groggy mornings in Vegas haha!  Also, they have some YUMMY select breakfast foods which I haven't seen anywhere else.  They serve breakfast burritos which are delicious!  And *drum roll please*, HASH BROWNS!  I love me some hash browns!  Not only that, but I indulged like crazy on the crab legs.  Mountains of crab legs on my plate, dipped with melted butter and lemon...yum!  My mouth is watering already.  Service here is also amazing.  Our waitress kept coming by with refills and was just on top of everything!  WHY ONLY 4 STARS: Well, although Aria had endless crab legs for me to indulge on and some delicious breakfast items, I still felt that the variety of food offered here did not compare to say the Wynn or the Cosmopolitan.  We also came here thinking that our lunch buffet was going to be $20 from the yelp reviews, but it turned out to be around $34 each =(  OVERALL: I may come back if I come back to stay at the Aria.  I sure do love great service, crab legs & breakfast food :)

8vzqxZXcafQpt6iiBw7quA.text: This was my worst meal in Vegas.  The food was bland and the oysters were bad. It was very disappointing considering how good the other restaurants in the Aria were. Definitely not worth the price.

wuxyly7d2DHgozRwDNOMgw.text: I don't know what's wrong with the food, this is my second time here, 6 months ago the food they're serving is pretty good, with variety choices, but today all the meat I had is over cooked, super dry, seafood paella look like smushed rice stir with some dry up seafood, the steam clam look like clam in mud, the only good thing is the crab leg is not over cooked.  Dessert is not bad, still many choices, coffee gelato is good. Anyways very disappointing!

Kma7OJ7oThnMJZPjuc7gmw.text: I'm not a huge fan of buffets in general, but this buffet is definitely nothing to write home about. I should have realized that there was a reason why this buffet is significantly cheaper than all of the other buffets on the strip.   The only okay thing about this place was the crab legs, but you really have to dig for the good stuff. Other than the crab legs, there was nothing too appealing about the food.   Service was good though. Our waitress was always ready to refill our drinks when they started to get low, which is something that usually doesn't happen at buffets.  Anyways, if I were you, I'd walk the extra half a mile over to the Wicked Spoon buffet.

Jxp-6ciVQyHlG7lPnpvmYg.text: Aria's buffet used to be my #1 buffet on the Strip and I've been to all the major ones minus Bachannal. However, they have been gradually going downhill for the past two years to the point that I wouldn't ever pay to eat here. I would only eat here when I could use myVegas rewards. If I had to pay for a buffet, I'd much rather go to Bellagio's buffet which has now become my #1 choice.

tK4wm2sBDI3UklImDajzSA.text: My husband and I ate here. what a disappointment. False advertising people!! The food was cold and not good! The salmon tasted funny the Mac and cheese was a step above a cafeteria and the sushi was dry and chewy. Way overpriced what a disappointing experience. If you want an amazing buffet go to the bellagio.

uc9Vqk7tNcxDRNmCAHn7Wg.text: Not much to say about this mediocre buffet except that it came with my room so the price was right.  Plenty of food but some was inedible.  Didn't get sick though, that's a plus!

zXH4uu20GoJJZVwk2zv5rQ.text: Came here during the Christmas week, so there was a premium price on the buffet during lunchtime, about $30-something per person. The regular line up to get in was PACKED, so if it wasn't for the line pass we had, it would've been bye bye to the buffet.  Been here before last year and it seems the quality has gone down. The food was okay, but there really wasn't anything to write home about. They have your standard stuff that can be found in other buffets like shrimps, prime rib, roasted chicken, etc etc. They also have the king crab legs which seem to be the main attraction as I saw many people just having piles and piles of them on their plates. I didn't try the king crab legs as I'm not fond of them in general. I found many of the food to be kinda dry and so I have to put a lot of sauce on them to taste better.  The best part I found was the dessert. They have different kinds of dessert from creme brulee to creampuffs to different flavors of ice cream, as well as brownies, banana fosters, and cookies. I tried the creme brulee and cookies and they're pretty good. Better than the main stuff honestly.  Pop and juice are included in the price, so try to take advantage of that.  Not worth the $30-something for lunch, but ok for the regular $20-something.

f3pAui3iS3__z2_3W9spGg.text: There are two reasons to eat at a buffet. Either you want to pig out on one thing, or you want to eat a wide variety of foods. This buffet is ok if they have the one item (like crab legs) that you want a lot of, but the variety and quality of most of what they serve isn't very good.
