Dungeoness crab was really good, and the service was pretty good for Buffett, so that's where the 2 stars come from.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Seafoods
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Alaskan and dungeoness crab.

XC3d-D33nm2Rlo0nwq-tZQ.text: I had not been to Las Vegas for a few years. In general, I thought I was over casino buffets. My overall thought was there is a wide selection of food at a very good but not exceptional quality. Either the Buffet at ARIA has significantly upped its game since my last Las Vegas trip or I just missed it in previous trips. Maybe, the other buffets in Las Vegas have significantly improved to. In the past, I have tried the Wicked Spoon at Cosmopolitan, The Buffet at the Bellagio, and The Buffet at the Wynn. They were all great and Wynn was my favorite. I was surprised that The Buffet at Aria was the best casino buffet experience I have had to date in Las Vegas.  I went for a weekday brunch. For $28.99, it was a steal. My rating is based on the quality and value of the weekday brunch. I cannot speak to dinner or the weekend buffet. My friend went earlier in the year and highly recommended it. As such, I expected it to be good but not be blown away. I was highly impressed with the quality of the food. The poke bowl section was amazing. The fish was very fresh and the selection of toppings was great. The poke bowl by itself is almost enough to justify the price. I also loved the fish tacos. They were delicious. I also liked the little pho bowls. I am normally picky about my pho but the Buffet surprisingly had a solid one. The Asian themed food was very good overall. In terms of the other food, seafood was solid in general. The cut meats were good. I did not care for the fried chicken. It was a bit dry. There was also an Italian bar. Although I was too full to eat too much of it, I did try one of the big meatballs and liked it. In terms of dessert, it was ok. Nothing below me away but I did enjoy the selection of gelato.

ckZYmZLEwns3ftaf5njDcw.text: Did they get a discount on salt? Why is everything so freaking salty?   Isn't it a buffet? Why when I ask for a second slice of beef, the waiter says no?    Disgusting food. Disgusting staff.   Don't spend your hard earned money here.

rR_2Cr9bEQskOipe3TykGw.text: It was very expensive, I loved the Creme Brulee, but not 60$ worth. The food was good but not 60$ worth

Qkl89BhlTru_8aH132OEcQ.text: Linda was amazing! She was the best waitress that we had in Vegas!!!  We could have used more vegetarian options and vegetarian items were always labeled as such. The weight at 11:30 was about 45 minutes. They were empty seats, but that would not allow people to stop them. The food was pretty tasty for what it was.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dessert was tasty. More vegetarian options would be helpful. The veggie stuff also wasn&#39;t clearly marked.

cI9WrNja78nLOWnJ8HQ6eQ.text: When one thinks of Las Vegas, a classic all-you-can-eat buffet comes to mind. This buffet takes it to the next level. It's seriously what dreams are made of. Every single station that I chose to indulge was delicious. There was an unbelievable amount of food choices, crazy amounts of desserts, and every single carb-and-baked-good you can imagine. We were smart and arrived at 10:40, so we got the breakfast prices and experienced both the brunch and lunch menu.  Here's a tip: some stations looked just 'alright.' Your experience can alter depending on the food you choose. I wouldn't even look at the Asian food station, but their pizza station was the bomb (truffle mushroom and goat cheese pizza? Yes please).  By the way, this place had the best fried chicken I've ever eaten.  Definitely consider this buffet if you're looking for a huge and delicious meal when in Vegas.

6ymUZI8Ti_gfN9kLP7ruxA.text: Had breakfast at The Buffet. Can be a little pricey, what buffet in Vegas isn't?! Everything was absolutely delicious! It was pretty awesome to see the HUGE round pancakes! Employees were nice and fast taking away used plates. Highly recommended!

dSUo8wVfGp6xf5p9487nwA.text: The Buffet was fine - a good selection of meats, seafood, salads, basically anything you could want. Lunch price of $28 is reasonable for Aria, the Lounge Burger or Five-50 would have cost about as much. The Buffet did not stand out as anything spectacular, not as good as Wicked Spoon or Bacchanal. Service was below average, and I was disappointed that I was seated in the furthest section from the buffet (despite the place being 80% empty), I guess you have to be a VIP to get good service and sit closer.

9Dsn2IVlL5u-dFdG7WHVzQ.text: Very underrated buffet. I came in and used my myVEGAS reward for a buy 1 get 1 free. Everything was very very good! The crab is some of the best I have ever had a buffet, and the prime rib was delicious. The dessert section was large and all of the ones I had were pretty good. My only star takeaway from this is that the handles for many of the serving dishes were pretty filthy, and the decor was nothing spectacular. Overall a pretty good buffet for the price!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pretty rare prime rib but very good! You can get it more cooked if you want.

56MxLFLSPZsjhCLLZL1glg.text: My favorite buffet on the strip thus far, I like Aria for the vast variety they offer. It literally felt like an international buffet as there were choices from around the globe. The amount of seafood offered from crab legs to crawfish made it a hit to me. The "limitless cheers" add on to my brunch was a perfect compliment. You weren't limited to only mimosas, you had Bellini's, Bloody Mary's, rum & coke and a vodka option all included and you were allowed to switch back and forth at your leisure. Pretty awesome if you ask me.  The place was clean, the hostess and staff were friendly and timely.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crab legs and crawfish deserved a plate to themselves
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Western omelette with waffles, bacon and sausage

JDk8-VxbAaR-gjS7cMRB2g.text: Went twice this summer while we stayed at the Aria. Food was marginally better than the last time, although service was horrendous like always.  Very inattentive and infrequent bussing of tables. I do love the tandoor oven though.

49F7aeUY3o3YZER0c-r1ew.text: Pretty good buffet, a little pricy for lunch about $30.00 each.  We had comps so used that.  Lots of choices and they make it in small batches.  Asian, Italian, Diner, Tandoori, Mexican and several others.  The desert bar is very good.  We've eaten at the Belligeio  buffet before and I think I would perfer this one,  easier to get around.  I should note that parking is free for one hour on self park then $9.00 for the next 2 hours.  The prime rib was excellent, I didn't try the crab legs but they were plentiful.

hexsw89V6sNGIIgSoK0vxg.text: This was my first Vegas Buffet, so yes, I'm a little biased.   It fulfilled all of my wildest dreams.   The sushi is ok, nothing insane.  The curries were ok.   I was really impressed with their salads, the uniqueness of them, and how good they tasted.  I loved that they had dumplings and dim sum.  The lasagna was awesome.  The mini sandwiches were gorgeous plus yummy.  Naan was delicious.  The build your own taco area was amazing, and the brisket was tender and flavorful as can be.  Paella was yummy.   Those are just some highlights. I realize that this is my "first time", but the amount of food that was there plus the high quality and variety was really impressive.   Also, I eat almost anything, so I've got a lot more options than picky eaters.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

7_paTvOew7tAV7Ax-zWvhQ.text: Decided to try out a new buffet on the strip rather than our usual M resort buffet.  The variety of food was awesome and plenty of options to choose from. We had a line pass and still had to wait about 15 minutes but I'm assuming that's okay since it was a holiday weekend.  I was disappointed that most of the dishes were cold :(  (hate cold food) Our server was okay but not as attentive of as other servers around us.  I would come back but not anytime soon.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. All the desserts were amazing!
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Southern shrimp and grits.
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Red velvet Nutella pancakes, carrot cake pancakes, and French toast were all delicious.

ehS8Q3-GnYX05v1ITsOx8Q.text: Prelims: clean. That's the first word that comes to mind when I recall eating at this buffet. It's very bright, with absolutely a galore of bright natural light throughout the whole dining area, if you come during lunch. When I was there, there were plenty of seats, the service was good, with drinks and requests coming in consistently and our requests were made appropriately, although it took a while to actually flag someone down. But overall, little to complain about in service.   The food selection is rather limited when compared to the bounty of the Bacchanal feast. However, no matter what you get, it's all very delicious. The food quality is probably on a higher standard than the one that we got on ill-advised trip to Caesar's Palace; we actually enjoyed even the salad. The standard fare was included, with brisket, prime rib, sausages, desserts, Chinese/Latino/French/Japanese/Mediterranean fare all included. However, I actually enjoyed everything that I ate here and I don't really have much to say in regards to things that you should avoid. I would say that this is a safe buffet - you can come and not be disappointed b/c there is plenty to enjoy and you would like whatever you picked up. Unless you know that you probably wouldn't like it. Then don't blame the buffet - blame yourself.   TL;DR - smaller, higher quality buffet with deliciousness in every bite.

SuD26LRpVf5JL-A-QZ02CA.text: This buffet, at $32 per person, is not $$, but rather $$$$. The selections, however, were wonderful and the food was good. Some selections were excellent. Pass on the crab legs. More shell than meat, fishy and undercooked. I honestly expect a buffet of this caliber to be priced closer to $20 but everything in Vegas is horribly overpriced these days.

G5DSatWlmOdokQzf2rFv-A.text: This buffet is quite wonderful! We were able to get a 2-for-1 deal so we were quite happy with what we paid for the buffet.  The food quality is actually pretty good. The selection is small compared to the famous bigger buffets in Vegas but I think that I would come back to the ARIA versus another buffet because of the quality of the food.  The salads were amazing! They had a duck confit salad and a brussel sprout salad that were out of this world! My husband also enjoyed the quinoa salad.  The prime rib was also very good!  I highly recommend this buffet!

WNxTSsHHTA13hWJl4o7agA.text: Was not happy how the cashier Martha, did not smile.  Did not Thank us. Instead I smiled at her as she handed us the receipts.  I told her Thank you.  She didn't acknowledge me.  We got our comps (BOGO) from myVEGAS slots. It's 8,000 loyalty points.  Hours of playing to EARN it.    Everyone on staff was miserable. The only guy that was happy to serve me was the guy at the carving station,  African American gentlemen. Can't remember his name.  Waitress asked us what we wanted to drink.  Doesn't grab us silverware. I had to ask for it. She then says, "Oh! It's suppose to be set already".  She didn't refill our drinks.  The food was okay at best.  They had "portuguese sausages", I asked the carver is it Chorizo or Linguica? He said to me,  "the first one". Lol. It was not as spicy as I expected. It was okay, edible. The only thing I liked was pleased with was the mash potatoes had garlic in them.  I ate the mash & tried everything.  It was all cold & old sitting out.  The chicken pot stickers were awfully bland.  The desserts were pretty good but the Asian man serving gelato was a prick. He had something up his butt. He sees me waiting behind the girl he was serving.  I let her go since she was there before me,  I thought.  She left,  he doesn't acknowledge me.  But the family that walks up, he acknowledged them but they were just looking.  Really upset how this experience went. I'm glad I didn't pay $50 but still.  I'm glad I tried it for half price.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Probably the best thing I had for lunch..
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Grabbed Chocolate cookie. My boyfriend noticed it had walnuts.  Glad I took my allergy pill today. Oatmeal &amp; peach cookie.Weird.
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken was dry &amp; flavor less. Mash was good.

5hFXiVTJ9VFSkwT09uCmWw.text: Very disappointed in this buffet. I came here when it first opened and it was much smaller but the food was great. This place now reminds me of a cheap Indian casino buffet. At almost $45 per Person it is not worth it. There is not much for kids to eat. We will not be back.

DGZZBuGd3Rj27LPHpvqAtA.text: It's like any other Buffet, but I'll admit...the food here was unbelievable.  The servers were prompt and friendly.  Not something I'd splurge at unless it was a special occasion.

JgzJBJHkL3Ae1jc_C_8ODQ.text: Finally got to experience a Vegas buffet as an adult and yes my stomach was happy! Yes, expensive but it's Vegas so if you are already dropping $100 an hour on slot machines, then you deserve a good dinner buffet! For 3 people it cost me around $140. Saturday afternoon, no wait, no line, no problem! As soon as we were seated, we went straight for the food! The Buffet has an array of foods from around the world and a chef at every station. I got a little but of everything and I loved it! My favorite though, being a seafood foodie, were the crab legs! They were steamed to perfection! Absolutely amazing! Highly recommend those. You should just grab a plate specifically only for crab legs. They do have a salad bar and a dessert bar! The new York cheesecake was really good and the Gelato tasted so fresh! Yum! Drinks are expensive so if you must get one then get one but other than that I would just stick with fountain drinks or water! It's included with your meal. Enjoy!

eyCjfO3XUIV_GlnPXu4fpQ.text: The food here was amazing and well worth the price! However the service was terrible. We paid for the unlimited drinks and our waitress barely stopped by. It was a very slow morning and there was no reason for her to avoid my table the way she did.  She had one or two other tables in the section.   Finally when we were able to flag her down and get her attention she couldn't be nice and said that we had been at the buffet for too long (1 hour and 45 mins) and that she would be no longer serving us and that we needed to leave. Well that did away with the minimal 15% tip I was going to leave. I normally visit this buffet because the food is so good. It was very disappointing that we were treated like that. I paid over a hundred dollars to eat and drink there and was treated with rudeness and contempt.  I will not be back again because of the rude service.

9sfmyfaqhbuPTMInxvw6PA.text: Really nice buffet!!!  We arrived early, which meant a lower price tag, but there were so many wonderful options to choose from nonetheless.    The restaurant was clean, the service at the carving station as well as the omelet station were great.  I'm not sure how they split up the waiters, but, unfortunately, out water classes and my table mates' coffee mugs went old.  The guy was nice enough when he appeared.    The dessert plates were a nice modest size and the food was really good.  We believe we got our money's worth without overeating and enjoyed great conversation in a nice atmosphere.    I'd recommend if you're in the area.  **one of my table mates loves crab and found that the ones served here were really good.**

c8ILH3nM_7FRPPz3aIJfUA.text: Don't waste your money and time hear.The stake and barbecue are the worst part cold. Raw and uncooked

tu0CJa836vY1bgIAiS0fmA.text: Long wait! Crab legs, stone crab legs, clams, oysters... if you like seafood, this place isn't bad.  King crab legs for dinner, snow crab legs for lunch.  Rack of lamb for dinner.  Other meats include sausage, prime rib.  There's also asian, indian, and mexican food.  Pretty big dessert bar.  Service was average.  One time they took forever to bring something, and the other time they bussed our table when we were just going to get more food.  The price was approximately $40 per person for lunch, which isn't too bad given all the seafood and meat.  Not the best buffet, but not the worst either.  Nothing that I personally was wowed about, except for them having stone crab legs, because I love those! Also, the watermelon juice they had was yummy too!

VNiF56FkiHsd40xqZTmJ-g.text: This is probably one of the better buffets I've had in Las Vegas. They offer a wide variety of options from asian cuisine, Mexican, Prime rib and sides, seafood and desserts. The great thing is that even with all their options, everything was still full of flavor and held to a higher standard for a buffet. This is definitely a great buffet option for lunch!

R0XZiUN-Nm507s-pO-k1Dg.text: Came twice, once for breakfast and once for dinner.  Both experiences surpassed my expectations.  Both visits were busy, but being an mlife Pearl helped make the wait a bit shorter than the standard line.  Not by much, but a little bit.  Both visits the cashiers were the friendliest for an elite-categorized property. Not exuberant but not dull.  Waitress on both visits were outstanding.  Linda was ours at breakfast, and Frances at dinner.  Both had numerous tables but ensured to spend time at each table, whether it was checking in, clearing dishes, or refilling drinks.  The food was very fresh, had lots of selections, and felt spacious compared to the stations at places like Bellagio or Bacchanal (Caesars Palace).  If they have it during your breakfast, the red velvet pancakes are a must try!  For dinner, of course the carving station and crab legs are worth the multiple trips.  Dessert items are very unique like Bellagio, but Aria's does have a gelato carousel with what I counted as 8 different flavors (some were duplicate like strawberry and French vanilla).  One concern I had was the labeling at the stations.  There were many that were not accurate or switched with other items, and some had missing tags altogether.  The staff at the stations were what drops the rating.  There was one gentleman, who had nothing in his hands, walking from the seafood section to behind the tandoori oven pathway.  He accidentally stepped on my foot, but took no notice, and kept going about his business.  At the carving station, the lady looked extremely irate, did huff a few times (unsure if at patrons or not), but did make me more careful to what I asked for.  As a result I did not try all the items I wanted.  At the pizza section, I watched a kid grab with his hands, and the two guys behind the station I overheard talking about how dumb the tourists are and how inconsiderate international tourist children are.  At the salad station there were two older Latina ladies that were cackling and joking around with each other.  While I did enjoy seeing them having fun, I did try to ask a question which took me 3 tries to get their attention as they were deep in their conversation.  They were helpful in answering my questions at least.  Overall, if you don't mind service at the stations, this would be a 5-Star buffet.  Overall service and quality is far superior to other buffets and you get way more than what you pay for as long as you do it right.  If service at the stations matters to you, be very careful with what you do and don't listen in to others so much or you may find yourself with a negative outlook on the overall service that the Buffet at Aria gives.

uzuPKu1UbV7c-WZOIW63WQ.text: Went on a Wednesday night. The line was along. It took us over 40 minutes just to get seated. It appeared they were way under staffed.  Food was great. If I were just rating the food I'd give them 4 to 4.5 stars.  It was the rest of what gives them 2 stars. My seat was COVERED with food. I'm not exaggerating (check out the pic). It took about 15 minutes before we got any water. I know that it's a buffet, but at $42...you'd think they could staff it better and clean the place up. It was disgusting.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

3y_zMqijq1T2rEkjhRkOCQ.text: Clean, big variety of food, great service, some wait time, but not much!! Love the seafood, Indian, Asian food, Middle East food is not as popular, but seems fresh too

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Eku91UuLYraTkkKZRddcJg.text: The reviews are right, the food is mediocre. Nothing really special or memorable. However, the worst part is how terrible the service is. For a 5 star hotel, the buffet is INCREDIBLY understaffed. Even as we waited in line for over 2 hours, one particular table that we saw did not get cleared for over 30 minutes. After we paid, I could see that the back of the restaurant was empty. As we were being seated, my suspicions were correct, there were so many tables that were empty that just haven't been cleared yet which is ridiculous considering how long the line is. Our waitress only sporadically picked up our plates and that was because she was also busy clearing tables, a job that should be reserved for other people. The item labels, especially for desserts, did not match either. For such a fancy hotel as Aria, I'm shocked that they couldn't even fully staff their restaurant.

a6MOj6LXFRUCKV-Zf0nhAQ.text: The only times I've gone to the Aria bugfet have been when they were packaged with my room rate. Unfortunately this has happened twice. 2 buffers per night is just too much, opt for credit if you have a choice. The buffet serves the same food every single time, even year to year it hasn't changed. If I was paying the rates they posted during the holidays ($40+ per person plus tax and tip on the low end) I would be incredibly disappointed. Free is one thing: it's really quantity over quality with this buffet. The staff is great and it's pretty clean, but as far as selection and variety, not so great. I'd rather pay more for better options.

P8y3u60h1mPKvrujUhnkgw.text: We typically hit this spot up a few times when we are in town.  It's USUALLY one of our favorites. Well today was a raging waste of money. Got in line at 7:50. Buffet closes at 10. No problem. After an hour in line got through, still just over an hour to close and we aren't slow eaters so we thought nbd. Imagine our disappointment when we saw the almost empty sushi bar, the only dessert left was cookies and gelato. The pasta station had one type of pasta left. Out of meats at the carving station. You name it. I mean I get it. They close in an hour but as I'm sitting here at 845, they're still admitting people and still charging full price. I get casinos make money but buffets are typically where you can go at least eat off your losses. Tonight this was just another loss. If this is how they will be operating now, don't waste your time. Save the money for Bacchanal.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Rh-1--aGR3pl7EmtHQenxA.text: The buffet is not a big deal, the staff are super slow and don't care about people waiting! Once a table is left by customers, it takes at least 15 to 30 minutes to be ready for new people! The worst thing is the wait in the line to get to the buffet! There is no notice for the wait time, but it can easily exceed 2 hours! We didn't know that, so we realized it when we waited for an hour! Having waited for so long, we waited the rest! We have been to other buffets in Vegas but haven't experienced such a nightmare of waiting without notice! This all happened on a Thursday!

OYzdhgw3VTetc0_8BMrqUw.text: I was really disappointed with their seafood options. We specifically chose this buffet because they were the only ones that served snow crab at the brunch. I even called ahead to make sure they would have the crab legs there on a wednesday - since they were the only one we could find that had those this early (this was a party of 7 coming to LV specifically for a buffet run) and I was ASSURED that there would be crab legs there at 11AM.  Here's the excerpt from their OWN website:  "Fresh seafood, unlimited crab legs*, fish and chips, paella and more  *Snow Crab, Dungeness and Crab Claw. Snow Crab served daily starting at 11:00 AM (brunch) & 3:00 PM (dinner).."  The snow crab and crab legs never materialized. I asked one of the staff where they were, and was told they only served them during dinner. I pointed out that it said on their website AND I called a few days before to confirm that they served crab legs there on WEDNESDAY - and was told that they only had the claws (which were grainy and not meaty at all).   Total bait and switch experience. 7 people were very unhappy with the experience.

JsMHpSAa4Cnfh3JVvSHp5Q.text: Stopped here.  3rd time. First two times were not great, but we like the rooms at the Aria.  Distinctly unpleasant here today. We arrived after 8am, and half the dishes had that film look like they'd been out for hours already. They took us to an entirely empty section as far away from the buffet as physically possible. When I asked be seated in the same area as the rest of the people there, to host just glared back, stomped us back to the desk and said please wait here. Know that there was no more than 30 people there. She let us wait for a few more minutes and then took us to seat us more normally.    Not one person who was working there seemed happy. We won't be back.

UUuQirTsBlHIrTluyWEXnQ.text: I'm vegetarian. There was plenty to eat, but had to scavenge it from across the floor. Many items weren't labeled or were mislabeled. Some dietary restriction marking would go a long way as well (vegetarian, vegan, shellfish, gluten free...) Everything was just okay. Desserts were unremarkable and too sweet.

fPT5qBFk4YbcL0r-m79tFQ.text: A solid and decent buffet. The variety is actually mind blowing and the price isn't horrible either. I enjoyed our meal but I'd have to say a little disappointed in the quality of some the dishes. I think this buffet is a victim of "doing too much" is loses a bit of points in quality. But to be honest I'd totally return to it without hesitation especially if I was staying at the Aria again. I like how they switched up the dishes too while we were there so it was always a surprise each round. As far as Las Vegas Buffets go...this place is a great place to start.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken and waffle in a basket
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. PHO STATION?!
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gelato wheel

PidToP03JZ3kQ-FhiBqkUQ.text: Really poor customer service and food quality.  Food was 4/10 Slow Service A lot of things they "ran out of" and refused to make more of even after requesting it and they were open for another 1.5 hours.  Would definitely pick Mirage Buffet over here at least they are 7/10 plus they're nicer people and cheaper.

T-RZRoBPmAA-HKjFEkmhFQ.text: I don't usually do buffets as it's calorie central and I hate the feeling of being overstuffed. I'm a seafood guy and would choose lobster, crab, shrimp, etc over steak. When I found out that the buffet offered crab, I couldn't resist!  Good thing we stayed right next door at The Cosmopolitan as it is just walking distance to Aria. It was $40/person for dinner, which was kinda pricey but being that there was crab & prime rib, it should be worth it.  Glad we went. The buffet wasn't as diverse as Bachannal at Caesars but the prime rib and crab were delicious!!!! They had snow crab legs, stone crab claws, as well as king crab legs!!!! I loved how they were served cracked and sliced in half for easy access to the succulent crab meat. So good!!!!!!!  Make sure you try the prime rib as the serve it bone-in which gives such a great rich flavor to the meat and makes it very moist. One thing that was very unexpected was the pork & shrimp shumai dumplings from the dim sum area. THESE WERE THE BEST SHUMAI DUMPLINGS I'VE EVER HAD!!!!!!!!! SO MOIST!!!!!!!!!!!!!  Verdict:  I would pay a visit everytime I go to Vegas. I was so surprised that I enjoyed as I don't usually eat at buffets. Our server was so nice and hospitable. She had such a great personality and was so funny!!!! Thanks Mary Ann for the laughs and superb service!!!!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. KING CRAB AND STONE CRAB LEGS!!!!

qkA-T4RU8Zr9x7NSawOElQ.text: Of course, we are always excited for any buffet at a Las Vegas hotel.  I was really glad to see some Indian food and Poke, and the thai tea in little tiny jars was so awesome.  There was a slight cleaning supply smell or something around the food, so I'm not sure if that was it or if it was something else.

yuJduqw55hviT9_x16vnYw.text: Great variety of food: seafood, meat, mexican, asian, viet, italian, indian, salad, soup, bread and dessert. You will have plenty to choose from. It's always pack so be prepared to wait in line for a few hours. The server was nice.

nDrhmYiqdaDxpjW7MJ2QTg.text: Hubby and I were hesistant about coming due to the reviews. But let me tell you this place far exceeded our expectations. They have such a good variety of foods and such a large selection! There was literally 1 or 2 things that I didn't like off of the buffet, but that's expected. There is literally something for every palette. Definitely recommend! Oh and the price was definitely worth it for the quality of foods. At $33.99 pp it was so good. They also have a bottomless alcohol package at 20$ pp.

SYyJZFZzyq50mcvV9cHJwQ.text: My husband and I did not enjoy this buffet so I must note. Not to come back. Easter Sunday 2016

9zBeba3sXJRI6mexABfWXA.text: We received credit for two free buffets with our stay at Aria.  We decided to use the credits for lunch on a day when we were in a rush and needed food quickly.  I'm not big on buffets, so I don't have a lot go on in terms of comparison....  I didn't find anything particularly outstanding or of which I would have gone up for seconds.   The mac and cheese was bland, the pico de gallo was flavourless, the pizza was ok, tacos were ok as well.  The dessert bar was fairly impressive however, with really nice squares, mini cupcakes, macaroons and a wide selection of ice creams with great toppings.  Because it was free, The Buffet was worth it, but I would have been pretty disappointed if I'd paid with my own money after reading all of the self-hype about being the best buffet in Vegas!

mOK72R3p5ITyl0PWKVGidA.text: Had breakfast here. The choices were amazing. More that your usual breakfast foods. Even some authentic foods. Deserts were amazing. Probably best buffet that I visited so far and I've been to many.

qEXWElRIqmYVknGU3AxV9Q.text: Cost is ~ $40 for dinner.  The Chinese food wasn't very tasty and the carvery had very dry meat.  That's okay because they have a large selection.  They also had crag legs, both warm and cold, but the thing that grossed me out was when I saw one of the workers putting the cold seafood away with his bare hands!  At first, I thought he must be throwing them away, but after walking around to see where he was placing the crab legs in, I was shocked to see that he was putting them away and not throwing them away.  Now that may have happened just that one night, right?  Wrong!  I had to go back a couple days later because a few of my colleagues wanted a buffet and it happened to be one of the few w/in walking distance and was opened.  I thought...maybe that was just that one time....  Nope, I saw the same guy cleaning up with his bare hands..  If you want to get ripped off and have some "natural" crab leg tastes, then go here!

o0YxLOsIN0BpAAOb9HhC_g.text: Dinner buffet: $20.99 per person  Crab legs: dip in hot butter and enter the gates of heaven! Beef brisket: heavily marbled and just delectable Sauteed green beans and veggies: well executed. great way to clean your palate Baked fish: YUCK!!! What the heck! *spit spit* Someone needs to be fired!

CWnEA6KOkKLX77-uqihzhg.text: CRAB LEGS.  SHRIMP. DESSERT BAR. BREAKFAST BURRITO. BACON.  I am still full and its been 2 days. Also none of my clothes fit anymore, so tyvm.   Probably would check out the Mandalay Bay one or Paris next time. I mean, the food wasn't life changing. Except that breakfast burrito- holy crap what did you put in there??

KQeViixBnLyMyfJ_3cDjUQ.text: There was a time in Las Vegas when people would get dressed up to go out to a luxurious dinner served by people in tuxedos in innovative  facilities with impressive modern design and atmospheric lighting.  While you may pay a luxurious price for this buffet your experience will not be one of luxury. The servers are dressed like farm hands. The maitre d or perhaps I should say the herder is dressed in a busboy outfit.  As for the design of the facility, think one step up from a lunchroom in a school cafeteria. This  is essentially a harshly lit box that charges a lot of money for poor service.

dHHyPCo4hKUEZg7X2bpjyA.text: The food was fresh lots of variety  still one of the best it LV   the service was good Our Waiter Randy was excellent

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Snow crabs mussels
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fisherman stew

IdqMEQMgYeAYL4Kxr9ujYQ.text: A solid Las Vegas buffet. Everything's clearly labeled but for me service was a little slow. Perhaps an upscale place like Aria is could have a more creative buffet restaurant, like The Cosmopolitan has with Wicked Spoon. Still, The Buffet at Aria is a good one and not even too pricey. There weren't as many different types of dessert as I would have liked but they were good anyway.

t44q6x53dwGv-3bdslh_Cw.text: Came here on a Thurs dinner time after Christmas and they're charging $50/person, ouch. Seriously, buffet at Vegas is becoming a joke now. What happen to all the good and cheap buffets they used to offer? Don't get me wrong, the food here is great and fresh but they don't have enough variety of food to charge at that price. If I want to pay $50 for buffet, I'll rather go buffet at Caesar's or Cosmopolitan. I've been here before during lunch and the only difference at dinner is that they added prime rib and oyster.  This is a $30 buffet at best. Food 4 stars and price 2 stars.

Vl5pn8J7eygUMug3xz0JXw.text: What a fantastic breakfast buffet. The red velvet pancakes and carrot cake pancakes were amazing. Great selection of breakfast meats. Well worth the money

-PQwRycoY_NoacQzO_55Eg.text: I came for lunch to meet someone from my online dog group that's visiting. I've never seen a buffet that has had such a mixed bag of reviews so I didn't know what to expect. It was convenient and right there at her hotel though. I rarely buffet and went to Bacchanal a few days before this, but found it was good for $22.  Best things was the snow crab was quality and just as good as the Bacchanal was. The carving station had a roast pork and a beef brisket that were tender and flavorful.  A few of the dumplings from the Asian section was pretty good. I've never seen Indian station at a buffet before, but this had a decent chicken curry. Nice charcuterie selection, the ceviche and my white anchovy/boquerones salad was good. There were a few misses, but minor like the pork belly steam bun was really dried out, I didn't like the satay chicken stick and one of my sushi pieces had crunchy rice.    Dessert wise, the buttscotch budino was really good. I had a few cookies and brownies and whoopie pies that were good as well, but that was the standout item.   Service was alright. Our drinks were refilled for the most part in good time. We weren't in a hurry and were distracted talking anyways.   It's not the largest buffet and gets overshadowed by Cosmo's Wicket Spoon next door, but I thought it was pretty solid. Nothing was really bad, which I can't even say for my experience at WS so if you're staying here at the Aria, I don't think it's a bad idea to try it out.

7Wk340FTdVRPCL724x05uw.text: I would have given this place four stars, but the price (my bad bro, who suggested Monte Carlo, but as an Elite Yelper I felt compelled to try a new place).  They had complimentary lobster which also saved this place!!!!

o-v9ggb8QbBFK0cjWqj3-Q.text: Not what I was really expecting from a Vegas buffet. Food was just ehhh, meats were sitting out for a while, you could see the harden layer above everything that was sitting out. I thought Vegas buffet's were supposed to be jaw dropping good.

HmAOOBxE1pxW3PZRAqC3Ig.text: With all of the buffets on the Strip, there isn't a lack of destinations to choose from.  However, considering how much I like Aria, I figured that their buffet would have to be on my list of spots to check out.  After all, if their buffet can match the hotel, then it must be pretty decent right?  So, after checking out their menu and being decently satisfied, some of my friends and I ended up coming on a Thursday night to give them a shot.    After paying and making our way in, I already started to get an ominous feeling though.  Now, I don't know about you...but I generally get worried when I start having doubts before I even make it to my seat.  Why so worried?  Well, although the spaciousness of the dining area might have had something to do with it, the buffet seemed pretty empty to me.  Though I didn't expect it to be a madhouse like how it is at some Asian buffets, I figured there would at least be a steady stream of people shuttling back and forth between the food and their tables.  In this case, not so much.   Refreshing as it was to be able to reach for the serving utensil without someone right on my ass waiting for me to finish, it made me wonder if all those missing people knew something I didn't.    Like most Vegas buffets, they have a decent variety of selections to cover just about every diner that should pass through the place.  From the usual buffet staples to Asian selections to Mexican food, they cover a lot of territory.  The question isn't so much what you want, but what is worth eating - like your choices, the quality varies as well.  For the most part, the food is fine - nothing terrible, but nothing that drives you back up there for seconds or thirds.  The Mexican food was pretty bad, though I like the chips and guacamole/salsa bar.  Then again, at a Vegas buffet, that's probably not the sort of thing you want to be chasing.    Among the few things that were of note, I thought that the prime rib was better than average for a buffet.  The seasoning on the outside was pretty good, and it was still juicy and tender.  The star though, if you're a fan, is the fresh crab legs they have.  Haven't seen all of the buffets in Vegas, but it's one of the few that I recall seeing crab legs at, and it's certainly the best that comes to mind.  They were very fresh and tasted great, and it's always handy when they slice it all the way through so it's easier to pick the meat out.  Hassle free crab legs?  Sign me up please!  All in all, the buffet isn't terrible, and it's definitely worth checking out if you like crab legs.  Just that in Vegas, with so many other choices (relatively) close, you're probably better off heading over to Cosmopolitan or Wynn.

Z5W5IPXPAzv2AgzPdofC5A.text: I like their seafood selections: tiger shrimps and crab legs. The Chinese food doesn't have many varieties and the quality was not impressive neither. The sushi was not great but still okay. The panini was good in my opinion but I am not that much into panini so I might be wrong about it. Overall it's a good buffet place considering the price is fair and the selections are good. I will return to this buffet in the future!

Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cheese

2eAUamf4zLZXuYQaMtCshQ.text: I haven't yet been able to try the food but the service is awful. I have been in line for almost 45 minutes and have watch as two work refuse to bus table circling around them and not doing anything. I blame this on poor management!! If you are going to try to have a high in buffet in a "higher end" hotel pay someone to make sure it is ran right. I hope the food is better than the line if I make it.

JaQUwovk-YyEcPYPVljvZg.text: Similar to my Aria hotel review, I'm already a little bias since the friends I was staying with are VIPs.  Thus, no wait :)   I thought it was OK - for brunch.  Bacchanal Buffet at Caesar's is definitely way better.  Again, it has several stations for different cuisines - asian (dim sum, noodles, rice, etc.) meats (sausage, ham), omelets (make your own), desserts (cookies, cakes, ice cream), bread, seafood (crab legs), pizza.  I'm pretty sure I've left out a bunch of other goodies, but my suggestion to you is to go to Bacchanal if you want to try the best buffet in Vegas.

sByDaI5x0hR1Hx0VQgET4A.text: Basic... Normal Vegas buffet, all flavored blend together, most items are pretty dry... The reason I gave 3 stars is because it wasn't busy and it was fairly cheap about 25$ a person... Just meh

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Basic

luiq6qj8my48iAOyWxaCgw.text: The selection was not satisfying. The sushi was not fresh and I can tell the sushi was refrigerated because the rice was hard. The crab legs were salty, I assume they boiled it in salt water. Not worth it to come.

2_jBld-XkIAuSAW2yctkhw.text: I've eaten at a lot of buffets in Las Vegas.  This has got to be one of the best.  It was not crowded when I got there.  The food is freshly made and tasted great.  The service was impeccable.  I have to reiterate that the best part of the buffet is the freshness and the great selection/variety of food.    You have your selection of seafood, fresh tossed salad just the way you want it, crab legs, oysters, prime rib/turkey, cooked food, asian station, soups, and a incredible dessert bar.  I wanted to go back again before I left Las Vegas, but didn't find the time.

aZuQz19wByi1BxFpyhgglA.text: We went there on Wednesday lunch  Pros: 1. Reasonable price for the selection. $19.95 2. Clean/bright inside 3. Small selections were they were all good. 4. Dessert was excellent 5. Service was excellent  Cons: 1. Nothing really. Maybe they could've improved sushi selections.

4QbyB1ARuPVI6T5lSubyFw.text: Shrimp cocktail was awesome. Their dessert was amazing. Crab legs were okay. Paris has the best crab legs still.  Soups were great. Everything else was okay, nothing you can't get at Wynn or Belagio.  Dinner time you pay more but you get lobster :)

eVZDhx1nOJthPYfxSq601Q.text: I have dined here twice for DINNER, on two separate occasions, and I must say I am a fan. Who wouldn't want complimentary lobster and wine! Sure the Merlot, which is my choosing, is a teeny wee bit on the dry side, it still is good. Their crab legs are definitely tasty too since they don't throw a bunch of salt on it like other buffets do. And their salmon nigiri is always fresh and delish! I loveeee salmon, and salmon nigiri is like jackpot! Their prime rib is cooked well, more on the medium rare side, my preference. It's not dry like other buffets and seasoned quite well, which is impressive. They have a make it yourself pasta section where you choose the noodles, sauce and meat. I don't eat the mexican and chinese food sections since I detest chinese food and I eat mexican food in San Jose on a daily basis. Their dessert section is ok, but after eating their food, dessert is tooo filling. Maybe add macaroons to your dessert selection? =)

skmAapORt9qpgeCFa0CG4g.text: 2 visits on same trip.  The Buffett at the Bellagio is the accepted head of class.  The Aria Hotel in City Centre is very un Vegas. Think clean, cool lines and textures. The Buffet carries the theme. Due new on the strip no huge, stomach rumbling lines at dinner. Nope walk right in on weekday visit and weekend visit. If you are a supersize me kinda of diner well this will not be the place for you.  Here the buffett doesnot carry the huge selection of the Bellagio, not even close. But what it has here is well done and for the most part tasty. There is an Indian station that one night had tikka massala chicken and another fish jalfrazie and would you beleive a naan oven right in front. Roast Beef, Lamb, Turkey, Pork. A smattering of pastas. A fish or two. Weekend as with hotel rooms and buffets means higher prices. Aria does it different in that they offer each person paying the Friday and Saturday ransom gets table service of a lobster tail plus a glass or your choice red or white.   The tail is not your New England crustacean but more like Naw 'leans crayfish.   Aria gets good marks for trying.  The deserts, though small in  variety compared to the massive sweets of say, the Bellagio's, is actually better tasting and visually more appealing.  Super sized? Nope. Fine dining? Nope. But less feeding frenzy and a good attempt at raising the buffet bar.

8LRu0pBHcm0aHcQ9ZHaWoQ.text: Not the value for the price, it was just okay. Not expected from such a nice hotel. There wasn't alot people there, didn't even have to wait in line which was good. The prime rib had a littel too much salt that mde it hard to eat. The crab legs and shirmp cocktail wasn't anything special but nice to have for lunch. The dessert station had a lot of treats but only 2 or 3 items got raving reviews. Everything just seems either bland or overly done.

7RL80GlsBt8uaI9UmTs91Q.text: I live in vegas so I have basically been to all of them. My mom and I decided to try the "Gourmet" buffet at Aria because it said they give a 1# lobster per table and we LOVE lobster! Lets just say the food was just average and the lobster we got was pretty cold and wasnt cleaned so it still had all the green yuck inside it which made us not eat it except the tail part. For $40 a person its just not worth it. The service we had was terrible and the "all u cand rink wine" is a joke u only get a choice of white or red wine. I go to M resorts buffet and get much better food and can choose an assortment of wines and beers all u can drink!

vithgZ5VEKPf3koBkhPu7w.text: Do not go here. The Aria hotel is beautiful site and a must spot to visit, but the buffet is the worst I have had  in Las Vegas (I am a local). I went with a small group and ran into friends. The buffet would not let us sit next to each other, or even the same section unless we paid an additional 18% which would have been $60 dollars - just to sit at a table next to our friends (several were open).  The service was really poor from the check-in to the server (who only showed up once the whole time).  To top it off the food was poor even by buffet standard, especially the sushi. Tried to have an open mind but even the prime rib was overcooked and thin, the salad had been siting so long it was soggy. So many better options- do yourself a favor and don't go back..   They are the first restaurant I have ever thought was so bad I would give a negative review.

Q9VOOr1Flzw2J9l_C7Brig.text: paid 40 dollars each person on Thanksgiving day, no lobsters, no salmon, nothing could eat, Steaks were dried out, snow crabs were not fresh at all and felt sick of it.  Overall food sucks and desserts disgusted.  really really disappointed, will not go there again.

XgXpgn_DkcoyLhipyI1kfg.text: Went there over the weekend for dinner as this was a new buffet in LV.   They adverstised unlimited wine and half of a Maine lobster tail to be included along with your $36.95 entrance fee.    The decor was more like a high school cafeteria.  Quite a let down for such a high end casino.  The service at the table was alright, but the waittress appeared overwhelmed at times.  Thus, service was intermittent.  The service at the stations, especially grilled meats, was horrendous.  The server was condensing and obnoxious.  We were afterall paying for the food (actually too much!)... just serve it over already.    The food selection was quite skimpy. Quality of the grill meat was satisfactory.  Otherwise, there was nothing else worth checking out, except for the sweets.  The lobster, small as it was, was tasty, but missing one of its claws.  We had two lobsters at our table and they were each missing a claw.  Someone at our table thought that the missing claws most likely ended up in the lobster ravioli's they were serving that night.  The red wine was mediocre but the white wine was decent.    I would recommend going to the Bellagio buffet instead eventhough that has also diminished in quality over the years.  You get more bang for your buck, nicer service, and better decor.

LT_ot9J8x2XGnJaqfGvnXA.text: Beaufriend and I went to this buffet wanting to try something new. Oh man, what a waste of $$! Buffet has very little selection of food! Panda Express has better selection and better tasting food than the Asian food they have laying out in this buffet. Italian food section-they only have fettuccine alfredo that looked like no one has touched. They also have 2-3 diff kind of pizza. Poor guy behind the make your own pasta station looked like he's begging people to make him cook for you. His station looked so plain that you won't even really notice him there. Dessert area, from what most of the reviews I've read..I really thought they would have a lot of selection! Wrong! I guess comparing it to the Wynn buffet...The Buffet at Aria is nothing!   Maybe the only good thing they have here is that they serve Indian food which you don't normally see in buffets. Also, they have good size shrimp cocktails.   The Buffet at Aria...never again. Sorry.

U_FLl0CLLNbyJTg_H6o7Qg.text: This was our first buffet in Vegas. The decor is modern, beautiful, and sleek just like everything at Aria. Food was ok though. We paid  about $35 per person before tip. The food was disappointing. Had the crab claws- was ok - I felt that they sat there for awhile and it wasn't refilled enough. Had the shrimp cocktail - two big shrimps in a small shot glass- pretty presentation and good since the size of shrimp was big. Everything else was cold. We went on to dessert and was not impressed. I had the flan and it was ok. Our waitress was just ok- we had to wait awhile to get drinks. Btw, you pay at first and then get seated. The cashier asked if we wanted unlimited alcohol for $12.99 and based on what I saw I declined. When we we were seated, they had more details about the drinks unbeknownst to me so I wanted to order that. The waitress said because I didn't order at beginning, it would cost an extra $1- what's up with that? Not like the buffet was cheap. By the time she came around, I was full and didn't want to order any drinks. Would not go back again. Go to Ceasar's buffet, more expensive but totally worth it!

q7WaICvEIo7horBb86CE_Q.text: We got a complimentary buffet pass so we decided to use it here since it was right next to Vdara. Let's just say I wasnt impressed with their selection at all. They seem to offer a nice greasy variety for breakfast and for lunch it was random. We must have walked several rounds around the buffet trying to figure out what we should eat not because we were overwhelmed with the selection but because I couldn't figure what to eat with some of the selections they offered. Their mixed salads were extremely soggy and flavorless so there goes my excuse for attempting to eat healthy. I think I would give their dinner buffet a try next time but skipping out on their brunch since the selection was not too impressive during our experience.

nVKdJkVINKQHsSvzxOdYWg.text: sorry the place is not good. the pros is that is looks clean and that is very good. but the bad thing is that the food is consstently COLD. everythign that seems to be a hot dish is actually cold or lukewarm. GROSS. the best thing about this place is that they offer a bottomless drink service for 2 hours i think and it's really good prosecco/sangria or champagne. other than that, the place sucks. it  is very clean. if they just would make sure all the items were actually hot or atleast warm that would be good.

rH-AzHzd0_83A9IchPbJJA.text: This place deserves a 3 star for its dessert alone. But I can't ignore the rest of the buffet menu. It has wider range of selections such as those mentioned in other reviews here. However, I suppose that's what happens when a cheaper price tag focuses on too many items.

QJ4rMLETCih2nWUq3_dd9A.text: Went for dinner and the food is very standard. The facility is nice. The crab and prime rib are delicious!

SK3WfvXwtxrlpL1x20dtmQ.text: Sometimes, a buffet isn't just about the food.   In fact, the food here is very good.   But, I paid about $75 for brunch for two (one had a bloody mary, so that added to the price a little).   It was crowded in the seating area--and really, really crowded at the omlette station.  It was maybe a $45 experience.

1iOsmLbeGWlG4QhhqVpm3Q.text: Food Poisoning.  Ate at the buffet around 9 pm, woke up early the next morning with FOOD POISONING.  Spent the next 2 days of my vegas vacation in the hotel room bathroom.  Thanks ARIA.

q0apHHfCjPYXsRsnwyfHLg.text: I was in Vegas for the long weekend (July 4th).  Stayed in Vdara which is located kind of in the middle of Bellagio and Aria.  In this trip I tried both buffets at Bellagio and Aria (paid about $35 at each place for brunch).  Summary - Avoid Aria!!  Bellagio was 100 times better than Aria's buffet.  PROS: Nothing special.   CONS: Slow service.  Too expensive.  Limited choice.

wC7Yb9nR-G4z_urlhjDIvw.text: the food was just mediocre gelato ice cream was good i would not recommend this place for buffet

4ZO8xIue5LzNPWD6cZnGCA.text: As Las Vegas buffets go, it's OK. My most recent visit to Aria included two comp buffets, so it was a good deal. But it would have cost almost $80 for two of us on a Friday night - that would not have been worth it.  Service was good - waitress greeted us with a smile and was usually pretty available - or her counterpart was. Never wanted for beverages.  For the size of their buffet area, the selection is somewhat small. It's really best to walk through the whole thing first to determine what you want for dinner.   Good sushi, decent desserts - but not too much stands out there. My brother loved this place - preferred it over Bellagio. I disagree.

RCW6gQ_kSJc3oDsq9j9BBw.text: Dinner starts at 3pm and is about $38 per person... which is WAY too pricey for the quality and taste of the food. There is an adequate variety of food but nothing is ~great~ just okay. The service is pretty bad too. I had to wait about 20 min to get my water refilled, they didn't clear our plates for a while, and our server seemed as if she didn't care about anything or anyone. Honestly, if you're coming to Vegas on vacation, I think it's smarter to just go to Caesars Palace. It might cost a little more but I'm sure you'll get better food and better service. I do not recommend this place!!

zLcZ2TF_PinkfV-GrkFycg.text: For $32 a person, this place was a little over-rated.   Everyone seemed to go for the crab legs but they had so little meat in them, you'd need to grab a dozen just to have a decent sized portion. The sushi was awful (they only had 3 selections of rolls and the only difference being the spice on top), the "fresh" bread was dried out and stale, and they didn't seem to restock on anything until it was all gone (meaning that it took them a while to bring out more). The pesto pasta was good, but it was the only pasta available besides some kind of Chinese noodle pasta. The pizza was also good but unless you get a slice right as they brought it out, it would get cold really fast (the heating plates didn't seem to work very well).  Its like they randomly selected a bunch of different food and hoped it was diverse enough to attract more people.   I had 4 glasses of soda but it only equaled to about 2 glasses because they stuffed so much ice in it.  If you're going to spend a lot on a meal, its probably better to go to a nice restaurant instead of taking a chance on a buffet.

pcBINzlqhhLf-_GpMxo6lA.text: I've eaten at many a buffet in Las Vegas but not necessarily a lot of the higher-end buffets such as Bellagio's.  Mostly this is due to the high cost of eating there when I would rather spend that money on a single entree at a regular restaurant.  Last night I had the pleasure of attending the pre-opening of Aria with all meals and casino play comp'd.  We had the choice of either the cafe or the buffet.  Since there was a huge line to the cafe, we chose to head upstairs and see what was offered.  The buffet is very attractive physically with different levels to the seating area as you move through the room.  The serving area surrounds the room, starting with salad and seafood and moving through the typical, yet sophisticated buffet faire.  It ends with the dessert area which is less substantial than many buffets but did have some good treats.  The food ranges from crab legs and shrimp to veal bollanaise (at least on this particular night), from hummus to asian noodles.  Again, much of the same stuff I've found at the Palms buffet or Wynn's.  Compared to Wynn's buffet, the Aria does not compare in choice for dinner or selection in desserts.  The food was of high quality at Aria but not worth the $30 after taxes it will cost for a dinner here.  Perhaps after the grand opening the selections will change.  There are some issues with people lining up for the seafood when they may not realize you don't have to wait to move around the rest of the room; a bottleneck that almost ends up having people lining up near the entryway.  I would probably come here again only if the meal was comp'd.  If I were a guest at the Aria this would be a good choice for a buffet as there is nothing else within walking distance from the casino (perhaps Bellagio but I've never eaten there) that would be any better, but maybe the walk will build up an appetite that any food can resolve.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. From my seat

x4y5fI3P1kMh3e408P0h6A.text: I saw a full page magazine advertisement offering local couples a special price of $30.00 at The Buffet. The advertisement stated that the offer expired on March 31st and was not valid on holidays. We decided to go there for dinner on Saturday night. I attempted to purchase the $30.00 special and was told that the offer was not valid because the Friday and Saturday before Easter were considered a holiday weekend. I ended up paying $103.80 for mediocre food and service!

Gbpohmexuuk89ZSM_ZK8mg.text: The food was AMAZING here.  The crab legs were so good, their Mexican station was great, the seafood station was so good. The Fried chicken was very good. Your going to be spending about $40 on the weekend and about $25 during the weekdays. $12.99 for unlimited wine, and beer. The only negative thing is that the service was slow and removing the dirty plates from the table and getting your actual drinks. The actual servers weren't to friendly which can make it weird at times, but who cares food was great. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone.

IypAY6oMTRt10GMjEVg2Hw.text: Luckily this was the first buffet we went to on our Vegas trip because otherwise, I would have been even more disappointed!! First of all, they don't have a wide variety of foods at all compared to some of the other better Vegas buffets... All of the food is categorized, which made it easy to find everything, but there wasn't a big selection in each category. I found the foods I tried to be OK, but nothing amazing. I had the Indian, Mexican, Japanese, and "American" foods (sweet potatoes, casserole), but nothing really stood out. The dim sum was dried out, and the Indian food wasn't very authentic tasting. Some of the foods weren't even hot, just warm. The desserts were pretty good, but the "gelato" was really just regular ice cream that you can buy in the supermarket. The worst part was the service... our server brought us each one drink and when we immediately finished them (they give you TINY glasses!!) she avoided eye contact and rushed by us many times, until I literally had to grab her sleeve to ask for another drink. She seemed annoyed that I was asking for a refill. They also didn't come by often enough to take our plates, which is a given at a buffet! We paid $45 each (with taxes and tip) which did not seem worth it... the taste and quality just did not measure up. I don't know how this buffet stays in business.  I agree with the others who have said that Aria is a 5 star resort and this buffet is very disappointing. It is NOT what you'd expect after spending time in the rest of Aria. My husband and I also had high hopes for this buffet, and it failed us! The buffet at Caesar's was amazing.. there's no comparison.

HSMKOPN9Asek7zbqZlpZXg.text: Love the aria buffet.  During my 11 day stay in vegas my girlfriend and I went 3 times and loved it every time. The food is well cooked and seasoned, they refresh the bowls really fast, service was super friendly,  and the variety was amazing.  Recommend going on the weekend for the gourmet menu food is really really great.

rdZiwlRXrPdjztqEe3eBmg.text: Buffet's are kind of hard to write a pro/con table for but i'll try my best, fitting different foods into the lists.  Pros: -Very clean, ample light, new  -Unlimited crab legs and smoked salmon (I think I could have just eaten an entire lunch of these). Although the crab legs were a tad salty in my opinion -DESERTS, where do I start? Every desert, aside from the Creme Brule was spectacular. I especially enjoyed the extra strong mocha icecream and the strawberry cheese cake. My sister had the German chocolate cake which she said was equally as good.  -The tofu spinach soup was really good, too bad I added too much Sriracha for my tastebuds to handle -Make your own pasta bar: say your combination of sauce and toppings and they whip you up a fresh bowl of hot pasta -The lines inside were nonexistent even though we came it at 12:30 -Waitress bussing the drinks was very polite and quick at clearing out unwanted dishes  Cons: -Drink selection is sort of limited or not properly advertised -$20/person for lunch is a little steep but it's Vegas, everything is expensive... -Some of the food seemed oversalted, i don't know if this is their way of making it keep longer but I found the chicken salad too salty to handle.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

FICDpp5pCsw7tbpCXQDgNg.text: This Buffet looks new and neat. But the price is Ridic high. The food isnt all that, there was only few good food. Also,some of the workers there are rude. When they get the plates, they leave the utensils on the table without putting it on any plates or tissue. Sorry but i will not go back here. Hotel is 5 star tho!

OuX_LOfOAtRkZtL8tU-guQ.text: As foody and picky like me, I think this place worth at least 4 stars. Lots of fresh seafood, and many of the dishes are pretty good.  The deserts are a must to eat, especially tiramisu and sugar free strawberry gelato (taste like fresh picked). I give them 4 stars because not all food created equal in quality and tasty, and they even charge my 8 years old daughter full price, who ate only very little.

0VepFFGpHCyL4n9AzCPubg.text: The place where 4 hour buffet happened.  5 girls ate from lunch til dinner and changed server 3 times. I don't remember what exactly we ate...but I knew we sure ate all of our money's worth.  Best part: maracons for desserts.  Devine left over cookies and naans at 3am post clubbing.  I didn't wear stretchy pants, but I think the food has digested long before we went clubbing at HAZE.  Best bang for your buck...$20 lunch that lasted til dinner time.

55EkMnxrz-7nm0kgB2mDEQ.text: I am here for lunch and am completely overwhelmed with the selection and variety of food.  Sushi, crab, meat, cheese, salad, Chinese, Latin, it's crazy!  For lunch I am impressed. I can't possibly eat enough! The buffet overlooks the pool too, so there is a lot of natural light which is nice. Come for lunch you won't be disappointed.

zjQJ1Uu67zxkK6gzreIsLQ.text: Had an early dinner here one Saturday night. $86 for two people. Did not get off to a good start. Seems that we were in the wrong line to pay (prior to being seated) and were barked at by a staff member to stay behind the sign. Once seated, had to wait for about 15 mins before a drink order was taken. Waitress really nice and working at full pace, but clearly not enough staff on. Food was fine and a number of different types - Italian, Carvery, Chinese, Indian, Mexican etc. some staff serving meals -- pasta and Carvery sections were very grumpy indeed. Overall, a very mediocre experience.

nkUoFkM-4QLr9pf35M21Gw.text: This buffet is neither worth $42+ in quality nor quality. There are many buffets on the strip that offer greater quality and selection at cheaper prices. Most of the food looks artistic enough, but the taste seldom matches up. The fresh crab legs, stewed oxtails, pork carnitas and linzer tarts are good, but the pizza, sushi, "beignets", "dim sum" and antipasti, are not items I would willingly pay for anywhere else. I also don't think I should be paying $40 for three different variations of scrambled eggs with cheese. (And if I was, the eggs could, at the very least, not be overcooked.)  The pros of eating at Aria though, consist of (1.) the pre-sliced/cracked crab legs, (2.) the modern, clean ambiance, (3.) the ease in which the buffet can accommodate a party of 16+, and (4.) the lack of lines.

c4lf_BOL4XnzPEhGwU3ZTw.text: Had a comp for 2 dinners thanks to my Vegas on Facebook. I had high hopes because its Aria...what a major let down. Even at no out out of pocket cost other than tip, this place sucked. We got there fairly early for dinner and I was excited for a free yummy meal.....major disappointment. The pizza looked like it had sat out all day and when they finally put out a fresh one, the crust was limp and not cooked through. The brisket was dry and all the food I tried was under seasoned. Ate at the bellagio buffet the night before an hour before closing and was worried the food would not be fresh...not the case...the best buffet food I've ever had....skip Aria and hit up Bellagio instead. You won't regret it.

nAWWAJh7zEsncTjWg5zjHw.text: Mediocre. Lots of average and below average options.   The bad: Sushi Oysters (Most seafood)  The OK: Cheese & meats Indian food Carving station Chinese food Desserts  The good: Ice cream  Overall, not worth the $40 a person that they're charging for a bunch of mediocre stuff. You'll be better off going with another great Vegas dining option.

GYjFTvWx7bERGdsYrpfPtQ.text: I wasn't sure a five-star buffet was even possible, but Aria's Buffet changed my mind on that. I'm normally way too cheap to pay $38 for a dinner buffet, but my friend offered to pay 1/2 my bill, and buy us a bottle of wine on his work tab. How could I refuse?  You know what? I *would* have paid $38, and I would have been happy about it. The ambiance in the room is excellent - light and bright, but not aggressively so. My friend and I spent a good 2 hours there and could have easily spent more.  Service was top-notch and a bottle of bubbly cost us about $35 - not a bad deal in Vegas. And the food? Oh, the food. Everything I tasted was delicious, and the desserts were divine, and perfectly portion-sized. I'll be back. Oh yes, Buffet at Aria - I'll be back.

lpMFBZSY1-Do9csq0P4uyw.text: Pretty decent buffet. Overall the food was good but not great. I'm allergic to seafood but my boyfriend said the crab was the best out of everything there. I enjoyed the beef bourguignon looking meat and the fried rice. Glad I only paid $35 after I used my MyVegas reward for the BOGO here.

hlG--Mg5K2MqNhjQ2pA1Mw.text: For 2 of us for dinner it was approx. $80.00, but we both left feeling like we would have been better spending $10.00 at In-N-Out! It wasn't that the food was inedible, it just was very lackluster. I guess if money is no object and your legs won't take any further than here...that would be the only time I could recommend this buffet.

fFp8Vgox1y41hUkVXqnO9Q.text: Went for dinner on a Monday night.. got there at 7:30pm..waited in line and then waited and waited and waited looked at my watch and was finally seated at 8:50pm!! Can't believe I waited that long for this buffet. $38.99 for dinner! Headed for seafood and crab legs and claws were dry and some were unedible. Mediterranean station was good and fresh naan bread was delicious. Didnt try anything else other than the desserts which was just ok too.. probably would not come back here unless I get a comp..

26ZKk17sXvwbhZceG4gv0A.text: We use to eat here a lots. But lately here cutting short on foods to choose. Foods are cooked with too much salts. Eating seafoods, prime rib and almost all other main courses just like you are earning salts. Soups are just like salts water. No sushi serving at all. Over pricing for the foods that they serve.

Z6FzSrDVxzgWfuMvneEF2A.text: The atmosphere is beyond modern and the breakfast buffet or really brunch has many options for a decent sized buffet. They have signs that differentiate the sections of the buffet which I greatly appreciate. They serve dimsum in the morning and the roast beef was beyond amazing in flavor. The service is quick and a good variety overall!

doQvL21r1Pj45tenyZslrg.text: Our family love this place and we came here a lot whenever we visit Vegas!   Just tonight tho, there is this lady without her name tag at the front desk yell at me and my family simply because we did not wait at the "proper place" while we are waiting to be seated. She yelled at us telling us to stand behind the line because there is only one exit AS THE SIGN said. ( I feel offended cuz she said it in the way as it we CAN'T READ) However, what she did not know is that The main reason we stand outside the line is that whenever we came here after paying the meal at the front desk, they always asked us to stand in front of the line so ppl behind us can pay their bill.  Even if she don't want us to stand over there, she should NOT yell at us !!   There are a group of well dress family in front of us stand at exactly same place as where we were and she didn't say anything.  Idk if she just have a bad day or she is racist or what ... SHE SHOULD NOT YELL AT THE CUSTOMERS!   I THOUGHT ARIA VALUE CUSTOMER SERVICES AND I AM DISAPPOINTED!

eWKMgfj34_AP5Ddka2XdYw.text: Wow very impressed with the selection and more importantly the freshness of the food and ingredients.   Are you in to sushi? Thai food? Chinese? Indian? Italian? American? They have it all!   Salads preprepared and a Salad bar for vegetarian/Vegans that want to create their own salad to their personal liking.   Top it all off with fresh fruits and an entire section dedicated to those with a sweet tooth.   Ambiance and staff were just as good as the food. Overall a great value. I can see how some would spend hours here. Very Highly Recommended!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. more nice decor
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. look up when you walk in thats what you&#39;ll see, great decor!

CX0n7lejAz_MfdGyaorBtw.text: The food was pretty good, but I was underwhelmed.  Honestly, I expected more "WOW" from the Buffet at ARIA in Vegas.  Instead I got A-Ok with no wow factor.  Came here with some friends for dinner.  Only about a 5 minute wait so our timing was good.  There was a long line by the time we left 2 hours later.  Dining area was clean and well lit.  Service was efficient.  I imagined there would be plenty of food stations here similar to Rio's World Carnivale Buffet.  My imagination was incorrect because the selection was not too plentiful.  Still as long as the quality of the food was great, I would be more than happy.  Quality was 3.5 stars in my opinion.  Everything from the crab legs to the ribs to the veggies to the desserts are worth trying.  Maybe my expectations were too high.  I hate it when a restaurant doesn't meet my expectations!  Oh well.  I would give them another go in the future.  I won't be expecting as much so there is a good chance this review will be updated some day.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cheesecake looked really good, but was underwhelmed with the taste.
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chocolate Peanut Butter Cake was okay.
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Sweets!

6TKz-Z6prIIPYNzO4eHxUA.text: This place is better than bacchanal at the Ceasars. Usually food at Buffett's looks good but taste is ok... here everything is good! Service was excellent. Great crab leg selection.

GimOzFApzSHPfaag73YIow.text: Highlight here and many other buffets in Vegas is there seafood, specifically the King Crab. The available selection was very small and crab meat was dried and freezer burn. Bottomless drink is not worth the money as very few options available and waiter took a long time to bring you a drink. Ended up have one glass of cheap sparkling wine the entire dinner. Lots of food options but most were not very well done. The only thing I thought was decent was their rack of lamb, moist and soft.  Skip the buffet and have a damn good dinner elsewhere.

OGT8ZjWwJ1gQCeszey7LqA.text: My date and I decided to go here for the dinner buffet. We got there a little early and they still had some of the brunch food out. The brunch selection pretty much sucked lol. 80% Asian food, 10% diversity and 10% dessert. The dinner selection was much better than brunch.   We upgraded to the unlimited drinks while we were there but it was extremely hard to order a drink. From the time we got our first drink to the time we saw the waitress again it had been about a hour.   I will definitely go to a different buffet next time.

ORNl8cntkTPCt00oesF68A.text: So good, they have upped their game. Mediterranean foods were awesome, desserts were delicious and the spinning gelato was fun and tasty.  Highly recommend!

ZaY7XKjkjLOPbxYekp9Uuw.text: We have been to the Aria Buffet many times over the past 8 or 9 years, but I was a bit complacent sharing reviews on Yelp! until recently.  During our most recent stay, Jan 8-13, 2017, we decided the late morning was a great fit for the plans we'd made on 2 days.  We were greeted warmly at the front check-in and our servers were wonderfully attentive on both on both occasions, this trip AND previously.    I am a big fan of hot tea, and it's the caffeine I just really must have to get my day off to a great start.  I know hot tea is a pain for a server because there is a separate pot of water, tea bags, etc. On both visits, our servers NEVER let my hot tea pot become empty!  Both were ahead of my requests when I'd finish a pot of tea, and had a new hot water and tea bag ready to serve.  This may sound very minimal, but to me, it's HUGE.  In some restaurants, this is not the case and I am lucky to see another pot of tea; but at the Aria,  my tea never ran dry. Thank you for feeding my caffeine needs!  The buffet was lovely.  I don't go to a buffet to eat a ton of food; I go to get a 'little of this' and 'a little of that' and Aria buffet has such a great selection of lovely fresh prepared foods from all over the world, so my little of this and that became a world food event.  For me, it's about QUALITY and SELECTION, not the quantity of food I can eat to just stuff myself for the day ahead.  My favorite thing on the buffet at Aria is the butternut squash bisque.  It is to die for!  Rich, creamy and the taste....INCREDIBLE!  Most people don't eat soup at a buffet; in my opinion, the butternut squash is an absolute MUST TRY for everyone. It is excellent.  The 'beef steamship' is really tasty.  Craved fresh and the taste is amazing.  While the buffet has an enormous selection, as I said, I just want a little of this and that, so I could not try everything.  My husband had the Chili Verde and said it was the best he'd ever had, anywhere, ever.  We've been all over the world, and he's a real taste-master when it comes to Chili Verde, so for him to give it that review, it must be great. If you are into Chili Verde, this one is a must to try.  I tried a few items from the Asian style buffet and everything was tasty and served hot. The Shu Mai was delicious and worth each bite.  The pork buns were great, too, as was the rice, but the rice not quite as sticky as Chinese rice.    The station with foods of India was nice, but I don't go for that curry flavor too often, so that one I skipped, though it smelled and looked delicious.  The seafood station featured mounds piled high of fresh shrimp and crab legs!  Beautifully displayed and great tasting.   The fresh green beans were excellent and cooked  to perfection.  I've made eggs Benedict at home for my hubby, but never had tried it until Buffet at Aria.  I loved it!!!  Cooked to perfection!  There were so many other choices at other stations, but as I said, I just could not eat that much and I know I missed a lot of great tasting foods.  The dessert station is ridiculous!!!  So many choices, all of them amazing.  I know my daughter loves the gellato bar.  I saw it, but just could not fit in another bite.  There is a lovely layered chocolate mousse bar which I found absolutely delicious and the perfect ending to my meal.  Here's a tip that is for everyone.  If you want to just linger over coffee/tea and you know you just don't want to chow-down and rush off, we find it good to give a nice gratuity to your server at a buffet PRIOR to eating.  This practice has always served us well at any buffet.  Many times customers overlook the server, which I think is very wrong.  We tip our server when our drinks arrive and then explain that we will be there to enjoy our coffee and talk a bit, providing there are not lines of people waiting to be seated.  Our servers have ALWAYS been delighted and also accommodate us in every possible way.  Sure, you go to Vegas to have fun and win, right?  Well, we see winning over a very busy server to be a big win.  It makes the server's day better and it's a nice enjoyable time for us.  I know the mindset of some is 'well, I am serving myself so why tip?'  That thinking is WRONG.  The servers are there refilling your drinks, taking empty plates and making your experience the best it can be.  A meal is an event; part of your Vegas experience!  Tip your server well AHEAD of when you leave and you will enjoy a lovely, unhurried meal.  Trust me, if there are 2 in your party, a $20 pre-meal tip will go further than you can imagine.
