The carving station had something called "cowboy beef" which turned out to be a dried tough roast.  The rest of the selections were also dry and looked over cooked like it was sitting under the heating lamp all day.  For the price I would have expected to have prime rib which they have served in the past.  What gives Aria? The only saving grace was our waitress that brought the drinks, she was so nice and fast thus the two stars.  Overall I would say don't waste your money, go to the Wynn or Caesars for a good buffet.  Needless to say we will not be back.

i03wz1CxPmZCkzdwPUywoQ.text: We were staying at Aria week of March 12. As a person with Celiac Disease, it was a sheer delight to eat at the buffet! Chef Seff (apology if spelled your name wrong) took me around the buffet and pointed out every dish that I could have. 90% of the items are the buffet were made from scratch without modified food starches, corn fillers. Butter was real butter! Thank you for making my vacation and stay with you complete Jackie Bridges

s8Il49V39DnruyPpKmMQDg.text: Diversity  quality  service  cleanliness  decoration atmosphere prices $$$  flavor... nothing that makes someone to impress!!!...

N-su29AyQTinWVGZyb6Mmg.text: The only reason  I'm  giving  two stars  was the staff was great but the food wasn't  the lettuce  salad was hot the rest  of the food was just short of being cold I was very disappointed I payed  $100.00 for two of us .and walked away wishing I had gone to Mc Donalds

ZmuxsfWDlLAn3HmAOvlXGA.text: The amount of entrees and dessert is insane. Enjoyed the wide array of food from various regions of the world.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. A small sample of the dessert at the buffet

YcIzbUPy4jWXAmxO2x3Xtw.text: Everything was delightful. My only complaint was that we dined on a Friday morning (August 29th) for Brunch, and they had already upped the price for the 'holiday' - Labor Day was Monday, September 1st.  $39 for a Brunch is a bit steep, considering most buffets on the Strip charge this much for a Dinner. But once we sat down to eat, I comforted myself with the fact that I would soon be indulging in delightful delicacies for brekky.  Which is exactly what I did. Orange juice and coffee flowed forth on a constantly refilled basis and we had a view of the pool area and greenery which was beautiful. My first course consisted of bagels with butter and cream cheese, croissants and smoked salmon. I moved on to the eggs, bacon, sausages, carnitas (yes, for breakfast), then I dived head first into the dessert section of the brunch offerings. Waffles with bowls of freshly whipped cream, caramel flan, chocolate and vanilla gelato, chocolate and almond croissants. I bellied up to the buffet one last time for another piece of smoked salmon but they had already taken it away to prepare for the lunch items which starts at 11am.  My heart screamed No but my stomach said Yes, I've had enough. Dazed and confused, I finally made my way back to our table with a look on my face of utter satisfaction...sugar, fat, protein and caffeine induced food coma.   I also saw congee and all manner of accompaniments, dim sum, lo-mein, egg rolls, fish, a whole table dedicated to Mexican food, Italian section of pizza and pasta and I was so sad I couldn't eat another thing.   This restaurant is supremely clean, inviting, modern, neat and organized, and being inside the Aria hotel made it even more spectacular. The line was not too long even for a Friday. Since we stayed at the Aria, coming down from our room to have breakfast was a wonderful treat, instead of hiking it halfway down the Strip without so much as a drop of coffee and a parched feeling upon arrival. This was a breeze, convenient and delicious. Thanks Aria Buffet! I felt like I won the jackpot. This has become my favorite buffet on the Strip for breakfast / brunch!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bagel, croissant, almond croissant, Smoked Salmon! Cheese and butter
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dessert for breakfast: Caramel Flan (yes), Chocolate croissant, gelato, waffles and fresh cream, more OJ and coffee. Food coma.

4ipw-u6kl_zEjsY3ETTDhg.text: The customer service here let this buffet down considerably. Our waiter seemed to be making a concerted effort to ignore out attempts to gain his attention and took over twenty minutes to bring drinks even after we spoke to the manager.  Food was okay do not under any circumstances order the ramen soup at the Asian station it tastes like it was made from the same ramen college students eat. It was watered down to boot. So foul. My slice of prime rib was blue which is not my preference. The ribs were good though as were the deserts I tried except the flan which tasted like egg and the creme brulee which was sloppy.   There is a large selection and they do have hot beverages available on request. Getting your waiter to bring them is a problem

0TvuBDe_uNOZoDi1p4YCeQ.text: Everything looks beautiful and you feel like the price is worth it until you bite into the food. The food was such a dissapointment that I would not eat it for free. The gelato and all the dessert are horrible .The other restaurants in the hotel are around the same price..... more or less and the food is 2000000 better. Please avoid coming here if you are a food snob. This is on a hospital food level of nasty.

ZjChg1AirgH_n4azqZaH8Q.text: Four stars for being gluten friendly. That's pretty legit. Every little substation tells you if there are any gluten-free options in their area. It wasn't perfectly explained... meaning, you kind of have to walk around a bit to understand what you can and can't eat... but once you get the hang of it, blammo.  I don't usually use that word but I figured it was a good time to start. Blammo.  The dessert area was dope. The crab legs were a lot of work, as expected. The paella was bomb. Actually, it wasn't paella. It was jambalaya. Still. Super bomb.  Bathrooms were nice. Hostesses were kinda meh. Overall, I'd come back if I was in the ARIA and I wanted to gain five or six pounds.

1_mXbfH0t6cdPmGSEIQp5w.text: Been wanting to try one of the Vegas buffets, so this was close to us. While there was a lot to choose from, it's a typical buffet with lots to choose from and that's it. Food was plentiful but not overwhelming, and at $62 for 2, once was enough. The unlimited drinks however was a good deal at 2 for 1 for $20.

Y-MA4VmgoY2A3Jfasxpn1w.text: I went to the Aria buffet for the first time last night. I honestly can't comment on the price, as a friend paid for the dinner.  I was very impressed with the cleanliness of the place.  It was bright, and open, and very appealing.    The server was polite when taking drink orders and clearing plates.  The selection was very impressive.  Curries, sushi, pizza, meats, and LOTS of seafood.  The quality of the food was standard buffet quality, except for the seafood.  I really didn't care for any of it.  The mahi mahi was cold...not even lukewarm, but cold.  The New Zealand mussels were chewy, and the seafood jambalaya was REALLY fishy.  I was very impressed with the fact that they have so many gluten free options.  Everything is well labeled, so there really isn't much guesswork.  My favorites of the night were the salad, the risotto, all the food at the Tandoori station (curries, etc), the chicken pot stickers, and the mac n cheese. Now, I have to tell you..the pasta was WAY overcooked and it was kind of mushy, but that's how I like my "comfort food" style mac n cheese.  I actually went back for seconds.    The desert station was huge, and beautiful.  I only had room for a bite or two of cheesecake but that was good too.  I probably would not go back, because I hear that its a fairly expensive buffet, and I'm cheap.  But if you have $30-$50, the quality of the food is pretty standard.

-6RiKZmYsWz7NiBFljYvjA.text: This buffet was exceptional both times we went during brunch this past week. My husband and I were impressed with the quality and abundance of choices. The service was exactly what you would expect from a buffet. Servers were adequately attentive refilling our drinks, etc. If we went back to Vegas and stayed at the Aria again, we would certainly eat here again.

ztOF75zJe1DEo7fqno3wWw.text: I was not expecting much but this buffet was off the hook. They had a wide selection of food and it was all very fresh. All the stations were excellent and everything was very clean. This is an outstanding buffet and an outstanding Resort.

ppGwpvRe5R3AFpGxAK_jDw.text: Went here for a Monday lunch buffet. The boyfriend  and I are loyal myVegas players so we got the 2 for 1 deal. Paid $25 for 2 people.   The food was just okay, not great. Definitely not something I would crave or even consider coming back (unless it's free).   +1 for having crab legs on a weekday lunch   -1 for slow service  -1 for RUDE ice cream lady named MARIA. Accused me of leaving dirty plates by her desserts when I was just standing there looking at the ice cream choices. Even after I told her those weren't mine, she continues to accuse me and said she saw me put it there.

VQaY5p5t5FcRlsoD_yS1AA.text: The cashiers were very rude, unprofessional, and poor customer service. Aria needs to train their staff especially the cashiers. The variety of food choices are actually pretty good but the unwelcoming attitude is not worth it. We will never eat at Aria again.

-YzsDeugbuHaIxOrsshH1Q.text: Alrighty.. 42bux Friday night dinner. I enjoyed it. All the buffets are expensive.  Here's the low down. Bread..3 shallot roasted potatoes..10, Mac n cheese..10, cream corn..10, mash potatoes..10, prime rib..9, ham..8, steak..6, salad bar..6,, corn on cob..9, Indian food..5, Alaskan snow crab in garlic chili sauce..10, pizza..9,  chicken parmigiana..7, meatballs..10, baked salmon..8,  Asian food..6 too spicy, desert..6. Overall I give this place a 8 for quality and a 6.5 for value.

ZjOwJi6K8hyDTsNzt0aMpw.text: Went to the buffet on Monday night.  Food was average. Crab legs were small. I sampled several items. Not worth the price. The tiny key lime pie was good.

5YUfkoA0hNx3E3mfaEecaA.text: * Welcome Experience - Blatantly Bad  Even for a buffet, this crew was just obnoxious.    * Establishment - Ordinary  It's a buffet.  It feels like a buffet.  It looks like a buffet. Nothing worth mentioning here.    * Service - Ordinary  Our server was prompt, friendly and attentive.     * Food Quantity / Quality / Presentation - Somewhat Encouraging (it's a buffet!)  I don't know should I write a review of buffet food or tell you how the food was at this buffet?  Ok I'll do both...  Buffet food: Ambitious!  They are innovative and are trying to do cool things!  Exotic(ish) entrees appear throughout the sectioned-off buffet and new ideas seem to be welcome here as they have small bites and cool combinations available.  For example...  A charcuterie section was a good try.  Tillamook cheddar and cheap lunchmeat slices made it a miss.    Small bites glasses full of various salads was a cool idea.  I tried Thai beef and it was just ok.  (A piece of cheap roast-beef lunchmeat in a glass with some dressing and greens.)  Stunning (looking) desserts will please the eye but disappoint the taste buds (IMHO.)   The food if it were not a buffet:  No good!  For the novelty of a buffet, variety and quantity, this place is your spot.  For good food you need to find another dining experience elsewhere.    * What I'll remember  - The Mecca of glistening desserts - I SO WISH my mouth's experience matched my eyes'!  What I can't wait to forget  The dried out brisket.  The sawdust rice.  The decaying Shu Mai.  The velveeta Mac and cheese.

Yf1QM_CA2b8lBoilxEXkOw.text: This place is amazing!!! They have warm crab which is my absolute favorite they also have more a variety to choose from compared to Wicked Spoon. The pricing for the Buffet was good, the only thing was that because it's so busy the service was quite slow. It took us a couple of half an hours to get refills on out unlimited drinks, so at the end we decided to get up and get our own drinks from the bar. Overall it's a good place to stuff your face at!

9CopYwSioE5UUrdWfpLa7g.text: I came for a Sunday Brunch with my family at around noon on a Sunday.  I wasn't very impressed with the service or the food.  The place was very nice with some background music that wasn't too loud.  There was plenty of room to maneuver around.   The presentation of the food in general didn't seem very appetizing.  We came at noon and I expected that the food would be "fresh".  Much of the food I got and tried was dried out, either sitting out for a while or over cooked.  For example, General Tsao's Chicken, chicken parmesan sliders, the Grilled Cobia, the country fried steak, the hash Browns,  sweet honey roasted chicken, pork at the taco bar, chicken & jalapeno sausage, and even the meatballs.  I didn't try other stuff because it didn't look very appetizing, especially the food in the Asian section.  The stuff just seemed like it was just slopped there.  The best things I had were the spring mix salad with thousand island dressing and the clam chowder.  The cold snow crab legs were fine because they were cut in half;  why can't the cut the boiled snow crab legs.  Also, the cold peel and eat shrimp was also fine.    The service was just so-so.  You have to pretty much ask for everything because when your drinks run down from tiny glasses, they do not automatically refill them, not once.  I saw quite a few of the workers gathered together just shooting the breeze.  The atmosphere was decent and I liked that there are bathrooms inside the buffet so you wash your hands after eating the shrimp and crab.    I don't eat desserts too often and was told it was just okay.  Just average, nothing special and not much to chose from.  There were quite a few flavor sod ice cream to chose from from their rotating wheel.  I was very disappointed with my food and service experience.

fXArHeH-hMPC6pjTCf1mKg.text: A huge variety of foods on their brunch buffet.  They have everything from scrambled eggs, bacon and a HUGE pancake to crab legs and prime rib!  There was a New England Clam bake, salad and food from many nations (the hummus was excellent).  The server who brought drinks was on top of it the whole time and even at $35 a person, it was well worth it.

vyF-7VERcVstd58cHmdbbw.text: I've been to Las Vegas now 10 times over the years....I've had meals all over the place, and visited many buffets.  I like a good buffet every now and then.  I redeemed a few MyVegas vouchers for my friend and I.  Buy 1 get one free buffet, and two unlimited beverage passes.  I DO recommend the buffet, I do not recommend the additional $12.99 beverage pass, unless maybe you're going with options like beer, or sangria...options I didn't try during my brunch.  I guess I'll start with that part of the experience.  My friend and I tried a bloody mary - when I asked what the difference was between the two kinds, it was just one was spicier than the other, and they ARE pre-mixed, so nothing special.  We weren't thrilled with them so we got the mimosas...which weren't any better.  The orange juice seemed "fresh" with a tad of pulp, but not sure about the rest...it wasn't light or bubbly or anything.  As for the food... we stopped in for brunch.  There weren't a whole lot of breakfast options, but what they had was good...as for the rest, they had EVERYTHING! Italian, seafood, sushi, salad bar, asian, you name it!!! And I can't say enough NICE things about the dessert options, along with a tasty gelato section which had flavors like peanut butter pretzel, and cinnamon toast crunch.  I will say, if you're in a bit of a hurry...and have the drink pass, you do have a 3 hour time limit.  We didn't plan on having a 3 hour brunch anyway, but the service was a bit slow on the beverages so I'd keep that in mind if that was an option you were considering.  Overall, the Aria is wonderful...the buffet is as well, lots of options and very clean!

pNAEzHKVXnzFvNyRhXn4ZQ.text: Ok so here the scoop, this buffet is pretty good normally in my opinion but why I'd give them 3 is because the server who took care of our table was very noticably biased towards a certain table and ignored us which was a larger group but potentially a larger payoff in the end. Tips are the driving force in the industry right? Well that should have been the motivation but there seemed like none, right off, not friendly, then she was acting like we were a burden on her. Hey working a buffet service industry is tough but if that's what you choose to do then wouldn't you be a little bit engaged with the people you service? Ok that's minus one star.  Next the food seemed to get saltier as the night went on. We got crab legs few at a time at various times and they started to get saltier. Are they leaving all the legs in a salt bath and not take them out at a set time? The tandoori chicken used to be really good where I'd go there and have a plate of chicken. This time is was dry. The lamb stew was flavorful but lamb was dry as can be. Also swordfish, don't get me started. It should have been let go and swam free to save a life not kill it and then kill it again with over cooked fish. Hargow dumplings, mind you I grew up eating them so I'm very particular and know plenty about them since I grew up helping my mom make them, so these were very bad. Like I refuse to swallow bad. The texture just was off and skin was tough. Ok enough with bad there was a lot good as well so I'd give the positive 3 stars based on desert, good curry, great prime rib, tasty ham that wasn't a salt lick.

1W18yu0Nba5Qg-mp77pRMA.text: I've tried several Vegas buffets over the last few years and really enjoyed this one. We went to the buffet around 4:30 on a weekday and there was no wait and it wasn't too crowded. The layout seems smaller and more compact than at some buffets which means I think they slightly less variety of food options, but what they do offer was top notch. The carving station BBQ pork shoulder was excellent and the brisket was good as well but a little fatty. I really enjoyed the Mexican fajita bar, with the barbacoa being one of the most tasty buffet meats I've enjoyed in quite a while. If you enjoy like I do you'll like their seafood station. They feature king and snow crab legs which are served hot and cold and were tasty and fresh without being stringy. One older guy who was sucking down crab legs when we arrived and still going strong as we left so he apparently approved of them. The chilled shrimp cocktail shrimp were tasty and the scampi had one of the largest shrimp I've seen anywhere. The desserts were tasty and featured an enjoyable pecan pie and large ice cream selection among other items.  This buffet is a little lacking in selection compared to some others but I enjoyed everything and will return. I'd say this is a 4 star buffet if you like seafood and 3 starts if you're not a fan. With the 2 for 1 special through My Vegas this was an even better deal!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Brisket, pulled pork, fajita vegetables, chicken, fajita pork, barbacoa, some Thai salad thing, and some other random stuff

WpLZ4-DPNI_ZClRQbJfE0w.text: Pretty disappointed in the quality/cost ratio.  For almost $60 per person (including tax/tip) on a Friday night, I guess I just expected better quality.  The crab was meh, the prime rib was meh.   I should have stuck to the rack of lamb, hidden away on the carving line, as it was very nicely prepared. Desserts were decent.  Definitely not a buffet worthy of a $43 price tag; quality really warranted paying no more than $20-$25.

sZ1sm-Ildc9ohlBXDaA5jA.text: Some of the best food I have ever had. A little pricey but food is excellent.   Crab legs were steamed and warm. Meats were hot and full of flavor.   Sweets were amazing. If your gonna do a buffet. Do it here otherwise your just wasting your money

EDXEL1m1F0CVm6w-hP9u6A.text: The food was excellent but the chubby male cashier at the front was rude as hell. He had a bad attitude all because we asked if our group could be split up. He slapped my receipt down and talked as if he was angry. Sucks that I'm a Mlife member and he'd act like that. Otherwise, everyone else there is awesome.

TDpA4DjpWC4nGthOjPA3lg.text: I was pleasantly surprised by this buffet. I have been living a keto lifestyle for a while now, and this place had everything I could want. The for was fresh, the line was short (I came at 2) and things tasted good

Qqsk1Ngnzea77DC_yOAcfw.text: This buffer is unreal and super affordable! There are different stations to choose from: Asian, Italian, Greek, American, bbq, and fish with shell fish and sushi options. The waiters will come around to take drink orders and clear plates as you finish eating. The buffet is about $28/person and an extra $16.99 for all you can drink, however the wait staff didn't check our receipts and a lot of people who didn't purchase the drink package were able to order alcohol drinks so maybe skip the extra $16.99. There is also an entire dessert section that had options from chocolate cake and cheesecake to flan and cannolis. My favorite part was the make your own pho section.

VcOrNr7vQ9j1O9A2olJqOA.text: Great buffet with TONS of options. You want noodles for breakfast? What about oysters on the half shell? Pizza? You got it!   Pretty clean, great selection, good service, short lines....   I wish I could say more... It's just a really solid buffet!

tHN0AcD7TBrwyheGqeHK6w.text: Yup a solid three star. Definitely an above average buffet but nothing about it jumps out and says I AM THE END OF HUNGER FOR YOU'RE ENTIRE STAY IN VEGAS! ALL OTHER BUFFETS KNEEL BEFORE ME! PREPARE YOUR PIE-HOLE FOR PIE!  The glasses for drinks are laughably small, i think the coffee mugs hold more liquid. Drink service was a bit on the sorry side as well. Here's an idea maybe if we increase the capacity of the glasses our guests would shut up less about refills! Yeah how bout that! Also heard something about the 'bottomless drinks' being limited to three, didnt cash in on that offer so i cant really verify.  So everything was your average buffet experience. You got Europeans who just love to cut in line or stand in the middle of the damn place or walk and suddenly stop causing you to dodge them or risk bumping them with loaded plates. You got chinese tourists with every square inch of their plate filled with snow crab legs. You got staff looking miserable as they refresh the station that's been refreshed a mere 15 min ago. And the busers who some way some how mange to balance a tray full of your BS while putting up with your BS. Tip these people well...  Meal highlighs include anything cooked in the tandoor. The tandoori chicken was a bit under-seasoned but the tandoor gave it much more flavor. The nan is semi made to order, if you'd like a fresh one someone at hte station would be able to reheat a premade one and even garlic that SOB up for you.   The garlic asparagus in the Italian section as well as the garlic green beans by the dinner section were quite enjoyable and cooked perfectly. Lots of freshness and garlic. Side note, i spent a few years eating in military messing facilities which are set up like buffets but considerably crappier and loads more depressing, unless it's an Air Force chow hall. Due to this, when ever is see fresh veggies that arent part of the salad bar i get all giddy and usually grab a hefty portion.   The dessert section was a bit of a hit or miss for me. The Panna cotta was quite enjoyable where as the red velvet whoopie pies were just bombed out and depleted. The gelato wasnt too bad but there were way too many chunks of ice that added to the texture.   I would go back if they had some kind of special promotion going on but wouldn't go out of my way to get some.   Yelp 100 - 044 of 100

h_jVA-nXgdGTRpbqrzyKww.text: This was my first experience with a Vegas buffet.  A co-worker suggested trying the Aria buffet as my first one.  They were definitely on to something.  That place is fantastic!! All you can eat gourmet food including sushi, turkey, crab legs, Indian food, stir fry, assorted meats and cheeses, dim sum and so on.  The list seems endless. All amazing food, with great spices and flavors. To accompany the great food, they offer bottomless drinks for $12.  Well worth it, if you ask me. White and red sangrias were flowing to our table.  As if that wasn't enough for you, they have an assortment of Gelato. I had to roll out of the buffet into the casino.  If you need a great buffet to hit up while gambling in Vegas, go to the Aria!

8MszOgwPUV47kwm9RJfucg.text: Vegas buffets tend to be all pretty similar.  Mass produced, widely varied, heat lamped foods that satiate your every food craving but rarely leaves you thinking you had a fine dining experience.  Back in the day, when buffets were $9.95, all of that was fine.  But now, a family of 4 will easily leave a buffet out more than a C-note even if you don't order a beer or glass of wine with your meal.   Aria is on the expensive side even by Vegas standards.   Better selection than most.  Appreciated the Indian food options and healthy portions of pre-cut crab legs that I didn't see at other buffets.  Their sushi was also pretty good but a bit annoying that there was far more sushi rice than fish.  All in all, I'd give the Aria 4 stars as far as buffets go so far as the food is concerned.  However, I feel compelled to ding them a star for their lack of a child rate.  They wanted the same $24.95 (+tax and tip) for my 7-year old daughter's lunch who had all of 1/2 a slice of pizza and a cheerio as they wanted for my wife and I .   I didn't figure that out til after we'd paid for our meal.  Beware future family travelers to Vegas.

ooIc76XwdfB9L6ToX7nVcQ.text: Came here with family and just want to try their buffet but it's not that good. Very disappointed. The service was pretty good but I don't think the food is fresh enough especially the seafood!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The buffet
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The buffet

uajxSH1gSyt-pQRl7jK0sQ.text: Good buffet inside the Aria--friendly service, about $20 per person without beverages. Lots to choose from, sorted by cuisine, i.e. Italian, Mediterranean, etc.  Good selection of fresh salads, prime rib, etc. Good food for "bargain" (for Vegas anyway) prices.

-sayEG-hM2hr4kciNVGaIg.text: Meh.  You'd expect a brand new, snazzy hotel to wow you with a marvelous buffet...it was mediocre at best.  My worst experience was getting burned by a VERY hot metal serving spoon right in front of a server, dropping it, and him giving me a condescending look. Really?   The waitress tried to get us drunk by putting 3/4 champagne in our mimosas...it's not bad, but I'd like to also taste the orange juice.  Food included Asian, Mexican, breakfast and roast beef with the works. There were no tags or signs, since they hand write it on the glass covers...hope you can read their writing.   And as for the dessert? 3 kinds of oatmeal cookies, chocolate whoopie (tasteless) pie, flan, and ice cream. I read the desserts were amazing.........where have people been comparing these to, hometown buffet? They were, at most, subpar.  Not worth the $40+ per person + $6 drink.

HHHENFedLfuQ-nA3bXQMNA.text: Now this is one impressive buffet. Some friends introduced it to us at lunchtime and we were not disappointed even though it's pricey. So many varieties of food and well prepared with great presentation. They offered seafood at lunch also. The ramen bar was out of this world. The meat cuts were succulent and cooked to desire. The Asian section alone would keep me coming back. The desserts were amazing. The decor was really cool and the people were friendly. If you are a seafood fan, you have to give this a try.

hAQKte01PUzqKcn2WO4mSw.text: Worst buffet restaurent i've ever gone. I dont want to give even one star for $ 40 dinner.

h5UWfQ5QsO8tQskdd2e7Jw.text: Waitress excellent,  food area clea, lots of choices, fresh made. Breakfast choices were well thought out. However way to costly for enjoyment $$$$$$

ksVQqTGY3fmOZUvBpchetg.text: The only memorable thing is everything on the posi+ive list. =)  Here's the scoop:  + crab legs (ask to get them steamed) + shrimp cocktail (i got 9 servings, like a shrimp junkie)  + chicken curry  + naan bread (regular butter & garlic) + won ton soup (omg, motha f-ing deeeelish) + gelato (3-4 flavors, always changing, always delicious) + mini cheesecake + bananas foster (imagine a warm gooshy banana with caramel) + creme brulee + very open dining area   - bacon chicken salad (if you like bacon, bacon and bacon, maybe you'll like it)  Don't forget to tip the waitress. The girl we had was on top of it! There was about 15 of us and our plates were always cleared and our glasses always full of drank. Kind of expensive...around $30/person I think? But if you want to try a yummy, safe buffet, come to the Aria and splurge. If anything, the desserts will impress you.

pfuiraTJn0gpMx17EaON-Q.text: Can't go wrong with a free buffet. Thanks to myVegas (free app and Facebook game) I was able to get enough points for a comped lunch buffet.  I waited far too long for them to ring me up because of computer issues -- shutting down, rebooting. I feel like there has to be a more efficient way. Then, no one seemed interested in seating me. Two women were chatting in a very intense -- and loud -- conversation while two other workers were trying to get their attention. It was awkward and definitely unprofessional on their part.  The buffet has such variety that it's overwhelming. How about I have some Latin with a side of Chinese and Mediterranean, then feast some more on Italian. I guess I liked the variety, but nothing really stood out.   A few highlights were the guacamole: chunky avocado and tomatoes with some kick. I was expecting it to taste store bought, but it's definitely made from scratch. The tabbouleh was also very good, and I was surprised they even had Korean kimbap rolls.  The desserts were the best part. I indulged in the coffee ice cream (scooped by someone via a giant ice cream wheel), cheesecake and red velvet whoopie pie. It was far too much but all really good. I liked that all of their offerings were mini-sized rather than a full-sized cooke or dessert shot.  The service was also better than I expected. Whenever I left for more food, my plate was gone by the time I came back. And even though I ordered just a water to drink, it was always refilled before the glass emptied.

QzRw8WdhiV7LxH2FljLxKA.text: The best Breakfast Place on hte Strip! Recepies are the state of art! If you like kashi, oatmeals, crapes and tartalets like I do, I strongly suggest you to ckeck this place out! While writing this at home, I still have some sort of sensation and my taste buds are awake. I used to be a fan of Wynn morning sessions, now I'm in beteween Aria and Wynn. Delicious and tempting is all I can say!

AOm4PQdZGdXa32AWHA-P1Q.text: This was a big disappointment I would never eat here again the food has been sitting out for way to long everything is very dry and overlooked.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

l1XlkVfbqxtuOCT4fzXY_g.text: it turns out the Coke machine was broken but they didn't tell us until we paid $120 and sat.. Waiter said to our table  "well what do you want me to do about it?"  (Gee maybe bring cans?) So, no soda. Very very slow waiter and management response.  Many people were asking for waters still waterless even after they were on their at the second plate from the buffet. Many tables were not bussed during entire meal.  Poor service marred the otherwise outstanding buffet choices.

gD4k48UKDYox_eDXXPKOTw.text: I wouldn't say bad and I wouldn't say over the top. We had the brunch buffet and it was pretty decent. Food did taste about average. I think for myself I was expecting a large selection. Maybe the dinner might deliver. Will be back to try it.

-8QbVhz9J3MV6oMS1G8k9A.text: I had a buy one get one free coupon from playing My Vegas slots online so price was not an issue for $36.99 for dinner. During the week at lunch and dinner they have crab legs, both hot and cold. It was not busy. The service was great. I was not overwhelmed by rooms of food. The buffet lined two walls with a salad and seafood stations in the middle. I will be returning for the crab legs.

OYGddlFbz8w2ns3iF-Wq3A.text: Really Aria?? A supposedly fancy/elegant/sophisticated hotel has a Mexican station with hard shell Tortillas, yellow cheese, ground beef and sour cream? For one moment I though I was at Taco Bell. What an insult for my country. For the price of the buffet I would have expected real tacos.   Not a really big variety of food. Even prime rib was chewy I couldn't eat it.  Only good thing was the ice cream and the men that served it. He made my day. He was really nice.   Also, Waiter looked like he was mad at everyone. I was scared to even ask for water.  Instead try the one at the Whynn, Paris or Rio

cGuJx4bOxQDNX2lSpskblA.text: "Tip the waitstaff!! Way overated!!!" Desserts were good..but the Mexican,Italian and seafood sections were sub-par.Pizza was far from fresh.Prime rib was decent. Was hoping it would be as good as the Wynn or the Bellagio..not even close,sorry. Better than {Circus-Circus though} Our waitress {Debbie} worked hard ,a large table of Chinese visitors {6 adults,4 children}had her running as they consumed miles of Crab legs and needed dishes cleared as the waved her away when she asked if she could get them anything else.,then spent an hour on their cell phones..I noticed they left NO tip..nothing..SHAMEFUL!! She said its ok when I asked her if they left her anything..said she was just happy to have her job! We tipped her well...Tip your servers..Geez!!!!!

DKsDgJh0BAcF226Th61BaQ.text: I wonder why Aria doesn't have this a greater buffet. I gave it a try because I earned the free buffet reward with the myVEGAS app.  It cost around $30 per person for lunch.  They have a big selection of food from different cultures, however, the quality is just not great.  Most of the food I can only give 70/100.  Such as the sushi and sashimi were not refresh at all and not even in good presentation.  Nothing really attracted me except they have a nice salad bar.  Well salad is simple right, just different raw ingredients to be put together.  So I did a simple salad and added a piece of roasted chicken. My husband didn't even feel like eating most of the food.   Comparing to bellagio and Cesar Palace, they have much better presentations and food quality than Aria but I thought Aria is a high-end hotel as well.    I don't think I'll pay another visit again... but the hotel is nice.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. My salad put together by me.
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

oK-M0ytzw9p6aGpvtFj-7g.text: Decent, but better options elsewhere at similar price points. Wait can be significant. Medium size selection.

-x2TNWtnWiXFzNhIDfgZSQ.text: Food was great, some stuff I didn't like but that's just me. The waitress Linda was very nice and helped us out a lot. We will be coming back again on our next visit. Thank you.

5_dtyLr6RVBS63fODldQPg.text: REALLY mediocre. I would have been so mad if I paid for this. It was included in our stay and id only every consider going back if it was free again.  All the food was bland, basic buffet food with little flavor or anything special. the ONLY draw would be the crab legs, but those are tiny, the meat is SO hard to get out and its like a zoo at feeding time when they come out, you basically have to fight to get them. not worth it.  A saturday brunch for the 2 of us would have cost $73. Save your money and go somewhere else. Everywhere else we ate in vegas was fantastic but I regret coming here even when it was free.

v2YDBzvBRvu1uGH1Gi_H5Q.text: The price is way too high for the quality. I used to come here when the buffet first opened and it was great. Crab legs, sushi, and comfort food for a great price. In The last few years the prices have gone up and the quality has gone down. The crab was old and dry. The bread was hard. We were never, not once, served drinks. There are much better Vegas buffets for much better prices out there.

xFvJ2i5fuUtUMJLyq0nW7g.text: You get what you pay for here. Wide variety. Great carving station with beef, pork, and lamb options on weekends. Lots of hot and cold shellfish. Even a poke station. Gelato options are great if none of the great looking deserts interest you. Husband really liked the lamb chops. I heard there's Thai iced tea as a beverage option. Unlike the Cravings buffet at Mirage, alcohol is not included at dinner- they're currently doing a buy one get one for free flowing wine, beer and certain cocktails (mimosas, bloody Mary's, other specials).

Sj2zHcCizeuIDXfzlZjGqA.text: "So, because you are lukewarm -- neither hot nor cold -- I am about to spit you out of my mouth." - Revelation 3:16 NIV  If I wasn't aware that the above is a Bible verse about God's distaste for lukewarm Christians who pander to the World, it could easily be assumed that it was a comment about the food at this buffet.  For the past 5 years as a resident of Vegas, I've tried nearly all of the buffets in town, including during the holidays.  Dinner tonight, 12/22/15, was priced at $48.99 a person for the holidays. Not a single entree dish was palatable. From lamb to pork belly, poutine to pho, every dish was lukewarm. All the meats were tough & the dishes were flavorless. I don't eat shellfish, but my mil does. She didn't eat some on her plate because she said it tasted off.  Service was spotty - I was consistently out of water & I piled our dirty plates on an empty table because they didn't come by often.  Bathroom in buffet was horrendous. Overflowing trash, empty soap dispenser, sanitary bin in stall so stuffed that the lid couldn't shut, no paper seat liners & a terrible smell was the icing on the cake.  If you want to pay Wynn prices for low tier Stations level food, spotty service and unkempt restrooms,  dine at Aria. Otherwise, stay away from this whitewashed sepulcher and save your money.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Background; beef steamship &amp; pork belly. Foreground: chicken parmesan, custard bun, lamb, taquito &amp; lamb ossobuco 12/22/15
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. &#34;Pho,&#34; lasagna, samosa &amp; aloo something over rice. 12/22/15

eT6bZFlviLcGhDmLLl5H8w.text: We waited about a half an hour on 12/22 and paid the Christmas prices ($52 for adults and $26 for children) The price, in my opinion, was not very worth it. There wasn't a lot of food in the buffet and the only thing I really came here for was the Alaskan king crab legs. Everything else was kind of bland, but the people working at each station was pretty nice. Paid about a $245 for 3 adults, one child, $30 tip and $15 parking for 2 hours.

QyAx-VEAqwZWErCYcIONnw.text: For the money spent here ($77 for 2), I was very disappointed. For that kind of money, I could have visited The Wicked Spoon (which is light years better in food quality). I tried the omelette station and the dude working it seemed very unhappy with his job and very unhappy that he had a line. All he did was look at people and shake his head, scowling the whole time. Like, "Dude WTF? Don't work making omelettes for people if you hate it." I would not return to this buffet.

4NEy4ZPC4oxr3AoTR5LvIw.text: Aria buffet has a bad rep, but we didn't let that detour us from trying it out. We stayed at the Monte Carlo so we said, it's next door why not...... Well that was a mistake! I can't think on one thing that was delicious. Maybe the crab legs had be content for the night but I will never go back and waste my money! The place was not too clean either which can be expected of buffets but this is Vegas! Atleast that should of been clean! With so many buffets out there I'd go elsewhere. We saw flan when we walked in and by the time we were ready for it, it was gone! So they don't have enough of one item, that was a bummer. Lastly go somewhere else

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Oh right... this is why no line, it&#39;s more
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. No line July 3rd wwoohhoo

v-GnGf2QFyLG6nf0nsPhqQ.text: My daughter and I dined here for lunch/dinner on 4/15, the cost was $26 a person. We arrived around 2:30pm, so not only were we able to enjoy the lunch options, we also were able to enjoy the dinner options since the dinner buffet started at 3:00pm. I honestly don't understand all the bad reviews of this place, we loved it! There were so many different options to choose from, and all the food was fresh. The array of proteins was amazing. Best place we ate during our 4 day stay in Vegas. And by the way, use Uber or Lyft everywhere you go, its way better than paying for a taxi or to park, the traffic on the strip is horrible.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

2tfH0m4goVmh5uWPexHfcg.text: 5 stars plus 1! Biggest buffet of fine foods I've ever seen. We went 3 times in our trip because the variety was too much to get it all in.

UnGqL7YNXKPC8YrTBHUJEQ.text: During our recent weekend trip to Vegas, we stayed at Aria and therefore had to try the buffet. Much like any other buffet, the options are endless, there were quite a few highlights and quite a few disappointments. That is the way of a buffet.  FATTY TIPS: 1. Save ~$7 by going in at 2:45 PM for a mid-day brunch/dinner and continue eating into the afternoon as they bring out the crab and other dinner specific offerings 2. Wear leggings or vv loose pants  TRY THIS: - Crawfish/mussels/clams from fisherman's stew - Steamed snow crab  - Salmon - Blue cheese salad dressing - California rolls - Oatmeal raisin cookie (v crispy) - Chocolate drizzled caramel corn   DISGUSTING, do yourself a favor and skip this: - guacamole - "paella" (my friend says "but put it in quotes, because THAT isn't paella") - lamb (my other friend says, "if you enjoy eating your wildlife raw, get this") - white chocolate mousse "cake pop" - pistachio gelato (so artificial) - butter pecan gelato  PS. Desserts are one of my favorite parts of Vegas buffers. Although the cakes were very pretty, they were all quite underwhelming (I tried 6). I wish the cake servings were even smaller, like bite size or something, so that I could try more. And also if you must indulge yourself at the gelato wheel, try the Cinnamon Toast Crunch gelato.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chocolate drizzled caramel corn in the sweets section

5eBhMIxVj-70DSG78TUr7g.text: Very disappointing... Food was good and lot of choice but the 30 minutes wait to get at table when half the dining room is empty is not normal! When asking why we have to wait so long after 20 minutes, manager replied rudely that I should be happy because it's usually worst. The service was not what I expected from Aria: had to ask every time for drink refill, dirty plates not removed very often of the table. We're locals we try a lot of buffet and this is not what I was expecting for a Sunday brunch... Once again food was very good but I rated the overall experience.

iX2afYrb8sut6666fOg1QA.text: I love this place for so many reasons!! Firstly, when we arrived, we wanted to see the buffet first. The cashier said that was fine but the price was about to change in a few seconds. It was going from $23 to close to $35( or something like that). So we didn't get to see food ahead of time, so we took our chances. Now the cashier could have not told us this and we would've paid higher price. Well, the buffet was beyond fresh and delicious. My friend, who has dietary needs, came back to the table at one point, with sauteed spinach that had me drooling . She said she saw raw spinach and asked one of the staff if there was any cooked. The person said thee wasn't any but it was no problem to cook it for her. Way to please customers.

hxdg-agjXjy8XztlfxUPGg.text: Straight horrible.  Looks 5 star eats worse than Burger King breakfast.  With the exception of a couple of items.  Most inedible eggs Benedict attempt I've ever had.  There are countless overpriced food options on the strip but avoid avoid avoid and choose one that at least has tasty food

maAtYJosj3FVJWyxwedUVg.text: Food is below any expectation. Asian: Tom Yam Goong - no goongs (shrimps inside), too sweet. Looks like halve of ingredients are absent. Chicken, meat - all over cooked and over salted and not tasty.  Crab "legs" are basically not a legs, but thin tentacles. Tapped water... Does it cost almost $70/person....?!

t9JrnAEA6SWZB4fT7Bg2Cw.text: Not bad, not bad! Going here for brunch is the best time to come because you get the best of both worlds of breakfast and lunch which impressed me more than when I came here for dinner. The build your own omelet section really put me at awe because of how yummy and fluffy the egg was. I feel my heart fluttering from the memory. In general, the food is just great and I'm glad they seem to have quite a variety to choose from!   The service is very nice and attentive. I'm used to seeing a tower of used plates on my table at buffets, but our plates never exceeded past a stack of three plates, so that shows how aware the staff are of their surroundings. Definitely impressed.   I will definitely come back in the future!

d_aIhxPu8iQhXCm06thxRA.text: Brunch here was amazing! Great seafood station. Great carving station. It's been a while since we've been to Vegas so I did some research on buffets. Aria won me over with their great service and great food. I can now confirm, this place is great!

qqWzuDwQAhGYoT9gDrRSAQ.text: To put it simply:  Given it was a brunch buffet and we arrived later in the morning, seafood was great. Endless options from various countries and great service from our server.   My sister-in-law has celiac disease and Chef Craig was very accommodating and eager to show her all of the gluten-free options. Fresh gluten free pancakes and a gluten free pizza was made for her. Delicious.   Thanks for a great experience, Staff, we will be coming back!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

iwVL9xDOHYlDqDjvznfD3w.text: I was ready to leave a 5 star review after our first visit to the buffet for breakfast, but after the second visit it was too big of a disappointment. The food options are good. There are always two bowls full of crap legs, fresh meat ready to be sliced and every type of ethic food you can imagine. The fruit isn't the freshest, the sushi tastes like it was made days ago and most of the mussels were not thoroughly scrubbed. The service though was horrible on our second visit. Our waiter was seen once, no plates were picked up, another waiter said he would bring refills but disappeared as well. So disappointed with this experience after such a great first one.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Could fill up a whole table with the plates that were never cleared

N2KIXhRr_9-kcQDvI-7msA.text: Weekday Brunch. Bad decision to come here when you're not that hungry because it is so not worth it. Im trying to gauge which ones I like but the only thing I remember liking was the truffle potatoes and the fried rice.   The pho soup was so salty that it seemed like the cook overpoured salt there. Same with the spicy beef.  The dimsum have gummy wrappers. Maybe they were from last night (Sunday)?   Under the scrambled eggs, there was fried chicken? And there was some random characters as label. Why place food tags anyway if they cant make it right.   Stay away from Aria's buffet. You'll have better deal eating at Ihop.

6ApBUSuhgvOBi2hj0KMT9w.text: My boyfriend and I came here on a Thursday afternoon. I love their bottomless beer/cocktail drinks for $12! I tried the mimosa and rum punch...the rum punch was really refreshing:)   The lunch price was $23 and I thought it was worth the price. My fav was the snow crabs! It was fresh, juicy and delicious:) I also really liked the pork belly, bacon, sliders,  and coconut cake...I didn't get a chance to try much because I was busy getting full off the snow crabs. Lol.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Snow crabs

_0iD3pnfkFVKuxLVc8dhEA.text: TOP one!! Really. Save money to eat there!!  The variety it's huge. But I think the focal point it is the meat.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

hvWREKLDRLQDo1HviCxS1g.text: What a disappointment that it's located in a five star resort and Aria is egoistic enough to call it "The Buffet" with capital B! Especially considering they charged almost double ($38.99 for just breakfast) for Easter weekend but woefully lack the quality to warrant that price, they seriously need to get their shit together.   It makes me furious that the scrambled eggs at their diner station is MADE OF EGG POWDER. Sure, there's an omelet station nearby so you probably wouldn't be getting your eggs from there anyway, but just the sheer fact that they had the nerve to put an atrocity even a self-respecting $15 buffet won't commit on display really makes me question how they think they deserve their "exclusively excessive" slogan. The yogurt they serve is also some genuinely low-quality sugary crap, that I had to spit it out after tasting just one spoonful.   As for their claim to serving "world wide cuisine"... it's not wrong, if a small selection of pizza counts as Italian, some lo mien in carry out paper cartons and fried rice that looks like it's been fried for 2 weeks counts as Asian, and half cooked plantains caramelized in syrup instead of brown sugar (which tastes disgusting, btw) plus a taco bar counts as Latin.   The only thing that might help the Buffet justify its price tag is how they serve large shrimps, but even those are hidden beneath piles and piles of mussels and are quite a hassle to dig out. The crab legs that basically blow up in your face in all of their advertisements are nowhere to be seen. Are you saving those for your holiday dinner?

ySqRKUM2OCxcecQGA448ew.text: They claim to have king crab legs.  Not exactly.  What they have is cold king crab legs that have been frozen and defrosted cut in half and served cold.  The Buffett is far smaller than what you would expect from a Buffett and the pricing for what is offered is pricey for just okay food.   Don't come here thinking your going to find mounds of snow crab, what they have out is a wok size portion of over steamed crab legs, and bits of claws.  I forgot to mention that is there "gourmet dinner" for Friday night.  What was priced nicely is the 2 for 1 all you can drink bar for $19.99.  That gave you an offering of a couple different beers, champagne bellinis, Bloody Mary, and a rum punch, there might have been something else offered but don't quote me. We opted for the rum punch and they were pretty tasty.  Our server who was covering breaks was amazing (Herbie, I think was his name) but the server who came back from her break needed a day off or a nap.  I'd recommend if you want all you can eat crab legs, travel to California and visit Pala Casino and get a real Buffett experience for about the same money you would spend here.

F4-rhNhZCJtRj6xGdQQv0A.text: Audience is not appropriate. People are just filling up their plates with lobster and the people afterwards don't have one anymore.

b3LwE9wiNVUiZyY_n-_pyA.text: An enjoyable dinner buffet for about $40/pp.   Plenty of tasty choices. My favorite entree was the prime rib - it was surprisingly very moist and juicy. I also really liked the cold crab legs and cocktail shrimp - sweet and tastes of the ocean. Also, plenty of desserts to choose from - my favorites were the coconut ice cream, the canole, and most definitely the creme brulee!!  The worst items were the pizza and fried mozzarella - the pizza was super oily/greasy, and the mozzarella was cold and hard.   Service was nice - plenty of drink refills and taking away of plates. I'd recommend this place, but would like to try other buffets before returning.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Round seven: chocolate gelato, coconut gelato with mango topping (very good)
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Round six: tiramisu, carrot cake (meh), and canolli
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Round five: creme brûlée (favorite dessert) and red velvet cupcake, pineapple

7LnsXAfByl8eKik6O9iFxw.text: Stumbled across this place while looking for breakfast.  Standing in line for an omelet was taking too long so I wandered around and discovered the crab legs.  Yes please!!  Many other options and everything was so good.  The desert station had some wonderful items, the pana cotta was by far the best.

AeKTb_TD_JVaTjJW7nMbTQ.text: I have to keep this review in perspective, because after eating at a bunch of Michael Mina restaurants and different cuisines on this trip, the food at Aria's Buffet just pales in comparison.   The first thing I didn't like about the buffet was that even though they list menu items on a touch-screen outside the restaurant, the list is not a clear reflection of what they serve that day. We were drawn in by the promise of dumplings, shumai, and other dim sum goodies, but when we went in, all they had were veggie dumplings, sesame balls and pork baos. I struggled with the sesame ball because even though they were bite-sized, they were really tough.   Another interesting station was their noodle bar which allows you to do your own noodle combination of pho, ramen or soba noodles. I got excited because a bowl of tonkatsu ramen sounded like it would hit the spot. But it didn't. The lady behind the counter misheard me and gave me soba noodles instead. The broth was really salty. The pork pieces were decent, but I've had better. There was just a lot of flavor missing besides salt. My fiance went back to get noodles but this time with the proper ramen noodles and it wasn't bad, but we were still disappointed with the salty broth which we fixed a bit ourselves by adding water to it.   The bad items: taquitos, empanadas, veggie dumpling  The good items: beef sliders, naan and the dips in the Greek/Mediterranean section.  There's definitely a variety at this buffet, but I've had better. For example, last year I went to Wicked Spoon and even though the food wasn't that great, it was still better than the food at The Buffet at ARIA.

m3bUdwR9CtZUB3RX30c94Q.text: How times have changed. I was given $100 food credit so my parents and I went here for dinner tonight.  My expectations of this place from last time were average so I was hoping that it was gonna be better. Far from it.  I was hoping to have a decent dinner experience since my last buffet trip at Bacchanal last year was really disappointing.  Where do I begin? Almost all the food I tried tonight really missed their mark. Cold crab legs were salty. Hot ones were ok when my parents brought some but when I went they were barely warm then became cold real quick. Sushi was terrible. Korean short ribs were burnt and had lots of fat on it. Pork ribs had decent flavor but was tough to eat. Pizza was awful and I usually don't have any problems with buffet pizza but the pepperoni slice was off. The only thing I tried from the Asian section was the sesame seed balls with red bean inside and those were tough to eat.  The only decent things I had here tonight were the shrimp and grits and mac & cheese.  But what gets me is the lack of variety in some of the sections. Mediterranean, Italian and Indian sections were poor with selections.  The saving point was the dessert. The rotating ice cream flavors tonight were a huge letdown. Not all the containers were used and some were repeats like vanilla. Dessert section was poor as well.  Service was not that great since our server took a while to get our drinks. And they still use the same tiny glasses.  Overall this trip was a letdown. Doubt I'll eat here again even if it's comped.

cm0flXyrduhHyiLITkgf1Q.text: Best dinner buffet in Vegas. Exceptional in every way. Something for everyone and everything fresh and tasty! If you're lucky, Yessica will be your server. Go! You will not be disappointed!

hMwAj-EW_N9ATR_mL2j4lA.text: Good crab legs. Horrible service. Server brought two drinks for each of us at the beginning and never checked back in on us after. Basically saying, "I'm not coming back for a while, so I brought you two."  The quality of the food is actually really good, but the line to get in, even at 8pm on a Wednesday night, and the price you pay to get snubbed by servers is not worth it.   Pro Tip: if you go here and want to eat the crab, ask for utensils when you order your drinks. If you don't, you will be stuck trying to crack open crab legs with a fork and knife, and since you won't ever see your server again, you won't have another opportunity to get them.

4kmE-h87zu4rE-Bveop5NQ.text: The buffet at the Aria was a high end type of buffet serving what was said to be a "gourmet dinner"! There's was from latino, Asian, Mediterranean, American, pizza, and a aisle full of salads fruits and desserts! The best part was the seafood section, there was Alaskan King crab legs, mussels,  shrimp, crawfish etc! My husband and I paid approx 93.00 for two at about 5:00pm so be prepared to pay but it's very worth it!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Rows and rows of desserts
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ice cream and gelato flavors
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Latino salsa section

FERPeuY0OmW4zWWWpbUF2w.text: Since I live in Nevada and have had 5days/week access to pretty decent buffets for a long time, buffets generally don't excite me anymore.  This trip however was with a first timer friend and we went for a mid week lunch.   There were expectingly no line at all at the cashier, very friendly, helpful ladies. There were a buy one get one bottomless drink offer going on so we took advantage of that plus I had a 2 for 1 voucher for the buffet as well. So price wise it was unbeatable for us at least.  What I loved the most about the Buffet? It felt spacious and the pool view and extra light was a bonus. The food variety was acceptable. Enough options that anyone can find at least few favorites to go back to. Mine was the mushroom cheese pizza and dolma. The Mediterranean section in general was my favorite.   Just had an issues with our server, it felt like he was deliberately avoiding to notice us! Had to flag him down every time we needed something. Before we leave asked for a beer refill and he rather aggressively ordered me to show him my receipt. He took it and came back with my beer (that was my 3rd glass, not that it matters) . And told me again with a very aggressive tone that this is your last drink you can't get anymore! We were done anyways and were almost about to leave but I asked why is that? And he told  me "there is a 2 hour limit no more drinks!"  It's not a big deal I'm sure he was having a bad day or something, and I calmly told him first of all if I want more drinks I will get more drinks and second, we were there for exactly 1 hour 10 minutes! So this was a little bit odd.   Bottomline this was a solid 3.5 star experience. To be honest , I would rather go to wicked spoon next door at Cosmo or buffet at Wynn if I have to pay the full price. But if you happen to score a deal, by all means give it a try and I'm sure my experience with our server was just a one time hiccup.

zK-uBOgkVghzWjRLiR8niQ.text: Our fascination with the buffet is over. Used to be our favorite buffet. Brought plenty of out of town guests here in years past. Dined from 11 ish till about noon for thanksgiving today. Not much of a wait which was nice. On the plus side the beef short rib and mashed potato was really tasty as was the strawberry juice. And I enjoyed the poke bowl. Things I personally didn't care for were the steamed crab legs which were dry (I got them right after they were cooked) and the papaya salad had no real flavor. A number of items we tried really had little flavor. Many items were not labeled correctly and some others were not labeled at all. Under the sign for menudo was a Thai noodle dish. I think there were lobster sandwiches but was not sure as there was no sign and no one to ask. It is a shame as this was our go-to splurge buffet.

KdHK2WqTSVMrOusdKf_HFw.text: This place is over price. Not many selections and the crap legs were salty as hell. Waitress was slow and didn't care. Save the trouble and go eat somewhere else.

54NqQyqWlV08OuUF5royRw.text: Dined here August 15th. Food was good. Nice international variety: Asian, Mediterranean Mexican italion in a few others. The key lime dessert was amazing!! Gelato was good! Crab legs  served a few different ways.  2 for 1 Unlimited Mimosas! They have beer also. Enjoy!

MDcBUu4wb5DALssv2fAjtw.text: M-Life membership means free buffet!  So dinner at The Buffet?  Why not!  If you're expecting to be treated like royalty, get real.  This is a buffet.  Drinks refills will be slow but at least the food quality is great and nothing suffers from being overly-steamed or super frozen.  There's a wide variety of offerings here.  There's mini sub-sections for Chinese food, Indian food, Italian food, and so forth.  They have your standard fare of snow crab legs, Alaskan crab legs, king crab legs, prime ribs, pasta bars, salad bars, fancy desserts, et cetera.  I like how they have sugar-free items and gluten-free items so if you're on a strict diet, you won't be misled.  I'm not sure if I would have stopped in if it wasn't for the M-Life membership perks but I will say that they make a delicious panna cotta.  Delicious!

UJLkbBZBWCrxw3AQu5IzAw.text: Went here for a lunch buffet over the thanksgiving weekend. It was $78 for two. I thought th price was reasonable considering a holiday weekend and all  Side story: We went to the Bachanal buffet Friday at Noon. We were given a 175 minute wait time and some smelling salt in case we fainted. j/k about smelling salt. Since no food is worth waiting 3 Hours for, we immediately called the buffet at Aria and were told that there was less than a 15 minute wait time. We drove from Caesar's Palace to Aria and directly headed to the buffet.   Pros: 1) Our waitress was super nice. There was no high chair for Ian, so she kept on looking and informing us every couple of minutes that she was still looking. She finally managed to nab a high chair and bring it to us. (+1) 2) Seafood selections were good. Crab, Shellfish, Sushi and dumplings (esp the Shrimp pot stickers) were delicious I thought. 3) Dessert selections were also good.  Cons: 1) Meat was not good at all. 2) Tandoor area was not good either.  Other than saying we can cross this buffet off of from our checklist, there was nothing going on with the buffet itself.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dessert&#39;s were good.
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Carvings were nothing special.
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Half cut Crab legs makes it easier :)

ahZMJgdLbTY_E997m09h0w.text: Worst dining experience in Las Vegas. Long line & wait to get in. Rude hostess. 15 minutes before our table was greeted & asked for our drink order - had to hunt down a server. For $16.99 the are limitless mimosa & rum punch, question if there if even alcohol in the drinks. As a person in the service industry it takes a lot for me to complain & not leave a tip.  On the positive, the food was decent & wide variety.

sWaEi6_wH1ddYgcWN0qGAQ.text: We were in Vegas for Christmas celebration and wanted to visit one of Vegas highly promoted buffet at Aria.  When we got there, we've been told that they have "Holiday menu" hence the price was increased to $50/pp for dinner.  Well, if what was there is a "special menu" I'm not interested in their regular menu at all! Food was mediocre, lots of carbs and fats. Barely any fruits, vegetables or seafood. The only thing we could eat was steamed crab legs but you can only eat so much of that, without feeling sick.  Overall not worth the $$

KnUBajsZCFOrI0yEuWnhQg.text: Best dessert selection of the vegas buffets I've been to.   Nice decor also.  The food is good quality, but not worth it compared to the competition. You come here for the desserts and ambiance (and depending where you are, the convenience) that's it.

JdCFPcSaAckwPwPFO3wtFg.text: We all know that the Aria's buffet when they first opened left much to be desired. It was almost Palace Stationesque in terms a food, quality and variety.  I am happy to say since the revamp, the quality has improved. I think that they took a look a whats up the road at the Bacchanal and decide to copy the quality vs quantity theory.   We came here on a Friday night at 6. I expected the line to be insane because of the Zarkana crowd but nope, not a single person in line so there was really no need to break out the M-Life balla status card.  Updates from the previous experience:  They now offer 2 carving stations with various cuts of meat. Much improved prime rib and briskets from the last time.   Indian/ Middle-east station Fresh Naan! I didn't come here for Indian curry but it was on point with most Indian lunch buffet's that surround the strip.   Asian Lots of dim sum selections but note, again I didn't come here for that however I did grab a set of char Siu Bao and shumai. They were decent but a little dried out since they were in the steamer racks for a while.   Kalbi (Korean Short Ribs) were decent BUT.. Beware of bone fragments!! The meat was not cleaned well when it was cut. I ended up finding several fragments stuck on the meat.   The is a dark horse for 3rd best buffet in town (behind Bacchanal for dinner and the Bellagio for brunch).

jt36RSrfLj8mBSmXf_R3iA.text: Came to Vegas and wanted to go to at least one buffet just for the experience. Came to the wrong one....  The service was good, the restaurant was very nice in appearance, and the hygiene was excellent.  The price tag was quite frightful, $78 for 2. They charge extra during "holiday" season =December. The "holiday" extra charge is for having holiday items which means they have pumpkin gelato and cheesecake...seriously.  We went for brunch.  Meats were flavorless, seafood plain, waffles and crepes dry, eggs nice and creamy, yogurt was yummy, the Indian food was worth returning for, chinese looked very unappealing and tasted generic, the majority of dessert were muffins, croissants, donuts, but they had gelato- best coffee ice cream I've had, and 4 cake options- carrot was dry but the vanilla cupcake was delightful.  Yes I sampled pretty much everything. For that price I was going to make sure I at least gained 10 lbs by the time I waddled out.  In summary, hefty price, not that many options, nothing to really rave about, charge extra for holidays.  It's vegas, there are a lot of options, prices, and sizes when it comes to buffets. Do your homework and decide what's worth your money.

dr4LlTgADp6NBL_TCVMWzQ.text: Was told if I want crab legs Aria had the best bang for your buck.  I have a hard time paying $40-50 for a dinner buffet when I mainly just want unlimited crab legs.  Found out Aria puts out crab legs for lunch which sold us.  Why pay $40-50 when you can pay $25 instead.  We got there at 2:30 and the menu didn't change when they had dinner switch over so we saved some money by going a little early.  The prime rib was excellent as well. The shrimp and grits was the surprise hit with me.  If looking for a nice buffet I recommend Aria but I also hear there are a couple other good ones as well.  The only thing I would say that should be better is the desserts.  They all look great but just wasn't super impressed with that section.  But let's be honest I come for the main dishes not the dessert and Aria didn't disappoint.

BL7FvE4cg-x6PgTHL8Yn4A.text: My husband got food poisoning after eating here. I am not sure exactly what he ate that caused it but I know it was from this buffet because that's all he had eaten all day. I would expect more from the Aria.

DbSHlsE97LFpR5LVjh5w3w.text: What a difference 2 years makes!   Damn you Inflation!!!!   5 STARS...if you come in Monday through Friday before 11AM and get the $17 price 4 STARS...if you come in Thur-Fri after 11AM and pay the $25 price  3 STARS...if you come in on Sat or Sun and pay the $33 price...FUC it! Walk over next door to Wicked Spoon for $29.    Sadly...the SD, LA and Seattle Yelp Springbreakers came in on...Saturday! :(  2 years ago it was Alaskan King crab legs...Snow crab now, which are are smaller but just as good.  The tasty prime rib was better than Wicked Spoon's, which doesn't have crab legs. $6 for All-You-Can-Drink champagne, Mimosas, and bloody Mary...did I really spend $39 on Brunch? Guess so!  The service was slow at times with drink refills...I wanna get my Mimosa on! But after 2 hours of eating and Mimosa-ing I was pleasantly buzzed in the end... :D  Moral of the Story? Get your hungover butt down here before 11AM Monday - Friday...otherwise just sleep in and walk over next door to the Wicked Spoon at the Cosmopolitan...unless you just can't live without those pre-cut tasty crab legs...life is full of difficult decisions!

Y6emhjAcu0To7V7rPUq_MQ.text: As arriving find out they charge for valet now even if you eat at Buffet will they validate it. Come to find out there gourmet dinner buffet is now down graded from last year very disappointed after spending 40@ each for buffet. Rather go to Rio way better. After we finished eating went to play after @30 to 40 min spent 100 dollars playing slots no sign of waitress call a lady said she couldn't go inside to look for her call "manger" gave lame excuse and casino wasn't even busy. Finally waitress comes brings water with attitude. Will never go there or any MGM properties they now charging for valet 13 dollars. They have attitude they seem they don't care.

UfvLI9JfFU4mp66d3iN8Pg.text: We went to go see a show at Aria & stopped here for dinner.   Overall I was really pleased with this buffet - loved the variety and the fresh made naan! The desert bar was ok, but the made up for it almost everywhere else!  Service was great - helpful & quick to clear our table without being obnoxious .

hTp-jrc33zWnxp2EI7sLJw.text: This is no five star hotel buffet. Lacked variety. Seafood section just sucked ass. Only thing decent was the carving station and the gelato section. There were a few nice dishes here and there but definitely not worth the 50 bucks a person. I also think vegas needs to rethink charging kids adult price. My friends kid hardly eats and she paid 50. It is ridiculous.

Fyl27SJAIQ3svpUBYst82Q.text: So me and the wife decided to go to the buffet in the hotel that we are staying at. The reviews were all over the place, but everyone's buffet pallet is different. I think we made a good choice listening to Matt R.   I had alot of hot snow crab legs(these are prob the most biggest snow crab legs I've seen/eaten. So sweet in flavor. I also had the peel and eat shrimp/cold king crab legs (pre-split), ehh. Didn't really care for the cold stuff. I did get my fix on the hot snow crab legs.   Got a piece naan put curry chicken on top it. The fresh tandori lamb just came out of the clay pot, that was all the Indian I had and it was delicious. I also had the prime rib, had great flavor. They had this huge, i mean huge piece of beef (possible a leg of beef). Salmon was also good. Sushi, ehh. Not good, but eatable. Dessert was good. All sorts of sweets.  They'll have something you like. Both of us for dinner=80 bucks. The wait staff was good. Overall worth a visit. If this doesn't convince you to go, think of all you can eat snow crab lags for 40 a person.

iXlE5oDkKekYAT3X8YxuTw.text: From the host not wanting to seat us where we asked, even though they seated people there before and after us, to the desert staff not seeing us standing there waiting for a gelato request because they were too busy socializing, to the popcorn and rice crispy treats on the line... Out of the six buffets I've been to on this trip, I'd be embarrassed if I was the manager or owner. I pulled the manager aside to compliment our waiter, and included in a calm tone how I was not pleased with my visit. Instead of asking why I was displeased, he instead wanted to tell me how he was friends with the waiter. Read my other Vegas buffet reviews.  I'm generous and usually very pleased.  I come here for the shows and buffets. Aria was no better than Main Street Station in Fremont, but three times the price.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Wow, rice crispy treats! How utterly impressive for a Vegas buffet at over $30 a plate! Id hide my head if i ran this place.
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. POPCORN on a Vegas buffet line at the Aria?!  They must be proud.
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

dQ8X40gpFqrJYmK3QBaQhQ.text: We stayed at the Aria over the 4th of July week and were excited to try out their buffet as it was rated top 5 on the strip for 2012. Well, we were disappointed to say the least. There werent a lot of choices. What was out on the floor wasnt that great.   It wasnt all bad. The dessert was super delish and the presentation was out of a 5 star restaurant. And the staff for the most was very attentive and super nice. And we found the Naan to be superb!   Price point was alright. Except for their fancy Dinner on Thur-Sun. About $46 bucks gets you lobster for two and unlimited wine. They can keep their wine and lobster should have been thrown back into the sea. Bc it looked small, over cooked, and just downright tasteless. I didnt have it as I feared for Poseidon's wrath for eating too much of his sea family already throughout our stay. Sorry little shrimpies but you are too yummy.   But we came for the food. The food was blah at best. So sad for a hotel that screams "opulence, i has it" as you walk through the front doors!

HWWaE2J0RUVZj3bZqRhAAA.text: The buffet is on the 2nd floor and I felt it wasn't as crowded as some maybe because it wasn't on the casino floor.  at first glance of the seating area and buffet it doesn't wow you but the food is good.  there is enough variety to keep anyone happy.      they have a nice salsa bar for the yummy mexican food.    they have a tandoor for homemade naan which was good but indian restaurants do naan better.    dim sum was just ok though.    meat station was a carnivores dream but it seemed all the meat stations at every buffet was the same, stacks and stacks of sausage, lamb, prime rib but the aria had an enormous piece of beef called steamship.  it was HUGE.  seafood was good too, easy to crack crablegs and loads and loads of shrimp.  it is a wonder how much shrimp is in this desert called las vegas.

EQ0Gt7ApcfpW35RiZx-9bw.text: Came here on a Saturday night with a group of friends for dinner at around 6:15 pm (by the time we left at 8:00 pm a long line had formed an the entrance of the buffet). Different stations included: salad station, seafood station (hot steamed crab legs, crab claws, raw oysters, crab fish, various sushi, paella, mussels fra diablo, seared salmon, iced cooked shrimp), Asian station (3 varieties of steamed dumplings, beef in garlic ginger sauce, chicken in some sauce as well), various breads and pastas, various cheeses and meats, pizza, and some other stations that I have forgotten. Upon looking around at all of the options I made a dive for the steamed crab legs and the iced crab claws. The steamed crab legs were delicious and salted just right and the iced crab claws were delicious as well. Besides attacking the crab legs and claws (which constituted the majority of my meal) I also tried the osso bucco, which was delicious and resulted in me coming back for seconds. I also had the mussels and clams from the paella, which were cooked well and a couple of pieces of sushi (nothing to wow at).     For dessert I had the creme brulee, which was perfect. Creamy custard with a crunchy torched sugar topping. Caramel macchiato and chocolate gelato with caramel syrup, Oreo cookies, and banana flambe. The flan was good too, but a little too sweet for my taste. The black Forrest chocolate cake was good, the sweetness of the chocolate cake was contrasted with the thin raspberry jelly on top of the cake. I also tried the smores as well as the caramel popcorn which tasted fresh.     Our waiter here was very attentive, friendly, and nice. She also brought everyone 2 glasses of water or soda (depending upon what they ordered) as the glasses are 8 oz, not 16 oz. she was also very quick to refill the drinks when they were close to being empty and was very quick to take away the dirty plates as well.     Caesars buffet, which I also tried, does have a lot more options than Aria, especially when it came to the gelato variety as well as the amount of various stations, but for a $20 difference ($40 at aria vs $60 at Caesars) I would go to Aria as I love my hot steamed crab legs more than I like the iced ones.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Desserts (tiramisu cup, creme brûlée, black Forrest with raspberry jam, flan)
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Meat Selection Station II.
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Iced crab claws, saw oysters, and iced crab legs.

yA2-bFMvhxi9_QhplH7XXA.text: Aria is a beautiful hotel I admit but the buffet was so subpar! And the service was atrocious. I'm a local and mom likes to play the slots so somehow we ended up here.   The food looks amazing but as soon as you put it in your mouth you wonder if it was just a display. Bland tasteless and the meat was sometimes chewy. The lamb actually smelled!   Our waiter Sonny gave us evil eye all night and looked annoyed when we ordered even a tea.  Never again .. But the creme brulee was nice lol

CwZXI-BtN8oFIqVFV_KROg.text: I'm not sure why or how we ended up at this buffet, but it was a total rip off! We went at 3pm and paid dinner prices. It came out to be around $50 per person including tip, which wouldve been fine if the food was amazing. Sadly, the selection was small and the food was average at best.  I usually dive for the seafood and steak at buffets to get my money's worth, but the seafood and meats here were just mehhh. So meh that it wasn't even worth getting a second serving.
