k6YcpDVqVNW2FwCdTJVBfQ.text: DO NOT EAT HERE!! if I could give 0 stars I would. Paid $102 with tip to eat for two and stayed about 20 minutes. Food was cold and just horrible. The food either had no taste or it just tasted bad. We honestly didn't feel comfortable continuing to eat because that's how bad it was. Every food station was labeled wrong from the breakfast Buffett numerous hours before, so you didn't even know what you were eating half the time. I advise you to not eat here whatsoever. DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY!

e4Xvn5eUnHaOASucLrn2zA.text: Okay so I came here for dinner two nights ago. Our server was awesome! She was very friendly and attentive. Also the drinks she brought us were great. I had iced tea and it was good quality.   The food, sadly, did not live up to my expectations. This isn't exactly the cheapest buffet so I expect pretty tasty food.   The two best things here were the ribs and the quinoa salad. Everything else was pretty bland. The salmon dishes were dry and the poke station had mostly tasteless fish and fixings.   Most of the food here is very heavy. Lots of heavy cream and butter and I don't really like that in ALL my dishes.   The dessert was subpar as well. The creme brulee had "burnt sugar" that was soft and not hard like it's supposed to be. The ice cream looked tempting but was mostly flavorless as well.   I really don't recommend this buffet. We went to the buffet at Bellagio the next day and had much better food. This rating would be lower if it wasn't for our awesome waitress.

izQUDLOL4-QJ03Wfu54lGA.text: 4 stars for friendly folks, and mostly fresh food even if it was later in the evening.  I see why they consider this one of the better buffets in Vegas.  Good variety, and it was all super clean.  The drink service (non alcoholic) was a little slow, but decent.   The food had some pretty good flavors, but there were some things that were lacking- like the brisket.  Deserts were a weak spot, but still better than what we'd experienced at another buffet earlier. We had a BOGO for the dinner, so it was affordable for us, but I can't promise I'd come back if we didn't have a deal.  Favorite of the night was the cowboy steak, Mac n cheese, crab and the spicy shrimp & grits.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp and grits, crab, deli meat

hMZfjLxafank1J01rcaz7Q.text: This visit must note The gluten free vegetarian friendly is not what used to be ... And some what disappointed   Less items in what are section stations  The pasta station at your request is gone!  Why?  Japanese ramen soup station instead was placed but non of the noodles even the rice noodles  are suited for gluten free as all are warming in same pot of hot water with the wheat kind ones....   Vegetarian miso broth (is soy...)  Many choices of humus dips instead of other salads  The pre mixed  salads are all with some sort of dairy or nuts.... Again the vegan or dairy free or allergic to nuts won't touch them Or with wheat base   More use of soy and simple menu like Mac and cheese or hot dogs.  The place is half empty Very noisy

MWsAODw-3cwnstYzZy7fLQ.text: Aria is my Go To buffet every time I visit Las Vegas.  Eating here is always a treat with my family that we went back the second day for another buffet feast!  Lesson learned, they practically had the same selection of what we had yesterday.  Almost same of everything!   So this time we were just gonna check out their Chinese food selection.  OMG, they had two kinds of chow mein!  Why???  Fried rice so dry, a gailan veg dish and some assortment of dimsum.  No meat selection.   A big disappointment.  I didn't finish eating what I had that I went to their Fish Market station to get the Poke bowl.  I stood there waiting for a good 5-7 minutes for help.  Two guys inside were too busy talking and finally asked what I wanted.  Told him the tuna/salmon poke bowl.  Poor customer service they were too busy chatting and laughing inside their station.  Also I went around to get grilled veg, I asked for asparagus and lady handed me two stalks, I asked for two more extra asparagus.  She gave me the eye!!!!  Why?   I thought I'm at a buffet, why are the servers at almost all stationed had an attitude?   On the other hand, our waiter was nice and lively always checking if we need mOre drink.    Aria is a high end hotel on the strip and not your regular mediocre hotel.  We pay good money to stay at this fine establishment and to eat good food and expect good service.

MaId36L1aXRRhisOzS131w.text: I wasn't feeling whAt buffet offered me at the location I stayed at so with a little help from google I landed at this amazing spot ...I deducted a star because they treat the buffet lines like a club now a days....half the room of buffet had empty seats, making people wait in line for 45 min is not cool....by than we aren't even hungry and more mad than anything ...OH YA...now they even have a express line sort of like a vip lmaoooo...where they can cut Infront people who have been waiting in line for a long time... ridiculous right ...but anywho they only used half the room and only sent ppl in once ppl left.....the food though I can say is amazing, they do it so right...not your average buffet , they actual make little dishes served to you almost as if you get the quality of a restaurant serving....I like it!

Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

FyeZOXG6CuEGkQzURrvPeA.text: Decent selection for the price compared to other casino buffets I have seen. However all the food available was fresh and delicious, there is a variety of food stations for custom orders, and the staff is quite friendly and personable. I would return mostly for convenience.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cereal encrusted French toast topped with Nutella
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bubble Waffle with fresh fruit

zA9bbUtG4Ya77iUVkQfpPg.text: Vegas is known for their buffets and the selections they have, and this was the first time trying the ARIA buffet. Definite pros and cons to it.  [[HOW TO GET MORE FOR YOUR MONEY? 1. Get the Bottomless Beverage Pass (unlimited alcoholic beverages) using the MyVEGAS app which is free to download and available on Apple or Android devices, go 1 hour before Lunch, so you can get two buffets in one (Breakfast & Lunch!), get a refill on your final Alcoholic beverage and take it to-go!]]  The buffet is about $40 a person. The reason why I chose to eat here is because I was able to buy a Bottomless Beverage Pass (unlimited alcoholic beverages) from the MyVEGAS app! If you don't have it, download it, it will save you a lot of money, and the rewards are FREE! The bottomless beverage pass is normally $20. If I didn't get the Beverage pass I definitely would not buy one, I don't think I drank enough - 1 margarita (very sweet because it's premixed), 1 glass of wine (chardonnay or cabernet are all they offer), and 2 mimosas.  The buffet itself does have a good selection between different cuisines: Chinese, Middle East, Mexican, Japanese and American. They also had a Carvery, Salad, and Dessert section. I got fortunate and went during breakfast just before they transitioned to lunch, but I didn't really grab anything 'breakfast'. I did notice they made their waffles fresh, had a great selection of breakfast items (hash browns, eggs, eggs benedict, lox, bagels, sausage, bacon, cereal, French toast and more.)   The selection of food though is very unique and less generic which is something that I enjoyed, you can tell that there is a great selection of items, they didn't just have the basic items you'd find at a cheap buffet, which is what I liked.   Foods that I absolutely LOVED: the mashed potatoes (omg, SO GOOD), pot roast (delicious), grilled veggies (wonderful once you add a little salt), menudo (I got seconds thats how good it was), creme brulee (creamy and cool), strawberry-lime-raspberry sorbet (tangy and refreshing).   Foods that were MEH: pork belly (found at carvery station), pho (didn't like the broth and the noodles were not fresh) and sushi (huge disappointment).  Service here my group got lucky. We got whom we believed to be the best server, Mary Ann. She was friendly, bubbly and you can tell she loved her job. She came by our table plenty of times to ask how we were and also definitely was not shy about asking if we wanted more alcohol (LOL double bonus). She bussed tables like a major pro filling up a server tray to the top (bravo). There was a table next to us where they seemed to be regulars because she talked to them and genuinely seemed to care about how their visit was and how they were doing since the last time she saw them. I work as an Operations Manager in the Food & Beverage industry and my friends, two of them are Servers and one a Bartender/Server and honestly, Mary Ann amazed us all. She is an asset for sure and definitely made our trip wonderful, 5-Stars Mary Ann, you were absolutely incredible! When I come back, I definitely would ask to sit in her section because her service and hospitality was just incredibly welcoming and wonderful!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menudo - absolutely delicious!
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mexican Food Section w/ fresh tamales!

SjYhwhVriuNgArodI9Q_3A.text: My first time checking out the Aria Buffet while I was in Las Vegas I'm not sure why it only has three stars because it was awesome!!  I only went for the crab legs which they were serving three kinds of . . Alaskan king crab, Jonah's crab claws as snow crab!! This Buffet had many different options to pick from  .they even had a fresh squeezed lemonade that was amazing!! I decided to check out this buffet for the crab legs and seafood since the Rio is no longer serving crab! I will definitely return here again on my next trip

Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Yummy king crab and claws

6kTG2adkJXgLwgOBY9do8w.text: Sushi, and bacon, and crab legs - oh my!  I'm not the biggest breakfast person, nor do I enjoy massively produced food, so I was a little bummed when our group chose the Buffet at Aria for Sunday brunch ($40).  I'm so glad I was out numbered, because this was easily the best meal of our trip. Aria does it right with food stations featuring items from across the globe - Chinese, American, Japanese, Italian, and Mediterranean.   This buffet does not limit itself to just brunch, they go above and beyond with carving stations, omelette making stations, and loads of specialty pizzas! My favorite part? The desert bar! I even tried to stuff a few rice krispies in my pockets, but I guess that's frowned upon.   There is a server dedicated to each table, who will refill your water, coffee, and clear plates. Sadly, the $40 fee does not cover alcohol, but they did have some pretty tasty juices on the brunch menu - champagne flasks anyone?

bYVpnIq9ESiGjRbl07JsEg.text: Large scale located on the Promenade Level open for all meals and their breakfast and lunch are really wholesome. Lunch had an Asian , fish , and meat section  . Not as. Rowed ad you would think .

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Buffet

cn0swpqOaWJa1GekkLcNNQ.text: I'm rating a 3 for good service. They have some of the better service for Buffet service. Our waitress was very attentive and helpful.  I lived in Vegas and worked on the strip for 5 years. I now go back back often to visit friends. I've tried just about every main Buffet on the strip. For the price, I feel you do not get near as many options as other "high end" buffets.   The good: if you like crab legs or some international foods, then you may be happy.  The bad: several of the desserts were hard/stale. Not a lot of options in general compared.

yPIFGtp9IAdqPRDG2bnQEQ.text: It has been awhile since I have tried this buffet at Aria. We had a bogo and came around 2:30pm. We paid for the brunch menu ($29.99) which starts from 9am-3pm. Luckily, we got to try both the brunch menu and the dinner menu since it starts from 3pm-10pm and normally cost $39.99 per person. They do offer an all day buffet for $60 with unlimited access and a separate line to skip the rush.   They offer a variety of different type of dishes. It is separated by fish market, sweets, salad bar, Asian, pizza, Mediterranean, Latin, tandoori, Italian, and carvery, and diner. It has a little of everything to satisfied your food cravings (check photos). Everything we had was surprisingly good and flavorful. The best thing I liked the most and was unique is the pastrami style pork belly! We also murder their crab legs! Going back for plates after plates. They precut them so it's easier to break open and pull out the meat in one piece. The creme brulee is also a hit! We were so full at the end but wanting to eat more of it.   I just want to shootout to our waitress Susan for providing excellent service. She was very nice and friendly and made sure our dishes were taking away in a timely matter. She also checked on us periodically to refill our drinks and it was busy! We had pre-tip at the register but ended up tipping more because of her! Thank you Susan!

Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Ypgutq7YBFXhnis_2uXcHA.text: It was amazing! There were so many choices! My personal favorite were the sliders and the lamb chop! I absolutely loved it! I would recommend this to everyone I know!

n-IIhVkDk1V_iJ6ZLUhJ-Q.text: Endless choices.  Brunch is awesome at Aria Buffet.  All cuisines including japanese,chinese,italian,mexican ....  Unlike other average buffets,everything tastes good here.  Great brunch option for the price  Totally worth it

9_y2xYcNDgmkbf5AwUAsFA.text: I came here with somewhat high expectations so I was a little disappointed that it didn't fully meet it but it was ok.  I never been to this buffet before so I was excited to check it out. We came at around 1100 and they still had some breakfast stuff and slightly transitioning to lunch. The selection was a lot smaller than I expected. I like the seafood section as they were fresh. Definitely like the poke section. The brisket was also pretty good but kind of bland. My sister stated 'everything could have been better, there was just something missing in everything' and I agreed. The dessert section was kind of disappointing as well, nothing looks super appealing and it was just ok. I only like the macaroon.  Some of the signs didn't correlate with the food so that was a little annoying. Another thing that was annoying was how long it took for the naab bread to be ready. I was excited to get naan bread but they weren't even finish prepping by the time I finished so I couldn't even get to try it.  The price was ok as well.

ZP83K8RirA6JK9XAFp2ZFg.text: Lots of different foods, however I noticed some items were sitting out for a very long time, especially the items that were in small cups individually displayed. Noodles had become hard and crusty. I stayed away from items that looked older. There were plenty of other foods that were fresh and in big batches. The dessert was excellent and my favorite part of the buffet. If you plan on drinking alcoholic beverages, the all you can drink package is $19.95 and definitely worth it.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Desserts

CxQMNDlMMknafJHo9U4XIQ.text: Had breakfast at @ariabuffetlv this morning. That curry beef was the highlight of the meal. Its a hearty price to not include bottomless but that's by @visitwashingtondc standards, its a completely different game in @vegas. I only went back there bc I thought it was a different place. By the time I realized it was the wrong place I was too hungry to search for the right place which I think was in @cosmopolitan_lv. The first plate was bomb. The second plate, not so much. The pancakes tasted as good as the first but everything else was a bit dry the second time. You may think I'm being funny with this one but the water was so good. For those that know me, know how I am about water but I had about 3 cups.  #buffet #Vegas #vegasstrip #lasvegas #breakfast #brunch #aria #thebuffet #thebuffetataria

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Buffet food
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

V5fhWOugEyBgfGnq2oR-DQ.text: I was here just last weekend on a Friday.  I think this place is pretty mediocre in terms of value for the price ($45 per adult).  Some pros and cons below:  pros:  1) kids eat free so this is definitely a great value if your kids have good appetite for things like prime rib, seafood, etc. 2) the carving station has some nice cuts of prime rib, pork belly (much leaner than I expected!), turkey, roast chicken, etc. 3) asparagus and various non-spicy peppers were tasty at the carving station as well.  cons:  1) the salad bar I felt was fairly weak and did not provide a good selection of healthy options. Half the options were literally drowning in dressing so I couldn't get the portions I wanted. 2) cooked fish was almost non-existent.  There was a salmon (in hollandaise sauce?) that was provided, but it was drowning in sauce for a one bite portion of meat. 3) most of the items are provided in preset dishes.  I know this is common in Vegas buffets and some are fans, some aren't.  I prefer to portion out what I want as I don't like to waste food in case I'm not a fan of the item. 4) The cooked Chinese veggies were drowning in soy sauce so I was not interested in these.  Overall, it's OK for Vegas buffet standards, but there are far better values in LA for AYCE.  I was here for a social occasion.

FIb-eSSXacGSTqHcDqGX1Q.text: Allen and I checked out of Aria on a Sunday and were going to head to brunch...only to realize (we knew this deep down already) that the wait at every single buffet was going to take at least 1.5 hours. We decided to check out the buffet in Aria, since no one has ever talked about this place before (LOL).   Wait: 15 minutes max. How great! Interior: I like the clean, simple look. Definitely felt more subtle than other flashier buffets. Service: the lady who helped us was super duper...slow. No offense, but we had so much plates on our tables that we needed to clear, and she only came 2 times throughout our dining experience.   Selection: standard stuff! Meats, Asian, Indian, Italian, seafood, soups, salad, and desserts.   +1 grilled vegetables!  +1 there's a poke bar!  +1 Desserts were pretty diverse! Gelato was mediocre quality, but the smaller pastries were good.   Overall, everything I tried was average. Nothing was below expectation (besides service), but nothing stood out either. Would come here again if there's no wait!

Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

xvdM5mnGTKychSQyCDHwyg.text: My first Vegas buffet experience. I came here hungry and thirsty. Line was not long about 6 tables ahead of me at 9:55 am. Place is okay.  Reviews about limited choices was spot on. For my palette, I wasn't left with much to choose from. I had scrambled eggs which was okay, bacon too greasy/salty, sausage okay, ham great, pork excellent and yummy. Did not like the dessert selections at all and was so disappointed. So after spending $39.59 ($30.99 plus taxes and 18% tip) I dont think I got my money's worth. I'm full mainly from drinking three glasses of orange juice, a cup of coffee and a glass of water.  I was really thirsty. Other diners look to be having a ball and partaking in a lot of the choices I didn't care about.  My server was great.

E0BxHbIULBldRGtkqqWrBA.text: I loved this place! I got a little nervous after reading the reviews however, going there for brunch time, i literally got everything i wanted. It might be also because i was really hungry that everything tasted good but there are a few outstanding features about this place. The seafood section had customizable poke bowls. The tuna and salmon were fresh enough and they got all the popular toppings and that already drew me in. I guess shrimp is a big deal for people (based on the other reviews). I thought it was fine for lunch. The other fantastic sector they have was the carvings (meat) section. Getting fatty portion of the brisket with Texas steak while drowning it in the ad jus... (drool).  Last but not least to round everything out; the sweets. I love the creme brulee with the multiple selections of gelato.  You really don't need much else than those places; all the other selections were ok but those 3 sectors makes the place worth for lunch.

DdwNWIkvoFnpwTtCWujo_g.text: Not worth the money. This buffet does not have the variety nor quality of food you would expect for the price. I looked up the price on their website and it said nothing about holiday pricing the day after Thanksgiving. We arrived to find it was $37.99, even for my son who barely ate anything. Positive notes: kept clean and had attentive staff.

Yyqk1OHg4SuOHC5yyBfSTw.text: This is probably one of the worst buffets I've been to on the strip. A lot of the foods seemed like it was sitting there for hours, un-flavorful, cold...I could go on to how bad this place is but I don't have the words to describe them. Do yourself a favor and go to Bellagio or even Planet Hollywood across the street.

spiNfwoAglreTpb-QbT7IA.text: If you want an experienced review, then i'll be straight with you and I wont BS you, and by "experienced" I don't mean on Yelp, I mean in terms of my experience with multiple vegas buffets. I know you'll find a lot of reviews for this buffet saying that it was a great buffet and that it was amazing but those people have probably NOT had the buffets at Caesars (Bacchanal) or the Wynn buffet or etc. because those are far better in quality and overall food selection. The buffet here at Aria is okay. The selection of food was very underwhelming, not very many choices. The size of the buffet is fairly small as well. The seating area is pretty large but the buffet itself is kinda small. Aria is one of the newer and nicer hotel/casinos on the strip and you would expect the buffet to be superb but it's really not. The selection of sushi was very limited to like 2 or 3 kinds and I'm not even a big sushi person. The meat section was terrible. The prime rib looked almost rare, which is gross and especially at a buffet. The beef ribs were also seemingly undercooked. This buffet is less than decent. If you're in vegas then chances are that you're visiting and hitting up a buffet is almost on everyones "to do list". Buffets are pretty expensive and honestly just spend the extra money and go to the Bacchanal at Caesars, it's totally worth it trust me. And to top it all off, my 14 year old sister got major food poisoning after eating here. My friends came with us as well and they were both vomiting after eating there also. We only came here because the line at Caesars was too long and we figured that Aria would have a good buffet given the stature of Aria but it was very disappointing. I know that the management reads these reviews so if you're looking for ways to improve your buffet then you need to add more items that are at the other top tier buffets and teach your waiters about customer service. Our waitress walked by our table at least 3 to 4 times before coming to our table to clean up, and that was after I had to ask for her. I spent more than $200 bucks here for 4 people and it was definitely not worth it. Don't come here, pay a little more and go to Caesars.

UXO-c773LCIP5tuysDB2ZA.text: Everything I ate was amazing. The dishes were rich and delicate. Especially the salmon.  The dessert section was impressive. I ate the pumpkin pie and almost cried. The worst part about this buffet is that it's ridiculously expensive.   I'd say this is the best hotel buffet in Las Vegas, which is really good because I've tried ~6!

Y_u7blWokHs39EegdDNeig.text: The hubby and I went here last weekend. It was our first time back since it re-opened. All I can say is OMG! This place is so good! We went for breakfast on a Saturday morning. We got there pretty early so we were seated right away and the server was very polite.  (Btw, the server told us that Saturday afternoons are the busiest.) The are lots of food options and if you have special dietary needs, ex. Gluten-free, there are some options for you. If you get an omelet made for you at the omelet station, it will be big so you might want to share so they you have room for the other delicious food.   We are definitely coming here again!

UipPZaF8YXZqh1Ux3JpTwA.text: Came here few times over the years but I was here again today and I must say the quality and the variety of food has downgraded. It's a little over priced but it is still a much better option than many other buffets with an equal price.  The best part of the buffet is the Mediterranean option and the Mexican. Other than that it has the same stuff you will find at every buffet. The desert bar is not good at all! Literally at all.

gBvstbaq-SrHtf4KqMndXQ.text: We were here for the soft opening four years ago, and it was very good. In fact, it was almost comparable to The Buffet at Wynn and The Wicked Spoon. We returned a year later, and it was less memorable but still good. Three years on, this place has gone way downhill. We were here for the "holiday buffet." Just about everything we ate was crusty, congealed, and flavorless, and the price is higher than the far superior Wynn buffet. It was clear that dishes, especially desserts, had been refrigerated and set back out. The pho broth was barely even lukewarm. Every pastry we sampled had soft, soggy crust (poor technique, storage, or not fresh), and the cake part of the carrot cake was so dry it was developing its own toast-like crust. Very poor labeling of dishes. What was labeled shrimp and grits was actually chorizo or some kind of ground meat with grits. Some dishes were unlabeled. We were very disappointed because we're staying in the City Center area, and Aria is convenient. The Thai tea and the service weren't bad. But we'll need to see an "Under New Management" sign before coming back.

9CuG2syMDOWrvyopi2ySwA.text: I have tried numerous buffets in Las Vegas, and the Aria ranks up with the Paris as tied for my favorites.  I go for the quality of the food and friendliness of staff  when rating them. I don't eat a lot but like the variety you get at a buffet. Marref stands out for her exceptional service!

Yql4wEL7h2qfutFE__Cz0A.text: I never have high expectations when coming to a buffet.  It was decent the fresh motzerella was so delicious so were the mussels and this clam soup with chorizo. The desserts were good I really enjoyed the gellato wheel.  My waitress I don't remember her name but she was excellent never had to stop her to insist on another drink, napkins or my plates to be tooken off while I'll give it 4 stars not 3. Won't be my first stop to go buffet wise but if I was invited as a group outting I guess I would go again

sfTg9Bxoji1GiM8h3zT0Uw.text: Good selections of good food. The drinks on the all you can drink option were delish. Server kept my drinks coming and did not rush us to eat and leave. We showed up at the end of brunch and were able to nom on some of the lunch items as well. Would eat here again!

lqYNY1X-eYYMrsncrWk5qQ.text: no one really expect prime dining when going to a buffet. and this one is certainly not. Still wonder why we made is there? Probably the fixed price $37 per person (not cheap but affordable in vegas) as we got burned by an mediocre restaurant the night before @ $120+ per person.  It is basically a combination of savorless cafeteria food, calorie galore dish that satisfy no other intent than stuffing yourself as much as you can to make your $ worth it. But no it's not good. Service is below acceptable. And atmosphere is a mix of a jail cafeteria (of what In think a jail cafeteria is), a economy waiting lounge in a train station,  or a feeding troff for people with scooters

ODj5HV4PnGi6lyoYZ9VB3A.text: Meh.  I've had better. There are so many buffets in Vegas, and this one is definitely on the lower side. It's almost $50 for dinner because they add lobster and unlimited wine, but it's still not worth it. Service was INCREDIBLY slow... I asked for a refill on my water about two times before finally receiving one fifteen minutes later. Food was okay, not bad at all, but not worth the price.  Desert bar was typical. Gelato, creme brulee, etc. Tasted yummy, but they have those selections in almost every buffet.  I love staying at the Aria, but I probably won't ever eat here again.  I recommend Wicked Spoon in Cosmo! Yum! :D

hyS0pkO5DKOhaEfBxD2BEw.text: It was Saturday morning and I was browsing the little booklet you get behind the headrest on the taxi and noticed this ad for a buffet at Aria.   It showed a picture of Alaskan King Crab and shows breakfast for $15, lunch for $20 and dinner for $28.    So we take a taxi to the hotel and by the time we get there, it was late morning.  Low and behold they charged us $25 each for BRUNCH.  We didn't think much about it until after I sat down and started eating.  I then remembered that they advertised Alaskan King Crab and that was one of the main reasons why I wanted to eat here.  When I approached the buffet line, they had SNOW CRAB LEGS-which is a anorexic, cheap version and very different.  I looked at the receipt and noticed that we not only were overcharged, but they Falsely advertised their shit.  Not only did they charge us MORE for brunch than breakfast, even lunch, but they didn't have what they advertised at all.  I approached the manager and her response was that the Alaskan King Crab is for dinner only.  Look at the ad I uploaded and you tell me if it says that.  HELL NO.  I asked her to show me where the fuck it says that the crab is "during dinner only".  She said, "Oh, I'll talk to marketing about that".  Are you freaking kidding me?  I'm not falling for that BS line.  Not only that, but why is her brunch prices higher than lunch?  She couldn't answer.  She then said, "Well, let me check with the chefs in the back and see if we have any Alaskan King Crab.  Uh...that's great, but I'm actually DONE eating and it's more about the issue more than anything now.  She brought me a plate of the crab legs, but I wasn't into it anymore.  I didn't like how she tried to pull the sheets over my eyes and mislead me, along with all the other people that didn't bother speaking up.  As a compromise, she refunded me 1 meal ($25).  I was satisfied, but wonder how many other people caught this.    The food was good, not spectacular.  One of my favorites was the thick-cut smoked bacon.  The pre-made breakfast burrito was yummy as well.  Oh...the absolute BEST thing they had was (drum roll) the COFFEE!  OMG...it was the absolute best coffee I've ever had in Vegas.  Starbucks/Peets can't touch this stuff.  The only other time I had coffee like this was in Portland Oregon in a coffee house there.  Aria has good breakfast if you pay $15 (as advertised), but certainly not $25 they tried to scam me on.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Does it show anywhere on this ad that the Alaskan King Crab legs are for &#34;dinner only&#34;?

2I7sVd3UdhNIWzB74_eZaw.text: Firstly food is good but the staff is money minded and if you don't pay tip before you have food the server will treat you like a dog. The big group when we had been there and planned to pay tip after we have food as usual they didn't even allow us to sit together. Pathetic staff, such a place don't deserve these worst staff.

CD9jOsKtZR_v8VgJGuMdmw.text: It's a buffet....yawn (did I mention I'm not a big buffet fan).  Compared to other vegas buffets this one is very small.

PUDLd7BOhus33skhKBoltw.text: For the price of the buffet, it was not that bad. I think that it was around $44 a person, and it had king crab, shrimp, oysters and mussels. So if you're going to a Vegas buffet just for crab, I would come here. However they did not have a good selection of sushi, actually the sushi didn't look fresh at all and I did not eat any of it. The Asian food section served the worst pad thai I've ever eaten, and the dim sum wasn't that great either. I did like the carving station because the lamb was extremely good and they actually had mint jelly which surprised me because a lot of buffets do not serve lamb let alone provide mint jelly. But as I mentioned before if you just want to eat king crab then you should go to this buffet because it is $20 cheaper then Caesar's Palace, but if you want more variety this is not the place to go.

79vPqjEQFlw0FXyM3HHylA.text: Good food for a better price than Bellagio. Lots of choices and fresh pasta was good. Lamb was good and they had Indian and Mediterranean menu which was very good for us.

i8Hp7Gnc4jwtnNyvVPMZ6Q.text: Great selection of food, prime rib outstanding. Only negative you have to pay for your drinks at the table before you get them.

YtFFak40INP5Usn7fs0gTQ.text: Went here for breakfast during a conference in Vegas, instead of doing the crappy conference egg sandwiches. I was really surprised how much variety they had and how good it was. Something for everyone and it all seemed relatively fresh and hot. A bit pricey at $20pp, but I would go back again.

B8pk9NJ_Bz7Bc_j3r9lPAA.text: Horrible service.... We sat down for over 25 minutes and my server didn't show up. I had to make a complaint and asked for a manager just to get a cup of coffee. Not a word of apology from anyone....  Then, I asked for extra silverware from the server, and she forgot. Food was not that good either, which made my experience even worse.  I will definitely not return.

Ubi19-GtLlqHGUIkotBEdA.text: My favorite buffet in Vegas. THIS WAS AMAZINGLY AWESOME! Quality & wide selection. Everything from grape leave wraps to miso soup to crawfish to pizza to fresh sliced prime rib & pork to eggs Benedict to hand made sorbet... Upscale and way better than Bacchanal that is advertised everywhere! I will be visiting this buffet each time I go to Vegas.

TuUbyKNEI7PjDJ7gKQSauQ.text: This buffet used to be way better. It had its own identity, with good food.   Now it is a sad imitation of the Bachcanal buffet at Ceasars. They have a few different meats at the carving station. They are serving things in their own little cooking containers. Just like the Bacchanal. They even use the same tyoe of music. Yet the food quality and service isn't as good as the Bacchanal.  My wife had a bagel that was hard. Our waitress went on break so our table stopped being served. When I went to get ice cream the server gave it to me. Then remembered he was supposed to be wearing rubber gloves. It didn't replace my ice cream that he used his fingers to help serve, he just went on to the next person.   The price is not impressive either. We paid $32 each today for brunch. Yesterday we paid the same at the Bacchanal for lunch.   My recommendation,  if you don't feel like walking or waiting this buffet is fine. If you don't mind waiting or walking then go to Ceasars.

477T5_Szlc4HePCKfDxiUQ.text: Best Buffet in Las Vegas!!!! I go here all of the time! They do need to make regular pumpkin pie though, they only have pecan and pumpkin mix.

RyHyrdh69sNtdbIpLdmJ8A.text: I want to give this place a 3.5, but the extremely high price of this buffet made me round it down to a 3. There was like 5 people in line when I got there at 7pm which was very weird. I went on a saturday and the dinner cost like $46 after tax and tip.   The layout and design of the restaurant give it a high class vibe. The general food and quality was very similar to Bellagio with more of a focus on Indian food. They have fresh made naan which was quite delicious.  Theres the standard crab legs and shrimp, but for some reason the weekend I went it had unpeeled shrimp and the crab legs were smaller then I remembered seeing before. They also gave half a lobster to each guest after you sat down, but you were not allowed to have refills on the lobster. Lobster was very delicious.  I mainly enjoyed the carved meats. They had a lot of options such as brisket, prime rib, pork ribs, beef ribs, skirt steak, mahi mahi, etc. I of which we very good. The chinese food and sushi was okay, but not real memorable. I didnt try the pastas, they had a pasta station, but didnt use it.  The desert area is sorta hit or miss. I didnt like it, but I know others who have liked it. Its more of a crap shoot on whether or not the stuff they had was the stuff you liked. I love cheesecake and creme brulee, but they didnt really have anything like that. The cheesecake they had was not something I would consider to be a cheesecake.  I would go back again, but I think I would rather go to Bellagio buffet.

3ckooqawMDOCR8MDpctHhg.text: Bellagio, Ceasars will be the better choice  -Meat ; smelled old  -Desert; not much choice, cheaply made therefore tasted Bad, only thing to eat is ice cream - Macaroni cheese ; more like macaroni soup - Calm Chowder ; Not served   Used to be a fair buffet, had great Calm Chowder soup & Mac cheese ; NOW all went downhill, management didn't seem to realize or care.  Why would a place like this choose to go downhill I do not know...  Sorry to see this buffet so down graded.   I will choose Bellagio, Ceasars, Wicked Spoon for better buffet taste & experience.

vJYlA2L1brlMdt9jL5HmZw.text: The foods is cold and not fresh, really disappointed, not worth it at all with the price. Dont eat this place after 8pm, we ate couple times after 8 pm and the food taste nasty and really embarrassing because we brought our guesses from out if country

ehozpAuM3bSxRb4iKAtAeg.text: Went there Wednesday for breakfast before flying out since we were staying at Vdara. $43 for 2 people.  The coffee was good and our service was 4 stars,  but the food overall was subpar.  All the hot food on the buffet line was lukewarm at best. The scrambled eggs were seriously undercooked and the omelet station used carton scrambled eggs not fresh eggs.  It's a shame that such a beautiful property such as Aria has such a mediocre buffet.

-dZYFCBUbikSKvu-3JiriQ.text: Went for lunch. About $25 per person. They had everything. However, only thing i liked was the roasted pork, Portuguese sausage, and their gelato. The Asian section was so gross...everything was stuck together in their little steamers. Their chicken dumplings look like they've been there for so long they turned black. Their Shao Mai have been steamed too long or re-steamed too many times so the skin is falling apart.  Not worth $25. Overall, everything was probably reheated from their leftovers from the night before. Not going back.

Wn990usWvG-wLMdDg4lmkw.text: The food here was spectacular. Service was a little slow. But with this aside, it was a great experience. Just don't pick a table near the window if people are sitting in the spa... you peer right out at them... AKWARD!

jrPhtmfiLRjZ0PRrLJMNtQ.text: Kid friendly. Amazing service. Delicious and healthy choices. Huge selection. Top notch.

LnirMPiwZAgSRXMUHOzSmA.text: Great selection but nothing was amazing. And for $32 on a Saturday that just didn't cut it for me. Not a terrible stop if you're wanting all you can drink as well but it's not a destination by any means.

BaWPFhnS459_3hoOKAviRQ.text: In my 3 time I'm stay at aria try the buffet and it have horrible service from the start the person who help in the entrance bad , the food is ok but really expensive.

615JbVg_VnWsNLXN6-E5nA.text: forgettable and bland. even the Chirozzi lacked flavor.  Skip this Buffet and head down something else.

O_QtEjUHrVmilO_y42qz0Q.text: Don't come here expecting the best buffet you've ever had. The food quality is mediocre at best. Crab legs are pretty good. Not as good as the Seafood buffet at Rio. Crawfish was lackluster. Come on where's the Cajun seasoning? Oysters during dinner were a decent value. Besides that everything else is disappointing. Chinese...boring. General Tso's Chicken tastes weird. BBQ Pork buns were not authentic. Pretty crappy Chinese fare actually. Italian? Forget about it...crappy pizza and vegetable lasagna. Indian.... Meh you get better Indian food at a local Indian buffet. Fried chicken? Over fried and probably double fried since they were hard as a rock and not juicy and tender. Mexican? Another meh... Prime Rib was decent. Having lived in the Midwest. Definitely not in the very good category. Not to bad though. I was highly unimpressed with this place. Everything was average to below average. Crab legs, oysters, and shrimp were the only positives. Even the clams and mussels didn't taste that great.  Dessert...wow was I disappointed. Cheesecake was lame. Their Gelato was pretty good.   For lunch $25.99 on the strip. It was ok value. Otherwise save yourself the trouble and go elsewhere.

cYwEHeoCbq1xgiiCLmoecQ.text: I had high hopes for the food, but was disappointed. I did go early, expecting to have all the different dishes I had seen on youtube. The King crab was never served the whole time I was there. The other crab that was served was skimpy and had very little meat. Ate mostly the green lipped mussels. Price was high for the selections of food that were available. Never go there again.

Wb2LUXuULDgTTNw9T-7oEw.text: damn this place is expensive! and  the quality of the food is just so so! I have tried many other buffets in vegas and I still think Bellagio buffet is the best....

_yRACenn62Fx5qTdCCSDwA.text: Not really impressed with the food quality.  They had the standard fare of thin crab legs, prime rib and assorted foods, but the quality wasn't there for me.  Perhaps I am on the road too much and have become too much of a food critic.  Next time I will use Yelp before I make my selection instead of when I do the review.

AlIigGM-l6i1k7e2UScT-Q.text: The Buffet at Aria is overpriced and pretty run-of-the-mill.  I have been to many buffets in Las Vegas and this is just another also-ran nearly finishing last.  I went in the late afternoon and squeezed in to snag the lunch price before dinner started at 4:00.   There was no wait which should have been a huge sign to me that this buffet wasn't going to be all that good. But I gave it a try and it will be my last visit.  The staff and service people are really nice.  But, the food is nothing special for the amount of money.  Don't get me wrong..the food compares well to less expensive buffets in the area.  But the selection is really not so great and this is not an inexpensive buffet.

SveZBpStrb96F3OxpegiHg.text: Had a lunch buffet with my mom and dad at Aria - Picked Aria over Bellagio because the former has better view and the latter does not have seafood for lunch...For about $21 per person plus tax and tips, it offers a good value.  The dining area is open and sunny bright that you can see the garden from the floor to ceiling windows.  Wide selection of food - sushi bar, salad bar, Italian, Asian, Indian, meat, desserts, etc., has something for everyone. The snow crab legs are my favorite - fresh and nicely prepared, absolutely delicious!!! The chicken noodle soup is heart warming but not too greasy. The beef brisk is mouth-watering juicy, and the gelato is yummy.  Worth the price, strongly recommended!

Pa3pZW3BPszn5W58_tsunA.text: probably one of the best places ever. the food was incredible and the selection was to plan another visit.  will be back on the next trip here.  the staff was only goal to make sire you are having a great time and enjoying the food.

gs141cgoPToSIml6FdzyfA.text: The price is WAY NOT worth it for the type of food we ate.   Mind you, this is the second time I ate at Aria and the experience was so dramatically different. My first experience was great and I would have recommended Aria to friends/family despite their lack of variety. However, during my second visit we did NOT experience items that were served during my first dining experience:  -soft-shelled crab (although a bit salty) -raw oysters -lobster tails (big ones)  There were at least 4 other people who I heard asking "Where are the lobsters?" including myself. The answer: "I THINK it is served on Saturday." I mean WTF kind of an answer is that. I don't remember the price we paid but it was probably AT MOST a $4 difference. We paid $36 on Friday.  Summary: To all of you hoping to have lobster tails, go on Saturday. And expect disappointment on any other days.....

f31l74Fu_YI_3by0All8aw.text: I went here for the dinner buffet which was $30 a person. The design and atmosphere is nice and they offer a variety of foods. Seafood, Mexican, Chinese, pizza etc. I felt that the king crab legs and prime rib were the best choices. They served other meats like rack of lamb, but they were not worth taking up space in my stomach. The dessert bar was good with several types of pastries and ice cream. The creme brulee was better than average for buffets. A friend told me the selection at brunch is good. I would eat here again, but only if I had free dining credit at the Aria.

yRYVe6wsz-UvSnGVCH2GPg.text: we were planning on going to wicked spoon again cause some people in our group had not been there, but we were out by aria so we just stopped there.  overall, i was pretty impressed and i wouldn't mind coming back.  however, it was a little bit of a pain getting there because it was such a walk  service: service was really good, and the staff was very nice.  our whole group was pretty drunk and they were still very nice to us and explained all the stuff for the buffet.  at the table they were fast bringing more drinks and they were fast at taking away plates but were not always there and getting in your way  value: i think the buffet was pretty good value at $35.  selection was more than bellagio, but the food itself was not quite as good.  about the same amount, maybe a little less selection than wicked spoon but there were different choices.  you get half a lobster per person too, but it wasn't really that big so i didn't think much of it, and i also am not a huge lobster person.  the thing that i think puts the aria up there is that you get unlimited merlot or chardonnay with dinner which is cool.  i am not a huge wine person, but free booze is free booze  food: there was a large selection, and for the most part there was not anything i didn't like.  sushi was better than wicked spoon, but not as good as bellagio.  they had a cool little greek section which i really liked between the salads lamb and other offerings.  the crab was really good (didn't taste like salt water, it actually tasted pretty good), the lobster was kinda rubbery and not too much flavor, but i always feel that lobster is like that which is why i am not a huge lobster fan as said earlier.  the shrimps by the crab with the shells still on were very good, along with the already prepared shrimp cocktales.  the pizza was decent, along with the fish and chips.  the only thing i don't think i liked was the baby back ribs.  they were just so fatty that it was not enjoyable to eat them.  dessert was a small section, but the choices all tasted pretty good, and they had butterfinger gelato which was absolutely amazing.  overall, I would probably come back, but i wouldn't make it a priority as i love going to different buffets all the time

4L949lZc5oAyxoRSQUhWww.text: Just got back from Vegas in which we stayed the last night at Aria, so thought we would hit their breakfast buffet, thinking it would be on par with Belligo and Wynn. Boy, were we wrong. OK, know it's only their second day in operation, but how can you screw up bacon and eggs? My wife and I were shown our table, and immediately went to get our food. The food area was quite long, but not a great selection. Usually I walk and look at the food and figure out the few things that look best so I can fit them onto my plate, but here, it was a struggle to find enough things appealing enough to eat. Their eggs benedict looked very weird; the eggs were freakishly white. Hard to find just regular breakfast fare. There were two omelet stations with many people waiting at each ( you know a buffet is bad when people opt for the 'ol standby omelet) I got in line behind Mr. Picky who had to have a special egg white only omelet with veeeery light Cheddar cheese and was also behind some punk kid who was eating off his plate in line. Idiot. The chef manning the station seemed overwhelmed by the special order so I moved on. A huge slice of ham (not bad), some Chinese egg concoction and a slice of pizza later I went back to eat. Started eating and no server yet. Half way through and still no server. Finally when I was almost done, a server asked if I wanted anything to drink. I barely chocked out, "orange juice". Finally, when I was on my second to last bite, my drink came, all six ounces of it. I asked for two more.  For 15 bucks, this should have been much better. I have gotten just a good breakfast at Terribles for half the price. Also, since this place should be one of the elite, what I found totally tacky was at each of the foods, instead of having a nice plaque with what the food is, it was written on the sneeze windows with grease pencil. Totally lame. Not sure if we would go back to eat here even if comped. Perhaps their lunch and dinners are better.

DbVBhX-1aiaihSO3x3qZWg.text: We ate here last week, it was very average.  And average doesn't cut it.  I go back to what I usually say about LV strip buffets... some people aren't going to agree... but... if you're thinking about eating at one...head to the Bellagio, and EAT THERE.  Aria buffet is OK.  But we had dinner on a Sat Nite which was about $40 per person with tax & tip (YES you still tip at the LV buffets) and was NOT worth it.  We don't drink, so the unlimited wine didn't come into play.  The lobster was downright bad, tasteless and dry.  Crab legs were fresh, decent enough...some poeple were just eating those and nothing else.  We had the displeasure of butting heads with the seedier element of Vegas right there in the crab line.  Some hill-billy woman was holding things up, just standing there with no one in front of her.  We politely asked if she was in fact in line - and she got all bent out of shape.  You know the type - fat with the K-Mart shorts exposing legs no one should see, clumps of greasy dirt-blond strands for hair and big, dull neo-biker tattoos on her arms.  How these people get in places like the Aria, who knows.  The buffet probably needs the business.  Anyway...  I gave Buffet at Aria 3 stars for its OK quality.  Plus, the people who work there DO work hard.  I won't  deny them that.  I say that, despite the fact that the cashier was, well, sort of abrasive we felt and the hostesses didn't really seem to have it together.  People were being seated from 2 lines (not the VIP line) and there seemed to be no order to it.  People were getting upset.  It's really more like 2 1/2 stars but I'll give 3 in recognition of the seemingly nice, hard-working serving staff.  But, I wouldn't return.

hAqZ5yhJlWWym6J0s5BKIA.text: After eating at the Buffet at Aria, I feel like it was probably the worst bet I made all weekend.   The only good thing about it was our waitress who constantly brought us drinks, sometimes even when they were extra. This was one of the only positive of the night. It's bad when the best thing about a $35.99 (+18% gratuity for parties over 8 + tax) is their Indian Naan and watery hummus.   At the start of the experience, we had to deal with the cashiers who had no idea what they were doing, with the hostess telling us to go to 1 register then the other rudely telling us we were going to the wrong one and that they needed to keep us together so we don't confuse the cashiers (even though we were the only ones in line). Another weird situation was after charging you the 18% mandatory gratuity, they hand you the cash, $12 and some change, and make you hand it to your server. Step 1, pay with credit card, step 2, receive cash, step 3, tip server.   Once we sat, we realized there is not easy access to the rest of the buffet because we were sat in one of these stage like sections of the place, with only one exit to our pod. We were sat pretty close to the old oysters and crab legs, but the line and traffic that it came with was not worth the proximity.   Our group pretty much came to the consensus that for that price, we'd rather eat at the Wynn or the Bellagio, or maybe go to Rio for the cheaper version. The Buffet at Aria, however, was not worth the time or money.   If i had to give it a price, I'd say it belongs around the $15.99 price range for both the food quality as well as the overall decor and service. While our waitress was happy and attentive, it could not save the glaring problems that this buffet faces. I would probably give a few stars leniency for service only, as it was opening week/weekend, however, food quality should not be that bad. It's not like the cooks are learning to cook on the job.   FAIL.

ACnU483VrgQxjX_FPg-09g.text: Lots of food, good service. A typical las vegas buffet.

Q_jznZkwDOH5HqLDY6Fktg.text: Pretty low end for a purported high end hotel. Price is good ($20) for lunch but it really seemed like a larger version of the Old Country Buffet. Nothing very surprising or interesting to choose from though the Indian station was a bit different.  Crab legs were a bit suspect, too.  I'd save my money and go to a better hotel buffet (Wynn, Paris, Bellagio).

403mKup6Jtsg2lo3IyJmgg.text: I really like the buffet at Aria.  It certainly isn't the largest buffet, but it has a certain charm as a brunch buffet.  The crab legs definitely helped my disposition after a long night at the tables in Vegas but the desserts probably put me over the top.  We had a very friendly Korean-born waitress who made sure our drinks and everything else was topped-off and ready to go.  Yay! I'm a fan.

g4q8fQe7JrDyLvmSdU-Vzw.text: We were looking for somewhere to eat quite late in the evening during a week night. We ended up at the Aria and decided to the try to buffet. The service was very good, the price was unremarkable and the food was EXCELLENT. The array was outstanding, we loved how many ethnic varieties there were, and the desserts were MMMMMM! We enjoyed the personal attention we got from the service staff especially as my mom was feeling very sick and weak. They allowed my parents to sit with us and have free drinks even though they didn't pay for the buffet, and turned a blind eye when we forced my mom to eat a little shrimp and dessert. Overall, it was a very pleasant dining experience and the best buffet we've had in Vegas to date.

iwtCzaKqhoaV0ikveDINKg.text: $20 for lunch/dinner is nothing to complain about. The actual food is only mediocre though (still not complaining), but you get to have the variety you want. The desserts were the highlight--yummu yummy yummy. I went back like 6 times.

Te3BwftEFN8C9WxImhfM_g.text: Well since it was new i was ready to try it...Bad idea! For about $68 for two people for brunch you would at least expect some good eating. This place had all your basic buffet food and the king crab legs were fishy i couldnt even eat it.

YEj1NuDfpxpzJ3H8hQZl2w.text: TOTALLY NOT WORTH IT!!! DO NOT GO THERE.  Went there for dinner on my birthday, Dec 2009, thinking that this new Vegas buffet would want to come out strong and compete with the Bellagio and Wynn Buffets.  I was sorely disappointed.  I mean come on! it's Vegas!  Buffets are one of the things that completes the Vegas experience!  All of the food was dry, as if they've been sitting under the heat lamp all day.  Furthermore, the selection was terrible.  I will never go back.   We also talked to the manager and politely gave him our opinion about the food.  We asked him if he's tried other buffets such as the Wynn or Bellagio, to which he replied,"I've actually never tried any of those buffets."  I'm very surprised that the manager of this buffet is not going out there and sizing up the competition or even just seeing what a Vegas buffet is like.   After a disappointing buffet, we took the tram to the Bellagio the next day to eat at their buffet and all was well again. :)

MjUz8Wl7FOhotfzRYuLkhg.text: I don't know why some people rated this buffet so low. For $31 you get unlimited champagne or bloody marys. That's a great deal considering everything in Vegas is crazy expensive. Plus, the food is really good. The place is really clean and new. I am glad I tried it out for myself, despite some of the poor reviews.

AWUjy5-1BrBylvuDzeWZxQ.text: So disappointing. The space feels like a cafeteria, the food is underwhelming. The food looks good, but not the best quality. Very good service however, and I sure hope for everyone's sake employed there the place is reworked.

xiuZUI2Mg2EYY78haDkj2A.text: Im not sure what to give this buffet...a mix between two and three stars...iits freakin pricey of course 20 day and 30 night. The food was many, but too much, clean bars, but the food wasn't very good. I;m not sure maybe cause I'm southern and Vegas taste is different, but the yogurt was sour and not good, maybe it was bad....the sausages were quite a feel to choose from, but all of them also tasted a bit sour and not like your usual mouthwatering ones...only the breakfast sausage was good, the bagles and cream chz were good, everything else wasn;t very tasty or satisfying. Thats all I can say....the service was okay as well, our waitress was ice, but the hosts, bar service, and cashiers sure didn;t seem off in a good feel. But they had a good diverse mix of food I suppose.

Km_SY-bpJovyViJj76ebVw.text: Brunch is $24 and for an additional $5 you can get unlimited mimosas or bloody marys. Brunch comes with king crab legs if you can stomach those in the morn/lunch time. A line started at around noon, but we got there by 11am so it was quick to get in. Service was attentive, except when the BF wanted his 5th bloody mary. Overall it's a decent buffet, and I actually sort of like how the seating arrangement is almost cafetaria-like.

eczgtgkNtNLv-HNvsbO4uA.text: Talk about foreshadowing: anytime you see a short or empty buffet line in Las Vegas, you should beware. The buffet at Aria was average. It was unimpressive for what i thought would be a buffet equal to that of other 5-star hotels like Bellagio or Wynn.   In terms of variety, I felt the aria buffet tried to accomplish that by offering a number of different international cuisines such as indian, chinese, japanese, etc. However, i still felt that WITHIN each cuisine, there just wasn't much. For example, sure they had japanese food, but specifically they only had 3 types of rolls and some nigiri. No other types of sashimi, no unique rolls, no tempura, etc etc.  In terms of seafood, they had the usual king crab legs, shrimp scampi, and oysters, but it wasn't any different from what you would find in any other decent buffet.  In terms of how they serve you the food, it's a little strange: they have their food on smallerl serving plates. While this may give an impression that the dishes are more fresh and replenished more frequently, this also causes an inconvenience to the customer when dishes are constantly running out and staff members have to refill it. This means customers waste more time waiting for their food than eating it.  On a more positive note, the service was excellent. This is strange just because no one really notices the service or remembers their waiter in a buffet, but mine was so good that i certainly did remember. She was always refilling our drinks, asking if we needed anything, and never late in clearing our used plates.   Overall, if you had a choice of buffets at Las Vegas, I would still opt for Bellagio or Wynn. The price at Aria is similar to that of other upscale hotel buffets (~40 for dinner) and simply doesnt satisfy in terms of variety or taste.

wV_OheQALBfi74XhyXbb0g.text: don't waste your money on the dinner buffet  The lobster was the size of bigger crayfish. There were plenty crab leggs and shrimps but nothing tasty.   The wine was horrible.  After havign 2 glasses everything tasted the same.  I don't think the waitress was happy if you sat at your table for more than an hour.  bottom line don't waste your money on buffet.  It would be better to spend a little more on an ordered menu in a nicer restaurant.  Aria hotel room was very nice but paying resort fee but not getting free wifi and use of the gym were the down side and we will not stay there again.

_P_QwmEk69n1Q1PoCNSjbw.text: Went there dinner 1/31/12.  They had the unlimited lobster tail for $70 special. Really liked their selection. Nice cocktail shrimps. Crab legs were already opened for easy eating. Good overall.

uVk5eAr19-2_zcmmdabA4g.text: My wife and I came here several years ago and loved the place.  We decided to stop by again and what a mistake it was.  The food selection was very limited.  The taste was ok.  I was anticipating to have lobster tail but apparently they did away with it.  We were disappointed.   One good thing, there was no line.  We were seated immediately on a Saturday night for dinner.

sqV-5hDQ0b4tNesm-bYhDg.text: How many nice restaurants are there in Las Vegas on the strip alone?  A lot.  How many did we eat at?  ZERO!  Thanks to my husband's inability to wait 5 minutes once he's hungry and our friends who would rather spend their cash on beverages, rather than food.  So Aria's buffet was our Friday night dinner.  With unlimited wine and a lobster for every two people, $36 sounded like a pretty good deal.  Unfortunately, since we never made it back to our hotel room the night before, I was not at my best for eating.  The buffet had just about everything.  Multiple carving stations that included lamb, turkey, New York steak, pork tenderloin, and prime rib.  I had none of that, so I can't comment other than to say my companions were pleased.  Seafood options included crab legs, shrimp and oysters among other things.    The "free" lobster was a mess.  Our order was lost, so there was a long delay, and it was NOT worth the wait.  It was so overcooked, it was like chewing on a piece of rubber.  Minus two stars alone for the senseless slaughter of crustaceans.  If you can't prepare it well enough to at least be edible, don't bother offering it!

FUkd97V5S2brp3ZXFb4avw.text: Best buffet in Las Vegas for its price. Well recommended!!

3wjjBSp67wpWT-exskmoDQ.text: After a long wait, we got in but the choice wasnt great. The price was a whopping 38 instead of the advertised 30. The decor is clean but the place is under staffed. The main highlight, snow crab was half frozen.

xKQBM2gyy9LE7AynY3FOSA.text: The lunch for 20 dollars is a steal....crab legs and solid buffet fare all around. People keep raving about the Bellagio and Wynn buffets which are solid, but why pay double for just a few more items you can't stuff in unless you develop that second stomach.  Virtually no line because most people haven't figured out what Aria is about yet. A great deal if you're looking to fill up for the day.  CAVEAT - if you're sensitive to shaking, (frequent grumbles from the train below) then you might get a little sick sitting here. My friend sure was. Can we say engineering FAIL.

HRLO05gDTtpRHlBWTm-NNw.text: The buffet itself isn't horrible but the service is pretty bad.   Came here on a Sunday night and they were way understaffed. People were confused as to where to sit and the hostesses didn't know which tables were open. Out drinks weren't refilled as the poor waitresses was running around trying to take too many tables on.   Food: It is allright. You obviously can't compare it to the Bellagio or the Wynn but it's decent. The garlic naan was SO GOOD! It has to be good since it was actually made in those cool stone clay pans and made fresh right on the spot. The shrimp is very large and fresh. The crab labs weren't bad.   Dessert: Ok well you know it has to be good since it was designed by Pastry Champion Jean-Philippe Maury. I literally tried everything! Not too sweet and not too decadent.   I really only came here cuz I had food credit from Aria. I guess it's not bad for the price. I believe it was around $27.00 for dinner per person

eYXbWv6xhnQBvvGHmNstdg.text: I came here for Sunday Brunch before heading back to Cali after a great weekend. This buffet was a total buzz kill.   So... if there was a "0" star option, I would've picked that and still commented that there needs to be a negative star rating.   This was hands down the worst buffet experience ever. I cant believe they even got away with labeling this a buffet, especially in such an upper scale hotel.   First off, they advertise themselves as being the Crab Leg central of Las Vegas. If by "crab leg," they mean "cold small crab fingers/slivers," then yes, this is your place.   Second, the rest of the buffet was mismatched, random and clearly lacking in any menu planning whatsoever.  You would have a carving station with lamb (no prime rib on the Sunday Brunch Menu, go figure), then next to it, you would have enchiladas, then scrambled eggs. Nothing made sense.   The decor was lack luster, sterile and looked like a hospital cafeteria. This place makes Hometown Buffet look like the Four Seasons.   The only thing good about this place was.... well. yea. nothing. I want my money back.

2IOQIcoMD276mkJ3LukLMg.text: Just had a great evening and topped things off at the Aria buffet. $86.46 for two at dinner time. The food was excellent . Try the prime rib it's to die for and I'm not sure why Butta every buffet I look for the clam chowder to try. This one was a hit. Not one thing went wrong on this go round

SYTK3mDzEUXgdWvc8VgvRw.text: don't do.   NOT worth the 33 bucks. Will never make this mistake again. Unimpressive is being kind.

agknvTQTE3VyjUHrQJxvzw.text: I booked Vdara which included a $20 per person per day buffet credit (excluding gratuities and taxes) and Aria was one of the participating hotels. We tried the dinner buffet on our first night in Las Vegas. The ambiance and decor was lovely as it was a newer hotel. A staff member escorted us to the table and politely asked us to watch our step on the stairs. Our server was fantastic. She kept up with husband's refills and she took away our plates promptly. I enjoyed the food selection. I love Indian food so I was happy to see Indian dishes and naan in particular. There were Chinese dishes as well which did not have much or any msg. I finished off the dinner with a sugar-free cheese cake which I enjoyed.  The regular price for dinner is $29.95 which is the same as the Bellagio dinner buffet. I really enjoyed the ambiance and service at the Aria buffet and the food is great. In comparison, the Bellagio dinner buffet has a greater variety of foods but definitely not as lovely of an atmosphere as Aria. I would go back to Aria for the dinner buffet.

7-S2jYED5ABcx1wK0fcbGA.text: I went for dinnertime, and it wasnt terrible, but it was nothing to write about. The "big buffets" (caesars, cosmopolitan etc) outshine this one, even the MGM is better in my opinion. However, it's not slop and it's vegas AND it's a buffet, so three stars seems sufficient. Plus, I love Aria. So beautiful.

Gawxjnr8Wveiod36kVl0Qg.text: They say you get lobster but they lie.  Pretty much pissed.  I called before arriving and asked if the lobster was included they said yes but we were informed after paying and being seated that is no longer the case and its been that way for quite a while apparently.  Food not worth 43 bucks a person.  I really didn't like the food.  It was cold, old, with films on top of everything.  I don't know maybe it was a slow Sunday night.  Took one bite of everything appealing to me and nothing but the crab was good enough to make it to a second bite.  I would never waste my money here again.

wUWONyB2-X9xLc1f_6Gy9Q.text: Enjoyed Aria's buffet, been here with the hubby for breakfast and Sunday brunch. I enjoy the pastries from Jean Phillipe :) A little of everything for everyone. I like the open seating feel. The crowd here is average and I am ok with that, don't like feeling like I'm in a herd of people. Food here is fresh and presentable. The times we have been here, our servers have always been very attentive and friendly!

btrUvGyWu39yXCrDayH2JQ.text: With all you can drink wine and lobster deal- you can't really complain about a buffet that includes prime rib and king crab legs.  I suggest you stock up on the cocktail shrimp!

L9ycZcGaXFTIKe1HUb4FKw.text: We tried this because we were going to the Viva Elvis show and thought it would be convenient, which it was.  However, I neglected to check the reviews here first...for the price wish we would've gone to Wicked Spoon.  Food was ok, decor was ok, size was smaller than I would've expected and selection was lacking.  Also, what I read online said 'rack of lamb'...no.  And price online was less than when we got there, this was for a Tues nite.  We do buffets quite a bit and there's many, even at 1/3 the price, which are far better.  Service, however, was very good.

nE_G0H3okEKSnkmnWqD5eg.text: Buffet is worth 4.95 very dissapointing coming from Aria. Only French toast, tofu salald and gelato were good.  The wait and price totally not worth it, save your Vegas Money and go somewhere else!!

FGc4_BrIiLo6lbDhbpIhBQ.text: It was ok. Th crab legs are split which makes it to where you have to eat twice as many. Everything else was pretty standard. Honestly you can get the same thing at harrahs but cheaper.

DlQN8pd5OYLj6HZG1Ovp-g.text: Hit up the buffet on a friday night after checking in because we had credits for the buffet with our stay. Great selection from a variety of cuisines. Everything looked great, but some of the flavors were off and weren't cooked well. It's to be expected a bit with a buffet. The crab legs were good though. I was a bit upset because it was later in the night and they were removing dishes, especially with dessert, so we felt rushed. Moments after we we received our final drink and coffee, we were told that we needed to leave so they could close up and we couldn't finish our drinks. I get it somewhat, but not exactly friendly. Not the best experience, but others have had better.

PJD4iNYiSTOhiiyYWe2ZVw.text: Let's make this review short and not-so-sweet.  There were literally bugs in the salad (more than one).  Food ALL OVER the ground - it was filthy.  When we complained to the manager there, he offered us $5.  We couldn't even get to the real food stations because of the filth, and he offered one person $5, not each of us.  Wow.  I've heard this place has sanitary issues from a couple others as well.  Not cool!

4uxFD-wPen61xIgoISiEpA.text: If you don't know me by now.. I love buffets. It can be the most disgusting place in the world and i'd still find something great about it. Giving a 3 star rating is kind of a stretch but it wasn't 2 star bad so there you go.   Came in for the lunch buffet my last day in vegas, a bit sad to go and a heck of a lot sadder I couldnt hit up several more buffets but girls gotta party and full stomachs + clubbing dress dont really mix. For $25 per, this place wasnt so bad, with food ranging from japanese, mexican, italian.. etc. Im assuming one has been to a buffet before.   Things to skip: -sushi rolls .. with very little emphasis on the sushi part.. actually, scratch that.. no sushi in sight, just a couple of rice rolled in seaweed with vegetable stuffings. blaaaand. dry. stuck together. disgusting -ceviche .. smelly little cups of "seafood" and vegetables in vinegar -kimchi .. next to the chinese food section, the only korean thing there. disappointing. bland. and just plain wrong -some type of nacho .. cheese, beef, salsa.. sitting on top of some corn chips which by the way turned soggy by the time I scooped some up  Things to try: -omelets .. they make them on the spot for you so you really can't go wrong -waffles .. hated the other breakfast items but the waffles were perfect!! -roast meats .. selection of beef, turkey, pork. I got the roast beef with aju and horseradish which was the best thing there -dessert .. at first glance, I thought they had a huge selection but there were maybe 6 cakes and the rest were cookies and danish. Loved the apple pie, banana cream pie, and strawberry cheesecake  -gelato .. the lemon sorbet!!  Things that were eh: -crab legs .. it wasn't bad.. it wasn't good.. it was just meh -chinese food ..  -soups  Overall, the place wasn't horrible but wish i'd gone to the buffet at the bellagio or mandalay bay. Should've just stuck around for the dinner at another buffet anyway since the drive back took 7 freaking hours due to serious traffic!! My opinion for the place.. skip it unless you're getting comped.

jbi19xUhmi1W0_wliiT8jQ.text: It's a pretty good buffet. Not the best - the Bellagio still holds that honor IMHO - but certainly up there.   The crab legs were exceptionally good. Everything else was just "good".   It costs about the same as the other high end buffets but in general is not as crowded.   Bottom line: If you are here at meal time and want a buffet it's good. Not the best but certainly not bad.  Other than that there's really not much to say...

aZlrTpW2IdudGX-Y3F4lqg.text: Crab legs...always available for crab lovers, unfortunately, it wasn't for me.  Garlic Naan and Indian Curry:  really good  Sushi rolls:  decent  Desserts:  good  I've been to many buffet places in Vegas (Bellagio, Venetian, Caesar's Palace, etc...this place is just ok for me.  M Resort's buffet is still one of the best I've had....great food, great price!

WZC7uveCiNpNzAZVO9IEHg.text: My family and I had some extra money after paying bills so we decided to check out The Buffet at Aria. We are a family of 5 including a newborn, it started off that after we paid we waited until two hostesses decided to let us in and didn't acknowledge us at no given time while we were waiting to be seated. (We were the only ones in line) Hope who ended us seating us lead us to a table for four and wanted me to put my baby and stroller in the walkway!!! We asked to be seated at the next table over which seated 6 and she refused to do so. We didn't want to make a scene so we just made it work, but ended up blocking another guest sitting next to us. During our whole time eating the table that we wanted stayed empty. Why couldn't we sit there??? Oh yeah it was 5 of us and the table was for 6!!!!!! We will NEVER visit them again.

QEx6y_3v-2juVPdyQzGP3A.text: Dinner is relatively good value compared to comparable buffets because this one comes with lobster!  The lobster was actually pretty fresh and very good.  Our server told us that we could get the crab legs steamed, which I don't think everyone knew.  But definitely get them steam - they taste so much better.  After the lobster and about 8 plates of crab legs, i couldn't remember anything else they had at this buffet.  Does it matter?

K7Vb4QGrCD8YvFVau1y3jA.text: OVERALL: I went here for the weekday lunch buffet for $21.99 and to be honest was a little underwhelmed. While the buffet was clean, nicely decorated, and the personnel were all fast and friendly, the food did not live up to my expectations.  LUNCH DISHES: The best items were the beef brisket and the snow crab legs. I found that the rest of the stations were satisfactory but not good enough to go back for seconds.  DESSERT:In my opinion the gelato was the best dessert and I liked that they had a large variety of flavors to choose from. The other desserts that I tried (cheesecake, cake pops, cupcakes, and some cream-like dessert in a shot glass) were not that impressive.

8qYtgacFWjwuRHW72WDwvg.text: Crab legs, Shrimp cocktail, and more! I love this place! The waiters are so nice and attentive, and the tandoor oven and the dessert section are the WOW factors. Don't miss the desserts! They even recently expanded their Asian selections!

xMGyQpiUVQrmlih0DfHnGQ.text: This is not the best buffet I ever had. But I wasn't in the mood for paying $40 at the Wynn or Bellagio since I'm not a big eater. In contrast Aria buffet cost $27 which I thought had decent food. I enjoyed the snow crab and king crab which obviously tasted frozen. But what do you expect, Las Vegas is not Maine. The fish - halibut and salmon tasted overcooked and dry. I enjoyed the lamb which my friend claimed to taste too gamey for him. My friend also had an under cooked chicken, pink in the center, yuck! But the desserts were a delicious heaven, so many choices. If only I had more room. I recommend starting with the desserts!

zb_OHoByNxA_IDu3QpD3Dw.text: We ate Sunday brunch here. They had all you can drink champagne and bloody marys. The price was a bit high, but we drank and ate enough crab legs to get our money's worth. Flor (our waitress) was AWESOME! She was very friendly and kept the champagne coming. I liked that they had Indian food on the buffet. You don't see that often. We did have to wait, but not long. I will say that most of the desserts looked better than they actually tasted. I liked that the crab legs were already cracked for you. It made it way easier to eat. I would recommend this buffet!

-NSThcUyUrMVtekY8UI0lw.text: Price is good. Selection is very limited, compared to the Wynn or Bellagio. However, the items that they do have like king crab legs and various roasts are gooooood. Veal bacon? Yummm.  What I liked most was that it wasn't overly busy. You got to enjoy your meal without having to fight through crowds each time through the line. The food is still refreshed regularly so that you're always ensured warm and fresh food each time.   Best part of this buffet is the dessert - no question. So many options and they're all sugar-coma inducing goodness.  If you're looking for a melee style buffet, go elsewhere. But if you're looking for a change of pace, you'll like it here.

ZTho_-7wTtNTg-r1rT6fog.text: The buffet that all buffets are measured against is Bellagio's. And Aria's new buffet is better than Bellagio's.  Here there is lighter fare, which is a positive or negative depending on your perspective. While Bellagio has great food, I feel like the Michelin man weighed down by ankle weights when I am finished there. At Aria, I was nice and full but I didn't feel disgusting afterward.   And here the variety is better. It hit all the requisite stations, but it did so in different ways than at traditional buffets.   Two downsides, though: The signage for the food was poor, leaving you to guess what some items were; and the price at 3:30pm was just about $50, including tax/tip.   I recommend, but not for those having to pay for a family.

Y-JwerDyiVXVOy-f1vT8vQ.text: My current favorite Las Vegas Buffet.  I pretty much liked whatever it was I added to my plate.

ShLhhhUwkj2Kg5aZokXM7g.text: My brother and I came here for a Thursday "holiday" meal on 12/24/09 with dinner pricing at $27-ish+tax+tip and a half an hour wait. The menu looked promising and we had moderate expectations given that this was a new hotel of the MGM Mirage group that would likely have some experience with pushing food at buffets - but we were sadly, sadly disappointed.
