Thus my boyfriend and I returned for breakfast.  Boy were we in for a surprise...a salmonella surprise, that is.  I was so pumped they had an eggs benedict station, so I got two different types of my favorite eggs benedict.  But upon cutting into both eggs it became apparent that about 70% of the egg white was significantly under cooked (and by under cooked I mean the egg "white" was clear/transparent).  I looked at the table next to me and sure enough her eggs benedict was under cooked too.    Thankfully our waitress noticed my displeasure and took the eggs back to the chef to show him they were under cooked.  She was the saving grace to that breakfast, so we thanked her with a nice tip.  Someone else below mentioned how pleasant the African American man was at the carving station.  I'd like to second that.  My boyfriend thanked him about 5 times and the guy was so gracious and "just happy to be here".  He definitely put a smile on our faces.  I would have given the place 1 star but the staff was very friendly.

rSQyvARj52Xy1OeFmz7VFQ.text: A lot of options, some of the food was cold and old.  However, they have some great fresh seafood and a large dessert section.  We went at like 4pm in the afternoon and some of the food looked like it was sitting there for days.  I had to pass on a lot of the options.  I left disappointed!  Service was good though......

r24DlqAxh0CtA4vc64BQyA.text: Best buffet I've seen in vegas so far. The one at the bellagio was not good at all compared to aria.   Snow crab legs, sushi rolls, peel and eat shrimp, carved beef, it was nice.   Not sure if it's just the price that makes everyone have too high expectations but it a BUFFET folks. In Vegas. So compare it to other vegas buffets not sweet tomatoes at home or something. Hello!

UdCoapLEIbgG78_Lnb9WuQ.text: At $39 person, this place didn't offer much for the money. The line for the sushi (limited selection to Tuna only), crab legs, and cocktail shrimp was long for a buffet layout. Food is limited in selection, I found better places on the Las Vegas strip and Rio for a better deal. We were there on Saturday of the Memorial Day weekend and there was no line at all! so expensive and far from the strip.

oKVWJPX6g7xhF3lK8vsIGw.text: it above avg. and comparable to WYNN , much better than cosmopolitan.

-hTEn6w6Xykwv0PlryQBSQ.text: Sunday champagne brunch was nothing spectacular, but the quality was exceptional. There are too many other amazing choices in this town for locals, so I will probably not return.

kFEPWb3dJbVP0jqlhsb7og.text: Ugh!!! Why or why did we go here? It is one of the worst buffets that we have been to and costs a ton. We were there over the holiday and paid about $110 since hubby got the unlimited drinks too.  Nothing was good except the pie my hubby had and their little glasses of salad. The oysters were not edible, crab legs weren't salted, the floor was covered in food and cloth napkins were on the ground next to our table! How busy are you to leave gross food and napkins on the floor. The staff was rude or just ignored you at the salad and carving stations. I heard some guy ask for the lamb that just came out and the carving guy told him no and that he could have the stuff that had been sitting there for a while. I was so shocked, I skipped getting anything from the carving station hoping someone new will come later.  If you hate your job, why not find another one. We will never never return! I was so disappointed that we will not return to Aria to even gamble or stay anymore! Too many other buffets and casinos that provide good service and food. Also, we gamble thousands per day and don't mind paying, but bad food and rude service, no thank you.

HgeMm5VvvQIfGbwTFPTFSg.text: I went to Las Vegas in the past weekend (24-26/12). I spent 1.5 hours standing on the line for this buffet. The food quality is very good comparing with other famous buffet on the Strip, like Wynn (one of favor). However, the price is kind of pricy ($39.99). You can find king crab legs, prime rib, soft sheel crab, homemade ice-cream, ... . The buffet is including juice, sode, red and white.  Food highlight: King Crab legs (outside over $30 per lbs), prime rib.

ZPHbCM2KDcHv-L3h8fY-UQ.text: It seems a lot of people were unimpressed with this buffet, so I came with little expectations but came away pleasantly surprised. During my trip to vegas I went to the buffets at M, Aria, and Planet Hollywood and surprisingly this was my favorite. While it isn't perfect, as long as you are selective with what you eat I believe this makes for a pleasant dining experience. I came here for lunch and while $20 isn't cheap, I easily got my money's worth stuffing myself with crab legs, jumbo shrimp, and raw shellfish. The prime rib was the best I had among the 3 buffets, although that wasn't saying much as none were as good as the prime rib at even an average sit down restaurant.  Pizza, which in most buffets doesn't even look like food, actually looked edible here, though I didn't try it. The asian food was entirely forgettable, but again, I don't go to buffets to eat those kinds of things.They also had an excellent selection of desserts which were nicely presented. Most of the desserts were good but avoid the fruity sauce thats on the side of the cakes because they're way too sweet.  Perhaps the thing that stood out the most at this place is the service. I was very thirsty that day and was downing my coke every 5-10 mintues, but I never had to go more than a couple minutes without a drink before our waiter came by and refilled my drinks. He also cleared our plates with great efficiency, as every time I got up to get more food the dirty plates were all gone by the time I got back. I also loved that there was no wait as well. Some people would interpret that to mean the buffet is no good, but cmon is any buffet really worth standing an hour in line for?   Probably the weakest aspect of this buffet would be the design and decor of the place. The buffet is a bit on the small side, so it was occasionally difficult to navigate past people at different stations. They had a custom salad station where they make your salad to order, and put it and the seafood section at the front, which caused an unnecessary bottleneck. The overall design of the buffet was fairly plain as well, although they do have some window seats.  I can understand why people who came here for dinner would be underwhelmed, assuming the food is mostly the same. I too probably would be hesitant to come for dinner, but for lunch this place is worth it.

5QhXNXsy1evMM1BbgTRX7w.text: Just missed the line for the Wynn Buffet the night before and went to Aria to check out the new casino. It was time for lunch and we found the buffet and thought it would fulfill our hunger. Unfortunately, the selection of food at the Aria Buffet was very limited. $30 per person for lunch is so not worth it. There was prime rib, king crab legs, turkey, asian entrees, cereal, Mexican entrees, dessert bar, etc. I think what I really enjoyed was the only two types of dim sum they had and the asian stir fry vegetables over rice. Which brings up, while eating away, My boyfriend and I saw their chef mix a batch of eggs (maybe for their scrambled eggs?) and he turned on the sink and mixed quite a good amount of tap water into the mixture of just plain eggs. Are they serious??? So if you don't want watered down eggs, don't try it. I probably ate about $10 worth of food there. Also, on another note. I asked for a Peach bellini and the waitress had no idea what it was. She had to come back two times to ask me what it was and what was in it. It finally came out after I got my food.

IClg0AmGJ9_gtCDu4ihp-A.text: We opted for the $35 buffet plus unlimited mimosas/bloody mary's. This place is ran poorly but the deal is unbeatable.  $35 buffet plus bottomless mimosas and bloody mary's.

8snX6EqBQfGKJXgec8ozyQ.text: I've never been a fan of buffets and still haven't been very impressed with any of the buffets in Las Vegas. I admit that I'm picky, will only eat certain foods, and I really dislike the idea of my food sitting out for an extended period of time. I'd rate The Buffet a C-. There was no line, no flies, the alcohol menu wasn't outrageously priced, and the food was decent. I had beef (it got cold and try by the time I brought it to my table), green beans, orange chicken (again, cold), basmati rice, and flan (I think the caramel was burned because the caramel sauce was bitter). I was disappointed with how quickly my food got cold but whatever, it was all edible. I didn't go back for seconds either. I wasn't really into the selection of food they had out today and I think it takes more effort to screw up the taste of flan than making it taste good. The people I were with seemed to enjoy their food though. I don't think I'll return though, I didn't have the "wow factor". Oh, and I didn't like being seated with a view of the pool area. I don't want to look at people in swimwear while I'm eating, it can get quite unpleasant.

9UpFV0aAuCYJLWWsMs1Oiw.text: I could not believe how bad this buffett was....and I am not hard to please.  My husband and I ate here for breakfast and it's the first buffett I walked away from where I only had one plate of food....that I didn't even finish.  The corned beef hash was atrocious, the potatoes were tasteless,  the coconut hasbrown was awful.  The cottage cheese didn't even taste fresh.  We had a voucher for a free buffett here that we were planning on saving for a dinner....but the food was so bad at breakfast - that we didn't come back.  I scoffed at the bad reviews thinking - how bad can it be?  Oh - it was bad.

e2Kyj27JRL0fghNbhqSuAQ.text: The new beautiful Aria Hotel just opened in Las Vegas. Unfortunately, like any new hotel, there are a lot of things not working yet or unfinished. But, overall, the hotel and casino are beautifully designed and worth visiting. The Buffet does not have the distinctive design of the rest of the venue with its cafeteria layout. The Buffet's food is very good but expensive compared to other hotels, with weekend brunch buffet costing $30, $5 more with champagne. The food selection is typical but tasty with the dessert bar being the highlight (although the dessert I had used frozen strawberries). A MAJOR warning: if you are a group of 8 or more, they add a MANDATORY 18% gratuity. I strongly disagree with this since it is a BUFFET. I realize a large group requires extra attention but since table service is basically busing plates and beverage service, 18% is excessive. An 18% mandatory gratuity brings a total champagne brunch cost for 10 people to ~$450 with tax and tip. The food is not THAT good - two stars.

TKcYs6M9ic8u2FxvXKnlIg.text: Considering the price, and that all buffets are mostly the same, I give this a 4 star. The price is pretty cheap compared to other buffet places and the food isn't too bad. We went there during breakfast/lunch so we had a chance to try both. They have an omelet station during both the b/l time. Carving station had a combination of beef, sausages, ham, etc. Freshly made naan bread, salad, chinese food and others. I came here for the corned beef hash, with the expectation of getting the canned ones... but to my surprise, they made it with REAL corned beef. Definitely worth the price but the service for picking up plates were a little slow.

wkhHVZ9a9Glvf6o7Pyt-GQ.text: 2 stars for this mainly because you will expect way more from a hotel of this caliber. If "The Buffet" were located in Circus Circus, then you would have a 5 star rating from me. I would describe the decor and quality of food as a glorified cafeteria. We ate during the dinner hour and they had not one BUT TWO cold cut stations (yes, baloney and salami)  out. $30 for dinner, really?? Thank goodness we had our meal "comped" by the hotel. We were disappointed with fewer food station selections compared to other lesser quality hotels (Orleans, Rio, etc...). Overall, MEDIOCRE. Eat here if you get it free, or you have a major  discount. 2 stars for this mainly because you will expect way more from a hotel of this caliber. If "The Buffet" were located in Circus Circus, then you would have a 5 star rating from me. I would describe the decor and quality of food as a glorified cafeteria. We ate during the dinner hour and they had not one BUT TWO cold cut stations (yes, baloney and salami)  out. $30 for dinner, really?? Thank goodness we had our meal comped by the hotel. We were disappointed with fewer food station selections compared to other lesser quality hotels (Orleans, Rio, etc...). Overall, MEDIOCRE. Eat here if you get it free, or you have a major  discount. cold cut stations (yes, baloney and salami)  out. $30 for dinner, really?? Thank goodness we had our meal comped by the hotel. We were disappointed with fewer food station selections compared to other lesser qualtiy hotels (Orleans, Rio, etc...). Overall, MEDIOCRE. Eat here if you get it free, or you have a major  discount.

VNlR9hS8QECPte-ZYZx5Og.text: This rating is only for the dinner buffet which is the one I now always go to everytime I'm in Vegas! As someone who goes to buffets only for the seafood the seafood here is excellent for the money. Gigantic shrimp, crablegs, lobster and the best salmon of all the buffets imo. The other nice thing is since it's tucked away on the second-floor of Aria there are usually no long lines like at Bellagio. Going back for New year's!

e8vdr-6O6uoYhib6ow1GNQ.text: My family frequents the buffets in Las Vegas and first came to Aria during Christmas dinner.  At that time, I would rate it 2 stars because it was a transported Mirage buffett with Bellagio prices.  Now coming back for Presidents Day, the Aria buffett is hitting its strides offerring unique dishes and good quality.  Luckily, we arrive at 10:50am and was able to enjoy breakfast and lunch, at breakfast prices.  Compared to when Aria first opened, I had a much improved experience.

NE-znj_g3i6K0qRRjvbHGA.text: Not sure how the Yelpers who visited Aria can give this place 4 to 5 stars. I came here for breakfast and dinner because it was comped.  Aria's buffet compared to Mandalay or the quick ride to Bellagio is terrible. THe interior designer of this buffet place is probably out of a job because the bland schemes look like a hospital cafeteria or a cheap road side buffet. There is no high turnover rate as the food has been steaming for hours. The beef (I think it was prime rib) was super dry even though the carving guy said it was not. The only thing I liked were the chips and salsa and desserts-hence the 2 star rating.

J3ny58CWnpTP7N5MSFmQnw.text: pretty reasonable price many selections lots of  variety such as desserts - there is bkfst lunch & dinner options any drinks u want exceot champange & bloody marys which is @ an additional price but overall food is good some saltier than others but good

_k12-gP0LZJcWF-oAdnsZw.text: We came with a big group of friends on a Saturday night in March and there was no line, which was a huge plus.  I thought the food was good and the selection was decent, but I was hoping for a bit more.  The crabs legs were pretty good, the salad bar was good and the carving stations were good (I had the prime rib and the pork loin).  I got some made to order pasta and it was not edible unfortunately.... they used way too much oil, the noodles were overcooked and the garlic was not cooked enough.  I do have to agree with the others though, the desserts were great.  They have gelato, which I thought was a nice touch.  The last and final comment was that many of the people in my group had stomach issues later that night... we're all not sure what it was that did it... but I definitely ate something that was either bad or maybe not clean??  Either way because of that, I probably wouldn't ever go back given all of the other available buffets on the strip.

yE_AG7e6DULUHVVmlqlTxQ.text: Compared to the other buffets I ate at...Bellagio, Planet Hollywood, and Wynn. I would say that this one is the best. They have a wide selection of food, and all of them are kept really nice and hot. What I would recommend skipping would be the mexican food. I've tried all the dishes at the Mexican section and none of them were good. Maybe its just me...but I would just skip it! The chinese section is definitely accurate, it's not just some asian fusion thing, but real chinese food. The pasta is also great! You choose what you want in your pasta, and they make it for you! It was very delicious..and the portion is huge.So I would recommend sharing the pasta with someone else so that you have more room for other food. The place is really modern, and its in a clean setting. I went for the dinner on a Saturday and it was around $25-$30..can't really remember. But I would definitely go here again seeing how the other buffets were like!

mAgN9CGdieB1FiVv6HLPIw.text: I am really surprised by the reviews.  We were there for lunch.  For a buffet, I thought the quality was great and there was a ton of variety.  Lunch was still a pretty good deal.  Guess I need to go try the Wynn's next visit and compare.

3WiXWRjJ_i4vGGqfKHEQJA.text: M'eh.  I wouldn't have chosen to eat at this buffet, but my colleague and I were exhausted after a full day at the Aria conference center and this was the only on-site restaurant that wasn't filled to capacity.  Maybe I just don't like the Vegas buffet experience.  Everyone in the place looked so sad, even as they were piling heaps of food on their plates.  It's kind of a depressing place to be.  The food was okay and there was a lot of it.  In keeping with Aria's overall theme, the focus is mostly Asian cuisine.  Plenty of sushi, curry, noodles, dumplings and the like.  Lots of seafood options.  There was also a section for southern diner-style food like meatloaf, mashed potatoes and a carving station, but none of that looked very appetizing.  It all appeared to have been sitting out under the heat lamps for a long time.  My favorite item on the buffet was the fish n' chips presented in an adorable little frier basket.  It was actually really crispy and tasted great.  Also, I enjoyed the desserts and there was a vast selection of sweets.  The bread pudding was unexpectedly exceptional.  There were about a dozen different flavors of gelato to choose from and a large assortment of pastries and tarts.  I purchased the all-you-can-drink option for... $15?  It sounds like a decent deal, but let's be honest: most people are going to stuff themselves with food and won't really have much room for alcoholic beverages.  Plus the beer list is really bad.  The only beer that I would even consider ordering was Stella.  I had one of the bloody mary cocktails too, and it was just awful.  No flavor except for an astringent, cheap vodka.  Ick.  Rather than hitting a buffet on the strip, my preference would be to take that $50-60 and catch a cab downtown.  Around Fremont Street you can eat and drink your fill of really delicious food in a much happier atmosphere, continue the revelry all night long, and still spend less money than one trip to the buffet.  That's just a personal preference though.  If you really enjoy buffets, I guess the one at Aria is par for the course.

faUImFDfEznSy4sYr-1hyg.text: My boyfriend and I really liked this place that we ate here two days in a row during brunch. Brunch over the weekends cost around $30.  On the first day we ate here, we got here just before dinnertime but only paid for brunch and was able to enjoy some of the dinner foods they brought out. I was really craving some meat that day and got the prime rib. I was hugely disappointed to find that it was tough, overcooked and dry.  My favorite item was the smoked salmon.  The chicken sausage was also great; the frittata that comes in the mini cast iron skillet was okay but a bit salty. The mashed potato was plain. The eel sushi was good. My boyfriend was a huge fan of the crab legs.  I didn't try any dessert due to a gluten allergy but my boyfriend liked the pistachio gelato. When dinner came around, we heard that they had lamb leg and I got a piece of that and was disappointed yet again; it too was tough, overcooked and dry. I also got some raw oysters which were pretty good.   The next day, the line was longer when we got there but it still moved relatively fast. I tried their scrambled eggs which were bomb-diggity. I got some more smoked salmon of course, as well as the chicken sausage. They also had some cooked veggies (zucchini, yellow squash and carrots) which were great. I tried one of their proscuitto and it tasted horrible. I think I remember telling my boyfriend it tasted like soap. It was so bad that I spit it out into a napkin. Again, no dessert for me but my boyfriend liked the creme brulee.   Overall I really liked this buffet. One star docked off because of the disappointing meat and most of the items were okay, not great. But I'd still come back here if I'm ever back in Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken sausage, smoked salmon, scrambled eggs, cooked veggies
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Raw oysters, eel sushi, smoked salmon, mashed potatoes, and lamb leg

MRyHC_iSv-SWuscqgMWDJg.text: This buffet falls short of the higher end buffets (i.e., Bucchanal, Wicked Spoon) in that the main dishes were mediocre and unimpressive.   However, I'd say this place is better than Spices (pH), and the buffet at Paris because it has clean, modern decor and the desserts were delicious!

MauwvCCjfDWUfFvbV5tecA.text: Exactly - "Meh. I've experienced better" Take your money some place else, definitely was not worth it. Very average and mediocre buffet.  Aria could do a lot better job than this.. pretty disappointing. Nothing stood out for me, I'm not a crazy fanatic of crab legs, for all others i guess that would be the only highlight of the entire menu.   Go next door to Cosmopolitan's Wicket Spoon Buffet.

C6lxIQ3_PLseGoQ4WeXF7g.text: Rather go to caesars palace. The food selection is so few and they do not look appetite at all. For the same price they charged here I would prefer to go some where else. Unfortunately. It seems like aria Buffett doesn't care about how their customers feel like after dinning here. Boooo.......

4eubwKR6YP0KhmKMyzNblg.text: The Buffet at Aria is a solid choice when you're hungry and you aren't quite sure what you want. That's the reason my husband and I went during our recent stay at Aria.   We showed up for a late lunch around 2:30 or so and there wasn't a line, so we were seated immediately.  There is a lot to choose from! I sampled the gnonchi with a meat and tomato sauce, several pieces of tuna sushi, California rolls, carnitas, a vegetarian salad with black beans in it, crab legs, fresh fruit, and chocolate cake.  My husband had a similar dining experience.   Nothing really stood out as excellent, but everything was good. The atmosphere was nice, and the lady who cleared the plates and refreshed drinks was on top of her game.  I'm not sure I'd go rushing back any time soon, unless I stay at the Aria again. I'm happy to have tried it, checked it off my list, and I'm ready to move on.

2X20o1s4SnOkz6QJdXKdsw.text: Stopped in tonight with my wife, figuring we would try something different. It was overall.. okay. Meaning it didn't make us sick.  Some stuff had clearly been sitting out too long, I saw some salami that looked like it was beginning to grow some new vegetation for the restaurant. The crab legs were good, the curries were a little bland, the sushi was basic rolls that you would find at a low end Chinese buffet.  The prime rib was good, as were some of the pasta selections. The crab legs were dry...   I expected more from Aria, likely will not be returning.

Edxsj5mboNA_tw-hpbvXxg.text: I am shocked at the 3 star review for this buffet! This buffet is $40 and has virtually everything! Starting off, the waitress that we had was excellent. The food was great as well. They also have unlimited crab legs. For the money, this is my favorite buffet in Vegas. My only complaint is that the crab legs come in individual legs and not clusters.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

4G0hBp7XOWG_dxx7aDxoQw.text: Here's why I give it five stars: -This buffet has the largest gluten free selection I have ever seen in a Vegas buffet! Great options! -That being said, I'm gluten free most often by choice not because of an allergy, I came here today specifically for the BREAD PUDDING! Oh my god! DELISH!!!! -Their desserts in general are fantastic!  -One evening when my husband and I came here for dinner we were presented with a lobster before our drinks even arrived! Crazy!  This is a top choice of my husband and I, we're always pleasantly happy and full every time we come! :) Eat up!

gS-7IDjSF_fIzGv93dhDfA.text: Our waitress, Eva, was efficient and friendly. The food was tasty and plentiful, and we will return the next time we're in Vegas.

rOSe3t0ZKeoTvLXjDgtj2g.text: A piece of advice for an employee named "Dee" who has intentionally removed her name tag after her poor and unprofessional customer service. DON'T ever argue with CUSTOMERS regarding where they want to be seated ( and It is none of your business why customers want to sit at a certain table) and you could have solved this problem easily with me instead of bringing your manager and chef out to defend for yourself.  Thank you for your horrible customer service "Dee" and making my first staying experience at Aria "unforgettable". I have to leave one star because I have to but I don't think you even deserve it. Definitely, I won't be back and it is a thumb down for future referral when someone asks. Lastly,  it looks like I am not the only one complain about "your" (upper management) restaurant's customer service.

Dkfx1HjIEKZKNIDDkqk1Ng.text: Great! Buffet! It has a bright, modern atmosphere and lots of choices that are a little lass conventional like the mediteranian section and the dim sum. Service was great, and the layout was easy to figure out. You cant beat the price here, and the bottomless drinks at that!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Deserts

soxAr1dxPaGn_uMaeIKWtw.text: It's okay, just not worth the price. I'd rather spend a few bucks more and go to the Bellagio or Wynn. I was expecting more from Aria...average food with fancy names. Not much of a wow taste factor.

RDJnkqAJ1PzuvCWtjhrrXw.text: i will try any buffet on the strip that i know will serve crab. this was my first time at aria. price was higher end but same price at any 5 star hotel buffet really. they had both warm and cold which is a plus for me, since i rather have warm. most places only serve it cold. i tried a little of everything but stuck to what was my main dish.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. nice touch on the dessert.

ARmYd87NJ4B8renAdObRww.text: If I could give negative stars I would. The cashier staff are ridiculous and clueless. They stopped us in line after paying, demanding more gratuity. We paid a random $25 and then we're allowed to sit down. Don't care how good the food is, they ruined the experience from the start.

tCNHjAnQdIH9cOpQw2Ct4w.text: The Buffet at The Aria was amazing. I have Celiac Disease and have to eat gluten free. The chef came out of the kitchen and walked me around to tell me what I could and couldn't eat. He made me a gluten free pancake, amazing gluten free ravioli and gluten free pizza.  The crab legs were fresh and wonderful . The staff were all very helpful, kind and prompt. And to top it off, there were several gluten free dessert options, including cookies, brownies and muffins. Plus, I didn't get sick, so the chef knows his stuff.  We will definitely be back the next time we are in Vegas.

98YQE7ZR40P5tSDc6KimIw.text: Losing quality quickly, while prices go up. Last time I had this, the coffee was absolutely horrible. Tasted like a cup full of burnt coffee beans. Meat carving attendant was asked by a patron where the gravy was and he simply banged on the container of gravy with his carving knife instead of speaking to him. Tacky.  Will be going elsewhere.

CXMyvQykx5xnKksP6R81WA.text: Lots of choices.  It was literally too much food for my eyes to handle, let alone my stomach.  I did the compulsory walkaround just to make sure I didn't miss anything.  They had sushi, chinese, american, italian, etc etc.  is it the best brunch i ever had?  I dunno about that, but it was maybe the most variety i've had at brunch.  maybe not.   I'm a little indecisive today about my buffet history.    So yeah, I went on a Friday which is brunchtime.  Not too crowded, but still pretty crowded.  The server was ok.  Not the best, not the worst.  I tend to take a little bit of each item that looks appetizing.  Then if I really liked something I'll go back for seconds.  Then I usually hit the desserts.  I know someone was wondering what my buffet eating strategy was.  So there you have it.  I heard the one at the Cosmo is better, but unfortunately I didn't have time to check it out.  Maybe next time.

owY6tuP86PYddWWUu7iKXA.text: HORRIBLE SERVICE. COME ONLY IF YOU WANT TO BE TREATED LIKE SHIT!  If I could give it less than one star, I would. The WORST five star buffet experience ever!  They made us wait in lie on a Tuesday morning at 9 am for 40minutes while the restaurant was half empty.  The management has no sense of customer service and what it takes to run a five star After complaining to the manager, he came up with some bullshit excuse of why he's making us wait, something to do with their system of serving. What they don't understand is that customers don't care about systems.  I just want the five star service that I paid for. And to make matters worse, the food was disgusting and not worthy he wait at all.  HORRIBLE!! Never coming here again!   Head over to Bachhanal at the CaesarsPalace. The best buffet in Vegas. The food and variety are insane. Excellent service too.

4bhM8h_40eMpb93G4Jg6Gw.text: Very Pricey and nothing that spectacular - there were 6 of us and some were in town to visit and wanted crab legs, the crab legs were good but you really cant mess those up.  As for the rest, it was not much better than an average buffet off strip like one of the Station Casinos.  Others in my party were disappointed in the Prime Rib, described as fatty and tough-  now that is a bit hard to do to Prime Rib.  Couple of Asian inspired bowls were pretty good, but overall...Skip this one, unless you love dessert- that was awesome....not worth the price of $194.00 and that was with the 'local' discount.  Pass.

RoVJBBblHLV2djWhs78JUA.text: Diner beware. As impressive as the hotel structure is from the outside, it looks like they ran out of money for their prime priced buffet ($36 dinner), both in decor and cuisine.  One would think that for about the same price as Bellagio's buffet, we would expect some competition.  We should've known something wasn't right when on a Saturday night on the weekend of CES, at 8pm, there were only about 30-35 people waiting.  Food was mediocre and maybe a step or two above Main Street Station's buffet.  1st slice of prime rib was excellent, second visit was medium well and dry (middle slice). Desserts were as unimaginable as flavorless (chocolate dipped strawberries had a waxy textured non-chocolate tasting dip, unlike Wynn's or Bellagio's).  The only thing better at this buffet versus Rio, Wynn, Bellagio is that their sushi rice was very good for a buffet.  My advice- skip this, until they re-vamp the entire buffet from chefs to the person in charge of tagging the food description on the glass above the dish with a black dry-erase marker.  Tacky.

V6nnVrsrSSuSUBSpwHs0yA.text: We were excited to dine at the buffet at Aria thinking it woulod be on par with the Mirage and Bellagio...The only on  par was the price as the selection was not so good....the food was not so good....Looks life half the section at the same price.

SIHGJXoDzl22HwRr62HA-A.text: During our stay at the Aria recently, we were given a $50 food credit. So, one night we decided to give the buffet "another" try. (The first time was a Sunday Brunch). Again, we were very disappointed with not only the lack of variety of dishes,( very limited )but with the quality as well. The crab legs were ok, but I guess they ran out of those little plastic cups for butter, cocktail sauce, etc. The carving station had prime rib and turkey....that was it. Maybe the carving guy was having a bad day, but he was the moodiest person.....cranky ol' fart. He was having difficulty slicing the prime rib and got miffed and said a few cuss words....maybe he needs a sharper knife???  The desserts looked better than how they tasted. There are sooooo many other buffets that are far better than the Aria....Bellagio's,  Rio's, Planet Hollywood. For $30 per person, I would recommend any of these, but not the Aria.

a9vrUHuBYkrXfMRfmREafQ.text: i visited for weekend brunch and for as new and as pretty as Aria was, i was expecting better. the desserts were good, food was mediocre, but the service was terrible. i don't know if it was because everyone was having a bad day or what, but very few of the staff were smiling... and the waiter who brought drinks to my table even complained that he had to cover too many tables.

FkYaLlOcGMgC5Y_MH9sJpg.text: disappointed 2 say the least. went exactly at 11am, switching out crappy breakfast for so-so lunch. almost all the items i tried were lukewarn to borderline dead cold. Lots of items, but very few good choices. Not one great item. If I'd have 2 pick it would be the orange chicken (got the hot batch thank God) Leg of sliced lamb is o.k. (looks better than it tastes) brand-new spanking place should have great buffet but it ain't good son. They have ginger but no sushi, go figure than one out. If you like baked items such as fish, chicken, and other stuff sitting and sitting on the trays for hours drizzled in nappy heavy cream sauces, this is your paradise. Salad bar very compressed but o.k. Maybe deserts and cookies and shit are good but I dont come to buffets to eat sweets. Employees barely got the strength to assist you behind their food. One saw me at the gelatto area and just ignored me, UFB I said enough. On bright side, best buffet lemonade I ever had. 15 BUCKS FOR WEEKDAY LUNCH NO TAX/TIP

yjWS0_fchfIQpJY6PNvKwA.text: The Buffet at Aria is one of the worst buffets I've had in Vegas.  The crab legs where flavorless, appears they were boiled.  They serve the legs cold but will heat them up if you ask.  The sushi was terrible.  Fish was hard and the rice even harder.  Most of the foods looked dried out.  Appears that the Buffet can't turn around the food fast enough so they just leave it under the hot lights to dry out.  The naan is pretty good.  I noticed that they had the garlic naan under the plain sign and the plain under the garlic sign.  I told the chef twice they were in the wrong place and he didn't care and didn't move them to the correct place.  The best thing in the buffet is the key lime shooter.  Was some type of graham crust at the bottom of the shooter, then some tasty key lime mixture then on top was a bit of sweet cinnamon apple mixture.  You enjoy a sweet and tart key lime tastes all in one little shot glass.  Overall, don't waste your money on the Aria buffet.  After we complained about the quality of the buffet.  The waitress said that the manager was going to come out and talk to us, the manager never showed up.  The waitress was very apologetic and was very attentive (terrible food is not her fault).  Actually, I change my mind since I can't remember having a worse experience at a buffet, the Aria buffet is THE WORST BUFFET I'VE HAD IN VEGAS.

rSuaDMWDizCxpDZ1OisnnA.text: My first time to the City Centre. Our group decided to give Aria buffet a try since we had already eaten at Bellagio which we knew would never disappoint. Aria did not disappoint us at all. It apparently is the only buffet in Vegas that comes with a whole Maine lobster per person! The lobster isn't small either....you get one big peice and it's good. I'd have to say the best part of the buffet for me (and I'm more of an entree person) was the desserts!!!! YUM!!!!! Save room for the desserts cuz they won't disappoint. I guess the variety of the entrees/side dishes was good, but something was just missing for me and I can't quite figure it out - it just wasn't enough to satisfy my appetite which I consider huge. Other than the desserts, do try the garlic naan breads - YUM! Other than that.....ambience/service is great. It's different than the other buffets also where the food is presented in a cafeteria-style lineup. It's been 5yrs since returned to Vegas so to be fair, I can't quite compare Bellagio's buffet to Aria's although I wish I had if the distance wasn't the issue since we were hanging out at Aria afterwards. After all the walking you do on the strip, anymore walking must be deemed absolutely necessary!!! I'd recommend the Aria Buffet - you have to give it a try - it won't disappoint - it's definitely not a bad one and probably on the same level as Bellagio if not slightly under.

USz1v7W5SrSX1sc6HUG2-Q.text: $15 breakfast buffet? awesomeness! i mean really breakfast buffets its pretty much similar anywhere you go. I wasn't really expecting much from Aria buffet but I think the breakfast buffet is great here. I love the interior where its very modern and new and outside views of the pool bringing in the sunlight. Food wise it was a great variety. Great hot food, usual breakfast items, tasty pastry desserts, some chinese items, pizza, fruit,the carved smoked bacon was awesome... for breakfast  its a great value. Our server was friendly and cleared our plates and refilled our drinks often. I think this place is a great breakfast spot!

NQok18O-npZjHHS2oaEdJg.text: Lots of variety but nothing tasted good. Buffet boasts a variety of Italian but only had a couple of pizzas and meatball and spaghetti. All the global cuisines were mediocre at best. Tried all deserts and they all tasted bland. Don't waste your money here. Just pay $10 more and brunch at Caesars buffet.

AMgY5kXetzK6w1KVBWnvuA.text: Decided to visit here while I was staying in Aria. There are some good reviews below but I did not feel the food was very fresh . I came for early dinner and it looked like most items had been left there since lunch. It could have been a slow day given it was a Thursday.   The food is organized by sections. I liked the seafood , which had crab legs , but avoid the sushi and shrimp, both were probably left too long. Indian food did not have enough flavor. The steak was hit or miss, some pieces were juicy others dry. Deserts were solid, other items not memorable.   Would not return given the plethora of other options but it could very well have been an off day for this buffet.

crsr7NxsgNQf2zg0I--gwA.text: If we're taking buffet standards, this was great. Prime rib was juicy, excellent steak, crab legs were a little cold, but if you dig you can find some big ones, great dessert selection, very wide range of international offerings, outstanding service from staff. Tip, if you're going for breakfast, get in like 10 minutes before brunch starts, and you'll get all the lunch items at the same time as the breakfast items but for the breakfast price which is lower.

LTMeJ3i4xFjFEl3O8JwmQA.text: Favorite. Buffet. In. Vegas.   I think the word best is very relative, but being that opinionated mood I seem to be in right now, I might just say this is the best buffet!   It's clean, it's classy, The staff was all over our table (Not literally...), and the food was the best quality I have found at a buffet at this point in my life. Everything was cooked great and I minutes away from a food coma, I assure you. Saying I like the place would be a huge understatement.  I would personally recommend segregating your food by cultures (as racist as that might appear) simply because you get to involve yourself in a cultural experience is it one at a time, and it is so so worth it.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miniature Keylime pie with the coconut macaroon. To die for.
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. A scoop of some fine pistachio ice cream. It immediately melts in your mouth.
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Garlic shrimp Alfredo&#39;s, accompanied by lemon juiced crab legs.

Gzsf46s8DZM8JP-lQGJ_kQ.text: We tried this buffet for the seafood and the the price was very reasonable. We were very impressed with selection of food. It was fantastic the food was hot and the location was very clean. I'd recommend this buffet as you can get several options of seafood, from crab legs to sushi even a roman station.

SWq3uI5shSHF4Ijy3RRBqQ.text: We went for the breakfast buffet and it was pretty disappointing.  Variety was limited and quality was below average.  Maple syrup tasted like plastic. Take a walk over to the Cosmo instead.

Uv7NmuTE18jQLaBQgvBnDg.text: One of my fav buffets in Vegas!  Great selection of foods! I like that portions are not always a tray with mush inside you serve yourself like a cafeteria. Some are, which is fine but there are also single portions that are plated and garnished which I think it ten times better. I can't say I have a favorite thing here, everything is tasty! If you go for brunch they have a little bit of everything for breakfast and lunch. I like that you can that your own bread/bagels, make your own salad, they have great cheeses and meats for a charcuterie plate. And their attempt on Mexican food might be the best one I've seen at any buffet in Vegas. (It actually doesn't look Taco Bell-ish)  The desserts are fabulous and the Arnold Palmer is freakin fresh !!!!

zESyT4xhXfG14kNLISteAA.text: I checked in late due to late flight arrival. I was hungry so decided to try the buffet. Paid $50 and was looking forward to an awesome buffet. I am a vegetarian (not vegan), and the only choices I had were some Indian food, pasta and pizza. For $50 the choices are limited and nor was the food taste was out of the world. I was very disappointed that I hardly got any value for the money and didn't feel satisfied either!

98ItWI6C6xTYyOObCZHNfA.text: The selection here is huge! However, the quality of the food is decent. I ended  up eating the crab legs... like 4 plates because that was the best value. I tried some of the sushi was ok compared to places that served great sushi. The steak was terrible. It was like cafeteria food for most items. Definitely not made with refined tastes or skill.  So yeah, crab legs and some deserts and other random items is what is good. The waitress was decent, but the all you can drink menu was terrible. I think it said the drinking period was only two hours and the drinks were weak. WEAK and diluted.  I heard better things about other buffets but this one was opened a little later than the others and we wanted plenty of time to eat.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp dumpling
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crab legs

l3DCck8APRg10rG2x8rfcg.text: One of the best buffets we've had on the strip. I just wish they would separate the seafood instead of piling the mussels, shrimp, and crab in a pile over ice. Probably the best buffet in Vegas for the price. Only The Bellagio and Caesar's Palace are better but also more expensive. The ice cream and dessert section are also very good.

yrJHOT7rYQ32kesdcy-PIA.text: Food is not good 44 bucks a person just sucks don't go the food looks good but it's not it is cold and nasty.

2yZe9wFClkCr6G7HXwNbhg.text: This right here was the highlight of my Vegas trip, lol. I esp loved their Egg Benedict. We didn't wait in line at all, lol. Money talks bs better walk to the end of the line. There were variety of dishes from all over The world. They even had Thai Tea shots to quench my thirst.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

3N8J-ah_1qKIEduOhHbl8g.text: Food was a bit rich. I didn't enjoy it much, but that's not to say they were bad, just not to my liking . Had many selections from different regions.

chPi-v56kCllOImlFP0C9g.text: I thought this was the best buffet for the price paid.  The restaurant is bright and airy with plenty of room between tables.  We went weekday during lunch and the place was packed.  - Seafood section had Snow Crab Legs, Crawfish, Mussels, and Boiled Shrimp - Asian section had Udon Noodles, Sushi, and Dim Sum - surprised to see Braised Chicken Feet,...also had Thai Iced Tea..yum... - Mexican section had Individual Fish Tacos which were very good - Deli section had Roast Beef, Korean Short Ribs (very good), Roast Chicken, Sausages.... - Desserts were highlighted by a circular Ice Cream / Gelato freezer which rotated for the scooper.  Gelatos were rich.  Meringue Cookies were also unique.  Good value for the money.

xMzLNaIj4dEXWhSLN0bqbg.text: The buffet is okay  Where is the cereal?  Dude where is my cereal?  I could not find it until I was full and my granddaughter ate her ice cream -no sugary cereal for her  It was morning -- there was a tremendous abound of shell fish--a big mound of shrimp and crabs  I like shell fish but not in the morning  Menudo -  taste liked the canned breakfast of champions  The Jamaica juice came from powder but it was good  The 5 stars for this restaurant was the cashier and the waitress The waitress was very helpfu  We gave her a 25 percent tip  She is an excellent employee

94qGYebnpBmvUCCzRxEVxA.text: Waited an hour in line. Only 1 person at the cash register on Labor Day Monday.  Came for brunch, Nice selection of food. Decent sized buffet. Sectioned by type of cuisine so easy to navigate.  Didn't try the unlimited drinks but they are for 2 so that's a really good price.  Would come back the next time I'm in Vegas.  Would give 4 stars but the line/wait brought it down to 3.

HyTskTkm6ouBd1qtUjr4cw.text: Aria buffet has a variety of selections. I love seafood so I usually pig out on seafood here. Wish they would have oysters. They have a noodle soup bar where you get a bowl and pour broth on it yourself. My only critique is that the broth isn't hot. They need to make it hotter. Their desserts are great. Overall it's a decent buffet.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The broth wasn&#39;t hot

Pioc7mNxCohCdVHNnv8_Nw.text: They have an amusement park wait signs, advising you the duration wait time   Buffet it's pretty standard, Good variety from Carvery, Asian, Seafood, Indian, Italian, Mexican and Desert Stations, it's decent tasting, prime rib was cooked well. Not dry and actually has a nice piece of Rare to offer, which is not common at most buffet joints. Crab legs are decent not the best grade, but again buffet,  Service was good, plates are cleaned off and drinks are brought to us constantly.    Carvery station: Prime Rib Roast, Ribs, Sausage, Chicken, Leg of Lamb and basic sides of creme spinach, corn, mac and cheese, mash and baked potatoes  Asian station: Chow mein, fried rice, Pho, dumplings, har gow (shrimp dumpling), and asian server  Mexican station: tacos, tortilla and some carne   Indian station: they have a roti machine,  so they serve up some curry, masala, tandoori chick and some garlic nan (by the way pretty good).   Italian station: just opt for the fresh pasta and bypass everything else, unless you want to grab a slice of pizza. Don't use your hands please, the server will yell at you.   Seafood station: two side bar, so one side serves hot crab, mussels and vice versa on the other side, they do offer oysters as well (i made it w/out being sick) so even if it doesn't look good, consume at your own risk.  Spanish seafood rice didn't try, but looks good.   Desert station: gelato, but melts quick, macaroons, cheescake etc.   happy stuffing

zi-zxDKI9oY7_pFazPAhqA.text: I know I can't expect too much from a buffet but this buffet was not good.. The food seemed like it was left out too long n tasted old.. I'm not going to go into each things I ate but even the desserts didn't taste good. They also use tiny cups for water so they have to keep on  refilling them... Let me give u a tip.. Use bigger taller glasses it will help w refilling often.   If u want a good buffet goto bellagio or cosmo.. Those r my 2 fav

kYTdhNNpJMTLiM24Ul0woQ.text: What's a Vegas trip without a visit to a buffet? Buffets in Vegas can sometimes cost around $60 so I was stoked about this 1 that was only around $40 a person for dinner+ 18% gratuity for bigger groups. The man at the front cashier was super rude and short with me when explaining how pricing worked. Our waiter however was SUPER sweet and kind. The menu outside said they'd have ramen but I didn't see any inside the buffet. The crab pieces are small compared to other buffets. The ice cream quality isn't good. I tried the coconut and it tasted very artificial.   Things I did like: 1. Thai tea  2. grapefruit juice  3. watermelon lime juice  4. seafood curry dish  5. no wait  6. variety (ex: naan, curry, sushi, pho, prime rib, paella, pizza)  The food overall is okay. There are definitely better buffets in Vegas but all with a steeper cost.

c5PXcA5GZCUHTPaG2AGTRQ.text: Just Bad. We were debating between coming here or going to Wicked Spoon at Cosmo, and decided to come to here for dinner last Friday night. We should have gone somewhere else. Three reasons: Food was incredibly bland, there was no variety, and very pricey. I don't mind paying about $50 a share if the food is good, but this buffet didn't make it for us. There is nothing special about this buffet. Save your money and go somewhere else.

IcwcZ_gru2c8v5TJ9TDpnQ.text: I visited this buffet three times during my stay and I really love how modern , clean and organized this buffet was . The thing the stood out the most was that each section had a big sign telling you what it was like Mediterranean cuisine , Italian , American . I mean it was so many sections that you don't know where to start . The dessert station was insane and the service was excellent. I been to so many buffets but the service at this particular buffet really stands out . I think the whole hotel to be honest . I got a really good vibe . I would definitely come back here when I'm back in town ...

6xsoj99oR2FTgyf6rI8ilA.text: I've only been here twice and the first time was for breakfast and I wasn't to thrilled with it, It didn't have much of a variety but then came back for brunch and they had a more variety so i was definitely happy. Over all the service is great, people are amazing. Restrooms are very clean! the prices are also very reasonable.

LvX5oc5C_FDy4w5T57GOhA.text: Went in with low expectations so it surpassed those.  First of all, the restaurant is half empty and they still make you wait for 15 minutes before getting a table. Ridiculous. This is the part of Vegas people hate.  Then the food...it was decent. Variety is good and quality is fine. Maybe slightly better than my college  dining hall (which was good enough)

wGbgriGlZiRgq-Ijj0-ZHg.text: Buffet is ok and not close to great. Seafood bar is so so but their ice cream selection is Good! Desert here is good, probably the high light of the meal.

FsxfDV4sWOm722rAKG3bOA.text: This was the worst waiting for a buffet. More than half of tables were vacant but they did not let people in. Slower than DMV!!!!!

gAsOhOOu03_6FhpDiajEGQ.text: My second time here and it a very good buffet. Pool views some tables. Open airy feel. I was going to do the Bellagio Buffet but was dark and dingy there no windows food looked sad . Glad The Buffet at the Aria saved the day.

o70lVRDv54cnmj2ztxX5CQ.text: I was extremely let down by my Brunch experience here. I thought I had done my research and was ready for a delicious brunch with endless options of tasty food, it was not what I hoped for. We ordered coffee and they give you your own carafe which would be great, but this was the worst coffee I've possibly ever had we couldn't even drink it. Aria's buffet is supposed to be known for having a large selection of seafood even at brunch...all I saw was boring shrimp and mussels, no crab! Nothing I tasted left me satisfied or wanting more.

5yvBqWE-uf_BTii866ut8w.text: A good value mix of classics and no thrills.  It's not much on quantity in terms of variety but definitely more quality.

yrDzHAqgzx-l5VRXzV3_mQ.text: I actually think this buffet had a good variety of foods. And I love that with a pearl card, I could get into the VIP line. The reason for the 3 stars is the service and lack of common sense by this buffet. They put out one tiny bucket of snow crab so the line is 15 mins long because after about 3 people, we have to wait for the cook to load another bowl. There were only 2 people running the seafood area and she was trying to prep everything herself. My concern is that how hard she was rushing and hurrying, she will undercook the mussels, oysters, crab. I think there is a lot of cross contamination here with raw seafood and cooked seafood. For a buffet charging almost 50 a head, it could be arranged with a bigger snow crab area. Also the server Delip in my area was such a nice guy and busting his butt. Problem is, he had no busser to  help and had a large area so we never saw him. It took forever to clear plates since he was carrying them back every trip he was making. Classy or not classy, I'm all for those huge carts that wheel back dirty dishes. Potential for workplace injury seems higher with all the physical labor involved. Why not have more bussers? A company this huge can't employ a few more minimum wage staff to help the servers? Especially on the weekend. You're doing a disservice to your Staff and your customers who wait hours long just to eat... and with all the choices out there, you'd want as many customers as possible. Also, with the huge line outside, tables were sitting empty for a while. I don't know if it is a marketing tactic to make it look busy or purely a lack of communication but again, cutting your staff short of potential income. I just felt bad for my server. The food was good. Lotsa different meats, a pasta bar, noodle bar, Indian and American cuisine.

hI-dZ4GZYLPDQXOL50iYRg.text: One of the larger buffets I've visited in Vegas, for sure. We came for dinner on a Friday night and beware - it's $100 for 2 people after tax & tip. That said, the options, quality of food, and service helps soften the blow of that price tag.   The dessert bar alone is massive. I enjoyed the large layout of the dining area - plenty of room for people to sit and walk comfortably. We ate as much as we could in the short time we had and it was enjoyable. The prime rib & crab legs alone make it relatively cost effective. I would like to return for breakfast because  I'm sure there are plenty of gluttonous options available.

PwYFEJr7-EsjWO7mXmug-A.text: Don't waste your time and money. I have never been to such a bad buffet. There is nothing worth eating there except if you like the crab leg and the made-to-order pasta. There is such a small section for sushi (not even freshly made, probably bought from a nearby supermarket). The dim sum and Chinese food section is just a joke. They serve popcorn and Costco cookies in the dessert section. It is obviously that they are highly short of staff. The Ice cream machine is partly broken. The whole place is just pathetic. Not only that it wasted our time to stand in line, and wasted our money there, it ruined our holiday mood. Aria should change the management team there or fire the cook.

MWW8zXzEMY_7dDfqA7s8Lw.text: I can only eat gluten-free foods due to having celiac disease. I read several reviews of this restaurant from other people with celiac who raved about the high quality service they received here, so I decided, why not?! I told our waitress about my needs and within 5 minutes, the head chef came out to personally give me a tour of the gluten-free options they offered. Surprisingly, he told me he also has to eat gluten-free as well which really assured me that he would know exactly what my concerns would be. I was also pleasantly surprised to find out about the vast variety of options available for me. They had everything from personal gluten-free pizzas to gluten-free raviolis and he even offered to give me tamari for their sushi rolls if I would like. Honestly I have never seen so many gluten-free options in one place, it was quite wonderful! AND all of the food was incredibly tasty on top of it all. I will definitely come back next time I am in Vegas.

wZMj6CPjzgJH_NpxpIBxkg.text: With a starving toddler we decided to hit up this buffet as it seemed to be the only kid-friendly option right where we were.  It's definitely not one of the best buffets on the Strip but it wasn't terrible either.  The place is big and clean and modern which I liked.  There was a decent variety of food, and the Chinese food / dim sum stood out for me!  Also they had a good selection of fruits, etc.  The breads were pretty hard and that was disappointing - it definitely seemed like they were a bit stale.

YTO0lj-SyeiIjH2EWLCL1g.text: The line was so long. I waited for about 45 minutes. As we got to the beginning of the line we noticed there was so money available tables. We were so confused about why we had to wait so long but it's a marketing scheme. I would never return here. Don't get fooled. I picked up a cannoli and it was as hard as a rock.

WvXh7U5r4c1ts84aUz0ziQ.text: Food was just OK. Top 3: cream brulee, grilled oyster, cheese cake. Crab legs are of medium quality. Would never recommend to any friend.

RctkOLGSW87H3WdOFn9Sgg.text: BEWARE THIS IS HIGHWAY ROBBERY!!! The worst buffet I've ever tried in my life. I created an account for this app because this was the first time I was so amazed by a restaurant at how bad it could be. I was excited to try the buffet at aria, but was extraordinarily appalling. All the meats were tough and bland. It looked like it was cooked to be rare but tasted extremely well done. The ribs were dry, the cold crab was dry, the steamed crab was extremely salty to a point that it was inedible(all the food tasted like salt overload), the fruits were not fresh, the desserts were honestly pitiful for such an expensive buffet. We had to pay the holiday price of around $52 and I wouldn't even go for the regular priced days. It was just terrible. I tried so many options and all of them left me extremely disappointed. There wasn't even a redeeming factor about this place. I barely ate and had to get good ole in n out after to fill my stomach. I recommend any other buffet in Las Vegas. I've tried the Mandalay Bay buffet a couple of times and it is superior and cheaper at the same time.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

p4hFF0qmnflXtFy1BrvCIg.text: Service here was nonexistent. The music was so loud we couldn't hear each other speak. The food on the buffet was of poor quality, and you couldn't be exactly sure what you were getting because none of the tags were right. It sucks so bad I'm sitting here right now writing the review in the restaurant.

UskslqwFCKO98Oww1A1ODA.text: I went to this buffet with my family last week and the service was great. The staff made us feel welcome and were very tentative to our table.   The food was excellent as well.

AF8dAbnmPXfpEfKiz7hiOQ.text: Went here expecting a great dinning experience and it was all around horrible! The only reason they receive two stars is because the lady who check us in was pleasant . We went here for our anniversary expecting crab legs because last week it showed that online ! Came in today looking for them and they said they stopped it today. There was no signs or anything...A guy at the oyster bar grabbed the head chef for me , because he felt bad it being our first time and all. The head chef blew me off basically when I told him that was the only reason we came. Besides all that this place is small, the options are few, and not at all appetizing. For this to be a high end hotel, I am highly disappointed. What a waste of $85... I will never, again come here.

Dfam7La6BzpnQ-U4ruypOA.text: My SO and I decided to go out rather than stay home and cook.  I would have to say, Aria is one of my favorite hotels, however I've only been to the buffet twice.  First time there was comped by my company :D. My second visit  was about $73 plus tip on Thurs around 5:00pm (2 ppl).  There was absolutely no line which was awesome! My review is based on what I inhaled or tasted.. lol...there is so much food it's overwhelming!  But what else can you expect at a buffet.    I'm a seafood fan, and they had a good variety of seafood, such as reg crab legs (hot or cold), king crab!!!!, large shrimp, mussels, scallop ceviche, shrimp cocktail (large shrimp too!), and clams.  (During my first visit they also had oysters and lobster.)  I spent most of my time around the crab legs.. With clarified butter..yum!  The shrimp cocktails were also good, the sauce is just right, and not over-powered by horseradish.  I love Sushi!  However, the selection they had today was sub-par and not even tempting enough to taste.  Rolls I can remember: masago, California, vegetable...  As for the meat selection they had.. pork shoulder, bbq beef brisket, rotisserie chicken,  prime rib.. (I couple of other items i cant remember). I tried the BBQ beef brisket and pork shoulder.  Out of both the BBQ brisket was delish, tender, and juicy!    Other memorable items, freshly made pita bread, cheese station, Asian food station which included chow mein, beef broccoli, Mexican, salad bar...and that about it.  Love the dessert station, bananas foster had just the right amount of rum, they have a good selection of gelato, similar to M buffet.  The carrot cake was slightly dry, coconut cream cake was too sweet, and the cheesecake was just right (fora buffet cheesecake).    Overall, it's a good buffet, service was good, drink refills came in a timely fashion along with plate clean up, plus I can't complain over AYCE king crab legs... One can definitely get their money's worth on the king crab alone!

7TkCP5jj7Yfjd5ZHYsfWLA.text: I was sitting in my hotel room at Excalibur trying to find a buffet that isn't a complete fail (like Cravings at Mirage) and I came across a top ten list of buffets in Vegas!  AWESOME!  One of the top ones was Aria, and in the description, it sang of how eclectic it is.  My fiance loves seafood, my mom is a foodie, and I get really bored easily.  This place sounded PERFECT!    The location is beautiful inside... extremely modern.  I was pleased to find an array of cultural dishes for my mom, a great deal of variety for me, king crab legs and snow crab legs for my fiance.  I read a lot of the bad reviews on here and disagree, but maybe I got lucky on the night I came, apparently you just shouldn't come here for brunch.  I enjoyed the Tandoori and the Carving Station.  They had garlic Na'an, it calls to me like the mothership.  The server was really sweet and attentive, and their coffee was even delicious.  I loved the dessert bar the most because it has miniature pies. cheesecakes, Grand Marnier cream puffs, and GELATO!  The thing about the Aria buffet is that it really is a destination... due to its location in Aria, most people wouldn't just happen across it while perusing the casino.  The lack of lines may be due to that.  I've seen an hour wait for Bellagio's buffet and I was not particularly impressed.

2eTtO-pi-oYkLrGCVqwvTA.text: i actually do like their buffet!!! reasonable price, and you get pretty much everything you get from any other buffets! i love that they cut the king crab legs in half so lazy ppl like me can easily get to the meat... their cocktail shrimps are HUGE... twice the size of the ones i had at other buffets!!!  two other things i love , and i don't see it at any other buffet, were  - the made-to-order pasta: so yummy and fresh! i had penne w/ chicken, artichoke, mushroom in green sauce, YUMMY!  - their chicken curry w/ freshly made garlic naan: i know, who eats naan at buffet? i didn't want to but it was so good that i had to go back and get more and more!!! their naan was freshly made, and the curry has a little spice to it which makes it PERFECT!  prime ribs and chickens were good too... so does their desert bar... one thing though: we couldn't find the fruits, ANYWHERE? no fruits?!?!?!  i like that they have the restrooms inside the buffet so you don't have to go out to wash your hand (or you know... so you can eat more after you.... you know... LOL)  suggestions::: - the service was slow... we already finished our first plates and our drinks still hadn't come.... - there were a group of 10-20 DRUNK ppl behind us... cutting lines, shouting real loud, very very rude and didn't have manners at all... but the whole 30 mins we were in line, NO ONE came and said anything about it.... i understand that it's vegas and there are drunkers EVERYWHERE but that was way way way over the line.......

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

tKwMS27EsEVmRzcNROB1Yw.text: Came with my family i paid for four an my cousin paid for four an they refused to sit us together they said it was against company policy with so many empty tables unless we paid 18% gratuity for serving water an soda.  Food wasn't fantastic spit 3 things out crab legs were dry so was the brisket, and ham. How can you mess up butter

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bad tap water an no refills

d2M79taJBBd4bANSQO-YrQ.text: My favorite buffet in Vegas.  I went for dinner.  They had crab legs, sushi (good sushi, not the crappy kind that most buffets have) and so many other options.  We go here as often as we can.

YIOc-PEeTxrYewouFTtsQw.text: ehhh I would go somewhere else for the price. The only thing I liked from here was the pizza and some corn they had. Service was not out of this world food wasn't either. I would've rather eaten at fat burger on the strip than this. I will not go back to this buffet.

WhcL4QO5C8po_njgdN6w9Q.text: Delicious breakfast buffet, so good I came back for more before I left back home. The omelette station was my favorite! Although it was breakfast it was nice to see the different cultured sections serving non breakfast foods. The unlimited drinks were awesome and the waiter kept them coming. Both times I went I was served by a waiter that went on "break" and never came back, that was a bit confusing. There aren't that many options but I loved the options I had anyway.

mWxdaRbWdlnzX8AJZCUDUg.text: This is by far one of the best brunch buffets I have ever eaten at. They offer a huge assortment of food. They offer an assortment foods from italian, to asia, to american. They also offer a omlette station as well as seafood bar. There dessert bar was also one like no other. They has some of the best rice krispy treats I have ever had. I at a little bit of everything. The pork belly is amazing. They also has a unlimited drink menu for an additional cost as well. I eat here everytime I am in vegas.

8PPnWRjbT838PP3B23qV0A.text: I was going to give this 4 stars because Aria comped it, but instead I give it 3, which is how I would have felt if I had paid. The buffet at Aria is a solid buffet option and should be checked out if you're staying at the hotel.   My girlfriend, parents and I checked out this buffet for the Sunday champagne brunch. The food is good, the service we had wasn't so good, though. Our waiter enjoyed talking to my flight attendant mother about the recent Steven Slater incident but he didn't see much of a need to refill our drinks. It came to a point where I gave my Dad the cup of coffee he gave me that I didn't order so my Dad could have a second cup. We're happy to socialize and discuss the issues of the day with the staff, part of the fun of Vegas is interacting with anyone and everyone around, but you still have a job to do.   Things I enjoyed: breakfast burritos, ice cream, biscuits, cheese blintzes, Grand Marnier Creme Puff dessert, all very yummy. I thought it was very cool how the desserts were so artfully presented. And to the other people who couldn't find the crab legs? How couldn't you? There were stacks and stacks of them around. The champagne was decent, too.   The atmosphere of the place is not unlike the buffet at the Mirage (my personal favorite). It has bright colors and an open design. The walls did feel somewhat sparse, but I thought the color scheme was well done. A buffet should have refreshing colors in the decor to help get your mind off of the overstuffed feeling when leaving.  Check it out if you're heading to Aria!

1pVq3NqhV8D2HmwCHHK_BA.text: Selection was great and the quality of the food was excellent. Service was a little slow but overall it was an enjoyable experience that was worth the money.  After going to other buffets I found that this was definitely one of the better ones in comparison.

GHar7tF1rju9AJXede73yw.text: Lots of choices to choose from. Crab legs are always a big hit for all. They struggled to keep up with them and keeping them warm. Really neat pasta made to order section! And there is something awesome to say about the mashed potatoes.

KEt-DR4mCvFaNypf2x5zyQ.text: This was such a disappointment for a Vegas Buffett, we went on a Sunday for a "Gourmet Buffett" however there was nothing special about it. I would not waste my time or money here again, they didn't even offer to go drinks, when other buffets will give you a to go drink. The meat was too tough looked like it had been sitting out a while, and the chef couldn't tell me what the sushi was. The waitress was also to busy being social.

j-WAttQM9_SqfZ0heT7sWw.text: I was super excited to see breakfast buffet being offered for $15 in the sleeve of the registration folder.    Too bad the Sunday brunch is $23.95pp.  And really not so good: -Greasy Chinese food, MSG laden, I did like the Napa Cabbage stir fry. -Crab legs, ehh.   -Shrimp cocktail, big, but don't be fooled.   -Smoked Bacon, cold.  -Thumbs up for having creamy balsamic dressing. -Mmm...seaweed salad, a little icy, but still pretty good. -TWO omelette stations. -Weak fruit selection, very lacking in berries.   -Desserts, it was cute how they all had 'Happy Father's Day' choco signs.   Iced tea and hot green tea, both a thumbs down.  Skip it all together.

eX3_NJPoJBP4JZJYB-PDQQ.text: The food variety and volume are so modest, it shouldnt be called a buffet place.   The only positive things about this place is that there is no line, bathroom is very clean and spacious, and table & decor are nice. The food is not even worth half of the price, given how casinos near by charge just as much, and offer food 5-6 times as much

CR-Dn-YWFaMzkKikn9VmHA.text: The food is great here . At a reasonable price, I just think they need to step up their service.  Not the first time here and came back to same experience

jhOiuQUnlJq-eHLXN1y8aw.text: The buffet does not offer varieties of red and white meat  And still is buffet quality for that expensive price It is not worth of what you pay Dessert selection and appetizers are ok but  Not good main dishes Very expensive

gssfi1CMg-0VEVSdDofXEw.text: This was horrible!!!! Over $100 for dinner for two with water and tea! The food was old and tasted gross. On top of that, we both got food poisoning! I know you're thinking people drink in Vegas and then puke, but that is not the case! We didn't drink a drop of alcohol!! We should've complained as we walked out. After throwing up nasty aria buffet all night, it's safe to say we won't be back!

QJacyzEjYHFoot5SGvFjeA.text: I just drove home from Vegas and wanted to give my review of Aria's buffet. We used a 2 for 1 comp here, so this made the whole experience a bit easier all around. Knowing we did not spend $35 each helped us not feel cheated. We did purchase the $12.99 all you can drink sangria, wine, and beer. I stayed with the weak Sangria as I did not want to get drunk, I wanted to enjoy the food.   I should have opted for drunk as the food was not good . There were stews (Chinese), stews (Indian) and more stews (fish, shellfish); boring, ugly and lazy for a buffet. Why have a tandoor if you are not going to cook nan to order? The nan was cold, and crisp and no one was there, at any time, to cook some up fresh. (And it appeared and tasted like the tandoori chicken was NOT cooked in the tandoor...perhaps baked?!) Sushi was stale and sloppy looking. Clams gritty. Cold prawn pasty and muddy tasting. Crab...well it was so small it was not worth the effort. Most certainly the cheapest they could find. Prime rib: flavorless (but at least there was both cream and grated horseradish). Sure there were lots of roasted meats offered on the carving stations so for some, this is a big plus, I am sure.   Other than the flirty gentleman serving ice cream everyone there seemed angry and short. No one smiled, no one was pleasant. Our waitress scored a big tip because she at least kept the sangria coming, but even she seemed ready to go home (we got there at 8:15pm for a buffet that closes at 10pm). We tried to leave with a glass of sangria, and the woman at the front almost jumped down our throats and told us we needed to drink it there. ( I have half a mind to say "Fine, but you know what, we were told at 9:50 it was the last we could get as the bar was closing yet the "rules" of the unlimited says two hours. So I will sit here, and BTW, I have another 25 minutes I could be drinking." Mind you. we were being rushed out of the place because they were closing. yet this abrupt woman was telling us to sit and drink it. I felt sorry for those customers who were rushing to get food and did not seem happy about the closing of the buffet before being able to enjoy it. If you want everyone out at 10...then don't close at 10!!!)   Back to the sangria. We pounded it and then promptly went back to our hotel which was NOT the Aria. If I cannot take a glass of sangria I paid for,(and was being rush, in my seat, to finish before 10pm) to the casino floor to gamble, then I leave.  Bad move Aria, you lost my evening gambling money.   Can I say anything good about this buffet? Nope!

Na_38ZmZxm3-QYzv1FdEMg.text: Let me start by saying when I booked my 4 day culinary excursion to Las Vegas, it included 2 free buffets at The Aria. That means that my friend and I had a $68 credit for the Buffet for 4 days. This is FAT BOY status...::grinch smile =). Aria also has a $12.99 Bottomless Wine, Mimosa, Beer, Heineken, Peach Bellini, Sangria, Mimosa, list is endless, drinky drink thing you can add on to any buffet. That itself is worth it's weight in gold!The flippin desserts!! They are world class! I'm pretty sure the people that make the dessert at Jean Phillipe downstairs make the desserts for the buffet. Just when you thought it couldn't get any better they add the new gelato "wheel of fortune" machine. I loved the Mandarin Yuzu flavor, it was a citrus explosion! Not too sour, not too sweet, and Yuzu has such a unique flavor. I destroyed the Vanilla Dulche Brownie flavor as well. Ahhh...so many flavors, so little time. Red Velvet Cupcakes, Strawberry Cheesecake with the little Aria chocolate square stuck in the middle like a ninja star, the Blood Orange Panna Cotta, The Carrot Cake, The Flan with the Raspberry on top...Raspberry plus Flan = Fireworks! My absolute favorite is the Pecan Pie. My friend's mom makes it every new year and I tell her that I will pay her for racks of this stuff, but she never believes me! Aria does not play they add a dollop of espresso, then they stack a little chocolate surfboard on top that with some gold specks. On the side of the plate is a streaky blob of caramel sauce. Heaven on earth! My slogan was Pecan Pie? Das Eriday! The Espresso takes it from great to amazazing! That is just some of desserts!  Remember there's still food! I always hit up the carving station. I just get the juicy wings off the roasted chicken and a couple pieces of brisket with some bbq sauce. Hits the spot everytime. Then I hit up the crab legs, not just crab legs. Aria knows better than that! They are pre-split in half!  So you just grab your mountain of crab and just pick out the meat. Everytime I eat crablegs, I get mad because they are not split this way. I liked the little fish and chips that came in a little fryer basket too.   I kept it simple and rotated everything that I mentioned for 3 days, the 4th day we ate at Sage. Lunch is only $23 with the bottomless drink $13. You seriously cannot beat that! Having it included with your stay is just stupid good.   Tip: If the line is long, go on the left side for Sky Suites members and you can just skip on in! Then, you can watch the line as you eat like a bowss!

o1DQesOnBA7JFWnL2X4fmw.text: I am going to be rather harsh in my review, although there are definite redeeming qualities about this buffet.  My cousin, his friend, and I recently visited Vegas for a quick trip.  We decided to go to only one buffet. I usually go to the The Buffet at the Bellagio, but we thought to give Aria a shot since it was a new hotel and all.  Like everything else at Aria, it was beautifully decorated with modern touches.  Our waitress was attentive and the crowds weren't too bad.  Now to get into the ONE and ONLY reason why this is a two star review:   - Holy s**t balls about the sushi.  It was like if a first grader was making sushi rice for the first time.  It was hard, under-cooked, and not sticky at all that sushi rice is suppose to be.  No one should be forced to eat things that can make your bowels run like Niagara Falls after rain.  And no good restaurant should even have the audacity to serve something like that.  On to why it's not a one star review: - Prime Rib cooked to perfection - Pasta bar that has a super nice chef ready to take your order.  (He also makes good basic pastas.) - Dessert bar to die for: Creme Brulee, Ice Cream Bar, Crisp-on-the-outside soft-on-the-inside cookies. more Creme Brulee, Oreo Pudding Shooters, Tropical Carrot Cake, and did I mention the Creme Brulee.  I don't care for Alaskan King Crab legs, but they have those as well.  I didn't have any of their Mexican or Indian wares, since I know I can get those on the cheap when I go home.  I mean chips, salsa, and guac is what you have for Mexican.  Really?  For a weekday dinner where I spend thirty dollars for a good meal, that money should have just gone to a sit down restaurant with a prix fixe meal.  That probably would have been more satisfying.

vGYSPMZsACOUKk2-UjGPEA.text: The Aria Buffet is actually REALLY GOOD. They use quality ingredients and the offerings definitely do not suffer from "steam table" syndrome. They also had some curry dishes which were quite tasty. We were there for lunch so the pricing was more relaxed ($26.99) and plenty of choices to keep me busy.  Service was A+ and right on the ball. We never waited for dishes to be cleared and our beverages always full.  I am a fan and as Arnold Schwart says, "I'll be back"!

kHqVe8nLBSO3ZsBRZSH-Kg.text: Aria lunch Buffett was awesome, if u like seafood it's a must! Paid $28 each, kids 3 and under eat free.
