5VK6kTvaE49nnMeEbUdluQ.text: So heres thedeal....if you're debating between the Aria and Cosmpolitan, unequivocally the Cosmo wins.  I found the food here to be unremarkable and unimaginative. Slides and old French fries do not win my heart. Sure there's a lot of selection, but it barely tickles mediocrity.

FVV-LmsiSabcB-WNSFMKNw.text: This buffet has several higher end selections, but I feel like the normal food got left out. There was duck confit, sushi, crab, etc. but nothing just normal. The prime rib was exceedingly rare (yeah, yeah, I know, it's supposed to be) and it took forever to get meat cut. Soda and juice was included but no wine or beer. For a week night dinner it was $40 for two of us with an Mlife coupon. I would have been pretty disappointed if we paid full price, but with the B1G1 it wasn't so bad.

K3vpnMQ5U0vDCYq_X2CnwQ.text: First time here and it was awesome, enjoyed all the food. It was great. And our server Beatriz was great, she was super friendly and had a smile every time.

MTJKWz0T4J5Qb-bkuQzhLA.text: Not impressed by the quality of this buffet. Although It appears to have all selections from Asian to Indian, to Italian, seafood, salad and variety of deserts, the quality is definitely lacking. Most food are over cooked and salads are not fresh. The Pad Thai is withering under the heating lamp. If someone likes to just fill up and go it could work , but definitely not worth the $42 pp ( on weekend lunch and dinner price and kids under 12  eat free). Much prefer the Bellagio buffet in comparison.

pytrxWlFSuglFboYj7G5lQ.text: I've had a Five star experience here and a one star. I will have to try it again and update you. I know buffets can have off days and maybe that's what happened yesterday but the first time I dined here it was amazing. I will dine there and let you know again, for now I give it an average of three stars, hope it goes back to five!

zADMg6iw6g-QCUCjo19-nQ.text: Not worth the price.  I expected delicious over the top Aria type food.  Most of the food has been sittin around dying.  The people cutting the meat were rocking an attitude too.  It's just ok.  I've had better...at half the price.

mJsI9nGd_A5CgxVkgGEdHg.text: Small selection consisting of mostly Asian cuisine and the usual pizza, pasta, and salad bar. The only worth while item is the fresh crab legs, that were delicious. $17 all you can drink option is a plus, great cocktails to choose from.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Getting down on crab! I love my lady

3ABVainmDnlZMKyFIpTHew.text: Does this place deserve a one star? Yes on many levels. Let's start with the price. $32 for dinner on a Monday night. OUCH! I immediately look around to see if it's the decor or view that I am paying for but disappointed to find neither. Keep in mind for this price I expect the quality to be on par with Belagio, Wynn, Rio, and the M. So you think my money MUST go to the food. No such luck as the courses are typical of all the buffets here in Las Vegas, but served colder and under-seasoned.  The bottom line is don't waste your money and your calories here.

9glVZbK9TneHkYDmNKQZ5w.text: Like all other tables in Vegas, there is strategy involved when hitting the buffet.  I took my practiced hand to "The Buffet" at Aria last weekend when I was in sin city. It's a good choice though not the best buffet I've visited. It features a few stand-outs -- and a few misses -- among otherwise average food.  I'll get to what I liked and didn't like in a moment, but first allow me to share my philosophy on smart buffet dining.  To get the full dining experience at any buffet you need to go in with a plan. There is no wrong plan, it's all a matter of personality.  For example, the Scouters will tell you to do a walk-thru of all the counters before even picking up a plate. The Meat Heads go straight for the carving table to satisfy their carnivorous cravings and get their "money's worth". The Aristocrats start with courses -- maybe a hearty salad and soup for round 1, followed by the protein and carbs in round 2, and finished off nicely with a dessert and coffee for round 3.  But for me, I personally fall firmly into the Forager camp. I am curious and I like variety. I need to try as many tastes as I can in order to feel my trip to the buffet has been a success.  Therefore, I start at one end with one plate and literally take just a spoonful of each item that remotely catches my interest. I'll sit down  with a plate that looks something like this:  A small helping of a greens and typical salad toppings, two pieces of sushi, a spoonful of garlic mashed potatoes, a beef enchilada, two small spoonfuls of lamb curry, a spoon of basmati rice, some blueberries, a spoon of Mediteranean pasta salad, and a slice of lamb with some mint jelly.  To the untrained eye, my plate looks like the mess of a buffet novice, however there is order to my chaos. It's all about portion control. I get one, maybe two bites of everything. Then I can go back and try other things, or get more of the items I loved from the first round.  I'd say I got to sample at least 80% of Aria's buffet this way. Here are my favorites:  1) Leg of lamb at the carving station 2) NY Strip at the carving station 3) Shrimp Cocktail 4) Freshly made garlic naan (they even have a tandoori oven at the counter!) 5) Lychee, scallop coconut salad 6) Crab Legs (I can't eat them, but everyone at my table said they were great) 7) Creme Brulee  Things I didn't like: 1) sub-par sushi 2) beef enchilada 3) dulce leche dessert 4) not enough labels on food (was I eating lamb curry, or beef curry?)  Another part of the plan: make sure you go for brunch -- it was $26 (with tax) before 4 p.m. The prices rises to $30+ for dinner.

LHjTf1l7SRN3GhvrJlOVgA.text: Anybody that is given Aria 5 star has not eaten at a real Las Vegas buffet.  The selection is not very good, The food is sub par, service not Las Vegas quality for the prices charged.  The atmosphere is like a high school cafeteria.  Even the desserts were disappointing.  If your going to splurge on a buffet on a buffet go to Wynn or Bellagio.

Q3HmapXcBY_rwu2F1YsYEg.text: 1. PRICE - 35 dollars for dinner. Go to to bellagio or wynn and you'll be paying 40 dollars for basically the same quality prime rib and food.   2. KING CRAB - Not the snow crab that you see at every buffet in town, but yes... KING CRAB. You can ask them to steam it for you also and it was delicious.   3. Not crowded - able to be seated in a few minutes, versus waiting more than an hour at some places.   4. Beautiful decor.   5. Desserts. Nutella cake, snickers gellato. must I say more?

znxBrxDok8i1bdH2_CaWAA.text: This was an outstanding buffet. None of the foods appeared warmed over or soaked in butter/oil.  The king crab legs were cut in half, so you didn't have to break them yourself. They were outstanding. The boiled shrimp were fairly large, but still had shells. They had a three types of grilled/baked fish.  The pizza was the best that I've had at a buffet. It was a cross between thin crust and a regular crust.   The desserts were very, very good with unique designs. You almost have to see them, but they are all wonderful bite size desserts. These unique desserts included the Aria take on carrot cake, strawberry shortcake, and even the Oreo Cakester!!!  This buffet would have gotten 5 stars, but the salad bar was virtually not existant and the fruit selection was lacking.  However, overall, it was very good and much better than many of the other LV options!

iujg7V-ZaNO2BKfpnNN6tA.text: Very good lunch buffet with seafood for $19.95.  Checked out Cosmopolitan buffet but they did not offer seafood.  It was also in a dark area in back of the hotel.  Aria was in a very bright sunny area near the pool.  Points for ambience.  Ver clean and servers were very prompt and friendly.  The quality of the food was great but focused on crab legs and shrimp.  They every heat steam your crab legs as requested.          Highly recommended.

-wUjiEjZXZsS6k9MtWEZ8g.text: I had enough comps so I decided to try the brunch buffet on Sunday.  The cost goes up to $24.95 for the brunch.  Champagne & other cocktails are extra.  The eating area reminded of a cafeteria.  I wan't expecting a fancy setting but for a hotel of Aria's caliber, I expected more.  Even though it was only 8:00 in the morning all the stations were stocked.  I started with breakfast foods: eggs, bacon, & sausages.  I was looking for an omlette station but it was not located next to the breakfast foods (what the...).  Then I tried the crab legs which are chilled.  They are snow crab legs halved.  It was more difficult to extract the meat than expected and what's worse, they were too salty.  Other food groups including smattering of Chinese offerings all looked pretty unappetizing.  I usually have a great appetite but I stopped after one serving.  In summary, this is a truly mediocre and disappointing effort from Aria.  I am not sure if I would try this even if I get comped again

uYRFzuWWb1skkVcs1UGcIA.text: Hmm, 3 stars? I'm kind of surprised because I thought this was one of the better buffets I've had.  I was surprised that they had crag legs.  I went straight for those AND the breakfast bar was amazing.  Delicious poached eggs with the creamiest hollandaise sauce, make your own omelet station, these amazing burritos in green tortillas (I forget what it was made out of but it was SOOO good), and much more.  The prime rib was so tender, the asian griller station was okay...why is it so easy to mess up asian food?  So bland there.  I can't remember what it was, but their mashed potatoes and gravy were SO GOOD.  Who would've thought.  But I couldn't wait to get through being a good girl and eating all my food so I can hit the dessert bar.  It is truly on another level.  It would have to be the main reason I spent $25+ dollars on a freaking buffet.  The presentation is nice.  They have small flan cakes and cheesecakes on their own glass dishes, and oreo, mango and various other flavor schooners.  The lava cake is BOMB.COM, throw some raspberry gelato on top and you will surely visit heaven during you inevitable food coma.  I seriously visited the bar three times and we were sitting on the opposite end of the room.   No shame.  I would highly recommend it, but then again I have a sweet tooth, so I'm willing to suck it up and pay $25 to satisfy my sweet tooth.

GZwMUnqSsOz28DzwO6-d0A.text: Given, most of the buffets in Las Vegas are pretty decent, but all four of us really enjoyed this one.  We went right before 4pm so we only had to pay the lunch time rate ($20) and got to eat from both the lunch and dinner menus!  The have unlimited king crab legs, and basically anything else you can imagine.  And the desserts were AMAZING!  Service was very friendly also, although they could have taken away old plates a little bit faster.  Would definitely go here again though!

Bcbq1fUNOk8ooCsVDXgUTA.text: I don't know why this place doesn't have 5 stars... it was AAAAMAZING. minus my intense stomachache afterwards because I definitely ate way too much. We only had to wait for about 30-40 mins (we were lucky as the line got longer when we were leaving) but it's so worth it! it's a nice dining room and the selections are amazing! We went for brunch so we started out with the all breakfast foods, and the scrambled eggs were literally the best I've ever had (so random). They were so moist and fluffy, I could have just had a plate of those. They had most typical breakfast foods including mini waffles, french toast sticks, bacon, sausage, etc. They had a meat carving station, a mexican station, a fish station with sauteed fish as well as sushi. They had crab legs and shrimp cocktail in addition to other types of seafood I didn't get a chance to get to. They even had a MAKE YOUR OWN PHO station!!!!! It was amazing and I've never seen that at a buffet before (not that I go to buffets all the time). They also had an omelette station as well as pizza and an entire chinese/asian food section. I mean come on, how can you not like it? I've been to a handful of buffets in Vegas but I have to say this was one of the best (please keep in mind I don't hit up any of the extra expensive ones so this is purely compared to other reasonably priced ones). And the dessert station was also amazing with their own gelato selection as well. I can tell you for sure that I will be back to this buffet when I'm back in Vegas and I highly recommend you visit it as well!

0T8kSCcVfkfYfJRhJEdn2A.text: For the price that we paid $38 for dinner was a scam! Food wasn't great! The prime rib was over cooked, the lobster that we got was dry, the BBQ rib was dry. Selection of food is poor, the carnival buffet at the Rio has better selection then at the Aria. ..

2XdXJTGEolpXdIvQf26m5g.text: This was the best buffet we have had in Vegas.  I like the selection and didn't even get to try everything before I got full.  The Gluten Free items are marked (not a ton of selections, but at least you don't have to guess).  The only complaint I have is that we had to wait a long time even though most of the tables were empty.  Not sure what's up with that.  Also, the music was a little loud & we couldn't really hear what the person seating us was saying.

HZb0lh1ptPA5XIskprTXmA.text: It's a great hotel...so why shouldn't it have a good buffet?  I was sorely disappointed. This buffet lacked selections. They tried to be different and unique, but they fail miserably. Every dish at the Aria Buffet tried to be a little bit different than your traditional Las Vegas buffet. So it sets up the expectation for more refined flavors and quality. Well,   The Indian station is interesting, but the flavors were unauthentic. The Chinese station was terrible...I'd rather eat at Panda Express! The Sushi station...ummm, I almost missed the 4 types of very ordinary and cheap rolls (and there was so much rice in the sushi that you could hardly tell it was sushi!). The "sage" rotisserie chicken had no flavor. The smoked pork chop was humongous...but had very little smoke flavor.  The crab legs were good, but the melted butter had no flavor. The prime rib was good (and rare!), but the whipped horseradish was terrible...there were clumps of cream...and I had to use my fork to break up the cream and mix with the pure horseradish. Really???  The desserts really piqued my interest, and since I didn't gorge on the savory items like I usually do at buffets...I had plenty of room for dessert! So here's my rundown:  -Gelato was great, but such a limited selection. -Creme Brulee was delicious! -Cheesecake was not rich enough nor was the crust hearty enough. -Sugar-free Chocolate Cake was decent...but couldn't they use some Splenda? -Cookies were so-so...I've had better at cheaper buffets.   The service was standard buffet service...not impressive. For a hotel like Aria, I certainly expected this to be a much better experience. I can easily find a better meal in Vegas for $27.99!

4dY2E0j1Tx20hohtOEUutw.text: came here because we had a resort credit.  would probably not have come here without it because it would of been 45 dollars a person since it was 'holiday' pricing.  but i believe most hotels will charge alot during holiday periods.  we came at around 5pm and there wasn't a wait at all.  we also noticed throughout the night that the line wasn't that long compared to lets say the spice market.  like most buffets they have your prime ribs, sushi, crab legs, etc.  some unique stuff we tried were the dim sum, and fish and chips.  they also have a really fresh salad bar.  we both felt the quality of the food and vegetables were very fresh.  unlike most buffets where they leave a lot of old food, we noticed they didn't do that here.  as for desert, they had many selections from creme burlee to cheese cake to ice cream.  one thing we didn't enjoy was the server had too many tables to wait on and therefore it took  a little to get our drinks.  but i guess thats a management issue.  overall i would say this is a great buffet with many different ethic foods and from what we tried, the food all tasted nice and fresh.  because of the price though, i'm not sure if we'll come back for awhile since wynn, belliagio, rio, and spice market are all really good options.

Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

xrY7TMLUyL1iBMHMNU8ehg.text: The alaskan king crab legs were great this time.  They weren't frozen and salty like the time before.  The prime rib, however, was overcooked.  Gotta thank the poker room for comped dinners.

SPdW10f1kgF3eeW8ygPqOA.text: So..we're in Vegas. Besides gambling, girls and sin---Vegas is known for its palace style buffets. We rolled the dice and decided to take a short walk from our New York New York hotel room and make an attempt to eat our monies worth at the Aria hotel buffet. The total came to over $50 for two people and we crapped out.   Aria won as we did not find a buffet fit for a king or my queen. There was a variety of global flavors: Mexican, Mediterranean, Italian, Chinese and a pitiful spread labeled American. I have to admit, I'm a bit of a picky eater and typically stick with the simple things--pizza, burgers, chicken--you know, steak and potatoes kinda guy. The pizza was dry and there was only two slices left as I approached the Italian section. There were no burgers or burger making station, that would've been neat but maybe too big an ask. The fried chicken was the highlight as it was crunchy and had a nice flavor. As good as the chicken were the mashed potatoes, problem is--I had to hold up the line scraping the last bits of potatoes from the bottom of the pot. O well, at least I should be able to find a nicely charred stake to go with my tea spoon of potatoes. NOPE. There was no steak on the buffet. No steak, that's right folks, no steak on a $20 plus/per person buffet. I had to settle for honey glazed ham--another positive element--and under cooked roast beef.   Hey, there was a great salad bar...O, no French dressing. Yes I know, I'm picky...why would I expect some odd request like French dressing.   The dessert station was quite an impressive presentation. Too bad the taste didn't quite match the looks.   If you like sea food, ignore everything you've read. There was plenty of seafood but I don't touch the stuff.

-5_QCL56z_sbaFuKT3y9Mg.text: Originally my group stopped by the buffet for breakfast on New Years Eve and were shocked at the $30 or so price tag for their "holiday brunch". We decided to come back for dinner ($39.95) at the suggestion of the manager who said since it was their "holiday dinner" we would have options of expensive fish, lamb, and other delicacies. Our group was expecting a dinner on par with the Bellagio or at least Planet Hollywood or the Mirage. We returned later that night only to have been lied to and left disappointed.   The only "high end" item other than crab legs were raw oysters, which smelled terrible. I would not have chanced eating them if you payed me. This buffet had no variety. For the price inflated "holiday dinner" instead of giving more food options it seems they may have taken roughly half away. So much space not used or filled. There were maybe two types of sushi rolls and two or three "Italian" dishes, one of which was noodles with red sauce which was probably from a can. There were about 10 options for sauce in the "Indian" section however there were no real dishes which would have needed them.   Highlights: The king crab legs were decent,  the (overcooked) lobster bisque had decent flavor, and the overcooked prime-rib was tender. Their "pork" fried rice (labeled), which was actually shrimp fried rice, was actually pretty good. Creme brulee was great and some of the other desserts were not bad. The gelato was good however we ended up with options of vanilla, chocolate, mango, or lemon. Nice boring flavors to encourage you to pay $5 downstairs to get something interesting.   Failures: The  sushi was inedible. The sushi rice they used was not fully cooked. The curry tri-tip was the texture of leather. Worst miso soup I have ever had. It tasted similar to the way gym socks smell and I seemed to have inconvenienced the guy who had to serve it, as he glared at me for making him work. The asian station in general was terrible. Some of the dessert combination were very strange, which is saying a lot because I love a good gourmet flavor combination or interesting parings. The chocolate covered strawberries were tiny, had no flavor, and the chocolate was the texture of wax.   In addition to all of the food failures the actual buffet area reminded me of a cross between my junior high and a hospital cafeteria. Incorrect labels were written in black marker above the dishes and the only way to tell where certain types of food were located was is to walk around the unimpressive buffet area.   Then we have the poor planning of the actual buffet's location. Our group was seated at a booth near the buffet line and ended up with a mild case motion sickness. We noticed that the ground and chairs were shaking constantly. The table next to us took out their iphone and used an ap which measures earthquakes. This shaking was enough to register on their phone. It turns out that the constantly running tram from the Aria to the Monte Carlo/Bellagio is causing the shaking (according to our server), it did not stop for our entire meal. We ate less than normal due to the motion sickness.   Maybe this, in addition to hiking up the price for a "holiday dinner", removing the majority of food items, and telling guests about all these non-existent gourmet food items, is the Aria's plan to make back the money spent on building the hotel? Who knows.   Save your money and check out  Spice Market at Planet Hollywood or Cravings at the Mirage. Both are far superior for the same price. We will not be going back to the Buffet at Aria.

4Aui-rj5h6Q-xxXmPfFUlQ.text: I'm not a huge fan of buffets.  I tend to think I waste money for the little amounts of food I eat.  But The Buffet at Aria was pretty good.  There's a good selection of food (not as big as some of the other buffet spots in Vegas).  They even have already peeled shrimp!  Most buffets don't have peeled shrimp, but this place does.    Two downfalls to The Buffet:  1. Price.  I believe it was about $25/pp just for lunch alone.    2. I hate that the Aria's pool is right next to The Buffet.  I don't feel like seeing people walk out of the pool or, better  yet, wring out and dry their bathing suits next to the place I am eating.  At least they should landscape it better - maybe have some trees or high shrubbery that would block the view of the pool???  Just a thought.

G9xgfvr7rPFxVaIUYUD5ZA.text: SERIOUSLY not worth your time (went for lunch, $25).  It's like a really shitty college cafeteria (with no hot college girls and middle America in their place).  We all agreed everything we had in there was sub-par at best. I was too sketched out to eat the fish. The hashbrowns tasted microwaved, the bread was gross, the breakfast burritos were legit from TBell (red tortilla), etc. etc. The Ice cream/gelato was the best thing they had. In fact, if you like all you can eat ice cream/gelato, I'd check it out.   In my opinion you might as well spend $10-15 more for the EPICness which is the Wynn buffet.

KyWsVFx-FSzyDUJdEfa7Qg.text: Such a nice hotel with such sad food. I was overall disappointed, even though the venue was nice. Saw some people from the Glee TV show there, but nothing worth writing about.

pIxNqr3cafKQnoWxkz2ZUQ.text: I have been to the Aria buffet quite a few times.  I use my points from "myvegas" to get 2 for 1.  We like to go at lunchtime because its 25.00 for 2 people to eat with my discount.  My husband really enjoys the shrimp, and most of the seafood. I am a vegetarian and I love the cold salads, especially the one with brussel sprouts.  Everything is usually clearly marked, and kept at the right temperature.  I have not been disappointed.  I'm not sure I would pay double this amount for a lunch, but definitely worth the 2 for 1.  I also like the way it is categorized into different groupings such as "Mediterranean" "Italian" "tandoori" .  I think it is a well thought out, put together buffet.

NICsrF6CzJaSm-Hu9A59GQ.text: Never again. We had two free vouchers so we went for lunch and I'm so glad that I didn't have to pay for this meal. They had seafood, Asian, Indian, Mediterranean, and different meats as well as a variety of desserts.  We tried a little of almost everything and our tastebuds were bored at best.    I would not come back to this buffet unless it was free again.

a9IKg_0MIk1EkAdS4Uf22w.text: I'd actually give then 3.5 stars. The biggest and greatest thing was that they cut the grab legs in half so you have to do a lot less work than other buffets.  I thought they'd have more options as far as different foods from different cultures, so that was a little disappointing.  The food we did have was just OK.  Another great thing - Luis, our waiter.  He was the sweetest and friendliest guy  :-)

LBuS9aT5cVb9ZXCdFrzWXg.text: It's comparable to the Monte Carlo Buffet I would say in offerings and taste.. Price was $39.99 per person. I would have been happier paying $35 per person for the quality received.

x9pHdKr1vops4dESsE126A.text: Note: Unable to check-in here since it shows I'm 10 miles away??  First time a couple months ago..I had dining credits so I decided to take my mum here for a meal. The most memorable was the curry tri-tip.. mmm.   Recent experience... ECK!  This time I had two comped buffets that came with the room.  We went for brunch and found a bug in my noodle salad!! Although tiny.. a BUG with little wings and legs!   So we notified our server and he supposedly in turn notified the manager and got the chefs to throw the dish out.   About 10 minutes pass and the server came back to tell us that the dish had been thrown out. OK.   Now sitting there disgusted, with an appetite that had ran 1000 miles away and only 1/2 a dish into the buffet we waited expecting a manager to come apologize at the very least. Nope.   We ask to speak with the manager and the server responded with "You want to see the manager? Is there a problem? Was it that LITTLE bug? (making a tiny gesture with his thumb and forefinger)" -- YES THERE IS A PROBLEM! Just because I didn't technically pay for the brunch- because it was comped - doesn't mean that I don't want a "refund" for a meal I didn't eat! Thinking of the people who paid $25 for a brunch and get treated poorly. (They had no reason to believe my buffet was comped since it was charged to the room.. for all they know I'm paying for it)   So I politely although agitated said "Yes I would like to see your manager and yes because of that LITTLE bug". So seriously, am I only granted an apology from the manager if the bug were over an inch big or what is the rule??!!   Another 10 minutes pass and the server returns with the manager who totally ignores us and speaks to the server right in-front of our table "Where's the bug? In the trash? Did you see the bug? so there was a bug? It was a TINY bug? What dish was it on? Are you sure so-and-so saw it?"  WOW!  1- I thought he showed the manager about 20 minutes ago when he took my napkin in which was a noodle piece where the bug had rested.  2- I said I wanted to speak to the manager and by her actions she had no intention of speaking to me!   I interrupt their little banter of whether we were telling the truth or trying to scam them out of $25 worth of bacon and eggs. She doesn't even ask me what I wanted to speak with her about and reaches for the receipt on our table. She then says "I don't know what I can do. It's been one hour since you started your meal" (Yeah I spent 40 minutes waiting for your slow ass!!). But also said reluctantly that "ok I will issue you a refund for one of your meals." ONE.   Although we were both only half dish into our buffet and had both lost our appetites now not only due to the little pesky bug that I had to unfortunately notice and not blindly ingest as the manager would have rathered. She would like to issue a refund of ONE meal because apparently my companion- who in his hunger finished his noodles before I saw the bug in mine - would have an appetite to continue with his meal.   I pointed out that we had both lost our appetites and hardly hate 1/2 a plate of anything and she blankly said no, she'll only refund one and walked away to process it. She came back and placed the receipt back on our table with a "It has been refunded back to your room", turned and walked off.   In examining the receipt.... she had refunded the full amount! WTF.....  Whatever... so we stood up, walked out and got her name at the cashier. Dree.   Honestly, it's not a bad buffet. They serve snow crab legs for brunch/lunch and king crab legs with multiple meats for dinner. Just pray that you won't have to deal with their nonexistent customer service!!   Verdict:  - Only for dinner.. their gourmet dinner also comes with 1/2 a lobster tail  - Bringing my magnifying spectacles (seriously... it will never be a comfortable meal here ever again)

Cg1rL2a-g7so9L3oudKVGw.text: This is the best gourmetish value on the strip and very nice.  A late lunch is ideal to see lunch and dinner like at caesars.   I would say the red rock and green valley station on weekends and rio buffet  for locals come close.   Others good ones like wynn and caesars are better but for more.  Im a brunch or late lunch  guy.

FWUWcUvbVoKJh2CS4VqtlQ.text: Because I wasn't expecting much it was much better than I thought.  Set your exceptations low and you won't be disappointed.    Redeeming qualities of the buffet:  I love crab legs and did you know you can ask them to steam them at night??  So I had two full plates of warm crab legs.  Yum Yum Yum!    They give you sub par lobster but its still lobster...   I am Korean and the kimchi was actually really good.  So kudos for authentic sour kimchi!  Not so redeeming qualities:   Service was horrific no fault to our waiter... he worked his ass off but he was covering a large area by himself...   Overall the dinner buffet was meh.... the breakfast brunch was a little better... It wasn't bad... wouldn't say it was earth shattering yumz... but like I said... set your expectations low and you won't be so disappointed...   Brunch much better than dinner.  I would give Brunch a solid 3 stars and dinner maybe 2 and a half stars...

6mX1v62Y0VPYm420wbF10g.text: While in Vegas for a Bachelorette Party weekend, buffets were not a part of our agenda at all, but on the last day of our trip, we decided to go to The Buffet at the Aria for brunch. We all had early afternoon flights and planned to pass out once getting on the plane so it was best to fill our tummies before the trip home!  We paid less than $30 each for the buffet and for an additional $6 Mimosas and Wine were also included (I think). Since it was around noon, there were both breakfast and lunch items available. Typically, I don't really get my money's worth at buffets since I'll get full really fast or just am not that interested in the food, but I def got my money's worth at The Buffet! I had 2-3 plates in total plus dessert. They had all your regular breakfast items (Eggs, Omelets, Bacon, Toast, Cereal, Pastries), but they also had Pasta, Fresh Seafood, Chinese Station, Pizza, etc. I got seconds from the Chinese station, it was so good! For dessert, they had mini Flans, Apple Pies, along with some others. Their Gelatos were delicious too.   We weren't expecting much, but were surprised on how good the food was! I'd def return if I ever stayed at the Aria again.

a2KasjdMEK4zIYWS9E-0eA.text: We had the breakfast buffet. It wasn't really worth the price, unless you eat seafood. The food was pretty dry. I tried some cheese and the edges were hard. You can tell that some food looked as if it had been sitting out for a while. I would have liked a make your own omelet section. Great dessert selection.

o1CEIK3Bjn3dH2-Pstkzvg.text: Came a few times for brunch and dinner.  Location/Accessibility: Aria, 2nd level  Ambiance: avg noise, great for groups  Dress Code: casual  Menu options: Buffet variety.   Had: i tried a bit of everything. nothing really stood out to me as being great or bad. dessert sections has some variety of cookies, brownies, creme brule, and gelato.   Service: The waitress was very friendly, but could have been more attentive.  Price: On avg $30/pp  Overall experience: this buffet is ok, but still looking for THE BEST buffet in vegas!

bLmZo2hydKjx_TZbb7O3tw.text: This place has dramatically declined in food quality. The food used to be made fresh, however I can honestly say that the quality is below even a free Holiday Inn breakfast. Even the bagels are tasteless and stale. They are tiny frozen bagels. And the cheap kind. The cream cheese is questionable. The meat at the carving station is dry. Their dim sum section used to be pretty good and was looking forward to it, but they are now disgusting. Its definitely not the way it used to be 3 years ago. The peal and eat shrimp used to be fresh, but now the shrimp are the cheap frozen kind. The soup used to taste amazing but now its just a pile of cornstarch. They went cheap on the food but kept the high prices. Even their service has declined. Everyone looks miserable. Do not spend your money here. I wouldnt even pay $5.00 for this crap.

ExADXwn_VCb-P0uh-dxz9w.text: I am almost embarrassed to say that we came here for breakfast/brunch all 3 days we were in Vegas. I also had dinner here back in March.   Breakfast has lots of options. I tried almost everything. I really liked the chilaquiles (sort of like fried, chopped up enchiladas for those of you who have yet to try this deliciousness). The waffles, plantains, pizza, bagel and many cream cheese options were also good. There are many meat options too.   The omelets made to order were just alright. The cooks who make them are very friendly though. The corn-beef hash was not that good. Note: their yogurt is more European (sour) in my opinion.   What I really loved about this buffet was dinner. Save sixteen bucks and go to McDonald's for breakfast and come here for lunch or dinner. Lots of options (American, Korean, Chinese, Mexican, Italian, Indian) and everything tasted great. The standouts were the stuffed shells and Indian fare (chicken curry, rice, and garlic naan). I ate shells and naan until I needed to be wheelbarrow-ed out.

SwgAGGrhInS_K0HxeBQ9pw.text: We waited in line for 45 minutes to enter despite there being dozens of empty tables. Then once we were finally in I was thoroughly unimpressed with the food. Yes there was selection but nothing tasted all that memorable. You'd think after the wait there'd be something magical inside. The only real memorable food was the gelato.

nbOLwpPCWLHnocBsW8fGNQ.text: We were extremely disappointed with this buffet.  Fortunately we didn't have to stand in line as we had VIP passes.  Standing in line for the final product would have been 'adding salt to the injury'.   After having to flag down multiple wait staff, we finally got a drink when we were three quarters finished our underwhelming meal.  We were hungry as it had been a long day at the pool.  We were open for anything.  We took a variety of food and were game for enjoying an array of food.  Unfortunately, half of our food was left on our plates.  Overall it was very bland.  I ended up filling up at the salad bar as my meal.   For such a grand hotel, this restaurant was very unsatisfying.  Although classified as casual dining, I have felt more satisfied at no frill chain restaurants at home.

2LxTEZ34p5Dg9zFhrrfCpQ.text: Amazing deal for 39.99 per person inc. drinks for an unlimited buffet. 12 different cuisines plus over 3 dozen desserts. Rated 8.5 out of 10 for our party of 4. This is not your parents buffet. This is awesome!

3HO9WWErU8GAMk1sAt3wzw.text: Been here many times I would give a 3 star but today is the worst experience ever, food taste bad, seafood not fresh, sushi without fish only veggies, no prime rib, and not many choice. I literally have nothing to eat. Very very disappointed.

5vuVs5qcIW6I8zssJelpow.text: I was very surprised when reading some of the bad reviews for the Aria buffet. I can only assume that those who were not satisfied with food have not been to other casino buffets on the Las Vegas Strip. If you are looking to get a five-star meal at a casino buffet well then that's your fault for being disappointed. It is a buffet, and the food is mass produced. But of all the casinos on the strip, the aria buffet is by far the best quality of food. It is by far, the cleanest buffet on the strip. It is by far the best presentation of food on the Las Vegas strip. For all those people who were not satisfied with the aria buffet,  stroll over to the buffet at the Mandalay Bay hotel and casino.....Awful. Now the buffet is a bit pricey. But everything on the Las Vegas strip is very expensive and inflated. In all honesty, Staying and eating on the strip is not for families or couples who are traveling on a tight budget. But if you've got the money to spend, spend it eating at the best buffet on the strip and don't waste your money going to any other buffet because you will spend just as much for dramatically less quality.

2NnILc77FkYkE6iIO9IE-A.text: Whenever we come to Vegas we usually go to at least 1 buffet and for the past few years it's been the buffet at Aria. We come for the comfort of its nice dining area and, of course, the food. But the food is up and down, hit or miss. The last time we came in March the food was great, but this time the food was not good. There's this station that prepares fresh seafood for you or, sometimes, surf and turf, depending on the day, but this time on Father's Day, it was salmon, prawns and scallops. The salmon and prawns weren't cooked thoroughly, the core of it was still raw. I'm surprised that they didn't prepare something special for this day and at $50 per person you'd think there would be champagne included, which did occur at least one time we went there. There seems to be a lot of stations but there isn't really a great selection, we ended up eating a lot of steamed snow crab legs as that was the only thing that was adequate and a good choice for the price being paid. The dessert station is big but it lacks a rich variety. We usually end up getting the creme brulee and ice cream. And in terms of service, our waitress was on top of things and friendly.

_mzi6VWdRVw9D-_A_omTpA.text: For some reason people are giving this place hard knocks.  I went there and absolutely loved it.  On the weekends there is an awesome gourmet menu with stuff like crab legs, venison, duck, steak, ect.  You name it they have it.  And who couldn't love the bottomless white and red wine???  Plus, every table gets a lobster tail.  I think that alone would make this a great buffet.  Anyway, I always come empty and leave full and a little too tipsy.  I have also been to the brunch buffet.  Not quite as good, but still pretty great with bottomless chamagne and a huge selection.

7yVb2XBCgO5J9KNri1nTUA.text: Definitely one of the better buffets in town (3.5 would be most accurate for the food; 3.0 for ambiance). Most dishes are well prepared and of good quality with flavors well balanced and the selection is a bit differentiated from standard buffet fare (e.g. garlic and herb naan and pepperoni pizza bagels). We were there for the brunch buffet and my husband says the cured and carved meat selections were quite tasty and the food stations are done in a visually appealing manner.  The room is spacious and open with plenty of filtered light and view of the pool area and trees; it's part of the Aria's "promenade venues" and continues the theme of plentiful filtered light, modern decor and open space. Thing is though, the buffet room gets a bit too loud (compared to other buffets, such as the Wynn) which takes away a bit from the upscale ambiance the place is supposed to have.  Hint for Vdara guests: don't take the tram and try to get there via the Crystals & Aria's main entrance. There's no need to trek through the smokey Aria casino, you can just walk out the Vdara lobby, across Harmon on the walk way over the street and into the Aria lobby. Head right on the second floor; from there and it's just a couple of yards.

1pgnv-A1Q7sXqiWcXpuyLQ.text: This is like a cafeteria, no extravegant decor in the dining room or food display.  They did have some variety for brunch, including breakfast, lunch, pre-split crab legs, asian food, meats, and a nice dessert section.  However, it still felt like a cafeteria, it's not like the surrounding competition, kind of disappointing since they are the newest hotel, I guess I was just expecting a little more.  Especially the walls in the casino and through out the hotel was so intricate and unique...I just thought it would be a unique experience...turns out it wasn't that great and unfortunately I believe that other casinos have more to offer as far as buffets go.

4m7LhXCNODJUU8OtxE_9pA.text: This really deserves a 5-star. Subtract 1 star for the long waiting time. I got a $45 dinner on Christmas with family. Everyone enjoyed it. Love the quality of service, variety of the food, and design of the place.

fKvjilmGT1uK8Wr_VsCfAA.text: The best thing here was probably the crab legs, they had king crab and snow crab. All the other food is pretty much lower than mediocre. The desert was pretty good. Not a big fan of this place though.

VgANCWPEUOnDUQ36H4SVSg.text: Come on, it was worth the money for me eating 5 bowls of gelato for dessert. Just a few feet away downstairs, one scoop of gelato costs $5 which is soooo overpriced, so I literally got more than what I paid for, including 2 trips to the buffet.   I went for lunch and it was $19.99 during the weekday. Since I stayed at Mandalay Bay, I just charged it to my room which was very convenient.   The dinner must be a lot more expensive but lunch wasn't so bad. There was no line when we went, could be interpreted as good or bad, All I ate was crab and seafood. The dining side of the interior was nice, but the food side seemed like I was back at my college cafeteria. The food was pretty good, but having a sweet tooth, I ate 3 cream puffs on top of the 5 cups of gelato along with a berry tart.

C67FTR-t0---uYsc9iJnUA.text: This place IMO was REALLY GOOD!  I came here for dinner with my friends on a Friday and it wasn't really packed at all.  We found out it was unlimited wine after we paid which was like ~$40 (just like any other buffet place in Vegas or prob cheaper).  So definitely worth it!  They had all kinds of food here from Italian to Indian to American to Asian.  The list felt like it went on and on.  Again, I am not a dessert kind of guy, but wow the thing I remembered most was their dessert...(sadly I know...)  Their strawberry shortcake...OUT OF THIS WORLD! It was so flaky and delicious.  Wasn't super sweet like most places.  Just RIGHT!  Next on the list...I know I'm weird...the marshmallow! Marshmallow...really?  YES REALLY!  By far the best tasting marshmallow ever!  It's located next to the chocolate dipped strawberries...(IMO sucked balls).  Hmm maybe I am a desserts kind of guy....=/

eifOWfm4M7AH9Ed3aveo2g.text: Went for breakfast since it came with our booking.  Waited about 25 minutes to get in which was not excessive.  Not much selection though.  They layout was nice but there was not much of substance.  Eggs benedict wasn't great but our server was super nice.  She was on it with clearing and refills and way very friendly

Q_niXx-jZ_4C609tVQnJ6g.text: Overall rating: 3.5 stars  Since Aria was new and we were staying at this hotel, we opted to try out its buffet.  It turned out that the buffet was average and somewhat disappointing.  Given the buffet price is the same as the buffet at Wynn, Wynn buffet has better food quality.  We may or may not return to the Buffet at Aria for our next visit.  Service:  Friendly The staff was efficient and friendly.  There was no line on a Saturday night, which was surprising since it was a new buffet - this was a good hint to the value of this buffet (overprice for the food quality).  Food:  Average One of the food items that other buffets did not have was the whole lobster tail.  The lobster tail was quite big; however, it was also quite chewy.  All the beef items, kobe beef steak, prime ribs, baby back ribs were all too dry and well done.  The Indian fare (tandoori beef, garlic naan) was quite good.  The dessert was great.  We loved the pistachio biscotti.

AmdIy51hg27lkj25IQBz9w.text: The buffet is better than the standard fare. There are a wide variety of foods from around the globe. My favorites? The easy to eat crab legs, clam chowder, naan bread, panacotta, and OMG the cake pops. The cake pops are filled with chocolate whipped cream. Overall, I was satisfied but wished there would be a bigger selection of foods. I use my "one round" rule when judging buffets. If I can fit all the foods I want to eat in my first round for food, there is not enough of a selection.

Y6FyTkrboBt9wJfROFvm6w.text: I mean.... Wow.   It takes like 5 minutes to walk the length of the "U" shaped Aria buffet, which is good, because your buffet-eating ass should get a small walk in while you're perusing the buffet-offerings.   But then, Oh...em...gee....the buffet has everything. We did breakfast there, but you'd never know it with all of the lunch offerings. Everything from a bagel and cream cheese bar to an omelette bar, an Asian-inspired bar, crab legs, shrimp, traditional breakfast offerings, a Tex-Mex section and every conceivable pastry.   And although $17.95 is kinda of a lot, it's not a lot for a Vegas buffet, comparably speaking. And if you like crab legs, well that's your money's worth right there.   You also get bottomless beverages with it, so yeah. Give it a try.

zuX9a7xnri72BHbd2_DHSg.text: you know, i can honestly say that i vastly enjoyed the buffet here. We came here for breakfast, at only 15 bucks a pop, and it wasn't that busy either. best time to come is 10:30AM, pay the breakfast price, and then stay for lunch..when they bring out their signature item, the Alaskan crab leg. I could tell everything here was fresh. good quality, and clean. Wife thinks that the place deserves one star less because the choices were not as vast as the Wynn buffet, and i have to agree. But  hey...i don't need a thousand choices of beef fried rice if i get a couple great choices of cervice or italian meats.   What i think everyone has to try if they eat here.. crab legs..the best part is that they already cracked it, so you just have to pick the meat out. I know peeps that have lost teeth trying to crack crab legs and end up looking like Asian hillbillies.  Shrimp cervice. Veal Bacon. Lemon meringue Grand Marnier Cream Puff. The Flan. Fresh peeled shrimp.  There is also a great selection of italian cured meats and cheeses.

yFaP7kr2pDIeog0k7UR7Kg.text: Buffet was great food was good. They heat up your king crab and warm butter is waiting. Staff is friendly and ambiance was amazing! Worth the money

4ze7Rpwc7chHelgzahp1mg.text: Worst buffet ever made in vegas. Basically a rip off ($35 each), with just a straight line of selection. Food was not even that great, the only highlight was the steak, the creme brulee, and unlimited wine. But if you're at a buffet, you want various selection of food not just wine.   I don't recommend this at all, especially if you're starving and they tell you that they're serving "gourmet" food, most likely thats a lie.

qa49Tv1nRiIA6Kn1VFS7AQ.text: My biggest complaint are the little earthquakes you feel as you eat.  I'm surprised I didn't read about it in previous reviews.  The mini earthquakes happen every 2 mins. or so.  I'm from CA and so I was a bit freaked out the first couple times it happened.  After awhile, I was feeling sick with motion sickness while eating.  Per our server, the tram that runs between Monte Carlo, through Aria, and then to Bellagio, runs directly underneath this restaurant.  Basically some engineer effed up.  This hotel should move the restaurant to another area of the hotel because who wants to eat while getting motion sickness?  The food was good.  Loved the pre-cut crab legs.  Loved the desserts.  Service was great/friendly/prompt.  Everything was presented well; buffet was clean.  Modern decor just like the rest of this hotel.  But I would not return because of the constant shaking of the floor/seats.

iTmUVX-sEPJlYHX9IinFoA.text: My visit was back in May of 2010.  The service was good and quick. The food is above average for a Vegas buffet. The one rub I have against this place is that you have to buy the lobster/wine add-on when we went. This was a mandatory purchase, which i didn't like. The lobster was over cooked and the wine was putrid.   The only reason why I gave it three stars is because of the variety of food this place had and the atmosphere was nice. It's in the Aria, which is new. The desert selection was fair with tons of variety.

bSufPDxOWh8z0ilkUXEvUQ.text: It really doesn't get any better! Love assortment of food choices.  Everything is fresh and wine is included?  FABULOUS!!!

5C-oBI01IMSKnMJVA4f4-Q.text: Paris, Bellagio, Wynn, PH all have better buffets. The selection of food is very average here. It takes the mediocre elements of all of the aforementioned buffets and combined them into one. Prime rib was okay (and they were very stingy with the cuts), and leg of lamb was good but nothing to rave about. King crab legs were plentiful, but they were very dry and discolored.. frankly, not all that appetizing. The one highlight of the buffet was a salmon salad, which had lots of fresh raw salmon in it. Sadly, most of my stomach room was spent eating that salad lol.

vlT9NizyXmqGRAEpeAcExQ.text: Very good! Service was good, food was excellent! Large eating area and a really good selection of food, from chinese food to regular breakfast items to crab legs! I loved this place. Oh BTW: Keep some room in your belly for the dessert. The dessert spread is to die for!

ilJ-Ww8HmN6SeFakb17isQ.text: Its a nice buffet looking over the Aria pool, but variety was just ok.... Meh..

A84qQVShup8gGnbz5rBvDw.text: Quality went way down. Very sad. Looked forward to coming here but disappointed we wasted 38.00 in a Monday for "brunch"

jSu5GxjIYC7TMP9HkstitA.text: Expected MGM's new buffet at Aria in Citycenter to at least be on par with those at their higher-end properties such as Mirage. I am not sure what they were thinking. Firstly, if you don't like seafood don't even bother - aside from the seafood section you won't get a lot of joy out of the Asian section where you'll find seafood dishes, the Italian section where you'll find seafood dishes etc. What food I did eat was of exceedingly average quality, with the only minor saving grace being the desserts which ranged from OK, to good. Oh, and don't even bother with the omelette station - unless you've ever wondered what a 1 egg omelette made by someone with no idea how to make omelettes looks like. Here's a photo of my omelette for those who need to see for themselves - farm3.static.flickr.com/...

gIir5SIAa0Pxi8LfcxmsSw.text: Best buffet in LV!!! Our server Susan was the best!!!!!!! And the Manager Geraldine was so nice and accommodating. And say hi to the hostess Nohora!!! They really know how to treat their guests. And not to mention the bottomless mimosas and UNREAL good selection.

L_1LPAdWC-tNcy-Efpxikg.text: Where to begin? The only reason we went to the buffet last Thursday was because I got a 2 for 1, plus a free one for playing this silly video game. My young adult son and teen nephew really wanted to try a Vegas buffet, so we went. I of course made sure it wasn't a black out day... when we went to redeem them however, they had changed the black out dates and wouldn't honor them. We decided to eat any ways as time before our Penn and Teller show was running out... $159 for 3 people. The food was decent, nothing to write home about... but the really FUN part, was that all 3 of us got food poisoning. Good times sharing a bathroom to all be sick was not our favorite way to spend one of 3 days in Vegas. Don't do it.

BoqRV9no55Jx21XJ-JhuNQ.text: Overall, a good buffet with plenty of choices from multiple cuisines.   I went here during EDC weekend with a friend and while the wait was a bit long, it was plenty worth it. The buffet is well priced for being on the main strip and among other restaurants charging much more for the same or less.  While you can start with Korean hot buns, you could also choose to go for the tamales, Indian curries, or even try out their large seafood section. Myself, well I chose a bit of everything.   As for my recommendations, go for the Asian foods, cheese and sliced meat, and the roast meats section. You might as well try the seafood section while it's there, but it's not going to change your life or anything.

3MAELg2llFIk1u2yw6nBzw.text: I don't usually do buffets because I don't like the idea of overstuffing my stomach. But, I had to hit this place up since it was my girls bachelorette. Surprised about all the ethnic foods and desserts offered! I think it was still overpriced unless you're there for the seafood as many are  killing for king crab legs! Too much work for me!

W03PNeyj7RUNREEgptZiPQ.text: Went here for the lunch buffet. This is the best MGM resorts buffet on the strip, but still a bit less in quality compared to wicked spoon and bacchanal.

bCCYl8EXQpXq7DS-wTe3MQ.text: I absolutely LOVED the Buffet at Aria.  First off, I don't care whether it was ' better before ' , since it was the first time I was there, and I really enjoyed it. Yes, the price is not on the cheap side, but Hey, you're in Vegas : If you want cheap, you'll get crap. There was a wide variety of  yummy tasting foods from all over the world around the gigantic restaurant, and I tried most of what seemed delicious.  What I prefered the most was the cheese choices and cold cuts, along with the sea counter, which was very appealing, although the salmon tartare was not very good. The seered sea-bass was Delicious ! And what about the desserts ? Divine !   Have a taste you won't be deceived !

Z1SYGYovUfkZMpHukUfegw.text: Nice selection of foods from all over the world.  Most of the things tasted fresh.  Sushi and desserts were a bit of a letdown but had amazing dishes like goat cheese and mushrooms salad, meats, indian, and chinese food.

uVdc_1lYkc9dLPyT0Wzu_A.text: This review is for Flor De Maria--she was an amazing server! Great energy and very attentive to our needs. Didn't expect this level of service at a buffet. Thank you, Flor for making our brunch experience a pleasant one!!!

2xwW3uk3ibJ-ObwE5IX9Ug.text: I was still hungry. That's all I have to say.  I literally didn't know what to eat. Everything I tried was either old, cold, or not appetizing. I just ate a bunch of salad and veggies.   The only good piece of meat was the cook to order steak but it had a lot of tendons.  The Asian food was not good. The Mexican was old looking. The meat carving was dry besides some parts of the prime rib. I did like the Mediterranean hummus and cous cous.   The desserts were okay, not bad.  I definitely didn't enjoy this meal but it got the job done. Sad times.   Literally called The Buffet. I guess it's up to us to put the adjective for them. Bad buffet. Sad buffet. Now the word buffet looks weird to me.

esFLJDu1b85wEqbP3kzslQ.text: I have changed my original 1 star rating to 3 stars for the following reason;     I was contacted by Mr. Grit Koppetz who is the general manager at The Aria Buffet.  He took the time to apologize for our experience and did what he could to set things right.    This follow-up on his part means a lot and we will definitely give the Aria another visit on our next trip thanks to his good customer service.

ihrFUZbjU2GA7fC8OoEkDg.text: Listen, I'm 33 years old and I've ate at all whole hell of a lot of Buffets in my lifetime this is without a doubt that Buffet I have ever eaten at. Every single thing from the pasta to the fruit to the ice cream to the crab everything else they have to offer here is exceptional. If I get this higher than five stars I would rate it 5 times over if you're ever in Vegas you have have have to come to the buffet at the Aria

CabLVmuB4krHvG-a6TDhRg.text: Worst buffet I've ever had. I can see why it was so cheap compared to other buffets. It's still not worth $39.

9zq_8ACzPMjmDbJhIOlT7g.text: I came here for dinner with my friends on a Saturday night, so the price of the buffet gourmet dinner increased to $39.99 pp. They offer bottomless mimosas and select drinks for about $13 pp; unfortunately, we didn't plan to be there for very long, so we opted out of this offer.   The selection is okay, not as much as I would have wanted for the price. They do offer a wide range of seafood though including snow crab and king crab. So for seafood lovers, you will definitely get your money's worth if you focus on consuming your omega-3's. The desserts looked a lot better than tasted, unfortunately. I did enjoy their thai tea gelato though.  The service was great.   I would easily return for their cheaper brunch and lunch options. But as a dinner option? I would rather take my $40+ elsewhere.

X4RZ0wpyQ5CiPmcnCsadqA.text: Five Family members visited from Orange County. Nine of us including local friends came for our Brunch. Despite declaring that some 5 of us were senior citizens and four locals, We were pleasantly surprised our bill came to less than $300 including tax and required tip.  It took a while for the servers to prepare a table for nine closer to the food service area. A female at table next to us was throwing up (perhaps, too much drinking) so we asked to move elsewhere. When the rest of our party arrived, we were all seated comfortably, hungry and ready to eat. Ruby was our server. She and the rest of crew were kind, polite and attentive. BEST OF ALL, THE FOOD SELECTION WAS AS GOOD AS CAN BE from several food stations: The stations within The Buffet include:  Fish Market: Seafood, unlimited Crab Legs, Fish & Chips  Asian: Dim Sum, Chinese, Japanese and Thai dishes  Italian: Pasta, Cured Meats, Cheeses & Mozzarella  Pizza: New York Style, Gluten Free & Stromboli  Mediterranean: North Africa and Middle East Selections  Tandoori: Indian cuisine Tandoor Oven including Naan, Tandoori Chicken, Vegetables  Latin: Mexican, South American & Spanish dishes  Carving Station: Grilled, Smoked & Roasted meats, Beef Steamship, Prime Rib, Turkey Breast  Diner: American comfort food like Spiced Meatloaf, Chicken Fried Steak, Grilled Corn on the Cobb and Giant Pancake  Salad: Choice of Salad selections  Sweets: Gelato selections, Cookies, Candies, Cakes  Add $12.99 for unlimited Mimosas, Bloody Marys, Sangria, Cranberry Spritzers, Rum Punch, Champagne, Premium Beer and Wine on TAP.  ALTOGETHER A GREAT PLACE FOR FAMILY!

hWeLI8iyOte4x-GxDf1Hmg.text: Food was good but service leaves something to be desired. Waited in line 45 min while tables sat empty with dirty dishes on them. Table servers were few and far between. Floor managers were rude and spent more time roaming the floor than supporting their staff.

yBqygTRWqbRTO-hDO0qjrg.text: This is a very good buffet! Food was awesome,  only reason for 4 and not 5 was the wait staff. Had to ask just to get refills. All she was interested in was clearing tables to get more people in. She worked more as a bus boy then a waitress.  The food was wonderful will come back to eat more. In the end I had the best creme Brule I have ever had at a buffet. Tasted like a fancy restaurant dessert. The price is high, but the food was worth every penny.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

DIjZnNPhd5LykskbnHMdUQ.text: Came over for breakfast and met three staffs working here during meal. They were so rude.... if you pick this place, do NOT expect any kindness or service! Their service so not deserve any star at all!

fnl0T4bfzzI9HVaMlMKzDA.text: Ranks up there with one of my fave's in Vegas. Clean, good, fresh food with a touch of class. Everything on my plate was good from the mini chicken and waffles basket to my cookies and cake i had for desert. They cut out all the unecessary stuff and leave all the good stuff. The carving board (Prime Rib, Ham) was waaaaay good. Our drinks came fast, service was good, can't complain I'll definitely be back here.  Honorable Mention:  Prime Rib!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Sweets...

Ff3b3q-dSiOVCPGX9BNSKw.text: This place didn't live up to the reviews at all. The good....CARB LEGS (both hot and cold). The hot crab legs were not open though so they were a mess but worth it. Other than that this place is like dry toast- boring. There was absolutely nothing else to write home about....nothing. They serve their beverages in very small glasses so get ready to have to ask your waiter three of four times for a refill if you're thirsty. And they play the music REALLY REALLY LOUD like its a club. We were there yesterday at around 3pm and the music was blasting the entire time. I can't imagine if someone were there recouping from a hangover...it'd be a no go! All in all, they serve Crab legs day and night but not worth it otherwise. We won't rush back!

une3qanHvKqkRmwagmoWIQ.text: Good selection. We came at lunch time and they had a lots of seafood, nacho bar, breakfast items were still available too. Yummy desserts also. Loved the creme brulee!

tx83HkAAdB2Ffo3HUtZnnw.text: I have heard good things about this. But wow. No. It wasn't good and wasn't worth it.  Chicken was so dry had to spit it out.  The steak was ok.    The Latin food.  No. The tortillas were crap. The rice seemed like it was from a Mexican rice box.   The Asian food was good.   Crab legs you really can't go wrong.  Ribs had no meat on them.   And the deserts were ok. But really not worth the 41 bucks.  Sad. I was really expecting more.  Our whole party was really disappointed.  Never again

9PnbjofduuEAP8CbcY97Eg.text: Do not waste your time. I had a 2-for-1 dinner MyVegas reward and even with that discount it was not worth it what so ever. The only thing people seem to like here are the crab legs and that seems like it depends on the timing on whether they will be fresh or not.   I tasted a bit a everything and there was nothing I ate more than 1 bite of other than the Cowboy steak they had at the carvery. That was pretty good and the only thing either me or my husband enjoyed. Go to Cravings at the Mirage instead!

9u6TLfceWlvM0EqFNUwcpg.text: There are so many buffet restaurants in Vegas.  However, I highly recommend the Buffet at Aria. It is high price but definitely worth it.  Why settle at other buffet locations with most of the food choices you won't even eat.  At the buffet, choice of the food is not many as other buffet locations in Vegas but all good foods.  One of the best buffet restaurants in Vegas if you want to eat buffet.  I normally don't eat buffet but this is the place.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

0bQk7itGHfIqqjsR5YNCfw.text: They didn't have many customers when we arrived. I was a little bit worried about that because a good place always has crowded people.   They don't have many choices, honestly. However, the flavor was AMAZING. Especially the Chinese food and Indian Curry. Except those, their fresh squeezed watermelon and lime juice was stunning! I just love here!  The service was just so so,  but I don't really care, it's just a buffet.  I'd like to go back again and again and again :)

XbkU_VbDhD6gcNMzPIDirQ.text: This place is about as good and original as the name. Came here during the week after Christmas before NYE. Beware all buffets raise prices during this time by about 20%. The Buffet is no exception.  Nothing memorable here. The sushi is 2/5. Doesn't seem fresh and not made very well. I was worried I would get sick so I only tried a couple pieces. Looks and tastes like day old sushi. There is a variety here. The best station maybe prime rib 3/5. Mine was a bit over cooked but at least the flavor was there. Didn't go back for a second portion though. Desserts are average. They had 5 flavors of gelato. It was Ok. Nothing to write home about. The other desserts were just a little better than what you get at Hometown Buffet. Definitely not worth $48.99. Not coming here again. Better sit down options in the Aria hotel.

Wzp7U3q2bG9en4dsqCvbLQ.text: This is definitely not the Bacchanal buffet. Or Wicked Spoon. So do not get your hopes up.   My group of 12 decided to come here because half of us got buy one, get one coupons. At $24.99 for breakfast/lunch it's not too bad, but it's not that great. We ate here the last day of our trip because it was so cheap, but it was a bad choice because we just compared everything to Bacchanal.   One unique thing about this buffet is that they have a section of middle eastern cuisine with curry, hummus, and naan. I don't really like that kind of food though... Especially not in the morning.  There is a custom omelet bar. What I thought was weird was that there were dollar bills/tips laying on the counter. Uh shouldn't they be in a jar or something to keep it sanitary? And why are people tipping the omelet man when we already paid for our meal and that's his job...? Idk.  Cons: The bacon wasn't crispy.  Eggs were watery.  Not many dessert options.  Slow service getting drinks and refills.  Ketchup not available at the tables.   There are way better places to eat in Vegas. Don't waste your time here unless you have a good deal.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Carrot cake, chocolate ice cream with toppings
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crab legs, blueberry blintz, hummus, naan
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Scrambled eggs, Denver omelet, mashed potatoes, and bacon

tjIRqWOkhAz-7cbiJz5x-Q.text: I hate to have to review this.. but I don't sugar coat the experience.   We had friends visiting and wanted to try out the Aria buffet. My boyfriend and I had never been there so we decided to give it a try. I was a bit embarrassed as you would think that for the price paid (it's WAY overpriced for the quality of food), the ambiance and the flair of Aria, the buffet would be dazzling and I pictured walking into a buffet that was over the top. It was far from. It looked like any buffet that you would go to downtown Fremont Street, namely, the Golden Nugget. The food looked as though it had been sitting for quite a while, not fresh and the serving stations were not very clean.   The waitress that had our table was very nice as were the greeters at the front door. I will definitely give a thumbs up. However, had I known that the buffet was less than desirable, we would have taken them to the M Resort (which has an EXCELLENT buffet for half the price! and has an outstanding seafood night), or to the Red Rock Hotel/Casino. Granted they are off the beaten path for tourists, but well worth the drive. The sad part is that tourists do not know the myriad of wonderful buffets that surround them... off the strip but yet, not a far driving distance.   The desserts were good... there was a chocolate/peanut butter dessert that was delish. So, for the dessert, I would say it was decent.   We entertain friends visiting out of town quite often and we take them away from the strip and they are amazed at how many restaurants Las Vegas has. Sadly, those that are stuck on the strip end up paying outrageous prices for food that is not the quality they pay for. So, when we pick them up, or they meet up, it's away from the strip to some great local restaurants!   Aria was a bit disappointing and hoping that the quality will get better. However, now we know, and in recommending food spots, that will not be one. NOT WORTH THE PRICE.

UoTI47klgkO9KYJvZGjLFg.text: FOOD The selection was pretty small. My thing at buffets is to get a little bit of everything and second round is dedicated to my favorites. Nothing at this buffet was my favorite.  SERVICE The service was excellent. The staff was friendly and totally on it. One staff member notice spilt water right next to my table, I'm normally pretty observant, but I didn't even notice it.

r8xvvSzCdsRDEaYYNPkLmQ.text: For anyone seeking Vegas' best buffet and service, I can tell you from experience, ARIA is hands down #1.  We've tried MANY over the years, and 5 Vegas trips later, every single time, ARIA always gets our business for breakfast, lunch and dinner!  Chef Craig, who's name I forgot the first time I posted a review, deserves most of my credit.  He makes us feel so welcomed, and treated very special with our unique food diet.  His attention to detail and obvious desire to take care of everyone with a genuine smile, keeps us coming back to ARIA, above any other reason.  Friendly service is often rare, so we thank you Craig, and your team.  PS Craig, this is Jamison and family, the gluten free French toast fanatics, saying thank you for being so nice and so helpful.  We'll be back asap!

cyA97oDSEsai7agqzGWLpQ.text: The Buffet at the Aria will forever be my favorite buffet on the whole strip. There is a wide variety of foods to choose from, from different areas all over the world. The customer service is always amazing as well. They really know how to take care of their customers.   I'd definitely recommend!

cNsMKcIsAyZmv74-jEseGw.text: Just go to the Bellagio instead. The food is better there & so is the staff. The Aria has a rather bougie crowd & the options & the taste of the food suck to be frank.

FfW4lPA1mwqeuyvOj60VDA.text: Everything was great. Tasty. Bottomless drinks. Fresh fish. Bomb Mac n cheese. Way better than MGM!! Or Paris. Or Harrahs. Or....

OS_KpcNs02nOC845ds5OPw.text: We visited the buffet around 2:30p before the change from lunch to dinner. I loved that it wasn't crowded. I found the food to be very hit or miss. The cold shrimp and salads were good. The pork belly was tough and not very flavorful. All of the Asian selections were a miss. The hot and sour soup was just weird. The flavors were just a bit strange overall with the Asian food. I will say I loved the prime rib. I went back a couple of times for this. They cut it thicker than other buffets too. The pizza sitting out looked old so I didn't try it. I tried to tuna steaks, not bad. The crab legs were pretty tasty and already cracked for you. I loved the gelato bar for dessert, that was a big plus for me after eating a so so meal. We also added the all you can drink for $16.99. I had several glasses of Stella and they just kept them coming.   I really expected more from this buffet. Maybe something closer to what the Bellagio offers as far as good quality. I really did appreciate their effort here. I think different people will enjoy different food items here. Just try a lot of different foods until you find your favorites.

T2K_XY3Gk16mMMnQYFrCXA.text: I was disappointed with this buffet. Although the price is pretty reasonable at $40/person, I preferred the Bacchanal Buffet. I don't know if today was a one-off, but there really wasn't as much variety and quality to their selection. The comparison was huge since I started with the Bacchanal.  Everything tasted too salty, and I didn't see any bone marrow, prime rib, or snow crab legs offered as mentioned by the other yelp reviews. The plus side was that their service was good, and they did offer sugar-free and gluten-free dessert options which actually taste decent. Not to mention, it helped that there wasn't a wait to get in, since my friend and I decided to do an early dinner at 4 pm. However, overall, the food was lacking and those positive notes weren't enough to have me coming back for a while.

il2U2cwZ-zWhZdpwA7PFYg.text: It's great everytime, good variety of delicious food, clean, exceptional service Highly recommended

-yolPB0FPZF4Ue6aCuKmew.text: My previous review expressed my appreciation for the great service and premium food we found at the Aria Buffet. My current review expresses my deep disappointment!   The servers behind the food counters are disengaged and surly. If they answer a question, it's in clipped tones  without meeting your eyes. Our waitress only picked up our empty dishes twice.   The food was so mediocre that it should have sold at a discount, not at $33 for breakfast /brunch. How can they get cut fruit wrong? They all tasted like they were soaked in water before being brought out.   I have some advice for the management. If you want to keep the price that you currently have, you need some serious upgrades.  1. Don't hire the cheapest staff.  2. Train them in the basics of customer service or make them work behind the scenes.  3. Don't use canned soups. People can tell.  4. Don't use frozen dimsum. It's really bad.  5. Don't up charge for seafood then serve C grade product. Your shrimps were the size of a babies pinky finger.   Don't expect us back. Although we are sad about that fact. Our Vegas trips  always included Aria. Not anymore. We couldn't understand why the ratings were going down, now we know.   Oh, they also charge for parking!

j5NWWM5Br36XpgAGkW04uA.text: My family enjoyed a lots every time we stoped by since we are local from Las Vegas, food is good, good price and nice staff, a only thing i qould not give it 5 star is the asian section, it kinda they do not put effort into food over that section. Overall, it is fine buffet

Voqlzgjz5DQxdZ5mE-VDTg.text: You're better off going to hometown buffet. I guess if you wait in the 2 hour line and pay $55/per person, you can try to justify the cost, but in reality you'll be disappointed.

2t1G49J7wb2MuQsMe-fFwg.text: It's good.....but it's lacking a signature dish or two....or three.  Also, after trying Bacchanal (Caesar's Palace) and Wicked Spoon (Cosmopolitan), everything else is also-rans. They have to create an amazing experience or a dish that would match or better the two that I mentioned.   Don't get me wrong here, the place is nice, clean, spacious and bright and the dishes are nicely prepared with their own sections.   But it lacks that umph. Yes, they have every kind of similar food items served at other buffet places, and one would expect something elegant, especially located inside the Aria.   At least I used my hotel credit on the place; otherwise, I wouldn't pay to return if given the chance with so many better buffet options in Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Eating healthy to give my stomach a break from steak and eggs.

MgKluTF9ThIy_IKsyvZkvA.text: After trying so many buffets in Vegas, I wanted to give the Aria buffet a try ! We went there at 3 PM they were serving dinner.  It wasn't crowded because its was so early for dinner. The place look clean and organized , there is different stations and choices ( Italian, Mexican, Asian, Mediterranean ...)  I tried different choices but unfortunately didn't like anything !! Food and presentation look so good but there is no taste at all. I am sorry to say that but its like frozen food reheated !!  The only thing that my friends liked was: lobster ravioli and paella.  After the food wanted to give the desserts a try ! I am known for my sweet addiction I didn't even eat half a cake because it has no taste ! My friend tried the ice cream and found it so sweet and didn't like it!  I am writing this review so that the management team of the buffet can read it and improve the food quality.  For the same price you can have way better food at others buffet.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Desserts
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pizza

DEXY5xicKl43NiAm0qYF9g.text: The food is great. I would suggest small portions so that you can try a little of everything. The wait staff was very nice and the cooks were very engaging.  The wait time is a different story. This is why I gave the three stars. It made no sense to wait an hour to pay and another 15 minutes to be seated. Only to be directed to our table and find droves of sections empty.

1caci0j-vtkr-SsKLH6eIw.text: We came here twice- once for Friday night dinner and also a Saturday brunch.    Not sure what is going on with Management because there are easily 40 to 50 tables open yet they insist on having on a line and keeping people waiting 20-30 mins to sit.  When we did get seated we were placed in the corner of the restaurant both times.  This is not to mention the fact that when you pay upfront they ask you to tip and now I'm not sure if this means if you don't tip at that time they will place you in seats at the back of the restaurant.  We had planned tipping in cash and had excellent service both times by our waiters, even though on Friday night the waiter just disappeared and never returned and nobody came to replace him.    Also don't come in the first 90 mins for brunch- they have nothing out and what is there is partially left over from the day before.  Wait until at least 8:30 or 9am.  Oh and management: how hard is it to correctly label dishes - they are sitting mislabeled for hours- this is easy!  Upper management- if you are reading this, keep a close eye on Sandra- she may be negatively impacting many of the customers by the way she seats folks in a delayed and seemingly illogical manner (corner of the restaurant near the restroom when 75% of the tables were open and remained open for the next hour?! Also she said if we wanted to have a different table we'd have to wait 10 mins, and then immediately proceeded to seat others?!)

53Ld89rHfzbLA4OUoEo6wQ.text: We were there on July 3, got there around 4pm and it was 5:15pm when we got to sit, so LONG wait even though the line was not that long. Upon asking, we were told, HALF the floor was on break and when they return the other HALF will go on break. WHO DOES THAT.  FOOD: decent choice for the price, I wouldn't say excellent taste but Definitely good variety Including some Indian cuisine and Hawaiian Poke bar as well.  PRICED : Moderately, NOT to expensive nor cheap  SERVICE: Good  Another thing that irked me was the other line with people either staying At the hotel or have the card would get first preference for seating, which means if it's lunch or dinner time and their line gets longer your wait gets longer too, which is so annoying and makes you feel like the lower deck peeps in the movie Titanic. Would I go there again, probably NOT

qO8UF38YFEH6ETVJ4bvgfw.text: This place has alot of choices . This is the only reason I gave 3 stars.. seafood like old .. taste .. the crab legs look dirty and old taste.. not fresh .. my wife big on sushi she said it didn't taste fresh.. for seafood get fat F.. I tried done the spanish peilla . Was was ok missing squid and octupus and lobster.. don't call this peilla it's seafood medley..

ZGOfwWBBjzIEQC26DnVaOA.text: 3 stars is perfect for this place.  A lot of hit and misses with different meal options.  Just go to the Wynn if you want a amazing buffet and spend the same to.
