It is $55 a person on Saturday night.  I will not be going back due to price and quality issues. Customer service was great though.

2iWu0_1HNadDRPitCBdOzA.text: First, it was free with my room. So it was great.  However, it is so badly run -- with lines around the yet dozens of table open.  And usually by the time my beverage order was taken, I was almost done eating -- on at least 10 occasions.  The staff are nice enough, but clearly over-worked with too much to do.  The food for the most part was delicious with two notable exceptions that were terrible.  If you going to have a carving station, have decent meat.  At least meat that can be cut with the knives on the table.  in the 3 times I got prime rib or cowboy steak the meat was so over cooked it couldn't be cut.  And the bread.  There is no reason to not replenish bread often enough to keep it fresh.  Everything else was delicious and ample.    I wouldn't pay for it. Ever.

lY0yQpShVW-q9E_oTpLEgg.text: I had a great experience at the buffet, there were many dishes that I really enjoyed! These desserts were also pretty good! What made it awesome, was Louis, that man has some incredible work ethic and was extremely attentive.

I8zSW__qSK4f0BlINs6gzQ.text: TLDR; Go eat at Wicked Spoon or Bacchanal instead :(  This is probably my least favorite buffet on the strip :( After tax and tip, dinner was $47.99. Please just go eat at Wicked Spoon for this price.  While I love the Aria, their buffet is rather mediocre and generic compared to other places on the strip. For a Sunday night, the only "fancy" offerings were:  Prime rib Cornish game hen Crab legs and stone crab legs - very overcooked :( Unpeeled shrimp with feet on Mussels  I'm restaurant and bar industry myself, and I guess the part that confuses me is how nothing was fresh. Everything had a sauce had a thick film or skin on top of it, no matter how much product they are moving during dinner service. I get that places that do mass production have to cook food way ahead of time, but nothing tasted fresh on a busy Sunday night, and ingredient quality is very pedestrian. You can definitely see the difference in food quality between here and Bacchanal.   If you're a drinker, they've got a great $10 bottomless drinks deal, so that might be worth your time. Definitely make a reservation if you end up here; you don't want to end up waiting in line for an hour.

9T__ppBIGG43dFcP94NoYQ.text: We had 2 rewards for a free lunch buffet at the Aria and we made a mad dash to the Mlife desk to put them on our cards. We got up to the buffet at about 2:45pm on a Friday afternoon and were not the only ones with that same idea. It was super nice to have part of the fresh dinner food they were just putting out! The drink refills were super slow, but most of the food was good. The dessert selection is very impressive. My favorite was the taco bar area they had. Wouldn't necessarily want to pay full price, but it was free for both of us so it was great!

1nQTbSrx3dR7z6D6zrDV7A.text: We were here for Sunday brunch. There was quite a long line when we arrived, but the line moved fast and our wait was only about 10 minutes. It was a little over $100 for the 2 of us, but that included the unlimited drinks package. The selection of food was amazing. They have a ton of seafood choices. They also have Asian, Mediterranean, Latin, American, Italian, a carving station, a soup and salad bar, and of course desserts. My favorite was the Asian station, a lot of awesome dumplings, pad thai, fried rice, and stir fry to choose from. From the Italian station, the pizza and meatballs were phenomenal. Save room for gelato and cheesecake!

4vTQjIFssWJq8BmoqEXG7w.text: The worst buffet ever ever. Wasted of money to come here. Paid over $50/person, paid total over $350 for 5 adults and 2 kids, had nothing to eat. No crawfish and missing many kind of food. not same as shown pictures on yelp. No seafoods at all, it was all meats, and food did not look good. Bad service, Slow food refill.There was no bowl next to the soup and I look around but could not find one, asked the lady who worked there and she seemed did not even bother to help. Should have gone inside to check the food first before paying. Never ever see you again.

WtBNoZW1vBRsm8g1IFXuvQ.text: Main attraction is the crab legs. Unfortunately they were way too salty. Actually, most of their meats are way too salty. Selection of food isn't to die for. Overpriced in my honest opinion.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

1nt9DX0Bd7F1q4geGOJTbg.text: We've tried the Aria Buffet 3 times in the past 2 months. The food choices don't change, and the quality is not consistent. This time, none of the stations were more than like warm. Service is not anything to rave about either. This is often the case with buffets, but at $95 + tip for two people, there are much better options elsewhere for dinner. If you definitely want a buffet, it's hard to beat the Texas Station for value if you have a car and can drive a few miles, or try the Silverton on Windmill, but Aria is really not worth it.

pCd8QlD5KZn5ngGMNp7IyA.text: For $44  per person buffet, I have been waiting in line for 40min and it looks like another hour of wait before I can get in. Totally not worth it.

oLWF8NYgsEHadQn-_iRfZQ.text: We came to eat  here on a weekend on family occasion. The wait time was a reasonable 15 minutes from arrival. I liked the food selections and in particular the fresh seafood bar. We have had a great time eating here and enjoyed very much the wide range and taste of the desert selection. I certainly going to come back for additional rounds.

b2EC78IYjmt7lXoTyZsDLQ.text: It's not bad. There is a lot of options but not a lot for vegetarian. I asked the chef if they're willing to modify some food like sushi and they said no. They can't make a simple avocado roll. But they do have vegetarian pizza, salad and egg stuff. But other then that it's not a lot of options for vegetarians. My waiter was amazing. She was super nice. All the waiting staff is nice. The chef is not all that great. I ask for ice cream and one of the chef gave me an attitude for not being able to see the flavor sign. It's not my fault. He was covering it. Haha. I don't think I'll come back next time. It's not very vegetarian or vegan friendly. And the chefs aren't nice as well.

5DK1omMNAk5Rt-h7mVYjrA.text: First things first, this is not a cheap place to eat. The buffet is $40 per person. However, the drink special is good; $20 for 2 hours of bottomless drinks for 2 people.   The buffet has a wide range of food styles and the quality is decent. I wouldn't say that any of the food was bad, but it wasn't exceptional either.   There are a lot of different desserts on display, but I would suggest filling up on the main courses instead. I was generally disappointed by dessert.

K00sPmRKCCoN2zCGoDmXZQ.text: We came to Vegas for work and needed to stay in the hotel today so I decided to try this place.  I totally forgot about the memorial pricing for each person for brunch was $39 which I was not expecting but why not give it a shot.  Well the food was dry meaning the heat lamps just took all the moisture/juices from the food, presentation was not good.  Food quality for the price was definitely not good.  Based on the food quality the correct price would be $16 a person instead tops.  But my curious mind got the better of me this time since I was wondering why there was a huge line there....well all I can say is that I got suckered but it's ok for if you don't try it yourself then I would not know.    Now that I know I will not go back.

nJ2T7r57MchlaiN5XSyf9w.text: I've been to most of the better buffets in Vegas including Sterling, Bellagio, Wynn, and Bacchanal. And I must say that the Aria lunch buffet (have not had their dinner buffet) is quite outstanding for the price. They have steamed and stir-fried crab legs which are actually nicely seasoned with chili peppers. They have a wide assortment of different cuisines and all the ones I tried were above average.  I would come here over many of the higher priced buffets to be honest, at least for lunch.

wEgAu3Cz-QFmcCky0cOozw.text: We ate at this buffet for breakfast but were also there when they changed over to lunch so we got to see what all they have for both times of the day. Comparing it to our fave, The buffet at the Wynn this left much to be desired. The service at the front was hardly service. The staff on the floor though were very nice. The food options were just alright. I would not come here again.

J3m2FRoLYlazWAKgarXIKA.text: Visited the buffet at Aria on 12/23.  Very disappointed.  This is the most over-priced buffet in Vegas as they were charging special holiday gourmet dinner price of $46.99!!! And they charged the same price for a 5 year old kid???  It's definitely nothing special and not worth the price even with the $34.99 regular dinner price.  The food is just OK.  Buffet at Wynn is a lot better.  The roast beef was over-cook.  Grab legs were just like any other Vegas buffet places.  The only positive thing I can say about this place is the newly remodeled decor.  The environment is clean.  I will never visit this place again.  There are so many other buffet choices in Vegas that are more price reasonable with better food than Aria.  Even with my 2 for 1 myVegas coupon for dinner, it's still not worth the money.  Aria buffet, you definitely let us down!!!

PuylnCwNso_ikGgQ8bT76g.text: For it being the Aria, I'm disappointed. Price is alright. Came for lunch, I wouldn't come again. Although everything was clean and I was seated quickly. I'm sticking to Cesar's, I'd rather spend the extra $10-$15 and walk out happy and with my tummy full. They should consider getting some crepes !! Those things are delicious ! Well yeah, that's my personal review of the buffet at the Aria.

4TH01QkyuO581A3-Dzb0LQ.text: Two thumbs up! The best buffet I had this Christmas in Vegas. Very tasty food which made me feel the cook's effort inside out. Snow crab legs and king crab legs were the best.  Plus the service was great.

BlVWcfTF6onjNh2uXX77Kw.text: The line was super long and not worth the wait.  The interior was promising, but the food was almost decent.  About the only thing I liked was that the food stations were more spread out compared to other buffet set ups.  The food was uninspired and inconsistent with the hotel itself.  Other important info: spread out food stations, uninspired offerings, long waits, TVs available while waiting in line.

LPveLOd2ZvnzmzGA7Rh0jg.text: Been to a lot of buffets, expensive and non and I would say this one is great for the price you pay. Tons of food to choose from, a lot of which is made to order. Loved the chilequiles for breakfast, the bacon was perfect and the yogurt bar was amazing! I got the french toast dips, a number of sausages, salad and everything was very tasty. The dessert bar... oh man. I felt like a kid in a candy store. Everything looked amazing. Lemon bar, brownie, gelato. All of it was great. The coffee was good too! I would definitely eat here again during my next stay.

VZxo-srD0Is82G-HlLx6mA.text: I don't know why there're so many bad reviews for Aria buffet. We had a great time there! Yes, the price is around $35 which is slightly more than others but we think it's worthwhile considering the overall Experience. The waitress that we had was awesome! She was super attentive that makes the one we had from Planet Hollywood's looks really bad!! The food was great, the 1/2 lobster was delicious and no extra cost!

3ROx_M90ThdkenyNFmJsQg.text: 86 dollars for two. No alcoholic beverages. High price to pay for food that had obviously been sitting under heat lamps for hours. Save your money.

2qKOfZ8rd8mtw-wNqTPC1g.text: I miss those days when MAFIA used to run LV. $35 (or something like that) buffet of almost nothing. I thought that for $35 at least they would have King crab legs but nope only cheap Snow crab. Shrimp was large but overcooked. There were hardly any prepared dishes. Most dishes are combination of ingredients put together and hardly anything is cooked.  This is basically, a cheap buffet with crab legs and shrimp.  The only reason I gave it a 2 star because the deserts are better than dishes. Seafood buffet at Fremont or even Orleans beats the hell out of Aria for half the price. For around $40 (depending on a day) I can go to Universal Studios Hilton in Los Angeles and have 10 star buffet which beats them all.  Lesson learned. Never again.

G4aqkDh2X1IzHnMH8p_JCw.text: This buffet was pretty decent...  That is if you liked the food they had to offer.  Not too much in the fish department, which was a downer for me...  But the spaghetti with the asparagus in the truffle oil was pretty good...  I mixed that with the corn and I was content...  The cold shrimp and crab legs was decent, as it is a usual standard in all buffets...   The sushi on the other hand wasn't doing much for me.  The Salmon and the Tuna Nigiri was not for me...  The fish was actually dried out...  NOT GOOD...  Especially for this sushi girl...  But never got the chance to eat the meat stuff...  It's because the dessert was calling my name...    There were these little shot glasses that got my curiosity going...  One was a berry cheesecake and the other was a coffee shooter...  So, I took a chance on the coffee shooter, and of course HAD TO HAVE my creme bruele...  But it only took one spoonful of the coffee shooter to have my mind set...  And I've got only ONE WORD for it...  AWESOME!!!  It was sooo yummy and it's just a light coffee taste...  So delicious, I HAD TO HAVE 2!!!  Anyway, this buffet is just "A-OK"...  Lucky for us, we had a $50 dollar food & beverage credit for staying here at the Aria, so it really only cost me, about 11 dollars for the buffet...  Works for us...  Maybe give it some time, it's still a new hotel and hopefully they'll jazz it up a bit...  We'll just have to wait and see...

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Creme Puff, and a Coffee Shooter...  That Coffee Shooter was so good, I had 2!

RVQDasCAUOC-D8KQ0AlNPQ.text: We are currently staying at Aria and have had pleasant stay until we decided to give the buffet a try tonight. We felt like having a casual dinner at the hotel tonight and were very very disappointed. The food was unacceptable for this class of hotel. The shrimp lacked flavor, the pasta was dried out looking, the Mexican food wasn't even close to mexican, the baked potatos were hard and not all the way cooked. The only thing that was good were the mashed potatoes of the day. My husband got vanilla ice cream which tasted sour and the chocolate chip cookies were hard. Save your time and money and don't bother checking out this buffet. For the price head over to the wicked spoon buffet at the cosmopolitan, it blows Aria's buffet away. We will never eat this buffet again. Such a shame in this hotel.

pm69pfZqkQTWomhCEh3RLg.text: GO FOR THE BREAKFAST!!!! You can't go wrong with the $15.00 breakfast price. The boyfriend and I ate here Tuesday morning around 10:00am and there was NO wait to get in. Who wants to wait in a line for 30-60 minutes...just for a meal...not me...I'm on vacation and I want to enjoy it...not spend it waiting in line.   As a matter of fact in our four day trip we NEVER saw a line to get into this buffet, morning noon or night! So if you are in a rush you could come here and fill up and be on your way.   The breakfast was really good...and had all your normal breakfast goodies. The only thing that was missing was that they didn't have any hash browns. I was disappointed about that but oh well. They had deserts out already and they were really good.   If you are looking for fine dining then go to the expensive restaurants that charge $150 per meal (and in this hotel there are plenty of those) but if you want an average meal at an average price I think you'll be happy with what this buffet has to offer.

3AcIQ5uNyd0MfZslWMIRWA.text: OK writing a review of a buffet in Vegas, your kidding me... OK this one is easy.  Food was a 4.  Crab Legs were enjoyed, prime rib was very tasty and just about every other item was very very good.  Price 2 stars, come on aria is upscale hotel, but 32 for buffet is a little crazy.  HOWEVER, we had a group of 11, charging people who have more than 8 people an 18% gratuity when all you do is slam 3 tables together and the same person who would have brought us our drinks ANYWAY does nothing more is a sin.... 1 star seriously, not enough to get hosed in the casino but to get the shaft upstairs as well was not cool.  But obviously you don't care.  So advice to all, don't tell them you are in a big group, just force the hostess to put u near each other, besides your gonna be grazing anyway, not talking.

4sNybOy94toJtie2bzwtCA.text: Aria what happened? You were our favorite.  Never again.  There was not one thing to put in my mouth and smile about. .....  Just average.  And below average   Shame on you

_EZccndq-CzJHshHD484vg.text: Cons: Potatoes au gratin were undercooked to the point where they were crunchy. Sushi rice was stale. Crab was dried up like it had been frozen and then thawed a couple of times, and was tasteless. Gnocchi was dried up as if it had been sitting for hours. The waitress stopped by only twice the whole time, so we could only get one beverage each.  Pros: Garlic mashed potatoes were excellent. Shrimp ha gow was decent. Dessert whoopie pies were great, as was the bread pudding. The buffet was generally very clean.  Not worth the $40+ per person for dinner.

NCKTyeTRh1ExkIgqitDsfw.text: I was really looking forward to eating here since most of the buffets in the newer hotels are pretty snazzy. Boy, was I wrong.  The line moved pretty fast which is a definite plus for a buffet on the strip. Lunch price was $26 per person on a Tuesday. Eeks! My initial judgement was that this was not nearly as bog of a buffet line at other price comparable hotels. They have like 8 (I know that seems like a lot but it really isn't) stations. Although I really dug that crab legs were included in the regular buffet, everything else we got was mediocre, at best. We came around 1 pm which is pretty much prime time for lunch, but everything in the trays looked like it had been there for quite some time under those heat lamps, thus making everything look old and unappetizing. I made about 4 plates trying to get something I liked but ended up leaving 80% of each uneaten. Service was ok, (and we even tipped 20% in advance, something I regret) but the drink glasses were so tiny we definitely should have been checked on more than 2 times in an hour and a half.  I tried to eat the worth in dessert but that was a failed attempt in every category except the gelato bar.  I would probably never return here again, as I would rather shell out a couple more bucks for a better buffet at the hotels next door.

ZFC3clk2r5db8Jvx0SfDnQ.text: If you like crab legs (whole, large, hot and cold) and homemade ice cream/gelato, this is the place to come. Those alone get five stars.  Other items get a solid four stars. Nice open ambiance and great service. Go during lunch or late breakfast. Dinner is not really worth the extra price.

JG9Vm3T57j8isHi-Y9r9kw.text: Went to The Buffet at Aria on a whim. It was amazing. The good was great, with many choices for every palate. But, the service was the most stellar, even better than the fine dining restaurants at the Aria. Our server, Susan, was so nice! She checked on us consistently and was always a smiling face when we needed something. We will definitely be back!

GKUOuUqBDPpmlCKGC_CmQw.text: THREE STARS GUYS?? Really? Are you guys buffet snobs and know of better ones and not telling me? Because honestly, I eat, and I want to know. The M is on my list...any others? Seriously, I only eat in Vegas, so I need more to do.  But the Aria buffet, compared to the other major casino's buffet along the strip is the best one that I've had - taking into account price and quality (better and cheaper than Wynn). It was around $32 per person for dinner on a weeknight.  There's something nice about the fact that it's not just food piled on top of food, you know? Because some buffets just do that. HERE'S A BUNCH OF FOOD and it looks great for feasting with your eyes, but taste wise...eeeeeeeh.  Aria's is clean and arranged in a way where food looks delicious (and sanitary), but not in the NOW GO STUFF YOURSELF sort of way. Though, okay, the crab legs are done as such, but did you guys see the chickens? LINED UP FOR YOU! The cocktail shrimp even comes in little glass cups - but only one to a glass (wish it was at least three).  Okay, and you know how Vegas buffet sushi usually sucks? The rice is hard and cold (why would you even allow yourself to serve that?), the Aria one is actually pretty decent. I actually contemplated getting more.  The salads were creative tasted fresh. The build your own pasta was decent (if you want to try but save space for other buffet-type things, ask for half the usual amount). The seafood ravioli looks pretty average and gross, and I would have skipped it had the lady next to me not ooze about how good it was yesterday and just HAD to come back. So I tried it, and it actually tasted...fresh? Not fresh out of ocean fresh, but it was good.  I tried the Indian. They had a nice (I believe) Cantonese lady making the Indian, so while one of the dishes was great and spicy (and completely unauthentic), the chick peas were watery. Also, the garlic na'an, while delicious, did not have the consistency of na'an...more like the Chinese/Taiwanese green onion pancakes.  And the dessert. *sigh* the best part. What an amazing presentation. I wanted to try all of it. I actually did get about 8 desserts (not exaggerating) for my table of 4, and I personally did major work on all of them. They're fantastic. Great flavors, not too sweet, and not overly heavy. I LOVE creme brulee and would always get it at buffets and order it at restaurants. Until I found out how to make it. Then I just realized it wasn't worth it. But somehow, the dessert masters at Aria made it taste incredibly light for a creme brulee. My favorite, though, is the bread pudding. I just thought of it a few minutes ago, leading me to write this review. Love it! The apple crumble was not my favorite. But what I appreciated was that you can taste the real honey they used in it (probably from France, because they provided a small jar of honey from France for our tea). You can easily remedy the over powering honey in the crumble with a scoop of gelato =)  Service was a bit slow in the refilling of tea and picking plates up. Understandably, we came in about 1.5 hours before the closed, but at the same time...=T

UrhV2tcpBIfcixLdOJiq-w.text: Family reunion of 30 on a Saturday night - and what a treat! Wonderful wait team, wide selection of food, half a lobster and carafes of red or white wine included - all for under $50/per person including 18% gratuity & tax!  I gorged on salads and vegetables. It was tasty, if simple (OK, so they made money on me, but who cares) - great ambiance, service and food for the price.

DzW4G4ZBh9JwAXG21bgkfw.text: Lots of seafood! Jumbo shrimp, Alaskan king crab legs, sushi, oysters, smoked salmon all of which tasted fresh and great to me. Saturday morning brunch was about $30. Beautiful contemporary decor. My friend enjoyed the breakfast burrito. There was great variety, and lots of choices. The dessert selection was amazing, tasted great, and were presented beautifully. There was a large selection of pastries, gelato, and cakes. Everything tasted great to me, I was sad that I wasn't able to finish the foods on my plates (they gave me a generous slice of tender prime rib). The staff were courteous and came to check on us frequently, keeping our juice and coffee cups filled.

eg3W1oD6D8Jx5WYJbrMpuw.text: Worthless and worst buffet. The food is so so bland. Does not worth the price. Desserts are fairy OK, but everything else is strictly avoidable. Stay away - does not worth 25$ nor your time

MNVDnGAPzxIh1wdZcMqbDg.text: Any place that serves pork belly wins me over! I was surprised to see that there was pork belly at the carvery. It's been a while since I've been to a Vegas buffet, but it doesn't seem like a common option from what I could remember. There was a large variety of meats at the carvery including chicken, BBQ beef brisket, sausage, pork belly, pork shoulder and more.   There was different cuisines from American to Chinese to Italian to Japanese (sushi) and more. They had pretty much anything you can think of and the food was well stocked. It never seem to run out. There was also a good selection of seafood including king crab legs which were quite fresh.  The desserts were just as delicious as they looked. The small portions allowed you to try multiple ones. I had the tiramisu, flan, whoopee pie and a few others which were all amazing.  I would definitely come back. It was a great value for only $25 a person for lunch. We also had a 2-for-1 coupon from MyVegas which made it an even better value. My two friends also got bottomless alcoholic drinks for $15 each. The variety of bottomless drinks  included bellinis, sangria, different wines and beers, as well as mimosas, champagne and others.

QndfAvTWHXEzItooCgiPgQ.text: Amazing for breakfast.  I can eat their biscuits n gravy all day any day.

3I2VTXnNcaLd3hcqStc2NA.text: Went here week day for lunch... About $25.  Split snow crab legs, hot and cold... loved it. mussels, clams,good,  craw-fish was too much work,  Asian dim sum, OK, fish and chips, lots of ice cream and desserts, gotta go back the next trip.  Too full to go to the carving station.  They drop off a thermos of coffee, don't have to find them for a refill....

ojqFsAd24JUUha-Mr6uZbQ.text: I suppose if you were to compare this place to other buffets--like, say, The Golden Corral--then you'd say the food was better.  Then again, the Golden Corral doesn't cost $40 either.  And that was the price for dinner at Aria on a Sunday night.  With that, you get the buffet, half of a small lobster and apparently limitless red or white wine (though certainly nobody seemed in a hurry to offer refills).    The buffet did have an interesting assortment of items.  I saw one man attacking the crab legs and shrimp as if he had not eaten in months and we felt someone would come along at any moment and drag his food away.    The bread pudding and bananas foster both seemed pretty outstanding among the desserts.  As for the food, it seemed fresh enough.  There were several options for ceviche.  Some Chinese food.  Nachos.  Pizza.  A carving station with beef, ham, turkey, and salmon.  And an actual salad bar.  There was absolutely no item in the place that made me think "I will have to come back for this."  Yes, you can eat a lot and get stuffed--but is being stuffed really the goal of eating?  There are so many other places from which to choose in the area that I'd much rather spend $40 a person and come away feeling pleasantly full and having a memorable meal elsewhere.    Again, as far as buffets go, it may be great.  I have no idea.  I'm not a connoisseur of the buffet.  As far as restaurants where you'll spend a couple of hundred dollars for a small party to eat, there are many, many better options.

B0sSaHMMYygcQJ7PlEETcA.text: I gave two stars because Prime Rib is good but the rest of the food is MEDIOCRE! I expect too much from ARIA since they boast of being one of the best hotel, so sad not True at all in terms of food. I felt that Ive been robbed!  Let me explain: the setting is two - three dishes different parts of the globe (ie asia), salad - no variety, dessert is limited choices (ice cream, cake, bread), thin crab legs! Imagine that ----- BUFFET?????? NOT!!!  Not coming back here for sure!

ZjJGKk6L1yfvOuJve9_efA.text: Not much to like here! Used My Vegas rewards for  lunch and cost was 28.00 for 2 for 1. Mandalay Bay buffet lunch is much better!

yPGXHQp2FZ4a5Bw4n2Z2RQ.text: There are so many places to eat in Las Vegas and for this buffet, I was not impressed. I was told to eat at a buffet because "that is what you do in Vegas." So, giving it a try, I landed in the hotel's buffet. Aria is a beautiful hotel however the food at the buffet is less than stellar. Most of the food that I had was either too salty or dry. There was not a great selection of foods here to choose from. I would highly suggest that they do a food makeover of this buffet. The only decent thing they had to offer, besides the nice staff, was the desserts. However, even the desserts were pretty basic and lacked any imagination. All that said, I would not pay the price to come to this buffet again.

Uz4-oJWy-0yi2po8MhUCzQ.text: Great food and if you get Linda as a server you will have great service too! The ice cream dessert is amazing coconut is my favorite all are very smooth.

SeSFsqtIs46l6ysJ0dAzxw.text: I've been here on a few occasions and I love this place. The pasta selection is amazing especially love the chorizo sauce for the spaghetti. The fresh seafood is amazing. I typically don't eat oysters and theirs are so fresh and delicious. They have great Indian and Thai food as well it's like a delicious world tour! I can't leave out the unlimited Thai tea! I recommend The Buffet to everyone I know when they go to vegas.

_5ByFjEREXHTeXIy39bHHQ.text: The buffet was good, but not GREAT. I would give it 3.5 if that were possible, because I was satisfied, it's just not something I'm going to be craving. The food was good for the most part and everything was cooked well. I tried a little bit from each section. But I felt that everything was pretty basic and not much really stood out for me. My favorite thing I would say was the salmon. It had this really delicious pineapple/mango salsa on top that was sweet and went very nicely together.   The dinner buffet was about $45 per person (4th of July weekend). It's on the strip, so I wouldn't expect much less, but still, just wouldn't go too often.

bidbmHyLcXbGP-CX5n0bpw.text: Wow wow wow.... Fish, meats, Asian, Mexican, waffle bar, pancake bar, bananas foster, salad bar, sushi, pastries, fresh everything- and the traditional breakfast staples. If you cannot satisfy your craving here, you are out of luck anywhere else! We have been to many of the brunch buffets and this tops even the Wynn! My only reason for not giving 5 on this is simple: the wait. But it was worth it!

oB1RS20xv4oINfvrq5njdw.text: While in Vegas, the boyfriend and I went to this buffet on one of our mornings while in town. This buffet is pricey at about $35 a person, but it is worth it! They also have unlimited mimosas for about $10. Wait is usually about 30 minutes to get a table.  Food wise, they have everything from omelettes, to french toast, to fruit, to seafood, to pancakes and much more. Food was really good and I got full petty fast.   Service was pretty good and they kept our drinks full and they always took our plates away right away.  I would probably be back here in the future when we are back in Vegas!  Cheers.

HkUpVThwxGeIVNeks2etxw.text: This was the best buffet I've been to! My fiance and I went on a Saturday night and the check was about $90, it was a little pricey but worth simply for the crab legs!! I think we each had 3 plates full of crab legs and shrimp. It was also nice the crab legs were pre cracked so all you had to do was snap it open and pull easy to get the crab meat. We also really enjoyed the prime rib. The dessert table wasn't a huge hit with us but everything was worth from the crab legs, prime rib, and the great service we had. We will definitely be coming back!

-OXqLuzluO6o0KAG6z5_Bg.text: The redesigned Aria buffet is good, but not the best buffet on the strip.  There's not much to say about it. It's clean, open and has a lot of food options. The dessert is notable, although I would steer clear of the gimmicky spinning gelato machine that looks like it's out of Wheel of Fortune. The gelato is subpar and is no where near the quality of the Gelato outside at John Phillipe's or Bacchanal.  That being said, I like the layout and the way the carvery and seafood stations are setup.  Don't miss out on the delicious King Crab Legs. Have the guy behind the counter steam them warm for you - it makes them less salty, especially compared to the really salty Snow Crab legs they serve.

L2NWmTP36gny4UF2ew0oHQ.text: Not impressed.  I guess after we ate at the Bacchanal Buffett (Caesars's Palace) the bar had been set fairly high and we expected so much more from Aria.   The food was mediocre at best. The atmosphere boring and uninteresting.  The experience as whole was not worth $50. Sushi was pretty much the only appetizing dish here. Won't visit again.

KixpjeV4aQ_jPAs6zRAj2w.text: This place was pretty good. It actually came at the recommendation of a server we had at Mandalay Bay buffet.Me and a friend of mine went here on a Saturday morning and had the brunch menu. At first I thought this place was going to have limited selection.....boy was I wrong, once we were out of the line and finally made it in....It was on. As far as the breakfast went, they had everything I can think of just about with the exception of grits( I'm not complaining though). I went to the station where you can have your own omelet made, that was very good. I love the selection of breakfast meats, bacon, sausage, ham, etc. The waffles were actually THE BOMB!!!!. I made it a point to try every station they had, which meant I had to pace myself, and not clear my plate :0( I did enjoy the bay scallops service. The olive tapanade from the Mediterranean station was yummy. The sushi was flavorful, I had various ones can't remember the specifics. Steam buns, oh yes, I'm not a big dessert person, but I did try them, but as another reviewer stated, I was unimpressed with flavor although the presentation was pretty. I paid the extra $12 for drinks, and had the mimosas, peach Bellini's, they were aiight. I was disappointed on the crab legs. I def. was not feeling them But overall I did enjoy myself, there were a lot of good eats. The service was great, it was clean. I would return again

6-MNK5kElbCSm0GxvvdTMQ.text: At around $40 Dollars for Brunch, I was expecting a really great situation when it came to food quality. The Aria Buffet did not let me down. They had many different stations that included LATIN, and ASIAN and and AMERICAN.. haha.. and some Mediterranean style dishes and salads too. There was a fantastic salad station which had a Waldorf Sald when I visited .. I like Waldorf Salad.. and a really nice dessert bar that included a rotating Gelato bar.   In addition, since it was Brunch,. they had chicken and waffles, biscuits and gravy, pancakes to order..hashed potatoes and eggs.  I'm a sucker for Breakfast. I Brake for good brunch. I could have my chicken and waffles with eggs, Chinese-Style steamed buns and Mimosa!   Pretty excellent and I would go again if given the chance. In a sea of buffets and all you can eateries ..thie ARIA Buffet stands out for me! Happy Eating!

FdGxpyX3CbCpryLbVsNjxQ.text: When I go to buffet's I understand that it is difficult to control quality under heat lamps and with customers constantly scooping food.  That said, when I go to  relatively new buffet at a premium hotel like Aria, I have certain expecations.  They are: 1) Clean and organized 2) better quality ingredients and preparation. 3) good service from the staff. 4) Variety  Sadly, the Aria buffet falls short on 3 of the 4 characteristics.   1) To begin, Aria is clean and organized although it uses the space poorly.  The food is categorized by food type with a round seafood section and wall hugging American, Italian and Asian sections. The Asian Section and Seafood are the focus of this buffet with several dim sum options in Asian and multiple types of mussels, both raw and drowned in broth or sauce.    2) I was very disappointed with the food quality and preparation.  The crab legs were tinier than those at asian buffets and not really worth the effort.  The muscles were varied and good and were actually the highlight but the cooked muscles were drowned in sauce and did not taste like they were properly cleaned.  The carving station had a lot of options including game hen, prime rib, flat iron steak and sausages however the prime rib was bland and the flat iron steak dried out from the heat lamps. The game hen was actually the best of the meats as the leg and thigh were most and well seasoned.   The shrimp were small, probably 41-50 count and did not taste very fresh.  There was only a small sample of very basic sushi.  The baked fish was overcooked and unpalatable.   The charcuterie was a poor comparison to Bacchanal as it contained only three types of meats to go with dry crumbly cheeses.  The meats were tough and fatty and definitely not premium quality.  I couldn't even sample the mac and cheese which was a liquid mess with the oil separating from the cheese.  The buttermilk mashed potatoes were ok.  Deserts were very good and possibly saved the evening but the gelato bar did not get adventurous in flavors.  3) The staff took forever to take my drink order, clear my plate, and refill my drink. I was able to get up, get a second plate and return and eat half the second plate before the first plate was removed.  my tea was never refilled.  4)  Very disappointing variety.  First, they bill the buffet as "a new way to buffet" but there is nothing new about it.  I was excited to see so many steam bins for the asian section but turned out they were doubled up and just americanized favorites such as dumplings, pork buns, shumai and the best of the bunch, the leek pancake.  They were not well cooked either.  Other than the dim sum, there were very few asian options. The fried rice was highly disappointing   The Italian section was also disappointing as it contained only pizza and spaghetti and meatballs. Other than the meatballs, which were nothing special, you could have had a better meal at Cici's.  The seafood section was great if you like muscles but lacking everywhere else.  I didn't expect 500 items but I did expect something to set it apart which I didn't find.

tqFh7PY_CJx7f-cKtZp8oQ.text: Ok, but totally not worth $40 weekday dinner price. Overall average selection although quality is good and they have see food. Overall beef pot roast with mashed potatoes was the best. Desserts look great but only 4 were pretty good, while I left not finding one that would really make it a happy ending for me. Likely won't be coming here again.' My 3 top choices on the strip are Bacchanal (expensive), Spice Market at Planet Hollywood and Wicked Spoon at Cosmo.

uZgoNeA6zLVN8uGvgCkaMw.text: One of the worst buffet in vegas, rode staff, for just one glass of water you need to wait more than 10 minutes. I was waiting for waitress to bring me spoon and fork for 15 minutes. Lastly I asked to meet manager. Then brought me that. Don't get there it is the worst buffet ever I have got.  When we wanted to leave, staff asked for tip.

RUO95FHdLPmArGhdn2xaUQ.text: Their buffet is Superior!  Let me start by saying its worth it's price if you are hungry or had a special or it's comped during your stay. The food / service are amazing, they steamed by iced seafood which made me smile. The crab legs come in half cut so no need to fight your way from the to the claw, just peel or fork it all up. Comes cold or steamed. They have all types of food from the seafood section to like a wheel of fortune ice-crew, the sliced beef was so juicy as well and always ask for an extra slice. If the line is long and your staying there, try to go through the sky suites line and charge to your room. A little perk to get inside as the other just sit and wait, tip your mimosa cup and carry on!  Amazing feature: all you can drink beer and cocktails (picture below) it's about $15 and to start your day go to the lunch buffet and come pre-game there!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. My second plate at brunch on my third day
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The unlimited

-qX8RyKNRhORgM4sMNc-lA.text: Oh my amazing! I loved this buffet and I can't wait to return!  The variety is astounding --- Asian, Mexican, Mediterranean, Italian, SEAFOOD! Those snow crab legs were, hands down, the icing on top of an already great experience!  We went for brunch, both their breakfast and lunch items were A-plus worthy. They offered everything I was craving that day. The craving for eggs benedict, fulfilled. Baba ghanoush, they had it. Cannolis, you bet! They even had brussel sprouts with applewood smoked bacon, another one of my favorites. And I can't forget to mention the banana foster waffles or red velvet nutella pancakes...  For the coffee drinkers out there, their coffee is also outstanding. Far from average like every other buffet I've visited.  I'd highly recommend the buffet at Aria. They're sure to have something for everyone, you won't be disappointed.

eL6qjyDV7IAnhNT9ijjx9A.text: Came here for a Sunday brunch after a long Saturday night. There was a line when we went, but it moved at a steady pace. I want to say we waited around 30 minutes in line with a group of 8. There was quite a selection of food; my friend said he was surprised they served crab legs. The meats from the meat station were ok, kind of bland even with sauces. In general, none of the food really wowed me; even the brunch items like eggs benedict looked uncooked and unappetizing. Saving grace for the Aria buffet? One word: GELATO. The other desserts were ok, but I could have eaten 10 cups of gelato. A coworker told me the gelato they serve at the Aria buffet is the same at Jean Philippe's, I don't know if it's True, but the gelato was the best part of the buffet. I tried pistachio, coffee, some triple berry thing, and one more fruit one I forget now. All good.   After this last trip to Vegas, I think I have come to realize that I do not like the buffets, and I'd rather go to a sit-down venue and eat/savor my food. Granted, some buffets are good, but oftentimes, I come out feeling like I just stuffed my face for the sake of stuffing my face, and that's never a good feeling. If I was staying at Aria of Vdara and didn't want to go very far for a buffet, I'd say go. But for me, I think I'll be done with Vegas buffets for awhile.

L_nQseEX4OiLpR-P38R8Zw.text: Even a bit disappointed given how nice this hotel is, but it is what it is.  Came here more out of convenience, didn't want to keep on looking, but at this point, wasn't aware of Wicked Spoon, but i digress.  Another justifiable reason was there were no lineups at 5:30pm on a Monday, so easy breezin.  Glad they had the crab legs, plump prime rib, and the mash potatoes, but that's about the best part.  There was congee and sushi, but didn't dare touch that.  The desserts were a bit underwhelming, though the circular display of their gelato was probably the only highlight.  Oh, the creme flan was pretty darn good.  Nice orange theme going around here, and liked the open concept here.  But can't really rant and rave for someone to return here.  $35/pp.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

JPBlzTq3CzVD5CHOuxDzug.text: Underwhelming for a lovely hotel like Aria. We did a Sunday brunch/lunch on a Valentines holiday weekend. It's $40/person, which makes it one of the pricier of the lot for Vegas buffets. They have standard fare of multi cuisines. Nothing was interesting or tasty enough to go back for a second. They had lobster and crab, so I can't comment on how that tasted since I don't eat that! Their desserts were plain, not necessarily special or tasty or unique. Would not come back! Too many better choices in Vegas!

Fx9VN3zL08FHORfId2LZuw.text: This place is the bomb. For the price and quality, you cant beat it. Yes its not as good as baccanal or the bellagio. But its right up there. Definetley way above mgm or mandalay buffets. You pay 40 bucks for a family or 6. Where else can you get this deal in vegas

vvTGYhnK0DA4KsMhhA2xng.text: We went here for Christmas eve dinner. Our first choice was Bacchanal but the wait was 3.5 hours! We waited in line for about 30 minutes and it was $47/person. The buffet was on the smaller side but it had a lot of good food to choose from. There's a huge seafood bar which has king crab legs, snow crab legs, oysters, mussels, shrimp, ceviche, salmon and tuna poke and cioppino. There's also a small cheese station, pasta station, asian station and meat station. My favorites were the king crab legs, har gow (dim sum), salmon/tuna poke, prime rib, and cheesecake. Aria buffet also had an extensive dessert bar. I love their panna cotta and cookies! Service was good and our table was clean and spacious. Overall, a good buffet but not as grand as wicked spoon.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

fxqk29GP6nZviv_bE2v0Bg.text: Two words: Crab Legs.  Lunch/Dinner: I've eaten at various buffets throughout the Strip and not all offer crab legs. Everyone does prime rib, ham, roasted chicken, Asian food, Italian food, salad, etc. Even the crappier buffets offer that. Not everyone offers hot AND cold crab legs.  Obviously more expensive than the breakfast, but a greater selection.  Breakfast: Only really worth it if you're super hungry. Nothing extraordinary. They make your omelets, have sausage, waffles, fruit, etc. Typical stuff.

N02JMpqc6VaNBP7W6CG3kQ.text: ZERO STARS... This is the worst food I have ever eaten don't waste your money ($31)! How do you make pizza with zero flavor? All the food looks like it's been sitting for a while... I came for lunch on a Monday at noon because I am staying in the hotel and it's absolutely terrible! I never write reviews, but if I can help some people save the disappointment and the money here it is... The crab legs don't even taste good hot or cold. Nothing here has flavor: the butter for crab legs has no flavor, the dang cocktail sauce for the shrimp tastes off it's literally freaking horseradish mixed with ketchup that's how easy it is to make... the hummus tastes like nothing, the Chinese dim sum was nasty, the carved beef was rubbery and tasteless. I wasn't impressed with one item here... maybe my Coke... my server was very nice, but the food was garbage. The desserts look good and once again garbage. How do you mess up a rice krispy treat? It's  literally butter and rice krispy's and boom delicious... Don't even bother looking at the sushi unless you like air dried out raw fish that looks like a pre-k art project same goes for the pre-made salads I wouldn't even touch because they looked so old that the film was starting to take place from being stationary too long.   F-. A high end hotel like this needs to learn from Bellagio, Ceasar's, or Wynn's buffet's = fresh food and good

BirN1y5HAy5qk6NBBWBdhA.text: What has happened to the Aria Buffet?  My partner and I have dined here on several dozen occasions over the past 2+ years, and we've seen it slowly go downhill. We are MLife Platinum members and frequent the Aria Casino regularly. Recently, it's been just hit-or-miss.  What a disappointment on Easter Sunday dinner at 7:30pm, when they do an extra surcharge at $47.99 per person, plus tax. I was expecting they could do a little better on a "holiday". Foremost in our minds was the decision to remove the made-to-order pasta station, which my partner enjoyed on almost every occasion previously. Now, in its place, there's just a lonely Pho station, which does not look appetizing and from which no one orders. It's confusing what exactly it even is.  The deli meats used to include high end selections- delicious salami and prosciutto. Now, it looks like thin slices of turkey, ham, and roast beef. They have even cut down on the cheese selection, no longer serving mozzarella, dried apricots, various nuts, or the flatbreads and breadsticks which used to accompany the spread on a daily basis.  The carving station used to have roasted vegetables- carrots, onion, purple cauliflower, butternut squash, and zucchini. This time-ONLY yellow zucchini.   In addition, some of our favorite classic selections have been ruined--Mac and Cheese is now Lobster Mac and cheese, Plain vegetable fried rice is now Shrimp fried rice. Not for vegetarians...  The Aria Buffet used to be amazing- a great and vast selection of food. I used to rave about it and recommend it left and right. We loved the Raspberry and Apricot Rugelach from the dessert station, which is unfortunately never served anymore.  Also, during our most recent visit, my partner went to the dessert station for a chocolate chip cookie. He returned for another one and saw an employee taking about 10 remaining cookies and packing them up. If there's only ten left, why not allow customers to finish them? Very perplexing.  My partner actually left hungry because he couldn't find anything appetizing. At $200 for a party of four, we truly felt we did not get our money's worth, and do not plan on returning any time in the near future.

jlQlBxTdVyqBj2-T2ECgww.text: I've eaten at this buffet a few times and have thoroughly enjoyed myself every time!! I especially loved the Asian food, carving station and dessert bar.... OOHHH!! And the unlimited Thai iced tea!! Yum!! The staff is always friendly and quick to serve drinks and switch out plates. Would totally recommend!

u5lUdM7Dn4i9_Y_h0V6XfA.text: Now serving brunch instead of lunch. Wad here few months ago for lunch it was so good. Came back the other day and the choices wete not as great anymore. Wont be back.

Qwiz3NUdpNyQNrRNwtRdgA.text: Better than the Wicked Spoon.  Very nice variety of food - especially the Asian section.  The line was short which was a major plus.  Would definitely try again the next time in town.

6zT6mLQEbfykcXYPYMhatg.text: Wait was over an hour and a half. Plenty of tables open. Not sure why it was so slow. Food was okay.

Re_OQ8Cw5Lht75a87mPJUA.text: A decent Place with so many options which made it very hard to taste each and every item!!   My friends were vegetarians and unfortunately they had one or two veg options in the entire menu. The chef was good enough to prepare one vegetarian dish.  The New England clam chowder is good. The Italian section has no pasta varieties!! Lot of sea food and Less chicken options.   If you can eat any kind of meat then it's a very good place. Other can try once but definitely not worth the price if your options are limited.

A2UzKrKf_yjJQVUdlqw7Rg.text: Worst buffet in Las Vegas ! Worst service and very pricey! Do not go pleeeeaaase! Over price reheated food.Chinese food was discusting. In general Horrible and not worst the time and money!

LKjO9QxteW-BnoZk0wHs4A.text: I'm not a huge fan of buffets. But we had two comped meals with our stay at the Vdara, so my girlfriends and I decided to go and make it our meal before we depart Vegas.  It's not very big like most Vegas buffets. The selection of food was also not a lot as well. I really didn't like how things were set up. It was all kind of bunched up together. Like the center counters, one side would be hot food and the other side would be crab legs. The set up just wasn't all that easy. Presentation was just ok. It kind of mimicked the Wicked Spoon with some of the trays items were put in. And the salad bar! Most people get excited for the crab legs and prime ribs. I get excited about the salad bar. The more toppings the better. But if you put the toppings in a jar, how the heck am I suppose to grab them quickly? It wasn't easy reaching towards the back of the bar.  The quality of the food wasn't the best either. I don't think I ate that much at this buffet. I didn't find anything that was amazing. And because it's so small the wait was longer for large parties of 5 and up.

m7JsOgs44aT6Bcvr7dyrJQ.text: We went during weekend (Sunday) brunch! Great food! Lots of vegetarian options. $32.99 is not bad for all kinds of cuisine they offer. The stations were Italian, seafood, Mexican, Indian etc. The food tasted delicious. The dessert station was fabulous and had bite size dessert portions.

nTysl3io1dwlf0R06VRP3w.text: Complete gatbage! $45 buffet that's worse than Golden Corral! I expected something amazing but was sorely disappointed. Truly garbage!!!!

uwjoBcZNdD45kj61CFs02g.text: This is my favorite buffet, because there's a wide variety of food. Some items are displayed in small easy to grab portions. American, Italian, Asian, Mediterranean, carving station, etc. Large variety of desserts and gelato wheel- approx. 10 flavors.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

hjXKJhscKl01_Ugm8pw4cw.text: My family just finished a weekend stay at Aria with three suites for a family of 6 adults and 6 kids (ages 3 through 7).   The only problem with our stay was the Aria buffet.    We had dinner on Sunday night.  Price was $52 per person for everyone.  $52 per person, whether adult or kid!!!!  Only the 3-year old was free.  The remaining 5 kids, ages 4-7, each cost $52.     The cashier, Paul, had a bad attitude and messed up our billing.   He originally charged $52 per person (gratuity already included per person for our large party).   After he charged 2 of our credit cards for the group, we asked him about the kids prices.   When he found out one of them was 3 years and should've been free, he gave us an attitude like it was our fault for not telling him up front.   Then the bad attitude continued as he tried to figure out how to give $52 back.  The whole line got held up because of his mistake, yet people were looking my family like it was our fault.   So then we get to our table, and we get a waiter who was pretty inattentive.   We weren't eating and drinking at a very fast rate at all.  But we still had to wait for extended times to get drink refills and plates cleared.    The food was OK, not worth $52.   Dim sum containers had nothing in them.  The available tuna sushi looked old and dry.  The warm steamed crab legs were a pile of broken unappetizing looking legs.     Good news is the oysters were good.  So was the prime rib.   Otherwise, hit and miss on the dishes offered at Aria.   As far as I'm concerned, it's better to pay up more and get amazing food and service upstairs at Carbone, or else get the overpriced pizza at Slaters or $10-12 burgers at the burger place.    The crazy thing is that you would think the $52 buffet price point would weed out some of the jackass patrons.  But it didn't.  There were idiot diners who took serving tongs and spoons from one dish to scoop out food from other nearby dishes.   There were also gluttons who did things like hoard oysters and crab legs on multiple plates at a time, leaving nothing for anyone else.    I'm not dinging Aria for the idiot eaters.   But as far as the price, value, cashier and waiter service, $52 is not worth it all.   If you really want a buffet, go somewhere else.

N37BcrwSIyRO6s5ra7_jPA.text: Great buffet especially if you can incorporate it as part of your room package.  This buffet offers a delicious variety of meals from around the world for breakfast, lunch, or dinner.  I must recommend the red velvet nutella pancakes for breakfast.  So mouth watering and good.

8N-_5NmRuJheW-Gvfh8WOQ.text: I wasn't really expecting much, especially after being a bit disappointed in the Bellagio buffet, but I liked the selection, the service, and the quality here.  Breakfast is fantastic, coffee refilled often (and it's a great breakfast blend flavor), the mango chicken sausage is fantastic, lox, Benedicts, Nutella red velvet pancakes,  fruit, salads, sushi, steamed bbq pork buns,  ... if you can't find something here to hit the spot for you, well, you might be too picky. And having the two free buffet ($100 equivalent) per night was a fabulous perk!

RxwIT8ztuHZ8IZYBM8MrDQ.text: This is honestly the worst place I have ever ate at in my life. Every single thing I ate was disgusting.  I wouldn't want my worst enemies to eat here. Save your 50 dollars for some place edible.

CSf5QUSgPNSNA-Y90xlC9Q.text: Good little buffet. They offered a locals Friday-Sun $30 deal and we're glad we gave it a go! Smaller buffet of the others in town but also less crowded. The staff was nice and everything was clean.   The meat station was pretty good. The usual suspects; Prime Rib, Ham, Roasted Chicken, Smoked Sausage and a Beef Brisket or Roast maybe. They called it Steamship. It was all really good, juicy and tender. We went on Sat night so they also had a Steak Station. The were grilling custom ordered Sirloins. While I usually don't care for a Sirloin, I gave it a try and it was good! Tender, juicy, flavorful and cooked perfectly!   The salad bar and the vegetable selection was a little lacking but what they had was good. I tried the Mac and Cheese, excellent! For a buffet especially. The Tamales were also very good and tasted fresh made. I'll say this, it's the first buffet I've been to in Las Vegas where everything tastes fresh made. I didn't taste anything that was bland or dried out.   They also served seafood! Cold Alaskan King Crab, split and oysters and such. Warm sweet Snow Crab, cracked and a few fish dishes and muscles dishes. I only tried the crab but it was delicious! The Snow Crab was super sweet and came out of the shell easily. They come cracked so that helps. The bins were always full, no lines.  And the best part was the dessert!! Let me say again, buffet desserts are usually bland and dry bits of cardboard but this buffet....holy smokes! Every single thing I tried tasted moist, delicious and fresh made.   I posted pics, check them out. Over all, great meal worth $30 for sure. We'll be back!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Desserts. Delicious! Most buffet desserts are dry and bland these are the best I&#39;ve had! Moist, sweet and fresh made!!
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Steak station. Good little sirloins, grilled to order.
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Prime Rib and Steamship both very flavorful and tender.

LFf6LO-T3cVZuKa9LGROsg.text: I love their buffet here!  Prime Rib, Crab Legs, BBQ Ribs, Oxtail, Salmon Poke, Shrimps and a variety of different kinds of cheeses were my highlights!   Their prime rib is nicely cooked, BBQ rib sweetly grilled and tender and oxtail well marinated in stew!  To a point that the meat is smoothly falling off the bone!  Smacking delicious!  Plus, you got the seafood part!  Unlimited amount of shrimps with cocktail dips and chopped up crab legs for you to hover over!  Zest it up with lemon wedges and it will be perfecto!   Desserts, desserts!  Do try their ice cream flavors and their delectable creme brulee!  They also have good looking cake pops that can entice you to just pop it in your mouth!  Oh my goodness!  This place is a buffet lover's haven!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cake pop and creme brûlée
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Salmon Poke
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Seafood section

-nBtkHiOWrwqk02DEeU3MQ.text: Experience All You Can Eat - Twice!  A friend and I had "brunch" here at the Aria buffet while visiting on a trip this October (2016).  The buffet promised a brunch style but was definitely a miss on several levels.  Although we were one of the first customers, many of the food items were already "old" and inedible.  They had already been sitting out too long or were reused from the previous day.  The selection was lacking, especially breakfast items like such basics as scrambled eggs, hash browns, sausage links, etc.  You won't find any of that here.  For the lunch side of the menu, basics that were missing were mashed potatoes, gravies and a variety of carved meats. Perhaps this buffet is trying too hard to cater to many different global societies, which is great, but most of the folks here were looking for the basics.  The best things here were the made to order omelets and the gelato.  My friend actually vomited up his meal soon after we left.  We'll probably stick with the Bellagio buffet or try out the Wicked Spoon buffet at the Cosmo next time we visit.

FlJMjBbMK4RZ8K35DDoMdQ.text: Came here on a Sunday night at 5pm. There was no wait, the food was fresh (unlike what others said in their reviews), and there was plenty of delicious king crab!  Great selection of food. I try to somewhat watch what I eat, and there were plenty of health choices to fill my tummy. Lots of different kinds of foods to choose from including American, Asian, Mexican, Indian, and Italian.  The food was delicious! Good flavor and not too salty. Service is top knotch, they were picking up our dishes and checking on us often. Would come here again for sure and bring some family or friends along with us!

aXnp0TqHBbwljr9rUqcynQ.text: How the mighty have fallen I remember how great this buffet use to be back in the day and now it's just average at best. I was comped a free buffet and decided to use it on breakfast. Wanted to get my day started off on the right foot with a good buffet. At least I remembered it being good and I was mistaken. I got their a little later the. I liked around 10 am but didn't think I'd be waiting long but I was wrong I waiting 40 plus minuets I was really surprised as to why it was such a long wait. Then when I got to the front I realized if you're a guest at the hotel and you check-in from your room you get to skip the lane and. Damn you really end up paying for it by waiting in line so if you're not staying here either eat somewhere else or be prepared to wait. The buffet seems to be on the smaller side compared to other hotel the servers were really nice and very attentive with bringing me my drinks quickly. I would also say it was very clean and not dirty at all which is nice for a buffet. As for the food it was just lack luster and boring nothing really good about it food was bland and offered nothing. I think the best part about it was that there was an horchata machine but that's it. I just wouldn't come back even if I was given another free comped buffet no thanks give it to someone else.

SNDKAbEtqldg-8Mr2wpYWg.text: First off, you better come with an empty stomach. And I mean growling uncontrollably hungry because the buffet cost $25 and you only get two hours before they boot you out. With that said, they have a variety of cuisines: seafood, Mediterranean, Italian, Asian, and the list goes on. Your best bet to get your money's worth is go all in at the seafood section. If you don't like seafood, I'd recommend eating elsewhere.

9OKGvFE5bZGIIECIF2EC5g.text: The Buffet is a veritable smorgasbord orgasbord orgasbord Even when the crowds have 'creased.   Each day when the lights go on it can be found by the pound all around Oh what a lovely feast.  This appetizing yarn of mine is True.  But, it's probably more of a qualified truth since the food you'll find at The Buffet at ARIA is decent but will become increasingly unappetizing as you consume more.  Nonetheless, this is a place where you can glut glut glut glut!  It's been several years since I've been to a buffet of this caliber, so needless to say, I was starved for the variety of options available at a smorgasbord like the one at ARIA.  My initial plan was to stay at the buffet from lunch to dinner so that I wouldn't have to worry about eating multiple meals.  After all, buffets aren't cheap!  (Weekend brunch is $29.99 / Weekend dinner $39.99.)  But, as I sat with a dystopian novel in hand, I found that my eyes wandered from the text to the serving area, which was in my direct line of sight - a foolish maneuver.  The more my eyes wandered, the more I wanted to eat.  And, eat I did!  Thus, my glorious plan to stay at the buffet from 2:30PM to 6:30PM was foiled, and I left after only two hours.  Like most buffets, you pay when you enter the buffet.  You're given the option to tip, and I would recommend doing so since there are friendly and helpful waiters/waitresses who will bring you drinks and clear your plates.  Once you've paid, you will be ushered to a table, asked for your drink order, and then are free to roam around the buffet.  The buffet itself has various stations that serve a range of cuisines (Asian, Indian, Italian, Latin, and Mediterranean) as well as various types of meat (fish, seafood, beef, ham, turkey), salad, and dessert.  Sorry vegans; there didn't appear to be any dessert that was free of animal products (or at the very least dairy-free)!  Part of the reason why I chose to dine at The Buffet at ARIA was because my friend had recommended their buffet as a decent, cheap-ish alternative to some of the fancier (read: more expensive) buffets like Bacchanal. In general, I found that assessment to be accurate, but your dining experience will probably be dictated by how much you eat / how terrible you feel after X number of servings.  Most of my pieces of prime rib were perfectly cooked (medium), but my last piece was tough, dry, and unappetizing (well).  Definitely specify what slice you want; otherwise, the carver will just give you something undesirable.  The ham was good, but not comparable to what you could get at Honeybaked Ham.  I would definitely not recommend eating any of the dim sum if you are at all accustomed to good Chinese food, as I found the charsiu bao and har gow both mushy and strange.  Some of the vegetable options in the Asian station were all right, but were drenched in sauce.  The seafood station had various types of crab legs, shrimp, oysters, smoked salmon, and the like.  Most of these items were tasty, though you could tell they had been previously frozen.  The salad station had ample fruit and vegetables that I would have happily eaten all day.  But, if you're a vegetarian, it's probably not worth coming to this buffet.    Although I generally enjoyed dining at this buffet, I probably should have stopped after my third plate of food, as my final serving made me hate myself and the food I had just eaten. Moral of the story: if you want to enjoy your dining experience, it might not be the best idea to try to get your money's worth.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Buffet area

wbwy7lzDbdnu2GJSRJpniQ.text: My boyfriend and I practically live in Vegas lol so this is our go to buffet every time. They have the most delicious selection of varieties of food. The seafood most importantly is always so fresh!!!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

7WUhnzOzwzWLNoCdlPQE0A.text: Worst. Buffet. Ever.  Do not go. Awful service, horrible choices. Who wants pad tai at 9am? The breakfast options were horrible, the pastries are gag-worthy, the meat was sketchy, the eggs were runny.  I wish I could get back the $62 I spent to sit and drink coffee and force feed myself one bowl of oatmeal.

JeRfrzZ3oZnoxvvLX3BKFA.text: Rum punch, mimosas, bloody Mary's. Unbelievable eggs Benedict. Crab legs. Oyster bar. Asian fare. An entire fish market and last but not least the bakery. It was so wonderful and everyone enjoyed to the last bite. 5 Star hotel. 5 Star buffet.

uDw5Cntvc4Q9fhcur21fjA.text: Crab legs, crab legs, crab legs.  Our family visited this buffet on Saturday Evening. Expected long line to be seated, there were few people out there and we were promptly seated.   Craving crab as i seated beside the buffet tables. And there were lot more asian fusion. Chinese wonton soup, Japanese sushi. Salad, cheese, salamis, and desserts.   The staffs were very friendly and the drinks were free. The end of the meal, we had coffee. It was gorgeous.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

h0HAYtW-73yzEOf23FdS4w.text: I think folks have been a little too harsh on this buffet. After reading all the reviews, I didn't feel like going, but we had a free pass, so what the heck! We did lunch on Monday, so $23.00 per person and almost no wait. It looks like they renovated, because the place looked fresh. I also liked that there were large windows there and a lot of sunlight coming in. Now, the view that opened was directly showing the pool area, and at certain places, those who dine could see those who soak in the jacuzzi pretty close! Not sure this is the best combination, but whatever.  Our server was on top of things. It looked like she had a lot to do, but we got all the drinks we wanted and she kept an eye on our table at all times. It might not seem like it, but these folks work hard, so we made sure to leave a good tip.   Now, to food. Some of the sections I didn't care for, but out of the eight different cuisines they offer I'm sure you will find something you like. My personal favorites were:  - the European section with the cold cut meats and breads - the seafood section (clam chowder was exceptional!) - the steaks and grilled meats were quite good - the Mediterranean section with pitas and salads - the desserts had a great selection, but you never have room for those, anyways.   I would probably not choose this buffet as a dinner option, but for lunch it was great!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The dessert plate
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The European deli plate
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The seafood plate

H54Tydfh0_c8Db_4GSPygA.text: Well it was a lot better than I thought. Ya know, buffets in general are just ok.  The place has a great feel, the Service was fantastic and the food was so good. Yes there were a couple things that were stale, but we came at the end of the lunch rush.  Overall a great place. Of course the BOGO helps off MyVegas.   Give them a try, I think you will like it.

3gzXrgIzLtvKgM3qbDKYIA.text: Just got back from Vegas and ate here twice, as it was convenient for us staying at the Aria. Not sure why so many people have given the buffet not great reviews. I will preface this by saying I am NOT a fan of buffets usually, but when in Rome...  This buffet has a very good selection of food. Everything from an Italian station, to Asian, to tandoori (with great freshly made naan), to a carving station and seafood. There's also soups, salad and Mexican. I think that's most of it? But probably more I'm blanking on right now. Clearly there's everything here depending on your mood. Everything I ate was solid. My favorites were the turkey breast at the carving station with cranberry sauce (went back for seconds and thirds lol) the mashed potatoes, veggie lasagna and shredded beef. Plus there's the dessert station with gelato and a nice selection of sweets :)  For being so busy everything was clean and organized. They were constantly replenishing food so I never saw them run out of an item. Service was good as well. Plates were cleared quickly and drinks were refilled without even asking. I plan of coming back here next time I'm in Vegas

mN191zPYLwylOQZXB3MYZQ.text: Service was crap beginning to end. Food selection was terrible. I cane for brunch and wanted breakfast. There were no eggs anywhere. The only way to get eggs was by waiting in line for an omelette. NEVER AGAIN!!!

nuu2VPw4KKRHPL72CxRjQg.text: Fair buffet. Good variety, descent food, descent price. Service was a little slow and it was not that busy. There is no shortage of buffets in vegas...not sure if I would do this one again.

eoRz2jcT5HguZF4mAXWyUg.text: I love the muesli!  Good sushi, roast station, and dessert bar, too.  They also have pretty good quality selection with this price.  I like their buffet much better than Bellagio's .  I thought Bellagio had more food to choose, but only a few stations are good, and it costs more.  If I'm going to a buffet, I'll pick the one at Aria.

jUfS07MMDiYa2JU0z7hhSA.text: this is a regular buffet for us we like the variety here and the food is good and fresh and that the bathrooms are in the restaurant is a plus and don't have to go looking for it.

J3JaHi9bLJ-S80uf9AezOg.text: All I can say is this place is overpriced for what you get. Yes, they have lots of selections but the food is not that good. Coffee horrible. My stay included two buffets. This place is not on my return list. $30 for lunch buffet.

0MTh-Sgh_gfglQO52L1gQw.text: If I hadn't had a free voucher for two to this buffet, I probably would have left feeling slightly unsatisfied.  It was good, but not amazing.  The crab legs were a nice touch, but not enough to make me want to go back.  Drinks were pretty expensive, and our waiter even said they're made really weak.

dkEFHaCMHOb6JvQRs5RhPg.text: I felt ripped off, even though we had a voucher for $33 off per person from our hotel. It just wasn't very appealing. We came for dinner, and the crab legs everyone talks about just weren't enough to overcome the profound sense of meh that I experienced surveying the other options. The sushi was meh, the pizza was meh, the Indian food was meh, the gnocchi was meh... I could go on. But I won't. Because this buffet isn't even worth the time for an extended review.

8fYLe1kSHf54Wd6Ao3gHeA.text: When first walking into the Buffet at Aria I was very pleased. The atmosphere is pleasant. The decor is not over the top. It is just a nice place to dine. I was surprised to find that on Friday to Sunday evenings your buffet also includes a whole Maine Lobster for two and all you can drink house wine.  When we first sat down it took over ten minutes before anyone came by to take our drink order. Our server seemed to not be in a good mood and we thought we might have problems, but that didn't seem to last very long and she provided very good service after our first encounter. For my wine selection I chose the Buffet's house red, which is a Merlot. I am sometimes hesitant about ordering house wines. They can tend to be watery, acidic, and have not much flavor. I was very pleased with the Buffet's house Merlot. It had a pleasant aroma, nice legs, and the flavor was acidic to the point of just giving it a little kick. The after taste was quite pleasing as well. The wine was a pleasant addition to my dining experience.  The floor of the Buffet is spread out with many live-action stations and a large selection to choose from. The selection includes what you might find in many buffets in Las Vegas, Sushi, Mexican, Italian, Prime Meats, Soups, and Deserts. But, all the selections have more of a gourmet feel to them. The salad bar is not very large, but it provides all you need to make a very nice salad. There is no iceberg lettuce to be found, only romaine and spring greens. There are many toppings for your salad as well as about a dozen dressings to choose from. They have a made to order pasta station with many pastas and toppings. The carving station has several meats including lamb, turkey and prime rib. I had a slice of the prime rib. I was surprised that I was given a thin English Cut and not a thicker slice, but the flavor was very good. Not as high quality as I would expect from a high end steak house, but the meat was tender and tasty.  One thing you don't find at all the buffets in Las Vegas is a deli station. This station has several meats, cheeses, breads, and condiments to make a quite tasty sandwich. Another item on the deli station I was pleased to find was an olive tray. There were several types of olives to delight in. Each having it's own unique flavor and texture. the Buffet at Aria is the only buffet in Las Vegas to showcase a Tandoor oven. Out of this oven comes kabobs, freshly baked naan, and one of my favorite items at the Buffet, a chicken & cheese quesadilla. Out of a Tandoor oven you may ask, yes, it was wonderful.  The last items for most people are the items in the dessert station. This station is not very large, but it does not need to be. There is a lot in this station including cookies, pastries, and freshly made ice cream. Many items are also prepared without sugar. This station is the work of World Pastry Champion Chef Jean-Philippe Maury. I had a chocolate chip cookie which was very rich. I could not finish it. I also had a scoop of their freshly made Butterfingers Ice Cream. It was very creamy and had a wonderful taste.  All-in-all this was a pleasant dining experience, but I would not put it at the top of the Buffets in Las Vegas, even though I did enjoy it.

DWTFq7pXM_ETLLehncAImw.text: The selection here is solid. Not too much variety compared to the other ones. However, this place has one thing that I love to eat..... King Crab legs. I swore that was all I ate here. The tri tip was pretty good as well. However, asides from those two selection, everything else is pretty mediocre. If you want King Crab legs come here, if not then I recommend somewhere else.

KbLoz0ApIqa2fLpvjs0rzA.text: I haven't tried enough buffets in Vegas to give this place 5 stars, but I suspect it might be worth it. We came here because it was a package deal with Zarkana tickets, but if you're looking for a buffet that's worth the price I feel like Aria's is good. My only real Vegas comparison is the buffet at the Wynn, which comes highly recommended by others, but I thought this one was much better.

F0U_dRMB_FxqfW6ye11Y9Q.text: I had both breakfast and dinner at this place. My only complaint really was the price, but you really get quality food in return. The lobster and wine dinner was awesome. I've never gotten hummus at a buffet before, but the garlic naan bread and hummus were excellent.  The breakfast was even better. They had bar none, the best breakfast biscuits I've ever tasted. Soft and flaky and tasty and just perfect. I don't know why restaurants always insist on cooking biscuits hard as rocks, its impossible to find good biscuits and gravy normally. They were heavenly at Aria's buffet.

pL9eDqbBoY_iNw949ZW37w.text: Really good - much better than the Monte Carlo!

iHYeSJyY4mytOSmtIPV-fA.text: This buffet should deserve more than 2 stars from my experience. First of all I had the brunch menu today which was 23.95. The service was great and our server was friendly. Presentation of the food was really good, the food quality did worth the price.  I do like the buffets at Wynn & Bellagio too, but comparing the price, I will definitely go back!

GwOt3zuRBmU98pH9U6xHIg.text: FIrst off, I would like to say, that this is my second time at the buffet at Aria.  I went to try it out a few days after the resort opened.  My initial experience would be rated a zero-star, but unfortunately Yelp won't let me be that unforgiving.  So, I would have rated it one star.  The food and service was as ugly as it gets.  Food tasted a day old.  The server couldn't do a simple task of refilling beverages.  Luckily, the manager was kind enough to refund my thirty-eight dollars.  I told myself that I would come back after a good amount of time, so they could take their one star ratings, and turn them into fives.  And now, I am back a year later.  The service is the same. Surprisingly, the food improved just enough to give them an extra star difference!  Come on, Aria.
