They're mussels pasta could've been really good, but was just WAY too salty i had to take a swig after each bite, i gave up after the 3rd.  Wasn't impressed with their sushi just cuz it looked like there was more rice ratio than anything.  And lastly their salads looked real appetizing but lacked good flavor on the 2 that i tried, the Caesar and Chinese Chicken salad.    The one thing i was very disappointed in was me and the hubby not receiving any complimentary champagne/wine/lobster as other reviewers were saying they received...  Maybe because we got there right before dinner time but still disappointing..  Lastly, their desserts.  Im not a dessert person but i tried some bread pudding and my eyes rolled back!  Had 2 plates of that.  Also had Tiramisu and their Snickers cake which was awesome!    See you soon Aria!

203FZsZYNUqVpg6UehgqFA.text: This was $23.99 without champagne for brunch and then $35.99 after 4 pm.  The selection for the prize was pretty much mediocre.  I have been to others where they have more selection and the prize was cheaper. I did enjoy the food tho.  And I will say I was very happy with the service.  Both people who served our table were very nice and patient with all our request.  One thing that was a little annoying was the vibrations we felt from people walking around.  I think the flooring were badly done cuz it felt like there were after shocks all the time.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

y_Bmqsc70FuVVZhwsbiG6Q.text: Everything was good, but nothing memorable.  May stop in again if it's convienient and the Bellagio buffet is closed.

zr-ugJE-KgvMz1xrTJrZRQ.text: Had breakfast here for $15.95 per person and convinced my wife that for the amount to eat at a cafe or coffee bar was going to be as expensive.  I really can't complain since they had an omelet bar, and the best hash browns ever.  We had refills on coffee and OJ and although there was no Salmon and only whitefish everything was aok.

vM5mciJlZ1rz-UJKDMdrXg.text: We stayed at Aria this past February.  During our stay we ate at The Buffet 2x.  Once for breakfast & once for lunch.  I must say for a buffet I was very impressed.  I loved the different foods and the service was excellent.  It doesn't get much better than this for a buffet.  I recommend eating here, especially if your staying at Aria.

CLFm_LOX_kBHmvrzRenFrQ.text: My boyfriend took me here because I absolutely love crab, and the only way you get to eat as much as I can is to go to a buffet. He chose the Aria. I was so excited to go, it was really beautiful and the lady who rung us out was the sweetest can't recall her name though... I get in food looks great although not as much seafood as I remembered... I make a plate my waiter was this warm hearted beautiful Ethiopian woman I can remember her name but she was very kind. In the middle of my dinner I end up getting a call its a family emergency I haven't even taken a bite yet. It's not cheap either... So me and my BF get up to leave I ask to speak to a manager they tell me he's on his way. I am greeted by such a warm face the manager Glenn I let him know my situation and he takes care of me without question with a personal note sign sealed delivered by himself for me to be able to come and enjoy the buffet another day. If I ever come to another buffet I will go to the aria the staff is unbelievably warm personable and kind,! Your dinner will be more than memorable,!

Lj_PiROga-aHG1PAHmjVrQ.text: We stayed at the Aria this past weekend. LOVED IT! The buffet was really good. Good quality and lots of choices. I didn't feel like crap all day long either. VERY GOOD. I recommend.

8dADrQ7E_emCAPS9L8Z4Dg.text: EEk! Methinks not is right! The food here was terrible. It's pretty bad when you walk into a buffet hungry and leave still feeling hungry.

LFwiaK7Ftt5h2ljdl0nqCA.text: We went to the Lunch Buffet on a Sunday. They have a fantastic selection of high quality and fresh items, including Alaskan King Crab Legs, Roast Turkey, Leg of Lamb, to name a few.The highlight would have to be the desserts which were equivalent to those you would find at any good fine dining establishment. Would have given them a higher rating if the admission was more reasonably priced.

SK5rgDRPGyI_iLB6AzcNFg.text: Eeeekkkk!!! Is not enough....Terrible, disgusting, and downright bad for your health. Why is there no "Zero Stars"? Took a chance on this buffet because it was the new thing on the strip and they had crab everyday. Walked around before buying the buffet, food looked good; well presented and fresh. Boy, were we wrong!!! The food was awful, insipid, and not fresh at all. Waitstaff was arguing about who had which table, no one took our drinks for over ten minutes, and when they did they forgot what we ordered. The pork loin at the carving station tasted like little smokies, the carne asada was dry and didn't have any seasoning, the sushi rolls were sticky and had some unidentifiable mushy fish product, the tortellini tasted like spagetti o's ,  the crab (how can anyone mess up crab!?!?)  was so soggy that when gently squeezed water poured onto the plate, and the shrimp cocktail was old and mushy. I tried to be nice, but finally gave up and asked for my money back. Apparently the manager was pretty used to this cuz he didn't look at all surprised.  Traumatized by our eating experience we went back to our hotel thinking our ordeal was behind us. How wrong we were... Next day husband wakes up feeling "off"... diarrhea, severe cramps, and to top off our experience a trip to the hospital. Thanks Aria, your disgusting eating experience is something that we will get to experience for days with a course of antibiotics for the bacterial infection that you shared with us...

mOB7afZXvXE65soUjwYbGA.text: I just went to the dinner buffet last week and that's the first time we tried Aria buffet. The prime rib and salmon weren't so good. And actually the one who served the prime rib was not courteous and I ended up complaining to the manager for that. I saw the chef cooking up a piece of prime rib for another customer but was reluctant to do so for me and my husband. I felt that his service wasn't consistent and impolite to us (while we were requesting nicely) so I had to complain to the manager. I understand it's a buffet, not a steak house, but service is still a matter regardless what kind of cuisine a restaurant is serving. So that's a big minus for us. The manager was very nice to help us out to get our prime rib grilled. We had to have the prime rib grilled because we don't eat rare or medium rare meat, and the prime rib was at most medium rare at the time we were eating there. And I think we got compensated by being charged for 1 person instead of 2 due to the unpleasant experience. So it's well resolved that way.  The desserts are great though regardless the unpleasant experience with the prime rib chef. The desserts are great and I had a lot of them. The buffet description said they have the desserts from Jean Philippe Patisserie. So I ate alot of the desserts that seemed to be from Jean Philippe Patisserie (but I really couldn't tell which one was and which one wasn't).  Anyway, it's good to at least try it once and see if we wanna go again. And we probably might not go there again for full price. I do like the dessert but I think I would rather just get them from Jean Philippe Patisserie downstairs, probably cost less that way and still satisfy my craving for Jean Philippe Patisserie desserts.

PnQOx0JPUAAdrvkqz0KSSA.text: I am not a seasoned Vegas veteran (in contrast to poster below), so perhaps my expectations are too high.   I went on Sunday, so was either lunch or brunch.  30 minute wait to get in at 11:30AM..  I did not like this at all, but wanted to see the buffet..  taken to table and ambience is basically a big cafeteria. Food is not presented well, served from "windows" cut out of a wall.. very cafeteria like.  Many tables are empty.. which I take means Aria staff pace the line vs. over-stuffing the buffet line.  Biggest line was for the crab legs.  I am not a crab connosseir but I enjoyed them.  They are served cold/ice with lime/lemons vs. hot/steamed.  Breakfast burrito, believe it or not, was very good.  So was the thick sliced bacon (a very nice touch).  Hash browns were bland, dry, bricks.  Omelette station was there.  Eggs benedict too too buttery, but otherwise nicely done.  Desserts were very good.  I wish i tried to eat more in retrospect.   I was offput by the presentation I guess.. I assumed the chinese food was not going to be good until I read these reviews...   Server bought OJ and bloody mary's often and cleared plates quickly and really did try hard.  I am glad I tipped the full 20% before being seated.. I would have not liked tipping 20% and then being left thirsty etc. or with dirty plates laying around.

E9rQhBJRCsDxsWPMNoloAQ.text: At $15.95 per head for breakfast, this is a very good value with so many options available. Choices are staggering, quality is very high. I haven't tried it for the other meals but I suspect I wouldn't have been disappointed. However wine list is minimal so if this is important for you and you're willing to pay a premium over the $40 price for dinner, pick another Aria restaurants. My rating is only for breakfast.

871ro6r3MUwyKyu2mGNEXQ.text: 1st buffet in Vegas and was very shocked...wide selection of food and drinks for a reasonable price.  Make sure you go hungry, their are endless possibilities.

wyax5r8TvnawWhDcM_QTfw.text: Great buffet for all the newbies if you think the Crab  is too cold you can ask to steam it at the same place a lots of people don't know about that so I thought it help ,the desserts are the best In Vegas !!!

SKbBWA6KnBwhiI3yt4_w2w.text: This buffet was great. It had everything. Many differnt types of sausage, waffles, Korean food, Indian food, Crab Legs etc. It didn't have everything under the sun, but everything was very light and healthy and not greasy or stale. Very good taste. And we stayed for hours and they didn't care. We lounged for 4 hours and ate multiple times. The bottomless mimosas are the bomb! Do a body good and eat here.

Si1bEGX1H4EPeCJ19YUL3g.text: I think this is the best buffet in all of Vegas, at least at any of the hotels. We stayed at the Aria, so going to their buffet was as easy as walking. Huh. Now I have seen 2 and 3 stars here for this place. If you can't spend $27 on dinner or don't like upscale food, its not the place for you.  I can only say that the food taste like a gourmet restaurant, rather then your run of the mill buffets, don't get me wrong, I love Spice Market Buffet and the likes, but the Aria is a step above. They may not have as many dishes as the other, but what they lack in quantity they make up for in quality! Did I say that out loud? I never, I say never go for quality over quantity, but the Aria is worth it. We don't like fru fru foo foo restaurants, and this is not. Even my wife likes it. For that to come our of her mouth (the words,  not the food) is saying something. OH, BTW, the pictures of the crab legs are making me hungry right now. I never order crab legs at a restaurant, but when I'm in Vegas, I get my fill of shell fish for the entire year. They are the largest I have seen at a buffet. But be warned, they may charge more on the weekends, as some do, as they have lobster on those nights.

s8eKh808BvR_wNLeK69XTA.text: The hubby & I stayed @ Aria in late September.  We hit up the buffet for breakfast, price wasn't too bad (you're in Vegas, everything is pricey anyway).  I don't know what they put in their French Toast but we were hooked after one bite, it was THAT good.  They had a great selection of food but all I remember was the french toast. Customer service was prompt and friendly.

Y40nGe0u24-Md5l2EcxhBw.text: Now then, the last place I thought you'd ever see me (well after Las Vegas itself) is an all you can eat buffet. Ironic as it may sound we actually went there because the portions everywhere else were so un-appetisingly enormous (well except Picasso, bellagio - see sep review) that we just had to go somewhere where we could put a nice normal portion on our plates and eat it, rather than a plate of food that would feed a family of five for a week. We were not holding out much hope. I have to say we were very pleasantly surprised! The value for money was exceptional (around 12-15) for a really decent standard of food and well cooked to boot.  The selection on offer ranged from sushi to roasts, to french and Indian, all pretty authentically cooked (a bit of a revelation for vegas!). We were having a day off the booze so cannot comment on the wine - but the wine inclusive deal was very reasonable. The surroundings were pleasant, the selection of food utterly enourmous and there were not too many people. Probably the most decent meal we ate in Vegas, all in all. It must be very heavily subsidised by the casino - it is a fairly new, modern 5 star, so I think they need to get people in the casino. Yes, I'd recommend this plce ( I can't believe I'm recommending an all you can eat buffet, but there you go, you have to hand it to them!).

tmSdAyGreuzKGq2bQpHsVA.text: The food was very disappointed..$39.99 for buffet, you would of thought the food would be great.  I was extremely disappointed with the food...very thing seems to be all dried up and over cook.

LyZ1xRIujvBo7bxQPlNMGw.text: Honestly, the only good about the buffet was the complimentary lobster and the all you can drink wine. I thought the food was below average for the price. I wont be going back!

Vi-yrxfz6k1xRrWdIOiUuw.text: Had dinner buffet at Aria which is a gourmet buffet and includes unlimited wine. It also includes half a Maine Lobster per person for $38.95 each. So at those rates I expected a lot and I'm sorry to say I was highly disappointed. The server we had was not the best. The lobster was small and over cooked. It was so soft I could crack the shell with my bare hands. The highlight of my buffet experience at Aria were the cuts of meats. The skirt steak, prime rib, and brisket were delicious, very tender. The pork & beef ribs were dry.  Sushi selection was basic and the other selections were simple. They have a special oven that cooks Indian Naan bread which was very good and the tandoori chicken was very moist. I've been to many Las Vegas buffets n Aria does not make my top 5 list. For them to call it a gourmet dinner is misleading. The presentation wasn't even gourmet. So if you're in Vegas and willing to spend $40.00 for a dinner buffet, try The Wicked Spoon at The Cosmopolitan which is a walk across the bridge.  That's more gourmet, just no lobster.

If3SFpJFruwHgCImJYReiw.text: You know the buffet drill: bring your least tightest fitting pants and shirts preferably sweats and a plain white t-shirt or colored t-shirt since you're probably going to fall victim to a rogue spicy tuna roll or a bombardment of butter from you copious amounts of crab legs.  The first roadblock to someone attending a Vegas buffet is cost. The Aria Buffet is reasonably priced at $32 for a non-alcoholic buffet and $36 for a bottomless champagne or bloody mary attachment. Um, if you're wincing at the $4 dollar difference, than you're probably not a drinker or have been hit hard by the gambling bug and do not want to open your wallet further than it already has been.  The 2nd part of a buffet equation is the quality and amount of choices given to a diner. Now, it is most certainly a form of gluttony and excess (what Vegas does in abundance...). The Buffet at The Aria gives you plenty of choices from bahn mi and soba noodles to the quintessential crab legs. There is a glorious carving station that offers mahi mahi, prime rib, ham, and turkey. You can also brunch it up with a French toast and pancake section. You want warm fruit nestled in sauce for your pancakes or French toast? No problem! Scrambled eggs w/o gluten more your thing, well, they have that as well!  The standout of this trip to the buffet, though, is the bottomless champagne. My friends and I made sure we were always with flutes of mimosas. The waitress was ever-so-generous and she was as attentive w/o being overtly pressuring. She kept the birthday weekend going and she deserved every bit of the generous tip we left her.  After nom nom noming our way through copious amounts of food items, we settled and conquered the dessert section. This place is immaculate! From cherry cheesecake to a bounty of cookies, this dessert section is one of the brighter sides of the buffet.  From attentive service to reasonably priced Vegas buffet, the Aria houses a great option for those staying and for those looking for an alternative to the long lines @ Wicket Spoon or Bacchanal. I recommend it for all those looking for a buffet to conclude or begin one's Vegas trip.

DvtWaS-I7qcgF9rJ7kZl0A.text: Avoid this over priced subpar restaurant. I drink wine out of a box and thought the wine options were bitter and just gross.

2pCJLVhJtreEMCwHNaV04g.text: Overpriced dinner. $45!!!  Nothing special. Not a good and rich selection. I would say mediocre. Food tastes ok for a buffet. Aria is an upscale place. I would not recommend eat at the buffets at all if you respect yourself. Better buy a nice dinner at the good restaurant you will enjoy it much more and for less.

1UeTlUZ2UTmjbnCADrjhDQ.text: Tried many buffets in Vegas .Aria is the best thus far.Big variety and great taste .Brunch is the best.

9zHNNVWRFLSaOM538p3a9w.text: The buffet at Aria is wonderful!! The crab legs were fresh and hot and kept coming!  Wide variety of choices and the desserts were great!  Gelato is delicious. The only downside is the price $42 per person on Saturday night. But well worth it - I will definitely be back!

6_GDHF_t65JgMCcfSx4xvg.text: Stayed at the Aria 1/3-1/5/13. We ate 3 meals there breakfast, lunch, dinner. We encountered hardly any wait when we went on all 3 occasions but obviously this is going to vary greatly depending on day of week etc. The food seemed to be up to par with the competitions. Everything was well laid out and tastefully displayed. The food stations were kept clean and restocked. On all 3 visits our wait staff kept our table clear and drinks filled. The dining areas were kept very clean and clear. The Aria's Buffet is exactly what I expect from a Upper end Vegas Buffet. Nothing outrageous but nothing nasty. The ayce King Crab & Prime Rib were as good as any. For me it was the perfect place to catch a simple meal without leaving the resort.

NetgmRJyTW4TAk9L5g3nTw.text: oh em gee... terrible food and terrible setting.  I HATE buffets, but went here because a dear friend of mine talked about it for two days and insisted on going. I am glad that I went because it reconfirmed why I hate buffets.   There was a HUGE selection, but a huge selection of crap. You had your usual prime rib, seafood, mexican food, sushi, asian fusion etc.- all lacking in quality. I don't remember specific details, because there was so much food, but what I do remember is that they used snow crab legs- - lame!! I am not asking for stone crab, but at least Alaskan king or something more meaty. Way better options in Vegas... tsk tsk

5_Why4NMKck0TnVHPZXbeg.text: Since this is new to me, I decide to try it for dinner.  I got here around 6 PM on Saturday night and there was a short line.  The price is similar to some others at $40 per person.  The dining area is huge but the food stations are not as big as I expected for a buffet place.  The Food - there are some hits and misses here.    Hit - Prime Rib, King Crab legs, salmon shooter, manhattan soup, and civeche.  Miss- the whole Asian station.  I pretty much tried everything and not like a single one.  So, I have tried various buffets and this rank right above MGM.  By far, Bellagio is the best for me follows by Wynn.

B7BTz4s_t64q0StQgXUzwA.text: This buffet went for $29.95 and is in a ultra modern setting in the new Aria hotel.  As you might imagine a Las Vegas buffet - it's massive, but comfortable, and with a huge and diverse menu.  I found the crab legs to be blandish and overrated, but enjoyed a bunch of fresh peeled shrimp, and chicken curry with basmati rice, among other selections  The prime rib was notably good, but the Korean short ribs were not.  Also notable were the excellent flan for dessert, as well as gelati.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Desert counter, not shown - delicious flan and gelati
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Our first plate anyway
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crab legs

9boEW-OGhqhSfrHHqltWlA.text: Went for lunch and had naan, masala, crab legs, crab claws, banana foster dessert, thai iced tea. The price was reasonable for lunch for the quality of food. The attendants were attentive and friendly.

xD-DKWht3aYN-ZF4YDJX5Q.text: All the buffets are going downhill in Vegas.  The quality of the food is just not like the way they used to be.  For $40 in Vegas for dinner, it's ok.  But I would rather have a pizza at the food court instead.  Lately I notice only the pizzas taste good at all these buffets but for $40 they should have more than just good pizza.  Everything else tasted mediocre at best.  I do need to mention our server was top Vegas style service.  I gotta give him a five star and a big tip.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Great service here.  He checks up every so often to make sure you got enough to drink.
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Usually only the pizza is good at buffet so I&#39;m going to start with pizza and prime rib

YFnlIg9FMalGv2rvxnyp1Q.text: Went there on a  Monday morning. The hostess (name tag said Betty ) first paid no attention to us first. After I waved to her, she told us to wait in line to pay first without realized that my wife was standing behind me hold the receipts. She gave no greeting, smile or eye contact to us. When I told her we paid and I stayed in the skysuite with a Noir card, she rolled her eyes and waved to us to another hostess to sit us. This is not a cheap buffet. It is in a 5 diamonds resort. Unacceptable service. Positive side is overall food is good.

kNneShcPaZaLrOUuG6E60g.text: It could be better - It could be worse.  I went to see  the newly renovated buffet at the Aria last week. They did a good job with the remodel. The place is more friendly but also more upscale. The food is easier to access.  The menu is not dramatically different from before but there are some new additions. It appeared to me that they were doing their best to copy the buffet at the Cosmopolitan Hotel.   There was a nice wide selection. The problem? 50% of the things I selected were either downright cold or lukewarm - maybe tepid. The other 50% ranged from warm to almost hot.  It appears it's not possible (at least at the Aria) to serve hot food on a buffet.   The prices are in line with other upscale buffets in the area. The food while cold, did have very nice flavors. The chef knows what he/she is doing. There were some very nuanced dishes - very sophisticated for a buffet.   I will give it another try but if they can't sort out the cold food problem by the next time I visit, my wallet and I will be moving on to one of the other 100 buffets in Vegas.

CYkMiqc_36F6usg-dJ8CcA.text: Really dont know why this place only have 3 stars.. i hate comparing but seriously if i will, this place will still be one of the best.. specially the crab legs.. and the price is reasonable.. so guys what are waiting for? Go go go..

8kKQiatEY5TElClPGkUPoA.text: I would have thought that this buffet would get a higher rating. I really liked this place, so much that I have eaten here a few times and all those times, never disappoint.  I just wish they would have bigger crab legs, i know that their crab legs are split for easier consumption but damn, their is barely any meat on them.

xWd8oqnblkLpKymEtf-Fwg.text: Terrible. I went with 5 others, and we didn't find a single item that we liked!!! We are not picky people at all, the food was all cold, and the just tasted terrible. We paid over $50 a person, and I honestly wish we would have just went to a burger joint, we would have spent less and actually enjoyed out meal. Not happy at all.

dY0KaUVNofzPG2DC1E5b1w.text: If you want mediocre this is the buffet for you. We would not eat here again, the prime buffet (and were not big on buffets) would be Cesar Palace - this is the gold standard buffets for us at the time of writing this review.   Aria had a nice atmosphere - good music, bright lights, a few choices, decent wait staff, but the food leaves much to be desired. A few options I tried were: prime rib, chicken, crab legs, fish and chips, caprese salad and many others. On the desert side I tried the butter scotch mini dessert, ice cream, pane cotta and few others. Maybe it was bad (in my opinion) because we ate late 9:30ish but even there the dinning room was packed and the food was mediocre at best. I ordered regular tea and my Wife had the rasberry tea which she said was good.  One interesting thing was the alcohol special advertised - $12.99 for endless selection of wine, beer etc not a bad deal in vegas.   We will not be back.

ss22CUu51CcocFEEeITv9A.text: I've been in line for an hour and a half waiting to be seated at the buffet. There are approximately 20 open tables that have been "closed" for the evening, despite the buffet line going around the corner. This food better be damn good.

IizzEeB_--_FqPW-iwYLUg.text: Huge selection to choose from. Different flavors and toppings were offered and servers were extremely helpful and attentive.

6UASG-1RTuYgDNcATUxE0Q.text: Really? All you can eat King Crab Legs (cold or steamed) AND Prime Rib for like $40???? They lost money on me that's for sure! If they want to collect some cash to offset what I ate, they'd better see the Blackjack dealers downstairs!   ;)  Everything on this buffet is great. Yes, the King Crab Legs are a little smaller than a "seafood restaurant" may serve, so you just go back for 2nds, 3rds, 4ths, 5ths, etc. The desserts are clearly gourmet and house made.   We did my sister's wedding rehearsal dinner here for a group of 70 and I cannot tell you how amazing the staff was. The pricing was excellent, they included a whole lobster for each guest and they were organized and prepared.  I've been back 2 times since that rehearsal and this is totally on my Vegas "must do" list every time.

VbGUwg9-4Kkpu0Be1FrfYw.text: I've been here a couple of times now (more than a dozen) LOCALS READ!!!!   If you live in Las Vegas (have a Nevada ID) you just hit the jackpot. Buffet is half off for you and up to 3 guest Monday - Thursday. Sometimes even on the weekend if it isn't a holiday weekend.   $60 buffet drops down to $30 ayeeeee why not! If I'm rating the food I'll give it 4 stars (this buffet is like a mini bacchanal at Caesars palace)   Here are some of my top dishes  -Hot crap legs  -They have a poke bar (omg!!!!) -Pasta Station  -Shrimp (jumbo size) -Oysters  -Salmon  -Sushi (could be better) -Cool drinks like Thai tea, horchata & watermelon. -Chinese area is yummy!  -Ribs  -Salad bar  -Taco bar -Desert, Desert and yeah did i say desert.   The reason why I'm also giving them 5 star is because the staff is friendly and the services is great!   ***TIP*** -Kids 12 and under are FREE!!!! (Up to 2 kids) -Pearl member (like me) wait in a shorter line.

dQU1knyD1oSTc3gfx-mOlA.text: The one thing about Vegas buffets on the strip is that not all buffets match the hotel.  What I mean is that certain nice hotels will have decent (maybe even mediocre) and some mediocre hotels will have amazing buffets.  With that said, I hate giving Aria buffet such a low review but I think the one thing that is missing at this spot is what most other buffets already offer at the same price offer.  The food across most buffets are very similar, so at times you're making a call on how things taste and how they're prepared.    Most of the things that we ate at this buffet were "okay".  I hate saying that b/c maybe the particular day I went things were off.  I get it.  But to have every dish and every station be mediocre is not a coincidence.  I thought the days of subpar buffets like the one that used to exist in the Monte Carlo were gone.    My buddy paid for the meal entirely and I felt bad b/c the food just wasn't good.  The moment we walked in it wasnt even at 15% capacity on a weekend.  Is that normal?  I think some major changes need to happen here before I ever return.  Bacchanal still takes the cake as far I'm concerned.

fUJUUF2GQOzXLv6qwOBSAw.text: I think a "good buffet" in Vegas is one that has a lot of cuisines, is always replenished, and keeps you wanting more.   Aria won. The Mexican station was better than Mission joints: Salty Pozole and fatty delicious Chile Verde. Warm tortillas. Yellow rice. Mmm! The Asian half of the buffet was hugely varied - Korean broth, Chinese stir-fry, Thai noodles. Yes!   Pizza, pasta, creative mini-servings of classics like Shrimp n Grits and paella, massive carving station.   With a bit more attention to service, this would've been heaven (or 5 stars). It just took a bit too long fir drinks, plate-clearing, and the check.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pozole!!!!!

86PKVP-uHoKnO8RNXVIVwQ.text: Dined at The Buffet for the first time.  Enjoyed the crab legs, served warm and not overcooked like a lot of other buffets.  Was pleased with their seafood offerings, especially the poke.  Bone marrow. Enough said.  Their carving station was superb.  Try their pork belly and here's a tip - Add some to your ramen to make the broth more flavorful.  Our server was attentive and friendly.  Enjoyed their selection of desserts and gelato.  Unlimited thai iced tea!  Nice.  Cons - waited in line for over 30 mins and the restaurant wasn't even full.  Wish the quality of their Asian section was better...fried rice, sweet and sour pork?  Price point is a tad too high.  Was expecting a little more variety, but still giving 4 stars since I enjoyed my meal overall.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

UsBXW2TAvWkNcMhPk3ALEw.text: This is one of my choices buffets in Vegas. Inside Aria hotel at City Center. The location is also nice. It is far away from the casino, so you don't have the noise and smoke from the casino.  I am here many times and the waitresses is always very attentive and stay on top of everything. My drinks was always filled up and my table was always clean! Good jobs!  The foods is little about the average Vegas buffets. Good salad bar, good dessert. Seafood is okay. The BBQ section has more selections then most of the buffets. But the Chinese sections is not as good as the rest. In particular the Dim Sum, it is awful! So you can skips the Dim Sum! Lol!  I like The Buffet at ARIA dinning area and the clean and nice table setup. I can be very comfortable to enjoys my foods and drinks! I wish they have better Chinese foods!

Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

wJ3L2b5sr-lT9DgwAzjCfw.text: Pretty decent as far as Vegas Buffets go. I'd been here once last year and noticed a few new things which I loved. They have a build your own poke bowl station and a ramen station. They have your usual buffet foods like the carving station, dessert bar etc. Some of my favorites include the seafood pallea, panacotta, beet and goat cheese salad, dumplings, soups and a handful of other things. Nicely priced especially if going for lunch.

Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

OTIj006kVjeUMbtQZzjLVw.text: My mom raved about this place so we decided to come with the whole family. We arrived on a Saturday around 7 pm, there was absolutely no wait for us & the price was pretty fair considering we paid over $75 a person the day before at the Caesar's Palace buffet. When we walked in we were seated and drinks were served. The service here compared to other buffets aren't as great, but it didn't bother me much.  I went straight for the meat section & got a serving of lamb chops. One of my favorite items of the night, I came back for seconds. The next stop was the crab legs. There was quite a wait and the selection is not nearly as big as the one in Ceasar's palace buffet, but it was good enough for me to get a full plate. Another interesting section they had was the poki bowl section, you could make your own poki bowl, but when I arrived to this station the lady just looked at me expecting me to know what to do. I just pointed at the things that looked good, but she didn't tell me they had rice or sauce. So this was pretty much a fail for me.   Some down falls here were the soup selections, the pho broth was surprisingly spicy in a weird way. The ramen broth was just okay, it didn't taste like ramen. The sushi section is very limited & not even worth trying. There's an Asian section, but its basically fried or steamed gyozas. Nothing special about that.   Overall the price is good & there is no wait, so I would come back. Dessert selection is pretty big so that's good too.

ejOgUump48NDFgN-ehbQiA.text: The service was great. Waitress was attentive and constantly cleaning our table. The food was amazing. I didn't have one thing I didn't like. I really appreciated the options they had even though some of the space was under construction.  I would highly recommend the brunch service here

j_mPe_jjjbcwNjjpuj2ilw.text: I stayed at the Aria while I was in Vegas and we decided to eat at the buffet one evening and I'll admit that I was disappointed. This is not the worst buffet in Vegas, but I have definitely eaten at better places. Everything just tasted mediocre and I did not care for the crab that they had. That being said, the staff was amazing and we received really prompt and quality service. I don't know if I would go here again, especially because the price is just as expensive as other, better buffets, but you may want to give it a shot.

cZmWjCPZsJlv2wTyHsJLIg.text: Went here for the first time for breakfast and I really had no expectations for the place, and I'm glad I didn't. This was hands down one of the worse buffets I've had in my life. Went here hungry as hell with 6 of my friends expecting a decent breakfast. Everything I ate here was mediocre at best, really the only experience in Vegas that I actually want to forget. I've had better $15 buffets, their meat was way too fat, other foods lacked flavor or just felt wrong texture wise. However the desserts looked amazing... which made it all the more disappointing. Honestly wanted to try everything just to see and we were actually having fun laughing at how they could mess up desserts this badly. I mean even the ice cream was bad, I'm actually surprised, so I guess in that way this was a memorable experience.

oO13RXS9TwuekkNMixoOLw.text: Came in friday for dinner buffet. I'm a seafood lover so I concentrated at all the crab legs and shrimp. So the snow crab legs are served hot, its okay they put a slice on the legs to make breaking easy. The shrimp are big. The cold section also has king crab legs. Forgot to ask if they can heat it up. But still enjoy eating those. The desserts are okay. I only ate the seafood so dont know about the other food. Coming back again? Hmmm maybe. There is no line for the king crab so its easier to get. For the snow crab theres a line at first but after like 30 mins there no more line. On the receipt it says you should only stay 2 hours at most, but I stayed like almost 3 hours.

LCFb29D-_JlWNpbR3_t_bQ.text: The update here is for the experience for Nov. 19th dinner. The wait was long and expected. After 70 minutes later, we got in but I would say the buffet was understaffed.  Here's why:  The hot crab legs was frozen.  Now, the first batch we had was hot and delicious and the second batch we went back came out frozen. I think they were just in a rush.   They were out of plates and utensils (spoons). Every fork we got was bent.  The were also out of bowls. I wanted some Chinese soup and used the Pho soup bowls only to have a Chinese lady tell me they were for the Pho which they were out of beef.   The $19.99 unlimited drinks included flat beer. Not so good.  The gelato bar were out of half of the flavors. No really.  We had to reuse some of our plates since we weren't sure if we had enough to go back with.  I do have to say the grilled meat and vegetables were above delicious. Prime rib and Asparagus were like the best I've had in a while.  Also love that dinner for kids are free with a paying adult.

gCXEKm3DUwiT5v39eAflWQ.text: My post is a bit late, but I'm going back to Vegas and trying to search for places to eat. We used to love the place, but after our last visit (May 2019)I won't go back there again. We we were there they closed down Asian section and didn't bother to tell us. They were no sign outside the restaurant. They literally have 20% less of food selection while charging the same amount. When asked servers staff what is going on "don't know" was the theme answer. My mom asked for a bowl of white rice and they told her that they didn't have any. I mentioned this to the the restaurant supervisor and to say that she didn't care would be an understatements. We typically stayed at Aria and think we may need to rethink that now. Basically if they would just communicate with customers and should consider lower the price during renovations, I would be less bitter.

Kvr8gVhRvmKy8tE2F3O_vg.text: Ooookaaay... I spent a ton of money here to feed 4 people and though the food was good, I really don't think it was worth 200 dollars. I realize you pay for location and experience but as a local it's still just a buffet to me. With all that being said, the food really was very good. Thing is you can feed the same 4 people at out of this world local establishments twice for what you pay once here, and have equally as good a food. I'm a local, born and raised, and I went here purely for experience and to see what all the hub bub was about. I mean there's one guy on YouTube that practically lives in this buffet lol. The experience was fun, we had a blast but I'd never pay that much for a buffet on just a night out. It was a treat for the kids backed by a bonus from work. It's actually the only way I'd ever be able to afford to feed a family of 4 here and that says a lot, especially in this day and age. I really can't say the food or experience is worth the price but keep in mind this is only MY opinion and even if they dropped the price 20 dollars, I'd still think it's too much. If you have the dough and just want the experience than I suggest you go for it because it is a lot of fun. If not, venture out to other establishments around the valley and eat just as good for 1/2 the cost. Check out the video! youtu.be/0ZRCp7IBkKU

rfDhP26BXUisUmHG4_vEaw.text: One of the better buffets on the Strip. There's several highlights (meat, tandoori, latin specialties, desserts), but much of the rest is pretty hum drum, and the East / SE Asian selections are downright bad.  I went for the "brunch" offering (cheaper than dinner), which runs from 9am-3pm. My thoughts:  * Indian / Tandoor specialities: Very solid. Good naan, lamb curry, rice, chicken. Probably the best thing here. * Latin: Some reasonable takes on LatAm dishes. * Carving Station: Good, but non-high-end meats. Sausage better than expected. * Mini-desserts: Better than expected. I liked their panna cotta. * Omelette and Waffle stations: Probably a waste of appetite at this price point. * Pho bar: Nice idea, will try next time. * Dumplings and fried rice: Seriously inferior to Trader Joe's. Don't bother.  * Thai beef: Was terrible. Poorly seasoned, some odd non-traditional vegetables, and none of the potent flavors that Thai cooking normally has.  Buffets have a tough balancing act-- food that keeps, that can be made in bulk, that people will want to eat, while keeping the price attractive. People tend to eat at buffets because they of how fast and casual it can be, how it's relatively cheap, the variety, and providing options for all the picky eaters in the group.  Aria does a fine job of balancing these things. Like all buffets, it's not the best versions of the dishes being served, but for the price and the convenience, it's solid. I liked Wynn's buffet better, but it's substantially more expensive.

jNgyaAwljZWJDyVh_IxT4A.text: Writing an update - we've been back 3 times since my initial review, always for dinner.    My opinion remains the same, for Vegas buffets, and I've been to ALOT of them, this ranks very high IMO for quality.  The price reflects that ($39), its about as expensive as they get.  And I really appreciate that MLife Pearl gets to use the 'special line', it made me feel.....special! :)  Asian dishes, the best i've seen for a buffet.  Real ingredients, real recipes.  Yummy soup.  Pho station (or was it Udon?) i forget :)  The snow crab, dang good, and theyre pretty good at keeping it filled as this is the star of the show here.  Grateful they dont saw these in half (which ruins it) like other buffets do.  While you're at this station, look on the other side, there is a 'hidden' gem, Oysters Rockefeller cooked to order (or they might have some made for you).  Steamed clams/mussels, and rock crab claws (you might want to 'try' 1 or 2 before you take a pile of these, they are called rock crab for a reason!)  So enter my only gripe: crustacean seafood is messy, working with your hands, for a $40 buffet, you should be able to ask for (or have them given to you by your server) Moist Towelettes!!  We shouldnt have to run to the restroom just to wash hands.   The Prime Rib was reliably fantastic.  Medium rare and tender.  Salad bar - check, good, lots of decisions to make.    Our servers each time have been delightful, and thorough.  I always leave a nice tip based on the total value of the meal (i.e., if you're comped, you still should leave a tip based on comped value).  And, still a big fan of the dessert array, I thought it was one of the best I've seen at a Vegas buffet,  EVERYTHING i tried was delicious.  Burnt cream, cheese cake, black forest cake, a scrumptious white choc chip cookie, etc.  The clientele here, generally well dressed - so I wouldnt show up in gym shorts/t-shirts.  For a buffet, I think they've executed it pretty well, far better than most, so by comparison to other buffets it gets 4 stars.

7pLb8nRAtgmoS3ha06lFUA.text: Unfortunately, we didn't try the food here because the wait was so long around 8 pm. Just a suggestion to hotel guests, estimate 1-1:30 to be seated. Aria management please put a wait time sign so we don't waste our time waiting!

VwWauBH44I2avPrDfF1JFQ.text: This is so sad, a beautiful hotel with the nastiest buffet in Las Vegas! I hate I paid $40 a person for food that is like Hometown Buffet or Piccadilly's (for those in the south). The staff is doing a halfway job on food prep & service. Although I'm adding a star for the floor staff (wait staff & bus service), they are hardworking and pretty friendly. I plan on making a complaint to the manager.   I guess their thought is; if you pass up all their quality restaurants to eat in a buffet, your standard for food must be low. This is ridiculous! I wish I had taken a Lyft to one of the buffet suggestions I found on YouTube. We were here for 5 days & everyday we had good meals; on our last day we missed big time.   Don't eat at this buffet! They have watery grits & oatmeal; undercooked bacon; cold sausage; what tastes like day old chicken fried steak. The seafood was good & I figure our money went there even though it wasn't as good as the seafood dinner we had earlier this week.

-tyUtRfqGteiBG9EaTEKHw.text: Came in Saturday night for holiday pricing and the price really wasn't worth it. I stayed at Aria so the buffet was conveniently close to the elevators (Level 2 in Promenade). I remembered dining at this buffet when it first opened and I was so happy back then because the food was great. Now...it seems different sadly.    Waited about half an hour at 5:10pm. There were plenty of tables available, so I think they controlled the amount of people entering so that there would be a steady flow of customers leaving the place.   Anyhow, the only good food they had was the seafood section and grilled vegetables.   The halibut was fresh and oyster wasn't bad at all (no strong fishy smell).   Grilled vegetables was absolutely phenomenal. Well seasoned and I was such a huge fan of the asparagus that I always came back for more. They did serve a burnt tomato....honestly please just throw that away. No customer should be served burnt food.   Soups in Asian section was incredibly lacking. Flavors were off.   Crab legs were also great and fresh, but too salty for my taste.   It has only been a few days since I've dined there. I already forgot some of the food that I ignored either because it didn't look appetizing or I can't remember the dishes I tried since the taste was just average. Well, sadly that's why my experience was "A-OK", a 3-star experience. I'm not sure if I will return when there are other buffets on the strip that also have good reviews like Bacchanal or Wicked Spoon, but I hope they improve and go back to the wonderful buffet that it was many years ago.

OJQsq2xUhZaVDSkbhJ34aA.text: Came back to the Aria Buffet while staying at Vdara. It was a week day about 3pm and there was not that many customers around (less than half of the tables were seated) and yet it took 20 minutes to get seated!  Selection of food is broad, from Asian, salads, Carving station (my favorite) to seafood and desserts! While food is good, it is not anything special to Vegas, and more of an average offering!  I was excited to see Spanish Paella but was full of shell bits making it non eatable!   Dessert station was good and Ice Cream offering was particularly good!!!  In summary-pretty average buffet!!!

TtrZKJhxBqZXsSBD3DkR_w.text: Since Rio closed its seafood buffet a couple years ago, this has been my go-to buffet for seafood. Unfortunately I think it's slipped a bit and Bacchanal at Cesar's Palace is  better.

lHTf1KKbdoGnj5OGDDUbrg.text: First off, I want to say the wait is LOOOONG. I'm talking 1hr 40 mins on a Monday. When we (2 adults and 1 kid) finally got a table, we were delighted to find that the food selection was pretty damn AMAZING! Sure, there are the normal buffet staples (crab, prime rib,etc), but I also saw a pho/udon station, a burrito station and so much more. There were some items like the braised short ribs on mashed potatoes and salmon with some type of salsa that looked like miniature versions of a plate you'd get at a  fine dining establishment- amazing presentation. Now, let me get to the bad part besides the wait that tarnished the experience a bit. Our server was slow! I don't expect much service at a buffet, only my plates cleared once in a while, and my water filled. That's all! My (tiny) water cup got re-filled only once, and this was after I had asked 3 times. She wasn't rude or anything, just busy clearing tables the whole time. Don't they have any bussers? This was in stark contrast to the Bellagio buffet we had gone to the night prior, where we didn't have to ask for anything. We had paid the tip before we were seated, and I regret leaving her a $20 tip for such lousy service. The table in front of us were also irritated and left her a cash tip of $3. Lol. I am glad that I had decided against the all you can drink because I definitely would not have gotten my money's worth on that one. Overall, I'd definitely visit this buffet again just for the bomb food.

Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Braised short rib on mashed potatoes &amp; chicken curry w/fresh naan bread
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Build your own udon and delicious prime rib

OReNr-RPHBsQ0YYGw-UyAQ.text: Best things about the whole buffet are 1) bottomless cocktails for $19.99 and 2) delicious gelato. A lot of people were getting plates stacked with crab legs and watermelon.  Saturday at 3:00, not exceptionally busy. A lot of the items looked old, filmed over, dry, you know the look. I wasn't compelled to try most of it. There were two excellent curries.   The carving station had three meats and only one was delicious. The carver-dude manning the station was a trip. He said "prime rib, steak and roast beef" were the selections. I asked for prime rib. He starts cutting a small slab of meat that doesn't look remotely like prime rib. He says it's sirloin. I point out the largest hunk of beef, he says it's "steamship". It was the only beef he had that looked medium and it was the only tender meat I got. I ask about the 3rd meat and he said it was tri tip. Got a slice of that and it was too tough, cut incorrectly.   The seafood station had an impressive array of crab legs, crab claws and shrimp. There was a gentleman standing under the sign that says "made to order" so I asked what he made to order. He gestured back toward the chilled selection and said it was all there. I asked what did the sign refer to that says "made to order". He said he had oysters rockefeller so I asked for that. He reluctantly pulls out a pan, pulls back the foil and plates two for me. I'm still not sure what the hell that sign is supposed to mean.   I saw 3 different tables leave a huge mess and zero tip. INFURIATING. The servers are bringing you drinks and extra napkins and clearing plates. TIP these people!

NnyY-Of0vw9LRFjeb2-Bvw.text: Was disappointed that they didn't have prime rib the  days I went. Decent seafood, but you really have to work to deshell. Chinese and Indian food are decent.  Drink refills are slow.

nVD_MTQwA7Arz6c4eWPIwQ.text: Ate here for lunch in October we had tons of choices and everything I had (seafood and poultry dishes) was great I can't speak on the meat dishes but I did not hear anyone complaining  I'm going there tomorrow so if anything has changed I will update Bob Jour

ToUcsAGdEeEi0bcZZ77UCg.text: Aria's known for their AYCE crab legs and seafood. I didn't indulge in any crab but got my shellfish on with their delicious warm and creamy New England clam bake with mussels!   First off, don't even bother using GPS to find self parking. I typed in Aria and it brought me to the registration area with no signs whatsoever for self park. I only found out two days later the Aria self parking is near the entrance to Crystals SMH. So cool how both buffets I went to this past weekend were orange in decor. Aria & Wicked Spoon are rocking my fave color!  $37 +tax/tip for Thursday dinner wasn't bad. Tess was our cashier and she kindly mentioned diners earn   points on their player's card, which can be redeemed for a buffet meal. $10 off for NV/Vegas residents! Our waitress, Luz, is super friendly AND hardworking-- she was the only one working in our area, constantly taking away used plates, busing her tables, wiping them down, placing new cloth napkins & silverware, warm smile never faltering.   Food! A variety of stations, the usual American, seafood on ice (crab legs, shrimp, crab claws, 2 kinds of mussels, clams), a bit of pasta, Mexican & Asian fare, surprisingly had Indian and Mediterranean options. I saw a few curries and basmati rice. The dessert bar had a spinning ice cream display. Most buffets I've visited have linguica sausage and hand carved meats. Wedge salads! Blue cheese dressing tho.   My plates had:  Mushroom & truffle pizza New England clam bake-- have never eaten that many clams before! Shrimp & grits Paella-- Latin rice dish with mixed shellfish, sausage Sauteed string beans Carnitas Creamed spinach cheese? Dip with crunchy chips!! Freshly baked naan! I added garlic hummus & tzatziki.  *Thai tea and watermelon lime strawberry juice were offered at the buffet the day I went! Just missing honey boba pearls for the Thai tea.   I probably won't stop by again unless someone in my group wants crab legs, but if you're staying at Aria, definitely grab a meal here before braving the Strip.

-mfnKrMM0e-bAVbumt_QMw.text: Worst buffet ever ! Don't come here waist your time and money! If there's an option of zero stars I would choose that option! We arrived at the buffet around 2:30pm, and we waited for almost one hour to get to the cashier, and when I see the people whoever already paid waited another twenty minutes and still not be seated i just took off! The point is, the dinning area was 10% full, just don't get it why they don't just let us in and sit down! Wasted time!

UW1Lski8D0Cik6beKDRSFQ.text: Honestly I don't know why this buffet only has 3 stars this place is a whole lot better than the buffet at Bellagio.  They have a large variety of food & pastries.  Another pro about this place is that they have ice cream and gelato. The creme brulee was amazing. Service was great our waiter was very friendly. I will definitely visit this buffet when in Vegas again.

sGLRvdtKJgcMtDmDZNZPAA.text: We went to more than one buffet and this one came out #1. There was way more variety and creativity with dishes. Instead of having just Japanese and Chinese food like other buffets, there was also Thai and Indian Cuisine. Plenty of seafood like fresh shrimp, crab legs, mussels and clams. There were a lot of toppings to create a hearty salad. Dessert bar was decent.

uN1v4y6aAkn0bNr9KnZ2rA.text: I had high expectations, as I heard great things about it... went on a Friday night, so of course there was a bit of a wait but we strictly went for their crab legs... service was great, I will give them that. But a lot of their food was sitting out, not getting tossed or freshened. There was a line for the crab legs, they need to figure out a new method cause it was ridiculous. Finally went to eat them and they were really salty. It was the cheap snow crab too I was expecting a higher quality of crab for being a buffet on the strip and being higher price since it was Friday. Won't go back... will do more research on better buffets on the strip.

pYa1hcZ0QiKbLDs84sesgw.text: There are many buffets on the Vegas strip but every time we come, we find ourselves at the Aria Buffet at least once. The location is convenient since the Aria is roughly at the center of the strip. The price of $30 after tax for lunch is not bad, especially if you come around 2 something and stay until they switch to their dinner menu, which will all be fresh! Overall, I would say this is probably the most economical buffet on the strip, when considering cost, quality of food, and wait time.  As for the food, the carving station and the desserts are probably your best bet. The Red Velvet Nutella Pancakes are probably my favorite. The Eggs Benedict are usually cooked pretty well. The seafood station is borderline ok. The Asian station is dismal.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Assortment of desserts. Make sure to try all of them.

h0NAnuKoSQRpGwo3FXAg6Q.text: This place is excellent. Excellent food, excellent service. The manager Stephanie is the BOMB- she has amazing customer service and she has a very friendly personality. I would recommend this buffet to anyone traveling to or through LV,  the bottomless drinks- the rum punch and the champagne......Simply amazing. Been twice and stayed for more than 3 hours at a time.......cant wait to go back

_iGFVp_Iqpnoyv8FRV_gjg.text: Hands down one of the best buffet experiences I've ever had in my life. Everything was so fresh and delicious and there were so many options. Our server Gracie was great, she was friendly and our drinks were always full. The cooks knew exactly what was in the food when my friend with dietary restrictions asked, which was nice. Will definitely be back!!!

emEwHUZP_w-8zdjmGtk8dQ.text: Having had Bacchanal's last time I was in Vegas, I couldn't help but keep comparing the buffet at Aria to the one at Caesar's. The carving station at this buffet has a decent variety of meats and I enjoyed their steak. The buttermilk mashed potatoes and roasted veggies in this section were also delicious. The next section had both Mexican & Indian dishes which were quite good. I enjoyed the Indian chicken curry with naan and the Mexican corn was super flavourful! That was actually one of the highlights of this meal and I could've gone back for more if not for the fact that I wanted to try everything.   Now this is where the rest of the buffet went downhill. The seafood section was disappointing. The prawn cocktail didn't taste that fresh, the crab legs I had were cold and the clams were gritty. Wasn't impressed. Don't even get me started on the Asian food section. The Har Gow was pretty gross and rubbery and I didn't care much for the other dim sum options. The dessert fared better with this one raspberry tart that I loved and of course, you can't go wrong with fresh fruit including a selection of cantaloupe, watermelon and pineapple.  Overall, for the price ($29) it was decent but c'mon you're in Vegas, you can find better buffets.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

iIARKK_zej37h2aj67l-4A.text: Ate here last week. seating feels like your average foodcourt, cheap and not relaxed at all. Food options are minimal, some lettuce, 2 or 3 choices of meat, some rice, some pasta. But nothing is spectacular or out of the ordinary. Could not find anything I liked, so I just had a salad.   Nobody of our party could find anything good at the dessertbar.  Not sure if this is standard for the US and we are a bit spoiled as Europeans, but this was dissapointing for a 3 star all-inclusive beach resort. For a 5 star Las Vegas resort this buffet is just (far) below par.  Quality: 2/5 Qantity: 1/5

JEIs5v012to-bbln7bxjDA.text: The buffet itself is really good. They have everything you could possibly imagine, their steamed crab is amazing!! They are part of the mlife so if you're a member you can get BOGO deals, pearl members and above get to skip the line! Unfortunately I'm a sapphire, so the reason for the 4 stars instead of 5 is because I had to wait 1 1/2 hours to get in..  Cesar's Bacchanal and Aria seem pretty similar so if you feel like spending an extra 30 per person then by all means go to Cesar's.

5EwDZE8Fsb2SMD_PUfok-g.text: one of the better buffet choices on the strip. I like the large seafood selection and they have a hot PHO station which was awesome.  I like mirage and mgm grand buffer better because beer and wine is included . here it is extra

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

PUP_l-ok7Dqq3mFu93ZtcA.text: It's a 3, but a very weak 3. I'm not a buffet connoisseur by any means, but this does not compare to Wicked Spoon in the slightest (not that I think it's trying to, but - still, that's the comparison I can make).  Even though the place was mostly empty, there was a pretty odd artificial queue in place. I get them not wanting to just let a thousand people hit the buffet all at once...but...still seemed strange.  Once seated, we were unleashed to do our damage. The food spread seemed to me very heavily tilted towards lunch/afternoon/dinner foods, honestly, with pizza, dumplings, even Mexican and Indian food. The variety was nice, but I think I would have liked more breakfast options...maybe I somehow missed them? I will call out that the lamb korma was surprisingly good for hotel buffet Indian food - nice tender flavorful lamb.  On the other hand, there were drinks stations (one with Thai iced tea that I really wanted to try) but no glasses to be found anywhere. I finally located some about the size of a thimble and just decided to skip the effort. Even getting water to the table took until about halfway through the meal, so maybe their queue was to limit impact on a too-small amount of staff?  I do want to call out their French macarons, which were excellent - fresh and tender with chewy shells. They also had "mountain yuzu" sorbet or gelato which was so so good - I'm obsessed with yuzu, so I was very pleasantly surprised to find it randomly at this buffet.  Price was, I thought, high, but so is everything in Vegas. My 3 star review means "I'll come back"...and...I guess I would come back...but...man, it would be a tough choice. I wouldn't say "never" but I would definitely try a lot of other options first...hence the very weak 3.

HtWQQTbp6ozxfOfRxHynrA.text: Best buffet ever. We had a horrible waitress that wouldn't acknowledge us so we asked a waitress in area beside us who was busting rear if we could sit in her section. From there on everything was awesome.   We had a bogo from myVEGAS so half off we are already winning yay!!  Crab legs awesome huge claws. Pre cracked. Hot butter. Tons of seafood selections. Fresh pastas. Skipped salad because well, HELLO SEAFOOD AND BEEF duh. Oh did I mention dessert? Ya Um YUM. Skip bread. I can eat bread anytime. Go for the yum. Go for the " not everyday". For 30$ they had a pitcher of cosmos. She said it was about 4 servings. I was only one drinking but the regular drinks were close to 15$ so I went for it. I drank half and was a little. Or a lot. Toasted. I finally just stuck my straw in the pitcher and went to town. Great night!!!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

E3VjdQH7NLYUK02b8m5Z2g.text: Located in a nice hotel in Las Vegas, the buffet seems enticing, but the food is subpar. Food is not as delicious as the bacchanal and wicked spoon--save your money and go to other buffets. The wait time is also ridiculous. We went for dinner around 245, did not get seated til 415. Many empty tables, but they take a long time seating people due to being understaffed according to the lady at the cash register. Only one person at the cash register. Paid for our meal in front, and still had to wait for another 20mins to get seated. I just do not get the logic why take so many people when there's not enough servers to accommodate the people. If only I can rate this as a zero, I would. If you still decide to eat here out of curiosity, make sure you bring some snacks while in line to prevent headache from hunger. Coming here with an empty stomach to make the most out of your money will make you faint from hunger. Also, they try to limit your stay for 2 hours.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

hu28V193b8pvZJomoTXWEg.text: Buffet at the ARIA served a variety of dishes from salads, carved meats, fresh seafood, Asian, Italian, Mediterranean, & Latin cuisines like paella, and sweet desserts. Everything was fresh and delicious. My faves were the kale salad with squash, goat cheese, beets and papitas, and the seafood paella, fresh salmon and juicy lamb chops.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Buffet at ARIA

9bzgPAMry6hx2wAVP_TVrw.text: I was really excited to go back to the buffet since we were staying at ARia but when we got to the buffet line - the line for sky suites was longer than regular line and service was horrendous.   We sat down and ordered drinks (no non dairy option for milk) and all our orders were wrong and the buffet isn't that big to start out and they don't have as many options if you are vegan or gluten free. None of the dishes are properly listed so you don't know what has dairy, gluten or anything at all.   Chef that was working the Omelette station was rude and was screaming and got a simple eggwhite omelette wrong.   When we sat back down after grabbing our below standard food, waitress was no where to be found and we couldn't get any drinks again.  What a waste of tummy space and our time. Wish we went to Cosmo or any other place for breakfast.

hm530WWstW8yWCsTba1XAw.text: very wide selection. I really like the spanish/latin food, the drinks from the buffet, and the ramen.  However, the pho broth was pure salt. you can't consume it at all. The Orange juice delivery by the waiter tasted very artificial, like super concentrated and worse than tropicana for example.

3bwBJhkYJlGETxiG9ljjYw.text: We came here ready to give Aria Buffet a 5 star based on our fantastic experience staying/dining at Aria last year but the disappointments after disappointments to our taste buds were unforgiving.  For starters, we had the holiday brunch buffet and first and foremost, we enjoyed the wait staff. Friendly service with some holiday humor is always welcomed.  Now, why 3 stars? Its tough being a buffet that is culturally diverse, but the biggest offender towards their food was the freshness of each selection. Some examples; stale/burnt/stiff waffles, cold chicken; incredibly soggy dimsum, curry was overcooked where the potato made it more mashy than curry; stale nan; pho...just forget about it.  Secondly, please invest some time into putting up the correct signs for the dish. Also signs that says "etm_009" for crab legs does not tell us much. Some people may come here with the promise of cultural diverse meal but won't mean anything if they don't know what they're eating.  However, the wait staff were amazing. Our waiter made sure our table was always clean and cups were filled. The staff at the dessert station were even more awesome as they accommodated our request to torch our creme brulee, which by the way makes all the difference.  A year ago, this buffet was worth trying out and we'd make recommendations to friends. However now? I'd say save your belly real estate for another buffet. 3 star verdict is an average between 5 star (last year) and 1 star (this year).

vU0xVwbPQnnqz7APzsCltg.text: First of all, this buffet has been revamped as of early 2013, so don't let the ratings fool you. They've added two new stations: Fish Market and Latin to bring a total of 11 stations. Of course, it's always a wiser choice to eat buffets during lunch on a weekday, and it's even better when your mom has free passes because she likes to gamble. But if I had to pay that day, it would have been $22.99 for a Friday lunch buffet. I really didn't think this buffet was that far off from Bacchanal at Caesar's Palace. I paid over $50, albeit dinner, for Bacchanal a few months ago, and I left just as satisfied.  Their Asian section is not as good as Bacchanal's, but they do have a few dim sum goodies. I was surprised that their chicken & waffles were really good. Waffles were moist and the chicken was tender and juicy. Another surprise I found were dried mangoes in their cheese section. I've never seen dried mango at a buffet before, and you can bet I snagged a few in my purse for the road. Dried mangoes - my weakness. They also had really fresh smoked salmon, which I made a lox bagel with their assortment of cream cheese.   Dessert was amazing, although I am biased because I have a sweet tooth. I pretty much love all pastries. On average, I spend close to half my time at the dessert bar, unless it's just terrible. The dessert bar here is comparable to Bacchanal's. They had a large assortment of pastries from chocolate and almond croissants, to blueberry crumble muffins. Their coconut macaroons were so moist and decadent. The only disappointing thing would be their ice cream. They have a good variety, but it just didn't taste very creamy. It was a bit puffy, like a little too airy or something. Overall, I really liked this buffet and would recommend this over Bacchanal; it's just a better deal.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dried mango!

9cm2n_2hG-q2C89aUiY_Ug.text: We had the buffet at Bellagios the previous day and found the buffet at Aria much much better. The seafood and Indian menu was amazing. There was a lemon grass soup which we had several times.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Seafood

ClxAwDT1tc6P53yvqpyGgA.text: Really enjoyed the buffet at Aria for breakfast.   They had a lot to choose from, so if you come with a group everyone should be able to find something.  They had an omelette station with the coolest chef who was kicking out made to order omelettes like nobody's business!  There was also seafood, salad, chinese food, fruit, cheese, oatmeal, french toast, giant pancake, breakfast meats, etc etc.  Really there was quite a lot!    Would definitely come back the next time we are in Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Buffet area
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Nifty entryway

B3xPrOxDd7Ityk2PESgMxQ.text: I was at the Aria buffet in its first incarnation and I liked it a lot.  I was surprised when some trashed it so much, so I was glad when MGM Resorts announced they were closing the buffet and re-doing it.  Yesterday I had the chance to try it since the redo.  It's basically the same place with a few modest changes and perhaps the addition of a few stations.  First the good--the prime rib was cooked nicely with it being a nice red rare.  The vegetable korma in the Tandoori section was quite good.  The chicken tikka masala was OK, but it needed more spice.  The seafood gumbo was quite nice.  I wish I had noticed the basmati rice in the tandoori section first.  I would have put some rice in the bowl and then added the gumbo.  The cheese bar was very nice with some dried fruit with the cheese.  The desserts were outstanding!!  A few lesser dishes.  The bao sandwich was not good at all.  The lovely steamed roll had dried hard from sitting warming for however long it was there.  The pork in the bun was kind of bland making this a fail choice.  There were some different bread selections but not a wide range to choose from.  The chicken satay was merely OK.  The peanut sauce was way too runny and didn't have a lot of flavor.  When you're paying $36.74 for dinner buffet, the shrimp should be PEELED.  I didn't have any because this is an onerous task for me.  Now the desserts.  While there was nothing exotic or earth shaking, they had some very nice small desserts.  I'm a sucker for meringue cookies and they had a fruit flavored one.  It was delightful!  I also had two of their mini whoopie cookies--one a snowball (chocolate cake with coconut) and one made from red velvet.  The cream filling was very good.  The gelato selection is good and I had the Oreo gelato.  Nice and creamy.  This isn't a buffet to which I'd likely return.  For the price, there are better buffets on the Strip with some very good selections.  Also for the price, I think I'd pay a little more and eat at one of Aria's fine selection of restaurants!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 5 layer cake.
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mini whoopie cookies and a mini peanut butter cup cupcake.
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Oreo gelato.

Z9RyOHTUccZYbK9Sp7Addw.text: Here we are... another place Yelp would lead you to believe isn't very good.  The Buffet at ARIA was very good for a buffet. After seeing Zarkana and having been starving all day, I was feeling a bit nauseous and felt as though I was going to throw up all over (though I'm not sure how, having not eaten much at all). I wound up getting two full plates of food and dessert at ARIA and felt A-OK. So hey, at least I didn't get food poisoning! Always a plus after having food from a buffet.  This buffet is the biggest I've ever eaten at... there's an insane amount of options from a bunch of different cuisines. Chinese, Mexican, Japanese, American, and Indian that I can think of off the bat. I didn't have any of the Chines food, but the Mexican was good, the sushi was decent, the American food above average, and the Indian food also really tasty.  The best part about my visit? Probably when my girlfriend's dad asked for peanut butter gelato with chocolate and nuts on top, but was given mango gelato with chocolate and nuts on top. That just about made my night.  Sure, the service is a bit slow (as seems to be a theme at Vegas buffets), but it's adequate enough. I appreciated that our foreign waitress was late to our table because she said she had to pee. Most people would probably be grossed out by that, but I appreciated the honesty!

xh-GdrN7nWr78hJjeBtyNA.text: Selection-ok (all of the labels were wrong above each choice!); Price-too expensive for what you get; Server-was wonderful!; Food-ok

liVIJpczktNBsITCvyIJUw.text: Really good service here and they carry Coke products!  It seems that most other Vegas buffets only carry Pepsi. I was very impressed with the seafood selection here: cold snow crab legs cut in half, hot snow crab legs, and king crab legs! I cut my darn finger eating all the delicious crabs. Medic!

photos.caption: Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crabs!!! King crab, snow crab (cold &amp; hot)!
Photo of The Buffet at ARIA - Las Vegas, NV, United States

DSFBawuSzflp29lpKEomaA.text: Amazing food and I personally think this is the best buffet in Vegas. It's a little pricy so usually what I do is skip breakfast and just eat here for my breakfast/lunch. If you have a Mlife card the price isn't bad though and there plenty of variety of food. Strongly would recommend to buffet lovers!

vIzwYD1JOXvawPrJsOS-JA.text: Monday visit, and right at 12:50 pm. This is my first time and last visiting the Aria buffet. I waited approximately 45 minutes from the time I entered the line and was seated. The wait time was what I had expected.   The waitress received my drink order immediately following when I was seated. The waitress came back about 7 minutes later and asked again what I would like to drink. Another 3 minutes passed until the water was served. She did however bring me two of them so this was helpful.  I tried a sample portion of each of these. Aside from the shrimp and a crab legs and claws which I had several of.   The rest of the reviewers are correct in their description of the hot crab legs and cold ones. They were very watery and the flavor was ehhhh. The cooked chilled shrimp were perfectly cooked and the shell pre-sliced at the mud vein for easy access. Their wasn't any boil mix added to it that I could taste.   The crawfish were on part for every single buffet I have ever been to. Bland, overcooked, dead ones cooked as well, and definitely not presoaked to make them purge. There was zero boil mix added to them for flavor. They were extremely muddy flavored. I really don't understand how so many restaurants can manage to screw up something which can so easily be made by taking an extra hour of time to prepare. They difference between what they all seem to do and the few extra steps and time it takes to prepare them properly is night and day in flavor. Oh well, I always have my people in Louisiana for excellent crawfish. The corn on the cob was overcooked and also had very little flavor.   The chorizo sausage, and chicken jalapeno sausage were extremely dry.   The chicken had a decent breading on it but was also overcooked.   The carved chicken and turkey were very moist.   The cashew chicken was made in a style which if I hadn't known I would have said it was made by someone at their house and not a restaurant.  The broccoli beef was grisly, and one of the worst flavored I have tasted.   The custard bun dough was perfectly cooked but very bland custard in the center.   I am not sure how they managed to screw up an apple pie, but they did. The bread pudding as well. Both had no real flavor, definitely didn't have much cinnamon in either, not much sugar either (think diabetic bland.) This is the first place I have ever been where the apple pie was so below average I couldn't finish it. It looked like they added pine nuts into the bread pudding.   The pot said it was chicken soup but it tasted like ground up rice in water.  The lamb ossobuco the broth was fabulous. But the lamb was not cooked properly so it was tough and chewy.   Synopsis: Even for the slightly lower price then other casino buffet for lunch $25.99, it was no where worth the price. If you need and like foods which are prepared with no spices or few if any, like dessert which is diabetic sugar free tasting, food which is about 15%-25% overcooked, seafood which is water logged, then this will be a smash hit with you.

qRbxtrcfbvzrajypHUvqmg.text: One compact Buffet..their selection of food are great .. They have sugar free desert .. Good salad selection..They have healthy alternatives....reasonable price to eat ....
